1 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


Africa's Last Colony


LENGTH: 1819 words


 

Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

June 30, 1995

A little-known struggle for independence continues in West Africa -- and South Africa has strange links to it. Ann Eveleth reports

the presidential inauguration of Nelson Mandela on May 10 last year was heralded as the end of colonialism for a beleaguered continent, but nobody seemed to notice that one distinguished guest was celebrating a very different anniversary that day: the 21st birthday of the Front for the Liberation of Seguiet el-Hamra and Rio de Oro marked the continued resistance of the Sahrawi people to their status as Africa's last colony.

Mohamed Abdelaziz, president of the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic (SADR) and secretary general of the Polisario Liberation Front, must have viewed the coincidence as a coming of age for his government-in- exile. Now that apartheid was gone, world attention could focus on freeing his tiny desert country from the ravages of two decades of Moroccan occupation. 

The emergence of a powerful new South Africa governed by Polisario's old ally -- the African National Congress -- would shift the balance of power in the United Nations toward the Sahrawis and bring an end to Moroccan King Hassan's dithering over the long-awaited independence referendum.

Polisario has since turned 22, however, and neither the referendum nor formal recognition by South Africa have been forthcoming. Instead, there have been signs that the old South African-Moroccan alliance which fuelled the war of annexation is continuing.

Deputy President Thabo Mbeki made a mysterious visit to Morocco last year -- speculation was that he was fund- raising for the ANC -- and Mandela this month postponed a visit to the Sahara until he could arrange to visit both sides of the conflict.

South Africa's Foreign Affairs Department has come under increasing criticism for this ambiguous stance -- which is all the more surprising given the parallels between the two liberation struggles.

Forced into what could be described as the arid interior bantustan of the western Saharan nation after Morocco's high-powered army annexed the 1 000km-long coastal belt on the eve of Sahrawi independence from colonial Spain in 1975, the Polisario fighters have defended the "liberated zone" with 19th century weapons and sheer pluck against a combined onslaught by up to 30 000 soldiers, aerial bombardments and napalm attacks targeting fleeing civilians.

Housing the Sahrawi women and children in desolate refugee camps in the southern Algerian military zone around Tindouf, Polisario set up a government-in-exile and declared the independent Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic in 1976. Its growing army was sent back into the desert to repel the occupiers' advance.

A nomadic people descended from a section of the 11th century Almoravid Dynasty which abandoned northward expansionism to return to the desert, the Sahrawi delivered countless staggering military blows to the well-endowed Moroccan army.

Still, the Polisario fighters could reach little more than a stalemate with Hassan's warriors, who were armed to the teeth first by the French, and later by the United States, Saudi Arabia and South Africa.

Hassan's resolve strengthened as internal dissent against his corrupt, autocratic regime grew. He survived several assassination attempts from dissidents, and strikes and demonstrations were widespread.

Although Amnesty International recorded thousands of cases of detention without trial of Moroccan dissidents, the monarch soon discovered he could divert attention from the domestic pressures wrought by massive income disparities through Morocco's desert war.

Despite growing international pressure from the United Nations and the International Court of Justice for a referendum to determine the future of the Sahara, Hassan increased his forces in the occupied territory. By the time the two sides signed an uneasy ceasefire agreement in 1991, he had accumulated about 130 000 troops in "Morocco's 41st province".

Morocco's intransigence was bolstered annually by more than US$200-million to $500-million in military aid from Saudi Arabia, US$50-million from the US, and unknown covert assistance from South Africa's apartheid regime.

Successive UN resolutions however, pointed increasingly to the inevitability of a referendum, so Hassan adopted a new strategy. Hoping to weight the referendum in his favour, he began infiltrating thousands of Moroccan settlers into the occupied territory, claiming they were Saharan refugees.

Refusing to allow UN personnel or foreign journalists to visit the occupied port city of El Aaiun, Hassan alternately blocked and rejected the UN Mission for the Referendum in Western Sahara (MINURSO) -- and imprisoned genuine Sahrawis in the territory.

Hassan's forces bombed a Sahrawi field hospital for nomads on the eve of the ceasefire agreement, reducing it to rubble. Refusing to grant passports to Sahrawis, detention without trial, torture and pressure on prisoners to renounce their claims to independence were just some of the means employed to prevent decolonisation.

The formation of a plethora of pro-Morocco "Sahrawi" political parties by Spain and Morocco failed to convince UN missions to the territory. But in the face of US foreign policy and divisions in the Organisation of African Unity, the UN was too weak to prevent the 176 ceasefire violations documented during the first year of the agreement.

Morocco received a windfall in international support in 1991 when it backed the US war against Iraq. The international community remained largely silent after the 1991 Amnesty International report stated that 800 Sahrawis had "disappeared".

And as these kudos continued to grow in the aftermath of the Gulf Oil War, Morocco grew bolder in its violations of the agreement.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Africa News


June, 1995


African Journalists Search For Voice


LENGTH: 1560 words


 

Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

June 30, 1995

African journalists are struggling to find a unique voice in the face of Western stereotypes and diverse beliefs, writes Chris Louw

Kenyan journalist Charles Wachira walked around in the streets of Harare last week, shaking his head in disbelief. "I never knew an African state like this existed," he muttered. "Look at the roads, man. Not a single pothole! And the cars are all brand new. I'm shocked, man." 

Wachira was one of about 30 journalists from all over the continent who gathered in Zimbabwe to take stock of the state of journalism in Africa.

But finding a voice of its own for African journalism to counter the "onslaught" of the American and European media with their preconceptions, soon proved to be difficult.

Like Machira, most journalists found that Africa is just too big, too diverse, and the countries too isolated to be able to unanimously come up with indiginous definitions for concepts like "democracy" and "human rights".

Most of the journalists were free-lancers, and almost all were loosely related to the Inter Press Service Third World News Agency (IPS), the fledgling organisation which for the past three decades has been trying bravely to give the South its own voice against the overwhelming communications networks of the Northern hemisphere.

The meeting was soon sobered by Dr Ibbo Mandaza, editor-in-chief of the Harare-based Southern African Political and Economic Magazine, who reminded delegates that intra-regional trade in Africa amounted to a mere four percent of all African trade.

Lambasting the northern countries for what he termed their neo-colonial approach to Africa, Mandaza maintained that all African countries were still forced to earn foreign currency by exporting their raw materials, thus undermining their industrial basis.

"We have a hostage economy, a subsidiary economy. There is no African state -- only a hostage state, a mimic state; it is a farce, to say the least."

Most newspapers on the continent, said Mandaza, were forced to toe the line by governments who had little room for political and economic manoeuvering and consequently soon lost legitimacy.

One after the other the journalists confirmed what Mandaza was saying: many of those present had been detained or intimidated by their respective governments.

Not only the Northern media was accused of being biased against Africa. Zimbabwean feminist Dr Patricia McFadden accused African journalists of being the main culprits when it came to perpetuating stereotypes of women. Women, she said, were seldom taken seriously by African publications as public figures in their own right.

The difficulty faced in establishing commonly accepted moral guidelines for African journalism was graphically illustrated when delegates from Burkina Faso and Cote d'Ivoire insisted that female circumcision, which is still prevalent in their countries, was an acceptable ritual.

The issue of human rights, and more particularly gender rights, led to a heated discussion. Female delegates were up in arms, accusing men of perpetuating the suppression of women.

The West African journalists stuck to their guns, maintaining that female circumcision could not be regarded an abuse of rights because so many women supported this ritual.

But "politically correct" arguments also very often stranded on the hard rock of African realities.

One example: Josephine Masimba, a Zimbabwean, establishes herself as a firm feminist in the gender debate. Later, she tells me of her experiences of police in Harare. She was having supper with her sister in a restaurant one evening and left to buy something from a pharmacy around the corner. On her return she was stopped by two policemen who accused her of "loitering".

She was arrested and taken to a police station where she was thrown into a cell. It was a Friday night and she knew she would spend the weekend in jail if she did not pay an admission of guilt fine. In the end she had no option but to pay 50 Zimbabwean dollars. "According to police records," she says, "I am now a self- confessed prostitute."

And while delegates complained about Northern media stereotyping of Africa as impoverished and woeful, most topics chosen by the delegates for discussion centred on exactly the same issues: desertification, cattle theft, the impact of the large-scale import of second- hand clothes on local economies ...

At the end of the conference each delegate gave a short account of the present political, social and economic situation in his or her country.

Jean-Baptiste Kayigamba from Rwanda focused on the genocide in his country. He has become cynical about the destructive forces of ethnicism, and says that he is an outsider in the country of his birth. A million people killed in the past two years ... the chairman had to stop him -- the delegates had only two minutes to summarise the woes of their countries.

Yohannes Abdi from Ethiopia talked about the crisis in neighbouring Somalia. Somalians are flowing into Ethiopia in their thousands to flee starvation in their own country, bringing with them poverty and social problems.

Ethnicity has a kinder flavour in his region. Soon, he says, Ethiopia will be divided in nine ethnic regions, most of them semi-independent, "states on their own," according to Abdi.

Abdoulaye Gandema from Burkina Faso listened to what everyone else had to say. In his country, if only 20 000 head of cattle were to be stolen, the economy would grind to a halt. Like so many African countries, the 'Land of the Upright People' is caught in the humiliating grip of poverty.

>From Nigeria, Remi Oyo complained about the pervasive corruption; from Zambia, Joe Chilaizya said his people are cynical about their democratically-elected rulers - - some people are even re-saddling old man Kenneth Kaunda with their hopes for the future.

>From Kenya, Charles Wachira tells of an opposition party led by a white man, Richard Leakey. "The question now is: do we want to be ruled by someone of our own skin-colour who is not reliable, or do we prefer to be ruled by a white Kenyan whose actions pass the test of transparency?"

Almost everyone refers to fears about the economic might of South Africa. Castle Lager is drunk all over Africa now; South African businesspeople move into Africa "very aggressively". Fragile local industries will just not be able to withstand the capitalist onslaught from the south.

It is soon clear that Africa is a continent caught up in woes. A journalist's paradise, if you will.

The last word goes to a Zimbabwean receptionist. Kenya's Charles Wachira tells him one night: "Your country really functions very effectively, man. You must be sure not to let it go to the dogs."

The receptionist, a mild-mannered, middle-aged Shona, flashes an angry smile: "That's where the country was, Sir. But we took it back from the dogs."

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Africa News


June, 1995


Pahad Hits Back At Foreign Affairs Critics


LENGTH: 1427 words


 

Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

June 30, 1995

Aziz Pahad, Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, rejects the claim that his is the least effective government department, reports Rehana Rossouw

South Africans are still extremely parochial and the Department of Foreign Affairs cannot be expected to act aggressively to protect human rights internationally if its citizens are complacent, says Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, Mr Aziz Pahad.

Turning the tables on the department's critics, he asked what the rest of South Africa was doing to stop human rights abuses in East Timor, Sudan and anywhere else they may be happening.

Pahad was responding to criticisms of his department from parliamentarians and and academics published in the Mail & Guardian, who slated it for being the least effective and least transparent in government.

He said the speed at which South Africa entered the arena of international affairs had been breathtaking. Within six months after April 1994, South Africa was readmitted to the United Nations and its organs, the Organisation of African Unity (OAU), the Commonwealth, the South African Development Community and the Non Aligned Movement. 

>From May to December 1994, South Africa established relations with 35 countries and more than 160 foreign trade delegations visited the country in 1994.

"We don't need to get too philosophical about foreign policy. Our mission is clear -- we need to reflect the nation's position internationally, protect the interests of South Africa and South Africans internationally and ensure that the new South Africa is able to participate in the New World Order.

"Our responsibility is to protect human rights, democracy and good governance internationally and transform the world situation from its present position in which rich countries get richer and the poorer get poorer.

He rejected the criticism that the Department of Foreign Affairs was Eurocentric in its approach because more money had been budgeted for its missions in the first world than in Africa.

"From the time we came into government we have been saying consistently that South Africa is not a European outpost, it is an African country. But we have to be practical, we have to establish links with countries that can help us achieve our economic objects and further the RDP project."

Pahad said now that South Africa had established a presence in many African countries, it will begin to play a more proactive role on the continent, particularly in assisting in the resolution of conflicts.

"We must not be too romantic about the problems in Africa. We have to look at the continent pragmatically, learn where our interests lie, before pouring money into embassies."

He said it would also be foolish to ignore the fact that South Africa's major economic links were with the European Union, the country's largest investment partner. At the same time, the department was mindful of the economic opportunities opening in Africa, Asia and South America.

President Nelson Mandela's visits targeting Africa and the Middle East were not "accidental", they were aimed at exploiting the potential in those areas.

"Whether we like it or not, foreign policy is driven by economics. Diplomatic relations with a country does not mean an acceptance of its internal politics -- they are state to state links, not state to government.

"This means that while we can oppose the human rights policies of a country, we often cannot afford not to have a relationship with it."

The controversy over South Africa's links with Indonesia and Sudan could be seen in this light. Pahad said the South African government had taken up the issue of the occupation of East Timor with the Indonesian government. This was done publicly and privately during Mandela's visit and by calling in the ambassador of Indonesia for a note verbal.

He questioned what other political parties and political organisations were doing to rally South Africans to condemn Indonesia's actions, saying the department could not take up political platforms on such issues -- that responsibility lay with civil society which could be far more aggressive than diplomats.

Pahad said South Africans were still very parochial and could reflect the greatness of their nation by showing a far greater concern for other countries. The mindset that South Africa was too beset by its owns problems to assist others had to be broken.

Foreign affairs were also not the preserve of diplomats and officials of the Department of Foreign Affairs, a misapprehension which developed under the previous government. Every cabinet minister was at liberty to act on the foreign stage to pursue the objectives of their line function, provided they were briefed by the department first.

"The Department of Foreign Affairs' role is to coordinate and assist them. The presidency, especially, is expected to play a leading role in international affairs. It would be foolhardy for us not to take advantage of the president -- South Africa's main marketer -- and his deputies."

Pahad promised that the Department of Foreign Affairs would publish a green paper "soon" and would draft it in consultation with academics, trade unions, political parties and the private sector. The document would give a vision of South Africa's policy well into the next century.

Responding to the criticism that the department was still dominated by a white, male staff, Pahad said the new government inherited six components of Foreign Affairs -- the existing Department of Foreign Affairs, the ANC's Department of International Affairs (DIA) and the TBVC departments of Foreign Affairs which had to be merged into one new department.

The ANC's foreign operatives had worked in more countries than those of the former South African government, although their activities were limited to mobilising support for anti-apartheid activities.

"The DIA personnel were probably the most experienced foreign affairs operatives. The ANC had more offices internationally than the old South African government and its staff interacted on various levels," Pahad said.

"But we couldn't ignore the fact that there was an existing Department of Foreign Affairs, we were not prepared to make political appointments and we were committed to integrating the TBVC foreign affairs staff."

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Africa News


June, 1995


SA's First Community TV Goes On Air


LENGTH: 854 words


 

Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

June 30, 1995

by Ann Eveleth

Greater Durban Television (GDTV), South Africa's first regular community access television station, is up and running, charting new waters in public broadcasting.

GDTV is operating under a temporary licence granted to a coalition of community-based video groups by the Independent Broadcasting Authority.

GDTV took to the airwaves last week with a range of community-based videos from church organisations, community groups and in-house videos filmed in the station's studio on the University of Natal's Durban campus (UND). Broadcasting from a borrowed radiation laboratory at the university, GDTV hopes to de-mystify TV broadcasting and generate wide community participation in a project aimed at "bringing Durban closer together" through video. 

Kubeshni Govender, a freelance video producer and media studies masters student at UND, who represents the Film and Allied Workers Organisation (Fawo) on the station's steering committee, said GDTV was open to "anyone from the community with an interest in broadcasting".

Govender sees the station as the natural extension of a video training project Fawo has run over the past four years for members of disadvantaged communities: "Fawo has trained over 100 people by now ... this is the ideal opportunity for those people to put their training into practice."

Run by a coalition including Fawo, the UND Centre for Cultural and Media Studies, Audio-Visual Alternatives and Durban Arts, and deriving volunteers from Natal Technikon's Department of Video Technology, UND media and drama students and Fawo trainees, the station provides training to volunteers in the use of studio equipment and sends crews out to film videos of local events, such as plays and music performances. GDTV representative Mike Aldridge said this demonstrated the power of media as "a way of linking people up and bringing them together across the divides in our society".

Programming this week also included a broad range of shows on subjects ranging from vivisection to censorship to the art of Zulu storytelling, or Izinganekwane, encouraging calls from a number of viewers who picked up the signal from Durban North to Pinetown.

Aldridge predicted the station would also provide a major boost to the local video industry, with local small businesses seeking production of advertisement videos for screening on the station.

'In terms of the RDP, this could help small, medium and micro- enterprises to grow. Not every business can afford to advertise on SABC, so we should look at developing an integrated approach which combines community broadcasting with the commercial or business side," said Aldridge.

While Govender said the group was still trying to raise funds to sustain the project on a long-term basis -- and pinning hopes on government subsidies in support of the RDP -- she added that: "The great thing about public access TV is that it doesn't require the kind of expensive equipment used in a regular station."

The sparsely equipped studio appears very basic, yet GDTV has broadcast five hours of programming daily with the aid of a single 486 computer, nine monitors, two SVHS video tape players, a production mixer, edit controller, camera and a tiny microwave link that looks like little more than a glorified antenna hooked outside -- all donated by companies like Panasonic, Orbicom and Sentech.

GDTV joined the airwaves last Thursday, and is licenced to continue broadcasting on channel 43 until July 11.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Africa News


June, 1995


Now The Olympic Bid Is In Ball's Court


LENGTH: 1254 words


 

Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

June 23, 1995

Sam Ramsamy is now on the IOC and there is other good news for Cape Town's Olympic bid, writes Julian Drew

After several months earlier this year when the Cape Town Olympic Bid seemed to be on a kamikaze course of self destruction, followed by a period of quiet uncertainty, South Africa's delegation to the annual session of the International Olympic Committee (IOC) in Budapest returned with some positive news this week.

Perhaps the most positive happening in Hungary was the election of National Olympic Committee of South Africa (Nocsa) president Sam Ramsamy onto the IOC, but it was by no means the only good news to come our way.

Accompanying Ramsamy on his trip were Chris Ball, the newly appointed CEO of the Cape Town Bid Committee, Clive Keegan, its vice-president, and Ngconde Balfour, a member of the new committee and vice-chairman of the preceding interim bid committee. "Although people weren't saying directly that they would vote for us there was a very positive feeling about Cape Town's bid and we didn't experience any negative vibes whatsoever," said Ramsamy. 

While bad publicity had reached the rest of the world about Cape Town's bid problems, Ramsamy believes the damage was minimal. "The international perceptions from what I gathered were that they'd heard about Ackerman's resignation and things like that but the news hadn't all been negative. They know we've had problems but they also know that we have now sorted them out. The fact that I introduced Chris Ball to everybody showed that we have sorted things out and they were all very impressed with him," said Ramsamy.

Another positive aspect according to Ramsamy was the way in which he and the other three South Africans worked so well together. "I would often only receive two invitations to functions which meant I could only take one of the other three with me," said Ramsamy. "Ngconde and Clive would always say 'Take Chris, he's the most important person', and that augers very well for the bid because people are already working as a team," he claims.

"There was a sentiment in favour of Cape Town and a sentiment in favour of Africa. There were a lot of personal friendships because of Sam's long involvement in international sport but there was also an awareness that we have to deliver on the technical side. We stand a very good chance of winning the bid and that is a position a lot of other cities would love to be in," said Ball from Cape Town this week before jetting out to London for a short holiday.

"The first thing we must work on now is getting the support of the people in Cape Town and the rest of the country because we are not simply entitled to their support. Until we give them the necessary information that won't happen, but I'm reluctant to divulge anything just yet until I'm satisfied that the information that's released will not change. But there will be an announcement soon," said Ball.

Ramsamy's membership of the IOC means that he will be able to study first hand the bids of other cities for the 2004 Olympic Games because he will be invited to visit them all as an IOC member.

"I will be able to study the strengths and weaknesses of all the other cities and relay this information to Cape Town. From this I should also be able to point out Cape Town's weaknesses so that we can try and sort them out," said Ramsamy.

"More significantly, I will become a voting member of the IOC which means that Cape Town is guaranteed at least one vote," he declared, tongue in cheek.

Membership of the IOC will eventually bring more responsibilities to Ramsamy who already regularly puts in a 16 hour working day at Nocsa, but he doesn't see any immediate problems with his work load. "I will still spend most of my time with Nocsa and I believe I can do that without sacrificing any of my IOC responsibilities simply because the one dovetails into the other so well. About 20 IOC members are presidents of their Olympic committees. I think one role actually complements the other," he said.

Although many IOC members have a reputation of living it up and travelling the world on visits to bidding cities or on other IOC business, Ramsamy will not be joining the bandwagon. "I will only take the mandatory visits. I will only do what is absolutely necessary," he declared.

Ramsamy currently chairs the Association of National Olympic Committees of Africa (Anoca) Commission on Communication and Publicity and has been asked to sit on the Association of National Olympic Committees (Anoc) Technical Committee and when he does get asked to serve on any of the IOC's commissions he could find himself overloaded.

Help is at hand, however, and the Nocsa management committee is already considering appointing a CEO to take over some of Ramsamy's administrative tasks. "We need someone with a good business acumen who will also have the respect of the staff and know something about sport. We won't just fill the position for the sake of it but we are head hunting right now," says Ramsamy.

"I think a CEO would be useful because it will free me from a lot of daily routine and allow me to do other work on behalf of Nocsa."

One task the former lifesaver has already committed himself to is relinquishing the presidency of Swimming South Africa next year. Hopefully he will also use his aquatic skills to keep his head above water until the management committee finds the right man to reduce his burden at Nocsa.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Africa News


June, 1995


Asian Brewer Steps In To Save NSB


LENGTH: 1440 words


 

Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

June 23, 1995

Meshack Mabogoane reports on the saga that has been played out at National Sorghum Breweries

National Sorghum Breweries (NSB) has teamed up with Indian brewing giant, United Brewery International (UB).

The deal means NSB will now produce the Indian brewer's Kingfisher Lager at Vivo's brewery.

The joint venture marks the most extensive Indian investment in South Africa to date, and it will perhaps give NSB the muscle it needs to face up to its powerful rival South African Breweries (SAB).

UB will buy 30 percent of NSB's equity with the option of increasing its shareholding. A Memorandum of Understanding between NSB and UB includes a "significant role" for UB in the management of NSB. 

UB, which has a R3,8-billion turnover, will also "undertake the training of NSB's employees at its various plants overseas" as well as evolving a management exchange scheme.

Most significantly UB will produce its brands at the Vivo plant. This will widen the range of clear beers in the NSB stable, adding more competition to this already crowded market.

The deal hopefully marks the end of the beleaguered NSB's problems.

In 1990, NSB's high-profile chairman, Mohale Mahanyele, threw down the gauntlet to SAB, apparently unaware of what befell Louis Luyt and Anton Rupert's group when they tried to carve a niche in the lucrative beer sector in the Seventies.

Mahanyele made daring statements about hiving off 20 percent of the clear beer market from SAB, which holds about 98 percent of the market.

Vivo Breweries came on line with sorghum serving as the milch cow -- NSB had more than 85 percent of the 1,2- billion-litre annual sorghum beer production, giving it a turnover of R600-million. The beer market is largely black turf and Mahanyele counted on black support, presumably along the lines of the erstwhile Afrikaner saamstaan. Unfortunately, there have as yet been no cheers from the market and Vivo flows sluggishly.

In 1992, NSB diversied into the food industry, a strategic and seemingly wise move since trends indicated a long-term decline in sorghum. However, all NSB's ventures into food and beverages -- Ting a Mabele, Soul Foods, NSB Mageu -- came to nought. Hopes were pinned on Jabula Foods, bought from Premier, but they were soon dashed by consumer changes and loss of outlets.

Only the soft drink division, producer of Pride Cola, is making some modest gains.

This leaves sorghum as the last, great hope to keep the company afloat. But, the 1990 agreement, which gave NSB the sole right to sell sorghum in the prime urban areas while keeping its competitors locked in the former, poor homelands, is due for revocation in October.

Already SAB's sorghum division, Traditional Beer Investments (TBI), which claims 20percent of the market, in spite of the restrictions, is planning to increase its share to 30 percent. Other small brewers may be waiting on the sides to slice off more portions.

Meanwhile, the huge Vivo investments, a hefty chunk being bank loans, have begun to weigh heavily. It is understood that its main creditor, Nedbank, has taken an interest in finding suitors to salvage its debtor. So, too, have the Liquor Industry Association and the Taverners Association.

Foodcorp, whose products include mageu, and black investment group Thebe, formed a rescue consortium, which has since been withdrawn. The consortium offered capital (up to 60 percent of equity), distribution networks and expertise, as well as internships for NSB's staff at Foodcorp. But, demands were made to close Vivo and to restructure management -- this involved separating the roles of chairman and chief executive, a move intended to curtail the power of Mahanyele. NSB, which had initiated the talks, declined, indicating the hold Mahanyele, its founder and driving force, has on the company.

Despite the UB deal, NSB is not out of the woods. Judging by past experiences in the liquor industry the scene is set for an intense "beer war" reminiscent of the Seventies.

Sceptics are apprehensive about the new partnership. NSB's rejection of offers from two companies rooted in South Africa -- the one in the food and beverages sector, the other at the centre of black economic empowerment -- is viewed as a missed opportunity to bring in local resources and relevant experience. Whether an oriental brewer, with less tradition and expertise than the European and American brewers that baulked at the prospect of taking on SAB, will succeed is moot.

However, Mahanyele's gamble may well pay off. With an increase in NSB's clear beer brands, a broader net would be cast in the market. But most interesting is the racial element. The local Indian community could lend both its distribution network and group loyalty to ethnic ventures. Africans may yet follow this example. And should NSB offer quality products, brand loyalties and consumer behaviour may change. Demand for clear beer will rise along with living standards.

NSB's long-term prospects thus look better. Even a 10 percent market share, half of Mahanyele's ambition, realised initially through regional concentration, would make it a sizable player. With the other brewers -- Bavaria and Sterling -- its share of small and medium size clear beer producers could well be 20 percent, a significant cut. Perhaps developments in the soft drink sector, where Pepsi and smaller cola producers are making real inroads, could be repeated in the beer industry. Mahanyele's undoubted shewdness, tenacity, vision and drive may pay off.

Those seeking a deconcentration of business, or real competition, without overt government intervention through anti-trust measures, should view NSB's struggles with interest. It covers all the key issues in South African business now: it is a privatised company, embodies black economic empowerment, involves massive corporate restructuring, underlines the difficulty of competition with an efficient near monopoly, and might yet present the government with a dilemma if it fails completely.

NSB is a test case. The first, most conspicous, genuinely black-managed of the new "black" giants is perhaps fated for this role. Its saga may provide a classic case study of the vicissitudes of black enterprise as it struggles to enter the mainstream.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Africa News


June, 1995


Lower Growth Forecast For This Year


LENGTH: 640 words


 

Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

June 23, 1995

by Simon Segal

Compared to our survey at the beginning of the year, South Africa's major economic forecasters have slightly scaled down their economic growth forecasts.

On average, the 10 forecasting units now expect gross domestic product (GDP) to grow 2,9 percent this year and 3,3 percent next year. GDP estimates at the beginning of the year averaged 3,1 percent for 1995 and 3,32 percent for 1996. 

GDP grew 2,3 percent last year and 1,1 percent in 1993. So, by consensus, South Africa is still on track for four consecutive years of economic growth for the first time since the 1970s.

The most optimistic unit is Old Mutual which expects growth rates

of 3,3 percent and four percent this year and next respectively. Most pessimistic is Amalgamated Banks of South Africa (Absa) (2,5 and two percent).

Six units expect the economy to gain momentum next year and two (Frankel Pollak and Absa) expect it to lose steam. The remaining two, Sanlam and the Afrikanse Handelsinstituut, forecast the same growth for 1995 and 1996.

Frankel Pollak and Absa are thus the only two units which expect the deficit on the current account of the balance of payments to fall next year.

The most dramatic turnaround in the forecasts is with the current account. An average deficit of R7,5-billion and R8,7-billion is pencilled in for 1995 and 1996 respectively, compared to a shortfall of R4,2-billion and R6,3-billion estimated at the beginning of the year.

Deficit projections for this year range from the South African Chamber of Business' (Sacob) R5-billion to Sanlam's R10-billion. For next year the spread is R5,5- billion (Frankel Pollak) to R12-billion (Sanlam).

All units except Sacob expect an inflation rate of 10,5 to 12,2 percent both this year and next. Sacob is looking at nine percent this year and 8,5 percent next.

On interest rates, seven of the 10 units expect a percentage point increase in prime rate (at present 17,5 percent) this year and six of them see a further percentage point rise by the end of next year. Only Sacob expects interest rates to start falling next year.

If Old Mutual and Frankel Pollak are right, prime rate will reach 20,5 percent next year.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Africa News


June, 1995


Making Presidential Whoopee Is Bad News


LENGTH: 907 words


 

Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

June 23, 1995

Writing stories on the sex lives of presidents has become a dangerous occupation for Southern African journalists, writes David Lush

Just last month, the publisher and two editors of Zimbabwe's Financial Gazette were arrested, interrogated and charged with an offence which has hardly seen the light of day since the fall of Ian Smith's Rhodesia -- all because of a story alleging that President Robert Mugabe had married his secretary, which he later admitted to anyway.

Now the managing director and the editor of Zambia's The Post newspaper find themselves charged under similarly ancient legislation for publishing a story in which a Zairean trader claimed to be President Frederick Chiluba's lover. Chiluba -- a born-again Christian who has publicly urged Zambians to be monogamous -- denies ever knowing the woman, nor the child she claims he fathered.

Following publication of this story, leaders and supporters of Chiluba's Movement for Multi-Party Democracy (MMD) took to the streets, burning copies of The Post and threatening to beat up anyone found selling the paper. M'membe was arrested at the paper's Lusaka offices on Monday morning, and both M'membe and his editor-in-chief, Masautso Phiri, spent the night in jail before appearing in court, charged with defaming the president under Section 69 of the Penal Code. 

Elias Rusike, Trevor Ncube and Simba Makunike, respectively the publisher, editor and deputy-editor of Zimbabwe's Financial Gazette, endured similar police hospitality for a story claiming that President Mugabe had married his secretary. Shortly after first light on May 13, detectives swooped on the homes of Rusike, Ncube and Makunike and took the three in for questioning, and trashing their offices in the process. After more than 48 hours in police detention, the three executives appeared in court, charged with criminal defamation.

While outrage at the Gazette's revelations has been confined largely to the environs of State House, even fellow journalists feel The Post went too far with its story. Respected media academic and chair of the Zambian press association, Francis Kasoma, told IPS that the development of press freedom in Zambia had reached a "dangerous stage".

To a lesser extent, The Namibian newspaper has also suffered moral whiplash for publishing details of The Post's story during Chiluba's state visit to Namibia last week. Callers to radio phone-in shows urged the Namibian government to act against journalists responsible for causing the nation such an "embarrassment".

At the close of his Namibian trip last Saturday, Chiluba reiterated his pledge not to muzzle the Zambian press, but added that it was not for the media to "create rules for democracy". "Even if leaders are wrong, it is not African to insult them in public," he added.

M'membe -- a distinctly African, self-confessed Zambian patriot -- disagrees. "Even the ruthless Zulu dictator Chaka could be criticised openly," M'membe wrote in an article published by the Media Institute of Southern Africa in December. "Whenever a voice of opposition is raised ... the first instinct of African leaders is to smear it with the filth of colonialism, capitalism or imperialism." Or in M'membe's case, Section 69 of the Penal Code.

In a report published in January, Amnesty International criticised Zambia and Zimbabwe, together with Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda -- countries related by legal systems shaped by British colonial rule -- for criminalising dissent through the use of often out-dated legislation which contravened international human rights standards. "The use of such charges is often as much about restriction and intimidation as prosecution and actual imprisonment," said the Amnesty report.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

9 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


How Rugby Scored A Try For The new South Africa


LENGTH: 1307 words


 

Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

June 23, 1995

The Rugby World Cup has been an enormous success as a catalyst for the kind of national unity which is possible in South Africa, writes Jon Swift

The Rugby World Cup is going to be a very hard act to follow. It is a point of national focus which has ranged from the sublime of the emotion-charged opening at Newlands in Cape Town exactly a month ago, to the farcical Leon Schuster song celebrating the South African team, Hier Kommie Bokke.

In all, organisers estimate that just over a million of the total 1,38-million seats for the 16-nation tournament will have been filled with people paying anything between R44 and R220 for a chance to watch one of the 32 matches.

The exercise will raise something approaching a staggering R100-million from tickets alone, and probably half as much again from the trade in T-shirts, ashtrays and other paraphernalia. 

More important than the eventual bottom line, though, has been the thread which has drawn the diverse interests of this rainbow nation towards the fortunes of 15 men in green-and-gold jerseys.

Viewership figures in this country have still to be fully analysed, but indications are that the TV sets have been switched on to rugby as often in Soweto as in Sandton and as enthusiastically in Phola Park as Putsonderwater.

While this new-found interest will pump much needed blood into the oft-criticised lifelessness of rugby's development programme, there has been a spin-off -- related directly to TV viewership -- of arguably far greater importance.

For, intriguingly, the World Cup has brought the white minority closer to the ideals of our new democracy, by the almost unreserved support of all sectors of the community for the squad who espouse the ethic of "one team, one country", than any past political assurances.

This has been led from the front by our state president, who embraced the South African team as "my sons", donning a cap adorned with the leaping Springbok emblem and putting his unreserved support behind the side -- when, in the past, as he admits, he would always have supported the opposing team.

In this, the president has not been alone. The scandalous barrage of bottles which rained down on the "non-white" sector of the stand at Ellis Park during the visit of the 1960 All Blacks because the disenfranchised had the timerity to cheer the New Zealanders is part of the legacy of division the game has historically symbolised for the citizens of this country.

For many, this legacy will take a lifetime to erase. For others, like the president, the present leads directly to a better and brighter future. The Rugby World Cup has been an enormous success as a catalyst for the kind of national unity which is possible in South Africa.

The fact that Mandela would don the badge which was for so many years a symbol of apartheid is just one sign of this.

For some, Francois Pienaar's insistence as captain that all the members of the team know the words of Nkosi Sikelel' iAfrika as well as they do Die Stem has put the game beyond the pale.

For the majority, though, this has been cause for celebration, an indication that our internal emphases are indeed changing from the narrow constraints of the old towards an all-embracing acceptance of the new.

Along these lines, too, it has been heartening to note the acceptance of C te d'Ivoire in the heart of Afrikaner Weerstandsbeweging country. The crowds at Rustenburg's Olympia Park took the luckless Africans into their hearts, waving Ivorian flags and supporting them in both face-paint and numbers.

Equally heartening has been the national response -- through the South African Rugby Football Union (Sarfu), the Chris Burger Fund and a national hotel chain, among others --to the sad plight of Max Brito's tragic fracture of the neck and subsequent paralysis of the Ivorian player.

The same applied to the Japanese team in Bloemfontein, the capital of the province which used to give people of Asian descent no more than the glancing courtesy of a 24-hour right of passage.

It is as if this country had awoken from a dreamless sleep and suddenly discovered that there are others of whatever lineage worthy of support who come from beyond our borders.

This has not held true, however, when the South Africans have been involved. There the support has been as one-eyed and partisan as it always was, from the euphoria of South Africa's 27-18 win over Australia in the opening burst, to the nail-biting vasbyt of the last quarter hour's siege by the French at the rain- lashed King's Park semi-final last week.

It has been as if the game which once typified white domination had magically drawn all sectors towards the centre and opened a new path, shown a new direction.

The nation has agonised with James Dalton and Pieter Hendriks, and, to judge by the fury of the phone-ins to talk radio, failed to grasp the fact that they had been found guilty as charged after the bloody brawl at Boet Erasmus Stadium in the game against Canada.

The country rejoiced in the fact that Chester Williams came back into the side he had disqualified himself from (due to injury) before the start of the tournament. And we went into a frenzy of delight when the winger celebrated his return with four superb tries in the combat zone of the 42-14 victory against Western Samoa.

Whether this jubilation will hold in the all-too-likely event of an All Black victory in the final at Ellis Park remains to be seen. But the game, the people and the country as a whole will surely have benefitted enormously from the whole experience.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


10 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


The Secrets Of Stratcom


LENGTH: 1587 words


 

Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

June 23, 1995

A former security policeman opens his bag of dirty tricks. Eddie Koch and Stefaans Brummer report

The State Security Council under former President FW de Klerk created a four-year plan to undermine and weaken the ANC and its allies in the build-up to the 1994 elections.

Details of the extensive dirty tricks plan, planned to run from 1990 to 1994, have been revealed by a former policeman deeply involved in it, Warrant Officer Paul Erasmus.

Erasmus' evidence, including information he has given to the Goldstone Commission, would have a major impact on the Government of National Unity, since it reflects on De Klerk's conduct during negotiations. 

Erasmus worked for the Witwaters-rand branch of Stratcom, the State Security Council arm which specialised in intelligence gathering and dirty tricks. He was personally involved in tapping the phones of and recruiting sources in the ANC as late as October 1992.

Although Stratcom was officially disbanded after the Mail & Guardian expose of the Inkathagate scandal in 1991, most of the front companies had been made self- sufficient and were allowed to continue independently. They ceased getting police money, but were allowed to keep their personnel, resources and premises.

No orders went out to stop their activities, merely to break official contact with them --and some of them continued operating until as recently as this year.

Erasmus was a long-standing security policeman who was given special Stratcom training in August 1990, six months after the unbanning of the ANC and the release of Nelson Mandela. On the course, they were told they had four years before the first democratic election in which to make sure the ANC was "reduced to just another political party".

"Stratcom had to consider identified target areas within the ANC, for example finances, and actions had to be taken to highlight the shortcomings and failures of the organisation with the ultimate aim of forcing Mandela to back down at the negotiating table."

There were, according to Erasmus, "soft" Stratcom activities -- projects with defined and "legal" aims -- and "hard" activities, "tactics such as murder, assassination, sabotage, breaking and entering, theft, planting of evidence and blackmail, subversion and a host of other activities in the 'national interest'".

Stratcom answered to the State Security Council, on which De Klerk and other NP leaders, such as Pik Botha, Roelf Meyer, Adriaan Vlok and Hernus Kriel, all sat. In addition, Stratcom projects in areas such as education had to be approved by the relevant minister.

Erasmus has provided details of a number of projects aimed at the ANC, its women's and youth leagues, individuals within them such as Winnie Mandela and Peter Mokaba, and the SA Communist Party. These included:

* Project Romulus, "covert action to put pressure on the ANC/SACP".

* Operation Gordian, "to minimise the effectiveness of the ANC Youth League and Sayco".

* Operation Jackal, "neutralising the ideological influence of radical organisations ... in secondary and tertiary institutions". The flagships of this project were the Students Moderate Alliance and the Afrikaans National Student Federation, set up to counter the influence of Nusas.

* Operation Olympia, to recruit high school kids as a way of dealing with the increasing difficulty they had in finding sources.

* Operation Ram, including a letter writing project, aimed at getting Stratkom views into the media.

* Operation Einstein, aimed at coloured education institutions.

* Project Omega, aimed at labour and under which the IFP union, Uwusa, was founded.

* Project Wigwam, the biggest of all, aimed at countering and neutralising the ANC, PAC, SACP, Cosatu as well as the far-rightwing.

Erasmus was involved in these projects, working from the offices of a front company in Randburg, until late 1991, when he transferred to the Southern Cape. There he worked for the Central Intelligence Services, which he says merely took over the work of the disbanded security police. Erasmus' documents reveal extensive surveillance, phone tapping, mail interception and the recruitment of sources in the ANC in the area as late as October 1992.

Erasmus' Stratcom work also stretched overseas. A major part of it was to spread anti-ANC propaganda in countries being visited by Mandela in a bid to damage his chances of raising money for his party. This was done in Britain, the United States and Japan, mostly by feeding anti-ANC information to the media and friendly organisations.

Erasmus worked extensively with a Scottish member of the Conservative Party's rightwing Monday Club, Harvey Ward, to feed information to MP's and other prominent British figures. Some of these were aware of the origin of the information.

He also worked with an American foundation, the Short Forum, to counter the ANC in the United States.

Brigadier Zirk Gous, now head of police community relations in the Witwatersrand, but named by Erasmus as head of Stratcom intelligence, yesterday said Stratcom was "a structured operation for a limited time period 1990-1992" and was then formally disbanded.

But Stratcom documents make it clear that it was formed in 1984 and Erasmus' evidence suggests that some of its work continued informally after 1992.

Erasmus left the police force in 1993, angry and disillusioned, he and his family "having been victimised by a corrupt commanding officer". "I became one of the first policemen to sue the minister for the loss of my career. As a result, I became the target of dirty tricks, disinformation and received information that previous colleagues were going to kill me, my wife and children.

"The commissioner, General Johan van der Merwe, personally ordered a massive investigation into my whole career, fearing, I believe, that I would reveal covert operations. I am prepared to accept responsibility for deeds that I carried out in the total onslaught era and after 1990, but I find it impossible to accept that my wife and innocent children should suffer in actions which were to be implemented against me. It was only when this vicious system turned on me when I realised what I had been doing to the white left for all those years.

"I don't regad myself as another Dirk Coetzee or a traitor. However, I believe that unless the evils of the past are exposed, they may be perpetuated in the future," Erasmus said.

He later gave evidence to the Goldstone Commission, where he was put on a witness protection programme and flown overseas for his safety. He was codenamed Q4, one of the key witnesses in Judge Richard Goldstone's expose of third force activities.

Erasmus' wife, however, is on record as being sharply critical of their treatment by the Goldstone Commission.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

LANGUAGE: English

11 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


SA's M-Net Wants the Lead in Africa


LENGTH: 1160 words


 

Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

June 16, 1995

M-Net corporate affairs manager Cawe Mahlati, tells Aspasia Karras how she hopes to see M-Net become the frontrunner of global broadcasting in Africa

Articulate and determined, M-Net corporate affairs manager Cawe Mahlati is a force to be reckoned with in private broadcasting. Not only does she have a vision of what broadcasting can become in the future, but she believes that the impetus of the future is already here.

As corporate affairs manager of M-Net, and an executive board member, she feels it is her duty to ensure that everybody else is aware of it.

The self-declared "rural Transkeian girl" believes that the information age is not exacerbating the divide between the third and first worlds, but is rather a bridging opportunity: "We have moved beyond atoms and into bytes." 

This, she says, has astounding consequences for our lives. Mahlati sees the information highway as a viable method with which to alleviate bureaucratic problems which hold up rural development.

Her excitement for her industry drives the representations she has being making at the Independent Broadcasting Authority (IBA) hearings, as she takes part in the sensitive debate around restrictions, structural changes and local content, and ultimately the future of private broadcasting in South Africa.

"Wherever there is change there is opportunity," she says. She contends broadcasting has traditionally been a single- territory-based industry represented by local national channels, but increasingly it is becoming global, and so the "product" should become global in nature. The various regulatory authorities should be aware of this tendency, and legislate for the future rather than in response to the past.

M-Net is being beamed into 42 African countries, an achievement which Mahlati feels is in line with international trends. Ultimately, her vision for M-Net as a forerunner of the globalising tendency in Africa depends on the IBA's approach to M-Net's proposals. Mahlati says: "If the IBA does not follow models like the French one then we are likely to see Gauteng becoming the nodal point of a South African broadcasting industry that could generate great wealth and strategic power for South Africa."

She believes that the IBA is obliged to help create an "enlightened", vibrant and sustainable broadcasting industry and should, therefore, not be concerned with the local production industry, but rather with the broadcasters that can take the industry into the 21st century.

In this regard M-Net resists a local-content quota. Its compromise is a specified sum allocated to local productions, escalated annually in line with the Consumer Price Index. This approach, she argues, is the only viable option for her pay channel which will soon have to compete with international pay channels. "We would be completely unable to produce the international quality show Egoli if we had quotas to fulfil, as essentially this would mean more local content but inevitably poor quality productions," she maintains.

As to the pending influx of competition, Mahlati says: "We welcome competition. It increases efficiency as consumers have a choice, but M-Net is laying its plans to ensure that it offers the most competitive product around."

She says M-Net's recent unbundling is part of the global plan. Essentially the company is following an international trend of downsizing and narrowing focus to become more efficient and productive. She believes M-Net's ultimate concern is to satisfy its customers, so programming has to conform to the needs of the customers.

Mahlati says her career has been a series of coincidences that has taken her on a heady journey to success. Her life reads like a high-powered Egoli fantasy, starting with her graduation from Inanda Seminary in Durban, "a high school run by militant American feminists who basically came to Africa to train African women to take up positions of leadership".

Next came a law degree -- she studied at the Universities of Lesotho and Edinburgh -- as well as a course in international relations and diplomacy in Austria.

She is worldly and cultured: she spent time in New York both as an exchange student and working for IBM as an associate attorney, and pursued her diplomatic career in Austria, Zimbabwe and Transkei. She expresses a deep love for the opera, dance and percussion instruments, all of which she believes are excellent mediums for cross-cultural pollination. She recalls fondly M-Net's support of a dance production called Gumboot Flamenco de Africa and she supports avidly the West Indian festival that takes place every year in London and New York.

Dukes Zondi, M-Net's human resources manager, confirms her role as M-Net's trump card in negotiations. "She plays a pivotal role in the establishment of relationships with various stakeholders, particularly with the government," he says.

Mahlati simply wants to see M-Net become "the leading entertainment television company in Africa".

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


12 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


ANC Backs Black Panther 'Killer'


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

June 16, 1995

As South Africa scraps the death penalty, the ANC alliance is fighting to save the life of an American journalist on death row, writes Bruce Cohen

The African National Congress, the South African Communist Party and the Congress of South African Trade Unions have joined in the fight to halt the execution of an American journalist.

Former Black Panther Mumia Abu-Jamal, 40, who has spent 13 years on death row for killing a Philadelphia policeman -- a crime he denies -- received his death warrant two weeks ago from Pennsylvania Governor Tom Ridge.

He will be executed by lethal injection on August 17. 

On the day Ridge signed the execution order, ANC secretary general Cyril Ramaphosa sent a letter of appeal to the governor. Ramaphosa asked for "compassionate reconsideration of the sentence ... and that (Jamal) be removed from death row and be allowed to appeal his sentence".

Cosatu, in its letter to Ridge, said it was clear from reports it had received that the trial was "fraught with bias and prejudice. We are therefore persuaded that his death sentence should be commuted and that the entire record of the trial should be reviewed".

Jamal, aka Wesley Cook, has been described as America's own Salman Rushdie. He was a prominent radio journalist and president of the Philadelphia chapter of the Association of Black Journalists. In the 1970s he was information "minister" for the Philadelphia chapter of the Black Panther Party.

Since July 1982 he has been in solitary confinement on death row in Huntington, Pennsylvania after being convicted of killing a police officer on December 9 1981.

The night of the shooting, he was driving his cab when he spotted his brother on the side of the road arguing with a policeman. He went to see what was happening, a melee ensued, and both Jamal and the officer were shot. Jamal was also beaten by police. None of the witnesses could testify who had fired the first or the fatal shot.

Throughout his trial, Jamal maintained his innocence. The 12-person jury that convicted him included 11 white men.

In 1991, the US Supreme Court denied Jamal's petition for review of his conviction and death sentence.

While in jail Jamal has continued to write articles for a number of newspapers.

Worldwide support for Jamal has come from a variety of individuals and organisations, among them Harry Belafonte and Whoopi Goldberg. Trade unions have been especially active in the campaign. Among the South African unions which have written to Governor Ridge are the National Union of Metalworkers and the Commercial, Catering and Allied Workers' Union.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


13 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


More Power For Shareholders


LENGTH: 1174 words


 

Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

June 9, 1995

Jacques Magliolo reports on proposed changes to the Johannesburg Stock Exchange listings criteria

Shareholders are set to obtain greater control of companies listed on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange (JSE) from next month. But the changes in disclosure and listing requirements fall short of statements made in a document circulated by the JSE in August last year.

A draft consultation document was sent out in August 1994 to companies, auditors and stockbrokers for comment. Alterations were expected to be announced in January 1995 relating to pyramid and shareholder structures, cash shells, powers of the JSE, creation of new sectors and greater transparency for company disclosure. 

While the exchange took six months longer than planned -- in order to consult more widely -- it has backtracked on a number of moves that would have increased transparency and improved liquidity.

The first is the minimum shareholder spread. At least 10 percent of a company's shares must now be in the hands of the general public. Companies will have to ensure this percentage remains in force at all times and existing companies will have until the year 2 000 to comply with this requirement.

The August Draft Consultation document had this figure at 25 percent, which would have gone a long way towards dismantling conglomerate control of the South African financial market. This would also have increased the number of shares traded and thus improved liquidity.

The issue of two-tiered pyramid structures is unresolved, which means that a listed holding company can only have one listed subsidiary. In turn, that holding company cannot have a major shareholder that is listed.

"Commentators on the constitution draft were split on the desirability of listing such structures and instruments. The JSE and the government will discuss the issue later this year and, in the interim, they will be listed," the exchange announced this week that

It seems pressure from business has forced the exchange to backtrack on minimum shareholder spread and call for talks with the government. Two examples highlight this:

Black groups listed on the exchange in the past 12 months do not fulfil the 25 percent shareholder structure proposed in the initial draft document, but all encompass multi-tiered pyramids. These companies include the much publicised New Africa Investment Limited (Nail), Corporate Africa, Real Africa Holdings and Real Africa Investments.

Although Nail's pre-listing statement indicated that 25,6 percent of its shareholders were "other black shareholders", it did not provide details as to whether these are individuals or organisations. During an interview earlier this year Nail chairman Dr Nthato Motlana warned the JSE not to tamper with pyramids.

He said: "We will oppose the JSE's forthcoming changes to regulations, particularly those affecting pyramid structures. Now that we are becoming more established in big business, the JSE and white conglomerates want to change the rules.'

Motlana's reasons for insisting that pyramid structures remain are logical. He asserts: "Pyramids enable companies with small shareholder stakes to control larger companies. If this type of structure is abolished it will make it impossible for blacks to own companies or to help transfer wealth to disadvantaged people." As such, Nail's recent bid for the restructured JCI is highlighted.

The second example is the unexplained delay in Mondi Paper's listing. In January this year the company was ready to list, but industry analysts say that the hesitation has been caused by the draft document.

"Mondi does not need to list for financial reasons, but to improve its image," says an insider. "A change in the shareholder structure means that Amic would have to sell a large stake in its subsidiary. I believe that Amic placed pressure on the exchange to reduce the 25 percent to 10 percent," he says.

Despite these compromises, an important new direction for the JSE lies in its desire to strengthen company disclosure. Companies will be obliged to announce "as soon as possible any information which is of a price- sensitive nature". This information will include details on possible takeovers, new contracts and even the discovery of new mineral resources.

Two new sectors are to be formed, namely a "redevelopment" sector to help black companies list and a "cash shell" sector. There are at present three cash shells listed on the JSE, namely Barnetts, Bergers and The Pharmaceutical Wholesale Group.

On becoming a cash shell, a listed company will be transferred to the new sector. If the company fails to acquire viable assets within six months, its shares will be suspended. Finally, the stock exchange has changed listing requirements for the Venture Capital Market to make it more accessible to the general public. The requirement for subscribed capital has been reduced from R2-million to R500 000.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Africa News


June, 1995


New York Dresses Up, SA-Style


LENGTH: 1734 words


 

Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

June 9, 1995

Displaced South African Andrew Dosunmu -- fashion stylist and music video director -- is hot property in New York. He spoke to Tony Karon

Andrew Dosunmu is pacing around his sparse studio apartment in Manhattan's fashion district, anxious for feedback on his directorial debut music video.

There is no furniture beyond the functional -- a futon, a drawing board, a music system, a large television set.

On the TV, the wicked bass-and-wah-wah-guitar rhythm of the legendary Isaac Hayes' new single, Funky Junky, drives a moody montage of expressionist, monochrome images of African diaspora city life. The video is brilliant, and not surprisingly, it has opened a new dimension to Dosunmu's career. 

Before Funky Junky, he had only directed a couple of short films and commercials for Gitanes and Revlon. But his work as a fashion stylist has earned Dosunmu a reputation as one of the most exciting influences on New York's aesthetic landscape.

Born in England of exiled South African parents, Dosunmu grew up closer to London's rebellious Jamaican "rude boys" than his parents' exile milieu. After studying fashion at St Martin's College, he worked for six years in the Paris design studio of Yves St Laurent.

"Then I realised it wasn't clothes I liked. It was the overall image, the look, that attracted me to fashion," he explained. Which took him to New York to work as a freelance stylist. Within two years, his work has livened up the pages of magazines ranging from bibles of downtown cool like Paper and VIBE, to establishment fashion vehicles like Vogue, L'Uomo and Esquire. He styled the designs of his friend Antoine Xuly Bet for Robert Altman's film Pret-a-Porter (the "subway" show presented by Forrest Whittaker's character).

Dosunmu uses unconventional settings for designer ranges -- the rugged slackness of the reggae dancehall, the menacing camaraderie of young street gangsters, the feisty elegance of Puerto Rican girls in the hood.

Last year, the New York Times included him among five young stylists turning fashion on its head, and throughout our interview his answering machine fields calls from fashion editors begging him to bring his signature to their pages.

Where once stylists simply finished off the edges of fashion shoots, today their ability to move between the worlds of couture, film and music videos has propelled them to centre stage in defining fashion.

Dosunmu and his contemporaries create the context for fashion by grounding it in street-culture and urban realities, lacing it with post-modern ironies and appreciating clothing as a vocabulary for identity.

"Designers tend to design clothes, not the spirit in which they're worn," Dosunmu explains. "It is up to the stylist to suggest that spirit.

"You're not just showing clothes; you're creating a feeling, an ambience which evokes a lifestyle. Stylists are responsible for the content of the spread -- putting the clothes together, and making sense of them. The stylist is really the creative director of a fashion shoot."

The "look" of a music video is as important as its sound in relaying messages, and this puts stylists at the centre. As the visual principles of music videos began to dominate other media, stylists found themselves interlocutors between the worlds of music, fashion, the visual media and street culture.

Today the fashion industry depends on them to interpret clothing for a media-savvy market. Which changes the rules of fashion: "Anybody can be fashionable," says Dosunmu. "You just have to have the money. But a lot of the people who have money and buy the clothes don't necessarily have style -- often they look ridiculous in them. Most people who's style I admire, when I ask them where they got their clothes, it's the shop next door or a thrift store. But they put it together so brilliantly."

Style, he says, is about putting things together, about using clothes to communicate.

Dosunmu and his contemporaries often wrench clothes out of the elite couture context in which they were created, setting them on the streets, mixing them up with thrift store and no-name brand basics. (Dosunmu is as likely to use neighbourhood kids as professional models on his shoots).

His aesthetic is unmistakeably African: "African people are not generally fashionable, but they're very stylish. That's a big influence in my life. As a teenager in England, I rejected the whole South Africa connection. I wanted to be like everyone around me. But the fact that I'm African was there unconsciously, and it came out in my work without me realising it at first. Which means that I appreciate it much more ..."

A concern with styling is common throughout Africa. An underpaid worker living in a squatter camp in Kinshasa may wear an Armani suit (often showing the label) or pair of shoes or sunglasses. It's a way of constructing an identity, appearing to defy the limits on the individual's mobility. The deployment of styles can also have a playfully subversive component: in colonial and post-colonial Africa, there is a long tradition of the dominated appropriating the outward symbols of power in order to mock that power and render it hollow.

"I love that culture clash," Dosunmu enthuses. "Think about what it means when you see a rugged African youth in a bowler hat. Or a guy in a traditional West African gown wearing mirror lens Ray Bans ..."

Style is used to construct identity throughout Africa and the African diaspora. In the US, for example, the Black Panther party carried guns to fight racism, but their dress codes revealed a deep awareness of the power of images: the Panthers' leather blazers and striped T-shirts, bandoliers and berets are an unmistakeable reference to the Hollywood representation of the French Resistance and other anti-Nazi partisans of World War II.

Similarly, the fact that Sophiatown gangsters of the 1950s opted for Hollywood gangster styling reflects a symbolic defiance of white authority, by appropriating the styles of white society's nightmare figures.

It is a game that Dosunmu enjoys playing himself: "I went to a wedding the other day, wearing a three-piece suit and tie -- I looked like something off Saville Row. It was a trip, teasing the powers that be, saying 'I could look like that too' ... And straight after, I went to a reggae dance, dressed like that. And all the boys were like 'whoa, gwaan rasta'. Knowing I could walk out of there and on the street some policeman would call me 'sir' because he would think I was some hotshot ..."

Dosunmu's fascination with African aesthetics has taken him on travels throughout West Africa, and last November, he finally ventured 'home'. A shoot for VIBE magazine took him to Cape Town for two weeks, where he used township youths to model casuals and sportswear by top New York designers. "I felt very at home in South Africa, and I've got to get back there to make a film," he enthuses.

Although more music videos and films figure high on his agenda, styling is still his great love. "I want to encourage people to take a new look at what's around them, and express themselves with their clothes."

If stylists' power to evoke meanings with clothing derives from their ability to move between worlds, then Dosunmu's diaspora African experience (a dislocated South African in London, Paris and New York) has given him a unique vision.

"I think the reason people like my work is because I'm an ethnic, an outsider, and because of that I'm very aware of any ethnic culture, or other outsider cultures like gay and lesbian. I'm sensitive to outsider cultures, and today people are looking for that."

With that, he dons a furry homburg hat and pedals off through the fashion district on a bicycle of the type used by South African postmen during the 1960s. A bicycle which, in the vocab of style, could be translated as a wink.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.
