Africa News


June, 1995


The 'Silent Majority' Raises Its Voice


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

June 9, 1995

by Pat Sidley

Last week's march on Parliament by thousands of angry Christians highlights the rapid growth of fundamentalist Christian groups in South Africa, and mirrors the advance of the religious right wing in the United States.

The marchers had come to protest the exclusion of the words "Almighty God" from the Constitution. But their agenda reaches much further than this.

Several of the groups, which marched under the same banner and share the same concerns, have large memberships, including the KwaSizabantu ministers, who see themselves as a counter to the more liberal churches which signed the Rustenberg Declaration several years ago. 

One of the organisers of the march, Reverend Peter Hammond, says many of them have grave concerns, aside from the Constitution, such as the exclusion of Ascension Day from the public holidays, the proposed legalisation of abortion and the growth of the pornography industry.

The group set up to represent those interests is called "The Christian Voice" and it raised tens of thousands of rands locally to fund the march, says its representative Reverend Soon Zevenster of the Evangelical Reform Church.

Hammond and Zevenster told the Mail & Guardian that the group was set up only a month ago with the express purpose of taking up these causes and the march was only a beginning.

The group hired the buses and trains used to ferry the poorer supporters of its cause from the surrounding townships and squatter camps, according to Zevenster, and printed close to 400 000 pamphlets advertising the march. Money was raised through individual congregations by asking ministers in churches to support the cause.

Hammond's group, the Frontline Fellowship, co-operates with several other groups (with which it shares offices in Cape Town). These include United Christian Action, whose purpose it is, he explained, to carry out the political and social concerns among the "silent majority". The chairman of United Christian Action is Ed Cain, who gained infamy some years ago when he was associated with the Christian League, a front group used by the previous government to counter the influence of the South African Council of Churches.

"He must have been burned in that experience," maintained Hammond, who said Cain authored the organisation's constitution, which explicitly bars the acceptance of any government funding. Cain's daughter Mirian runs another associated group, African Christian Action, whose business it is to fight pornography, abortion, and so on.

The Frontline Fellowship itself, according to Hammond, sends missionaries, bibles, medication and food into countries such as Sudan, Malawi and Mozambique and, to a lesser extent, Rwanda and KwaZulu/ Natal. Hammond, with some of his missionaries, spent an uncomfortable week in prison in the hands of Frelimo troups in 1989, when they abducted him from Malawi and accused him of gun-running. He vigorously denies this, stating that he was released after a week.

The Frontline Fellowship, he says, is funded by spontaneous donations from several sources, including local ones, and others in the United States and Europe. He does not, he says, raise funds, having biblical objections to the notion of fundraising. The money flows in spontaneously to do God's work, he explains, while being critical of the Christian Voice's fundraising.

The size of the march, which caught even its organisers off guard, has struck a chord of worry among the leaders of the "mainstream" churches. Many of these leaders noticed with concern that the numbers of marchers must reflect the fact that some of their own members were among them.

At the Press Club in Cape Town this week, Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu dealt with some of the complex issues raised.

"There are those Christians who claim that there are unambiguous and categorical directives regarding what the Christian position ought to be on issues such as abortion, homosexuality, divorce, euthanasia, etc.

"Such people are able to claim that 'the Bible says' and then believe that they have dealt once and for all with a complex issue and anyone who disagrees with them is really not Christian."

He argued, too, that the inclusion of the words "Almighty God" in the last Constitution did not prevent abuses of power -- a point which Hammond acknowledges. But he points at previously Communist states which guaranteed in constitutions a right to religious freedom -- and failed to provide it.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

June, 1995


Draft Law Gives Teeth To Gender Rights


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

June 9, 1995

by Rehana Rossouw

Draft legislation spelling out the powers of the Gender Equity Commission has been prepared by the Department of Justice, giving the body the same teeth as the Human Rights Commission to perform its tasks of ensuring gender equity in Parliament and society.

The Parliamentary Commission on Gender Equity met on Wednesday to grapple with the scope of its functions and powers. The commission, chaired by African National Congress (ANC) MP Ruth Mompati, was established by women parliamentarians who were concerned about the advancement of women. 

National Party MP Shelia Camerer said a Commission on Gender Equity would be more effective than a Womens' Ministry as these had failed dismally across sub- Sarahan Africa.

A commission could be given power to introduce legislation and vet legislation from other ministries for gender sensitivity, she said.

Dr Ellen Kornegay, of the Womens' Development Foundation, who gave evidence before the commission, said what was needed was a dynamic and interactive relationship between national, provincial and local governments, and access to non-governmental organisations on women's issues.

"Participation should not be limited to parliamentarians alone. We need to monitor gender compliance in both the public and private sector. The commission could then report annually to Parliament and society on the advancement of women."

Mompati said the Ministry of Justice had promised that draft legislation on the commission would be completed within the next week and would serve as a working document.

She said that while the commission would have to consult widely on the draft Bill, it should be mindful that the deadline was approaching for the draft legislation to be submitted to the Cabinet so that it can be dealt with in Parliament this year.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

17 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


SA Gets Its First Taste Of Satellite TV


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

June 9, 1995

Speculation is rife that Sol Kerzner is involved in South Africa's first satellite TV channel, reports Justin Pearce

South Africa entered the satellite television era on Wednesday evening when Africa Satellite Entertainment Corporation (ASEC) launched its sports and entertainment channel amid speculation that casino king Sol Kerzner is involved in the deal.

The move is an embarrassment for the Independent Broadcasting Authority (IBA) which intends to regulate satellite broadcasting but which still has no means of doing so.

ASEC's programme was beamed from Swaziland via the Intelsat 704 satellite from 7pm to 11pm and will be broadcast daily. 

The station is due to be launched officially in September with a full line-up of entertainment programmes. ASEC is currently broadcasting on 10,974GHz with sound on 6,68MHz. The ku-band (small dish) signal is unencoded and, for the time being, free.

Wednesday's launch makes ASEC the first satellite broadcaster to get on the air in South Africa, several months ahead of rival MultiChoice, which will be broadcasting in association with M-Net.

The controlling interests behind ASEC are being kept under wraps, but there is speculation that Sol Kerzner's Sun International is among the backers of the new broadcaster. Although a Sun International representative could neither confirm nor deny the speculation, observers commented that the sports footage aired during the test broadcast showed an overwhelming bias towards events at Sun International venues.

ASEC, which initially intended being on the air before the beginning of June, delayed its first test broadcast pending an IBA ruling . Managing director Mark Grey said that the company had no intention of becoming a pirate broadcaster. However, this week the IBA appeared flummoxed by ASEC's appearance on the air. IBA head of licensing Jac van der Merwe said the IBA councillors had discussed satellite broadcasting but had not yet reached a conclusion.

"I don't know how we are going to deal with this issue," Van der Merwe said.

He said that in terms of International Telecommunications Union norms, the IBA could tolerate signal spill-over from a satellite aimed at a neighbouring country. However, if the signal were aimed at South Africa -- as is the case with ASEC -- the IBA would have to intervene.

ASEC has got in ahead of the field by using Intelsat 704 which was already in the air.

Meanwhile, the launch of the PAS-4 satellite which is to be used by MultiChoice has been put in jeopardy by a rocket which could well be described as the Francois Pienaar of the skies -- it is injury-prone. The Ariane rocket, which is due to put PAS-4 in the sky later this year, has suffered no fewer than six failed launches in the past 18 months. In January this year Ariane killed five people after crashing in China shortly after a launch, and previously at least two satellites had been destroyed by malfunctions in the rocket.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


18 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


Foreign Affairs Department Under Fire


LENGTH: 1360 words


 

Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

June 9, 1995

Alfred Nzo's ministry stands accused of not having made the leap into the new South Africa, reports Rehana Rossouw

Minister Alfred Nzo and his Department of Foreign Affairs came in for a barrage of criticism this week from the ANC alliance and academics who charged that it had failed to provide the moral leadership the world expected from South Africa.

They said the department's record over the past year showed it was one of the least effective and least transparent departments in government today.

The critical focus on foreign affairs took place at a parliamentary workshop in Cape Town at the weekend and at a symposium on Monday organised by the Centre for Southern African Studies and the International Labour Resource and Information Group (Ilrig).

At Monday's symposium, Cosatu spokesperson Neil Coleman said the department did not provide the moral leadership on the international stage the world expected from South Africa and, particularly, Nelson Mandela. 

"South Africa can play a leading role in challenging global apartheid and the policy of the Department of Foreign Affairs should be geared towards doing so. But we have yet to see such policies emanating from the department," Coleman said.

University of Durban Westville political studies head John Daniels said almost 90 percent of Foreign Affairs ministry staff, including Director General Rusty Evans, have been retained by Nzo, and ANC members trained abroad in foreign affairs before the elections found the doors to the department shut firmly in their faces.

"The management of the department lacks expertise and new blood. Foreign policy is made by a small elite and a group of bureaucrats who are determined to maintain the shroud of secrecy in the department," Daniels said.

"The only response we get to our barrage of criticism is a promise to establish an advisory council. But if there is no desire to receive advice, what is the use of such a structure?"

Althea Macquene of Ilrig said Foreign Affairs was the "most opaque" department in government. "It has not yet published a white paper, nor has it made known the process it will adopt to do so or set a timetable for its completion."

A number of controversial foreign policy decisions taken recently remain unexplained -- Mandela's relationship with the Indonesian and Sudanese governments, South Africa's stand on the review of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and its refusal to support a United States resolution at the United Nations to investigate human rights violations in Cuba.

National Assembly Select Committee chairman Raymond Suttner said he could only conclude from articles in the press that the relationship with Indonesia stems from the fact that its president made financial donations to the ANC.

"Does the Department of Foreign Affairs not have a duty to explain to the public why this situation exists, particularly in the light of Indonesia's occupation of East Timor?" Suttner asked.

"South Africa's vote at the UN on the Cuban issue was seen in some quarters as very controversial. Yet immediately after the vote, the South African representative to the UN was unable to explain to the media why we took that stand. The department has yet to give an explanation of its vote."

Suttner said there was little information about where most foreign policy originates in the government. Decision making in the department has not changed substantially under an ANC government and the problem is compounded by the fact that the president, Vice- President Thabo Mbeki and other ministries, particularly Trade and Industry, Home Affairs and Health, regularly make decisions with foreign policy implications.

He said foreign policy should not be the exclusive preserve of professional diplomats and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, but should involve Parliament.

"We need to remember that whatever is done by the minister or the Department of Foreign Affairs is done in the name of South Africa and the public. We need to move away from a situation which presumes that because foreign affairs has a special area of concern it can be exempted from the same degree of public scrutiny that applies to defence or security or home affairs."

Suttner said the presidency and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs left little room for the public or Parliament to make an input on its decisions. However, a significant step in this direction was made when the department's budget was reviewed by the select committee.

The committee agreed on the overall goals of the department, but criticised the allocation of funds to South Africa's missions when the budget proposed spending only R105-million of the allocated R645- million on African missions.

While the ministry was providing a "fair number" of briefings to the committee, these were generally at the request of the committee and related to international crises or controversies. There was never a briefing prior to an important decision or visit, and there is no mechanism for briefings to the public.

"The failure to talk to one another before important decisions makes it harder to have good relations. It impedes the type of common reflection that is needed to move away from ad hoc approaches to foreign relations," Suttner said.

"Foreign Affairs should be sufficiently transparent to enable meaningful parliamentary and public scrutiny and debate."

He called for a "rupture" with the past in the Department of Foreign Affairs, especially with regard to its policy process.

"Now that we have a democratic government, we are entitled to expect democratic foreign policy which is accountable to the people of South Africa and driven by them."

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


19 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


Editorial: Noose Gets The Gallows


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

June 9, 1995

It took three days of court argument, three-and-a-half months of deliberation and 244 pages of opinion for the Constitutional Court to re-establish the sanctity of life in South Africa by declaring invalid the death penalty. This week's decision is a major break from the past. It brings to an end South Africa's long-standing dominance of the international capital punishment market. And it is the first time in this country that new institutions have given the rights of individuals ascendancy over the force of public opinion. 

Those who argue that the 11 judges are over-riding public opinion, or that a matter of this sort should be settled by referendum, miss the point of a Bill of Rights and a Constitutional Court. The function of these new institutions is to give individuals and minorities protection from the shifting winds of public opinion. The public may come to believe that the killers of Chris Hani should be beheaded in public, or those perpetuating violence in KwaZulu/Natal be locked up without trial, or that abortionists should be jailed. But a Bill of Rights is intended to assert that some rights are so fundamental to democracy that they are inviolable. It is intended to ensure that individuals and minorities are protected from the vagaries of public opinion.

Hopefully we have a government strong enough not to feel the need to pander to public opinion on this. One would expect the National Party to latch on to this populist cause, as it has, forgetting quickly that it found itself unable to hang anyone in the last few years of its government.

It is worth noting that there was an outcry when President Nelson Mandela said he would ask for changes in the Constitution if it was necessary to prevent violence in KwaZulu/Natal. No such outcry has accompanied the National Party request to change the Constitution to allow the state to kill people. But if you water down the right to life in the Bill of Rights, you will be giving up the most basic, the most important, the most fundamental right of all.

There could be an argument for this if there were substantial evidence that the death penalty was an effective deterrent to crime; or that one could eliminate the possibilities of errors which sometimes take the wrong person to the gallows; or remove the likelihood that some defendants -- those without access to proper defence -- would be more likely to be hanged than others. But none of these over-ride the most basic argument against capital punishment: that this country, more than most, needs to re-establish the sanctity of human life, not continue to degrade it. You cannot do this by giving the state the right to kill.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


20 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


SA's Gordimer A Conscientious Cannes Judge


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

June 2, 1995

by Paul Martin

Cannes -- This is a glamorous place, and glamour is not something that sits easily with Nadine Gordimer's self-image. She was wary of a request for a photograph of her on her top-floor Hotel Majestic balcony overlooking the azure Mediterranean, though she did allow two. "People back home may get the wrong impression," she worried.

The right impression, folks, is as follows: Gordimer worked very hard indeed, judging 23 films in her capacity as vice- president of the jury, and no, she was not swanning about with superstars. "It's a pity that we're not able to meet the great actors and directors. But it would be wrong to be seen in their company if we're judging their films," she properly pointed out. 

To her credit, Gordimer has never been particularly interested in gratuitous socialising -- last year, for instance, she declined an invitation to tea, just before Nelson Mandela's inauguration as president, with the wife of the United Nations secretary general.

Yet, despite her formidable work ethic, one got the distinct impression that she was actually rather enjoying it all. She found the members of the jury stimulating. "People may have expected me to clash somewhat on the jury with (Serial Mom director) John Waters, but we got on tremendously well," she noted.

"We're very different personalities, yet we have one thing in common: we like to push right to the edge ... even if our edges are different," she somewhat opaquely expanded.

Just what, I ventured to ask, qualified Gordimer, with her Nobel Prize for Literature, to be an arbiter of films? She bristled slightly. "It's the writing of the screenplay that really sets apart the great films from the good," she stated. "In fact, my jury colleagues believe that most films are getting better and better visually, so the dialogue is really the distinguishing feature. That's where I come in."

In any case, Gordimer is no stranger to the movie world: she wrote the screenplays for three of the seven short films of her works that were made on shoestring budgets in the late 1970s.

The jury's preferences were, at the time we spoke, top- secret. But it wasn't hard to tell from her approach that the winning film -- Yugoslav director Emir Kustorica's Underground -- met her criteria.

"I want a film, just like any good book, to be set in a social and political milieu. If the human and the political aspects are not related, then the film is a failure. How can a story be devoid of politics? Where would it take place -- in the clouds? In the end, stories without depth are forgotten."

Kustorica's setting of his film in war-torn Yugoslavia mirrors Gordimer's own themes, perhaps having some resonance with her Six Feet in the Country. This was made into a low-budget film, which the late Chris Davis brought to Cannes many years back ...

South African products, despite the huge political upheaval, she lamented, were noticeably absent -- apart from Souleymane Cisse's outdated and crass Waati, about which Gordimer wisely declined to comment.

"I'm not privy to whether other South African films were submitted but didn't make it to the last 23," she said. "But I've been actively promoting South Africa's film industry." She had, for example, alerted a top Indian producer to the wealth of themes about the South African "Asian" communities, reflected in works already extant in South Africa.

"Many international filmmakers are seeing South Africa as just a place to make their motion pictures. But what they don't realise is that they don't need to bring their own crews and their own actors to South Africa. We have superb black actors, good enough technicians, such talent. And good writers."

It "deeply disturbs me", the Nobel Prizewinner commented, "when black Americans play the roles of black South Africans". She would be outraged should an American be cast in the role of Nelson Mandela in any film of his life. Gordimer believes there is a plethora of wonderful material for future South African films (and books). "People's experiences in the new South African realities, facing up to changes personally and politically -- that really is the subject matter we will be tackling," she asserted.

Of her books, she would be most keen for The Conservationist to be made into a feature film. In the story, she pointed out, a black man buried by a white farmer is unearthed after a flash-flood. "It's my most lyrical, and perhaps my most difficult work," she mused. "It'll need somebody very special to do it. The central issue in South Africa is the land, and this book deals with who owns what."

Will South Africa's Nobel laureate incorporate the Cannes experience into her future work in print or on celluloid? On that, as the cliche goes, the jury is still out.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Africa News


June, 1995


Mozambique's Ambitious Privatisation Plan


LENGTH: 880 words


 

Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

June 2, 1995

by Reg Rumney

While the world waits for South Africa to spell out its privatisation plans, next door, Mozambique has thundered ahead with a far-reaching privatisation programme.

By the end of February this year, Mozambique's government had privatised 21 large, strategic enterprises, and plans to privatise a further 40 or so over the next two years, said World Bank resident representative Simon Bell at a regional press seminar in Windhoek.

By the end of 1996, says Bell, most industrial sector activity would be in private hands. "The process is now accelerating with the sale of the cement plants to Portuguese interests, the cashew nut processing plants to Mozambican and other

interests, and the sale of soft drink plants." 

The sale of the breweries, additional cashew nut plants, coastal shipping operations, and plastics factories is being negotiated with serious bidders.

The irony is all the more obvious against the strongly socialist stance of the Frelimo government in the past. To be sure, South Africa did not nationalise to anything like the extent that Mozambique did after its independence, and so there is not as much to privatise.

One of the main concerns of the World Bank, said Bell, was the dramatic decline over the past seven years in the relatively well-diversified and dynamic industrial sector Mozambique had at independence.

On the agricultural front, as part of what could be construed as a kind of recolonisation, Anglo American is coming back to work its old cashew nut processing plant at Xai Xai, though Mozambican investors have put money in as well. Mozambique now produces 10 percent of the cashews it did at its peak.

International investors were also involved in cotton, Bell revealed, with Lonrho in a joint venture operation.

Recently there have been moves to privatise some of the large sugar, copra and tea estates.

Fisheries were among the first to be privatised and sold to, among others, Mozambican, Spanish, Portuguese and South African interests.

In transport, feasibility studies are underway for a toll road from Komatipoort to Maputo, and similar private sector initiatives may be possible through the Beira corridor. There could also soon be private sector involvement in the national airline, LAM, and there is already involvement in Maputo port.

Along with financial sector reform which allows new banks to be licensed in Mozambique, the government recently announced that Mozambique's two state banks, which account for about 70 percent of total banking system assets, would be privatised.

Investment is not confined to privatisation: Fortune 500 company Enron is involved in a $30-million Pande gas field study. If the project, in which the World Bank is playing a catalyst role, comes off it will be a big foreign exchange boost, bringing in $200-million a year for a $400-million to $600-million investment.

It is no surprise that much of the private sector investment comes from outside, specifically South Africa and ex-colonial master Portugal. Mozambique is the world's poorest country, with a 1993 national income per head of $80. It is also one of the world's most aid-dependent countries, with aid pledges made in March of $800-million constituting a big chunk of the country's gross domestic product of $100-million.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

22 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


Investment Money Starts To Flow Into SA


LENGTH: 854 words


 

Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

June 2, 1995

by Paul Dixon and Nicola Gain

Foreign investment is on the increase. While falling short of pre-election hype, the tide is changing, with inward investment is gaining strong momentum.

United States firms have taken the lead -- not surprising since they disinvested heavily during the 1980s. 

Current activity may only be the tip of the iceberg, as it is expected that up to 50 percent of total foreign investment will ultimately come from the US. This represents a radical turnaround from the present position, where British companies account for around 50 percent of foreign investment -- estimated at R50-billion in stock and assets, with interests in about 1 500 companies,according to the Southern African Economic Research Unit.

One huge potential source for investment is expected to be corporations forced to disinvest during the sanctions era when $25-billion in foreign investment was withdrawn.

Despite these developments and the many promises of further investment, potential investors do face barriers which require urgent attention. The list of deterrents has only shrunk slightly despite the euphoria surrounding the elections and installation of the Government of National Unity.

Prioritising the list of concerns repeatedly raised by foreigners, while crucial, is as yet unresolved. If something is not done timeously, it is likely to result in many lost foreign investment opportunities. The key concerns raised are: high levels of crime and political instability; high corporate taxes and limited incentives to foreign investors; exchange control; adverse labour relations and low productivity; and low economic growth and a depreciating rand.

The flip-side portrays a number of attractions, especially when seen in the context of other emerging countries. These include: a sophisticated infrastructure; a local market of 40-million people, with growth forecast in consumer and aspiration spending; a "stepping stone" into Africa; the Reconstruction and Development Programme; a privatisation drive; conservative fiscal and monetary policies; and no ownership restrictions on foreign companies

The number of US companies doing business in South Africa has risen by more than 300 over the past three years, of which 150 have invested funds in the country. The US-based Calvert Group, which looks at socially responsible investment, says that the number of US companies with employees or investments in South Africa has risen almost 20 percent since 1993, but adds that this still compares poorly with non-US firms currently in the country.

The US Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) is committed to spending $85-million in 1995 alone, to finance US investments in South Africa. OPIC has also established two funds totalling $150-million for joint ventures and new investments.

Foreign investment means that some of South Africa's more "sleepy" business sectors are in for a shake-up.

Foreign investment will come, and only those companies pro- actively seeking joint venture opportunities and strategic alliances are likely to entrench their position in the new South African market as it becomes internationally interactive.

This is an edited version of an article which first appeared in E&Y's In Touch magazine.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

23 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


SA Blacks Buy Big Stake in Giant Firm


LENGTH: 1320 words


 

Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

June 2, 1995

The 'black empowerment purchase' of JCI and Johnnic has important implications, reports Reg Rumney

The National Empowerment Consortium (NEC) is poised to buy a big stake in Johnnic, the industrial firm that came out of the unbundling of conglomerate Johannesburg Consolidated Investments.

The details of how the union and black-business-based consortium intends pulling this off are unclear.

Chairman of the NEC, Metal & Electrical Workers Union (Mawusa) secretary general Tommy Oliphant, indicates this is only the first step. A stake in the mining house JCI Ltd, the second of the three companies left after the dismemberment, is next. Some members of the consortium believe NEC should have a small stake in JCI Ltd, say 10 percent, as well as a larger one in Johnnic. Oliphant says a meeting with Anglo American to discuss details is imminent. 

Corporate Africa's Nthato Motlana, initially lukewarm, is now interested in coming along to buy into Johnnic. The other recent black empowerment exercise Real Africa Investments Limited (RAIL) has also been linked to the consortium, but Oliphant says RAIL, headed by Don Ncube, is only interested in the mining company, JCI Ltd.

The union groupings involved, according to Oliphant are: Mawusa, the National Union of Mineworkers, the National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa, the Food and Allied Workers Union, the South African Commercial, Catering and Allied Workers Union, and the South African Railways and Harbour Workers Union.

Along with them are various black business interests, including both arms of organised black business, the Federation of Business and Consumer Organisations, and the National African Federated Chambers of Commerce. Several prominent black figures have been linked to the NEC, including businessman Don Mkwhanazi.

The Board of Executors, locally, and Lehman Brothers, internationally, are advising the consortium. They will mobilise funds overseas and from South African business to buy into Johnnic, says Oliphant. Locally, the unions will approach pension and provident funds to direct investment towards the consortium.

Oliphant says the details of the financing have not been worked out. One source maintains the NEC will not use debt, either local or foreign to acquire equity. This would make little sense, anyway, since servicing the debt at present interest rates could cancel out the monetary gains of buying into the company.

Although Oliphant says that from the union point of view, the consortium would not want the full 48 percent on offer for control of Johnnic, he mentions a figure of 34,5 percent. That kind of stake is effective control, as Anglo American Corporation's Brian St John points out.

That size stake would not come cheap -- around R2-billion at the present value the market places on company's shares of R5,8-billion. And the 10 percent stake in JCI Ltd Oliphant mentions alone would cost R400-million, based on its present market capitalisation of around R4-billion.

Yet investment without control makes no sense, since the NEC might as well buy into the underlying listed assets, such as South African Breweries.

Anglo has made it clear there will be no special deals: it wants a market price for its shares. Indeed, St John points out that buying a controlling stake usually means paying a premium for the shares. Johnnic is now trading at an 18 percent discount to asset value, giving an indication of how much higher the price might have to rise.

Oliphant also points to differences in the way the NEC sees black empowerment. On the one hand, he says the reason for not wanting control is not to create a conflict of interests. "We don't want the unions toyi-toying at us." On the other hand, he believes the NEC can have an influence on how the companies which are bought are run.

"We have succeeded in doing that through the Community Growth Fund," says Oliphant, who has been intimately involved in the union-led unit trust.

Oliphant says the exercise will empower black business, but the unions do not want to create instant millionaires, as was done with the listing of Motlana's New Africa Investments and Ncube's RAIL.

Empowerment should be spread, he says, and new conglomerates should not be created to replace the old ones being dismantled, with black conglomerates dominated by certain people. "We don't want just to reverse the roles."

This would rule out the kind of pyramid structure whereby Motlana rules New Africa Investments. It also means the NEC will have to find a good deal of hard cash to buy control.Understandably, speculation about the deal is rife. One source maintains that borrowings would not be used, and that Motlana will mobilise funds from Sanlam, which aided his move into insurer Metropolitan Life, to help him buy into Johnnic.

That is bound to make Liberty Life nervous. Johnnic's biggest asset is South African Breweries (SAB), a conglomerate in its own right. Although Johnnic has only 13,8 percent of SAB, it accounts for around 60 percent of Johnnic, with Premier, Omnicor, Toyota and various property interests making up the balance.

The Liberty Life board must be wondering whether the deal is a cheap way into SAB, Toyota and Omnicor for Sanlam.

Johnnic and Liberty have a joint control agreement on Bevcon, the holding company of SAB, and Premier, but St John points out it only kicks in if Johnnic decides to sell. The agreement, in simple terms, means that either group has a pre-emptive right on the other's shares. But there is no "grandfather" clause, so the agreement stays with Johnnic, whoever buys controls of it.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


24 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


It's Do Or Die In The Season Of Strikes


LENGTH: 1560 words


 

Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

June 2, 1995

The upcoming season of labour protests will make or break the labour movement, argues Eddie Koch

Do or die. That's how a union shopsteward this week explained The Congress of South African Trade Unions' decision to stage a 1980s-style programme of mass action around the Labour Relations Amendment Bill. Although unintended, his statement may just portend the fate of organised labour after the protests in June.

Cosatu last week announced it would mobilise its members in a campaign of rolling mass action, including lunch-time work stoppages and marches, that will culminate in a national day of protest on June 19 to back its demands around the new labour laws. 

Central to the dramatic decision -- which could lead to the biggest display of popular militancy since last year's elections -- is a determination by the unions to ensure that industry-wide collective bargaining is made compulsory in the country's new labour relations law.

The parties are divided about why this breakdown in what appeared be a honeymoon spirit of cooperation and tripartism occurred so suddenly. Employers say it is a sign of weakness and desperation on the part of labour. Unionists insist it reflects a growing confidence and grassroots militancy in their ranks.

Either way, now that a de facto deadlock has occurred in talks over the Bill, which have been taking place in the National Economic Development and Labour Council (Nedlac), the labour movement stands at the crossroads.

If the unions' collective muscle is strong enough, they will stamp their mark on a law that will shape industrial relations for the next few decades. If the mass action fizzles, they will lose the fight for the heart of the vital Bill.

Sources close to the employers' team that has been bargaining with organised labour over the Bill say the move reflects a strategic decision by Cosatu to secure its rights by statute rather than by on-the-ground organisational strength in the factories.

"The unions here see labour movements around the world in decline or under attack. Their action -- together with other demands like those for a closed shop or mandatory workers' representation on company boards -- reflects a deep concern about union security in a period of declining organisational strength," says one commentator.

Cosatu representative Neil Coleman rejects the "brinksmanship theory" that dominates management explanations of Cosatu's strategy. "We are undertaking this action now simply because business is not taking the negotiations over the Bill seriously," he says.

"Despite a number of meetings over our demands, business has repeatedly refused to come back to the table with fresh mandates from their constituency to negotiate in a flexible way and move forward."

Coleman says his national executive committee's decision to embark on mass action followed, and reflected, popular militancy among rank-and-file members over an issue that "will shape labour relations in the country for the next 40 years".

Proof of this, he says, is that a rash of strikes and protests over employers' reluctance to accept industry- wide collective bargaining during annual wage negotiations had broken out in the chemical, retail and textile sectors well before the executive meeting last week.

"Our assistant general secretary Zwelinzima Vavi attended a regional shopstewards council on the Witwatersrand that was attended by about 1 200 shopstewards a week ago. He came back shocked and said he had never seen such a militant mood among our members".

Coleman acknowledges that the unions' bargaining power over the bill will be weakened if the collective muscle fails. "But the history of Cosatu shows that single issue campaigns have captured the imagination of our members, particularly around burning issues. And make no mistake, this is a burning issue for our members."

There are other reasons that explain the timing of Cosatu's strategy. Most importantly, the labour federation clearly hopes that "the state" -- the labour ministry, cabinet and a parliament made up of numerous former union activists -- will lean in their favour.

This expectation is strengthened by the fact that the African National Congress cannot afford to alienate its strongest ally during the run-up to local government elections.

Another factor that may tilt the balance of forces in favour of the unions is the government's need for a stable system of labour relations in order to encourage foreign investment and economic growth. Labour Minister Tito Mboweni said as much this week when he insisted that the two parties meet the June deadline for agreement on a draft Bill.

Says Coleman: "If the mass action fails, the workers' grievances will simply resurface later. There will be continued skirmishing and these issues will continue to raise their heads until they are resolved.

"Mboweni needs a new Bill in place and has gone on record as saying the old apartheid law is not in line with the new political situation. So although we are directing our demands at business, there is an element of challenge to the government."

For the time being, however, employers have battened down the hatches and are hoping that countervailing forces will take the wind out of union strength in June.

"It is patently nonsense to say we are stalling in the negotiation because it suits us to have the old Labour Relations Act instead of the new law," says Adrian du Plessis, senior member of the employer delegation at Nedlac.

"We unreservedly support most of the proposals in the current draft of the Bill including the clauses which allow for central bargaining on a voluntary basis. It is the unions which are introducing new demands and holding up the process ... We are firm on rejecting their demands for compulsory centralised bargaining."

The tough stand by business will receive some encouragement from the stance adopted this week by Godfrey Oliphant, chairman of parliament's standing committee on labour.

He said Cosatu's assumption that ANC and fomer Cosatu MPs would support the union's demands "might be a reasonable assumption" but was "not necessarily a given one balanced against national interests".

Oliphant, himself a former vice president of Cosatu, said union members were justified in believing that it now had reliable allies in the state but that the unions' case would ultimately be judged in parliament after being weighed against the country's best interests.

Stayaways, general strikes and national days of protest in South Africa are notoriously labile and their outcome difficult to predict. More clear is that next month's season of mass action -- whatever its outcome -- will mark a watershed in the history of the country's labour movement.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


25 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


African Weekly Press Review


LENGTH: 1320 words


 

by Olu Sarr, PANA Staff Correspondent

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The Organisation of African Unity Summit in Addis Ababa attracted most comment in the African press this week. The assassination attempt on Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak drew most discussion.

On the drama, the semi-official Dakar newspaper Le Soleil said that the event highlighted the inefficiency of Ethiopian security because the attackers, "who certainly came from abroad, managed to prepare their plot calmy."

This security lapse, it added, would only give more ammunition to those people who want the OAU headquarters moved to another capital. 

The government-owned Times of Zambia advised Egypt to find a peaceful solution to the grievances of its Islamic militants.

"It is our view that the present hardline approach against the fanatics will not ensure peace," it said.

While not blaming the militants directly for the attack on Mubarak it termed the incident as "extremely alarming", noting Mubarak's importance on the African and Arab political stage.

The other government-owned paper, the Zambia Daily Mail, ridiculed what it termed "Africa's enemies who had tried to derail the summit" by trying to kill Mubarak in Addis Ababa.

However, it said, the act only served to further unite Africa.

It, however, hailed the summit as success. Unlike previous gatherings, it said, the summit had not ended as a mere "talking-shop".

It said: "Not only did the OAU look at the possibility of an intervention force" but Secretary-General Salim Salim decided that the body "needed teeth to bite."

The paper was referring to the ostracisation of defaulting members and those at war with each other.

"For how can Africa explain that it goes to donors with a begging bowl in hand seeking money for development when most of it is used on war," it said.

The Zairian News Agency, AZAP, said that the summit was conspicuous by the absence of several leaders among them presidents Nelson Mandela of South Africa, Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire and Yoweri Museveni of Uganda.

However, the Ethiopian Herald said that despite its battered image the organisation had not failed in all undertakings.

"The OAU has just successfully completed the first phase of its struggle: decolonisation," it said.

It continued: "The OAU has now embarked upon the second phase of its struggle: the struggle to overcome the ever deepening socio-economic crisis."

It concluded: "There is definitely a long way to go for Africa to achieve its set goals but there has to be a reaffirmation of commitment on the part of OAU members to match words with deeds."

Other papers could not have agreed more with the latter part of that sentence. Most were clearly disappointed by the organisation's record.

Ouagadougou's (Burkina Faso) satirical Journal du Jeudi was openly hostile. It said the summit produced "nothing new".

"Africans have come to the conclusion that their meetings by their leaders amount to nothing more that paper tigers," it said.

Despite the poor turnouts at many summits, it went on, African leaders all make a point of attending meetings called by their former colonial powers.

The entire organisation needs to be reorganised, it said.

"It serves no purpose to denouce countries in arrears of contributions if they are not made aware of the fact that their contributions are essential to the smooth functioning of the organisation," it said.

Another Ougadoudgou paper, Le Pays, termed the organisation an African illusion. It said it found it odd that the leaders meeting in Addis Ababa seemed more concerned with the meeting of the Council of Europe in Cannes than their own summit.

Kampala's media urged the OAU to find a new role for itself now that decolonisation has ended. It called for renewed commitment to the organisation.

"Part of the problem is that member countries do not believe in the OAU instruments and protocols they sign because it doesn't seem to make any difference whether they flout or follow the principles on which the organisation is founded," The Monitor said.

It advised the organisation to devise "innovative approaches" to issues confronting Africa rather than take the back seat and let the UN and other international agencies run the whole show.

"When the stakes are raised and the organisation ceases to be a free-for-all where no minimum acceptable standards of behaviour govern membership, African states will begin to value their places in the OAU," it said.

Kampala's New Vision commented on Nigeria where former president Olusegun Obasanjo and retired general Shehu Yar' Adua have been detained for alleged participation in a coup attempt in March.

"As things stand, the impression to outsiders is that (Moshood) Abiola and Abasanjo are in jail not because they committed any offence but merely because they are an embarrassment to an undemocratic government," it said.

"In the meantime, Nigeria should seriously consider setting up a broad-based government that would incorporate all parts of the country and all tendencies," it added.

"Military politics is not working and multi-party politics also has a poor track record in Nigeria. It is time for a change. Nigeria urgently needs a fresh democratic initiative if it is to retain its standing as the leading nation in sub-Saharan Africa," it concluded.

Libyan papers were unanimous Monday in prasing Africa's support for Libya's seat at the United Nations Security Council, despite attempts by the West to block it.

Al-Chams said Africa's support was a demonstration that the continent was on the right path to consolidating its independence.

PANA OSS/DS 30June95

LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


26 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


Mozambique Gets Postal Code


LENGTH: 534 words


 

by Paul Fauvet, PANA Correspondent

Maputo, Mozambique (PANA) - The Mozambican post office introduced postal codes for the first time Friday into the country's mail address system.

From now, letters and parcels should bear a five figure postal code immediately after the town or locality to which they are addressed.

The first figure indicates the province, the next two the city or district, and the final two the locality. Consulting a booklet printed by the post office gives users the correct postal code: thus should anyone wish to send a letter to Renamo leader Afonso Dhlakama at his former bush headquarters in Central Mozambique, they will find that the correct address now is "Maringue 37100". 

The first envelope bearing one of the new postal codes was posted Friday at Maputo central station by the Chairman of The Post Office Management Board, Pedro Murrima.

He said that the intention of the codes was to speed up the sorting and distribution of correspondence.

"The fundamental goal is speed and security," he said.

The codes should avoid confusion caused by the fact that various localities bear the same, or very similar, names but are located in different parts of the country.

The post office believes that the postal codes will be particularly useful when mechanised sorting is eventually introduced (currently all sorting is manual).

Envelopes bearing five black-lined squares for the five numbers of the postal codes are being distributed to post offices all over the country for distribution to the public.

The postal service does not cover the entire country. Statistics available today to the Mozambican News Agency, AIM, show that there are 94 principal post offices, five major sorting centres and 45 secondary ones, and 103 rural post offices.

A further 186 post offices were closed during the war of destabilisation supported by South Africa's apartheid government but the management plans gradually to re-open them.

PANA-AIM PF/OSS 30JUNE95

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


27 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


UN Needs $44 Million for Angola Refugees


LENGTH: 360 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees needs $44 million for the voluntary repatriation of some 300,000 Angolan refugees over the next 30 months, the organization said in a statement to PANA from its Geneval headquarters Thursday.

There are 200,000 Angolan refugees in Zaire, 96,000 in Zambia, 12,000 in Congo and 1,000 in Namibia. There are also some 15,000 Angolan refugees are in 32 other countries.

Some 5,500 of the refugees have returned to Angola on their own since the signing of a peace accord between the government and Unita in November. The accord ended 20 years of civil war that left an estimated 600,000 people dead and 3 million others displaced internally.

"The continuing spontaneous returns make it essential that livelihood and integration projects be started inside Angola now," the UNHCR said in a financial appeal to donors Thursday.

A programme to make Angolans better aware of the dangers of an estimated 10 million land mines scattered across the country is also being undertaken in the refugee camps.

The UNHCR expects to begin voluntary repatriation convoys by the middle of next year after the harvest season in the main asylum countries. Some 83,000 refugees are likely to join the convoys, the organization said.

PANA DS 29June95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. 28 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


Southern Africa Women Prepare for Beijing


LENGTH: 400 words


 

by Mildred Mulenga, Pana Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - The Southern Africa preparatory conference for the fourth World Conference on Women scheduled for September in Beijing, China, opened in Lusaka Thursday.

The conference will provide a forum for women in the sub-region to review the United Nations "Platform for Action" document to be presented at the women's conference. 

The Lusaka meeting will identify issues of concern to women in the sub-region they believe are not been adequately addressed in the current document.

The platform of action to be adopted in Beijing aims to accelerate the removal of obstacles to women's full and equal participation in all spheres of life, including economic and political decision-making.

It also seeks to integrate women's concerns into all development issues.

The Beijing conference aims at implementing what most governments have not implemented in the Nairobi "Forward-looking Strategies for the Advancement of Women to The Year 2000" adopted in 1985.

The three-day Lusaka conference, opened by Zambian vice-president Brig. Gen. Godfrey Miyanda, is the last preparatory meeting before the main conference in Beijing.

The final consultations between governments and non-govermnetal organisations will take place in Addis Ababa, Ethopia, from 10-13 July.

PANA MM/MK 29June95

Africa News


June, 1995


Zambian Opposition Leader Cries Foul


LENGTH: 414 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Kebby Musokotwane, the man who has just lost the presidency of the main opposition United National Independence Party (UNIP) to former Zambian president Kenneth Kaunda, claimed on Thursday that the elections in which he was soundly drubbed were a "sham".

Kaunda polled a massive 1,916 votes to Musokotwane's paltry 400 votes in party elections held at the University of Zambia main campus in Lusaka on Wednesday.

The ex-Zambian president was a clear victor even before the balloting started: the incumbent had failed to raise 10 supporters from each of Zambia's nine provinces among the delegates to the congress to back his nomination for the post of president as required by the party constitution. 

Kaunda, who was the challenger, had to instruct seven provincial leaders to raise 10 people each for Musokotwane to enable the latter to contest. He had managed to raise supporters only from his home Southern Province, and Lusaka.

Musokotwane, speaking at a press conference in Lusaka said however, that although the elections were a "sham" he would not petition the results "in the interest of the party".

He accused Kaunda of using underhand methods to win the elections and regain the party presidency he had relinquished in 1992 after suffering a crushing defeat to President Frederick Chiluba and his movement for multi-party democracy (mmd) in Zambia's 1991 general elections.

Musokotwane said the elections had been rigged by Kaunda whom he claimed was power hungry.

PANA-ZANA SKLK/DS 29June95

30 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


Mozambican Women Demand Attention to Concerns


LENGTH: 614 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - The Mozambican Women's Forum is taking the government to task saying women's issues should be the concern of the State and not just the responsibility of one Ministry or Institution.

"No one institution on its own could be expected to deal with the whole range of problems facing Mozambican women," warned the Forum's Chairperson, Isabel Casimiro.

She was speaking in Maputo Wednesday at the second national preparatory meeting for the United Nations World Conference on Women scheduled for China in September. 

Casimiro also said a gender perspective be incorporated into the analysis and definition of national development policies and strategies, as a matter of urgency.

The forum, an umbrella group linking various organisations involved in women's issues, regretted that there had been no significant progress in solving problems that were identified at the first preparatory meeting, held last year.

In particular, said Casimiro, the government had still not drafted a long-awaited bill that would revise and update family law. It also has not taken any measures to repeal laws that discriminate against women.

The women accused the courts of lengthy delays in solving family disputes that come before them. This means that women complainants were kept waiting for months before the courts took decisions on their cases.

The Mozambican government pledged at the United Nations Summit On Social Development in Denmark, in March, that it would work to eliminate poverty, and create jobs. The Forum now wants Maputo to fulfil the pledge and help solve some of the problems of Mozambican women.

At the Summit, World Leaders agreed that there could be no social development without the participation of women.

"If the government does not honour this promise", Ccasimiro warned, "there was no way the country could escape from its chronic poverty".

Official statistics indicate that between 60 and 70 per cent of the rural population, and 50 per cent of urban households are living in a state of absolute poverty. Mozambique's current population is estimated at 17 million.

The three-day meeting is debating the government's "Draft Platform Of Action For Women's Progress Up To The Year 2000", plus an annex based on the current situation of women derived from countrywide field studies.

The final document of the meeting will be included in the report which officials will present at the Beijing Conference.

PANA-AIM MOP/PF/FON 29June95

Africa News


June, 1995


Ghana to Host West African Summit if Nigeria Declines


LENGTH: 360 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Ghana will host the July summit of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) should Nigeria decline, Finance Minister Kwesi Botchwey said Wednesday.

"Signals we have received from official Nigerian sources indicate that Abuja is not willing to foot the entire summit bill," he said in Accra, the Ghanaian capital. 

Ghana, which holds the chairmanship should automatically host the summit but asked Nigeria to do so citing limited hotel facilities and financial difficulties.

"It is important to maintain the integrity of the organisation," he said.

Botchwey was speaking to reporters after he had accompanied ECOWAS Executive-Secretary Edouard Benjamin for talks with President Jerry Rawlings.

Benjamin, a Guinean, briefed Rawlings on preparations the secretariat was making for the event and its financial standing. Benjamin said members of the 16-nation community owed the secretariat about 40 million U.S. dollars.

Citing a similar backlog on contributions, the larger continental body, the Organisation of African unity threatened sanctions on debtors and was able by this week, during its annual summit, to recover close to half the arrears due.

June, 1995


ACTIVE TRADING ON GHANA STOCK EXCHANGE


LENGTH: 494 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - In one of its active trading which ended mixed wednesday, nine out of 17 equities listed on the Ghana Stock Exchange (GSE) here recorded price changes.

Gains by Standard Chartered Bank (SCB), Ashanti Goldfields Company (AGC), Kumasi Brewery Limited (KBL) Pioneer Tobacco Company (PTC) and Guinness Ghana Limited (GGL) helped the market to recover from its previous loss.

The market's capitalisation, therefore, surged as these gains neutralised losses by Super Paper Products Company (SPPC), Paterson Zochonis (PZ), Metalloplastica Ghana Limited (MGL) and Enterprise Insurance Company (EIC). 

Reflecting this positive change, total capitalisation closed higher at 2,340.90 billion cedis, up from its previous 2,328.44 billion cedis while the GSE all-share index also climbed 4.64 points to close at 310.39 points.

There are 1,166.3 cedis to one U.S. dollar

On the broader market scb which led the advancing issues went up 200 cedis to end at 5,400 cedis, AGC closed 25,400 cedis up 100 cedis, KBL gained 25 cedis and ended at 625 cedis while PTC finished at 120 cedis up 12 cedis with GGL going up by four cedis to close at 210 cedis.

SPPC and MGL shed two cedis each to end at 115 cedis and 128 cedis respectively while PZ and EIC also lost one cedi each to finish at 481 cedis and 551 cedis respectively.

Trading, bouyed by fat sales of PTC (686,300 shares) and GGL (74,300 shares) ended business on a good volume of 790,240 shares. Total shares offered closed lower at 1,079,340 against bids of 1,130,260 shares.

The following are the last prices of listed securities: ABL 280 cedis, AGC 25,400 cedis, CFAO 36 cedis, EIC 551 cedis, FML 220 cedis, GGL 210 cedis, HFC 120 cedis, KBL 625 cedis, MGL 128 cedis, MLC 57 cedis, MOGL 3,800 cedis, PTC 120 cedis, PZ 481 cedis, SCB 5,400 cedis, SPPC 115 cedis, UNIL 841 cedis and UTC-E 69 cedis.

June, 1995


Ghana Charges Newpaper With Libel


LENGTH: 347 words


 

by Mawusi Afele, PANA Correspondent

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - The Publisher and Editor of a bi-weekly newspaper in Ghana have been charged at a circuity Court in Accra for intentionally libeling the First Lady Nana Konadu Agyeman Rawlings.

The two men, Tommy Thomposn, the Publisher and Eben Quarcoo, the Editor, pleaded not guilty and were remanded in custody until Thursday. 

Judge Victor Doegah refused them bail saying that although their offence is a misdemeanor for which bail could be granted, he was remanding them in order to ensure peace and tranquility.

The two men and a columnist were last year convicted by the Supreme Court for publishing an article which said Chief Justice Isaac Abban altered his judgement in a constitutional case.

Chief State Attorney, Thomas Ahlijah said the newspaper six months ago published articles which alleged that the First Lady had smuggled gold during European visits and deals in cocaine.

"The publications are all false, malignant, fiction and manufactured against the First Lady out of hatred for her," Ahlijah said.

He said the allgeations were "vicious and conducive to breach of peace."

Africa News


June, 1995


Egypt Attacks Sudanese Police Stations


LENGTH: 520 words


 

by Yahya El-Hassan, PANA Staff Correspondent

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - The Sudanese Ministry of the Interior Wednesday said Egyptian troops attacked three police stations near the disputed area of Halayeb, killing two Policemen and wounding seven others.

A statement issued by the Ministry in Khartoum said large numbers of Egyptian troops Tuesday night attacked police stations in Shalatin, Badee and Abu Ramad, killing police Lieutenant Mahmoud Mairam and Private Mutwalli Abdallah of Ab Ramad police station.

It said the invaders had earlier attacked a police station killing two policemen. The statement did not say when and where this previous incident had occured. 

Sudan and Egypt have been claiming a triangular piece of land in the extreme North-Eastern Sudan since 1956, when it gained independence from Britain that had ruled the country since 1890.

In 1992, Egypt occupied and annexed the area prompting a protest note from Khartoum to the United Nations.

The ministry said the Egyptian attack on the police stations aims at the perpetuation of the occupation of Halayeb.

Egypt, it added, is massing vast numbers of troops in the area in the face of a very small and poorly armed police force.

"The Sudanese people are aware of their legitimate right to Halayeb and will not relinquish even an inch of it despite the Egyptian government's arrogance", the Ministry said.

Egypt on Monday accused Sudan of masterminding the assassination bid against President Hosni Mubarak, as he arrived in Addis Ababa to attend the 31st Summit of the Organisation of African Unity. Sudan has denied the accusation.

Sudanese Military Ruler, Gen. Omar El Bashir, who attended the meeting denied the accusation describing it as "irresponsible".

"Egypt has a problem with the Islamic groups and it should address that problem instead of accusing Sudan of involvement in such incidents," he said.

PANA YH/FON 28June95

June, 1995


Niger Arrests Student Protesters


LENGTH: 320 words


 

by Amadou Oumar Seydou, PANA Correspondent

Niamey, Niger (PANA) - Riot police brutalised and then arrested seven students who converged at Parliament building in Niamey, the capital, on Thursday.

The students were among hundreds of other colleagues from various institutions in the capital, preparing a rally in support of University students who had their campus closed Friday. 

The public relations officer of the Niger Students Union (USN), Amadou Modi Korom Beize, told PANA that the students decided to call off the rally to avoid further trouble.

On Thursday last week, Niamey university students, angered by the non-payment of up to eight months bursary arrears, torched two private vehicles and clashed with security forces for 24 hours.

The government decided to close down the students halls but allowed lectures to continue.

The students are boycotting classes in protest against the government decision.

Africa News


June, 1995


Departed Burundi Minister Criticizes Inaction


LENGTH: 480 words


 

by Hamadoun Toure, PANA Staff Correspondent

Addis Ababa, Ethiopia (PANA) - Former Burundian foreign minister Jean-Marie Ngendahayo has resigned from his government in order give himself "the freedom of action to mobilise the international community in support of his country".

In a telephone interview with PANA from Johannesburg, South Africa, where he arrived Saturday evening, he said he had felt ineffective in a government that had failed to guarantee his people's "right to life".

He criticised the attitude of the UN Security Council towards his country, saying it result in a catastrophe in the region. 

"If nothing is done, there will be an eruption of violence that will spill into Tanzania, Uganda and Zaire," Ngendahayo said.

The former minister last week led his country's delegation to the OAU council of ministers meeting in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.

He left Addis Ababa for South Africa to join his family which had fled Burundi earlier, he disclosed.

He did not state the means and methods he intends to use to mobilise the international community on the situation in Burundi where the Hutu-Tutsi divide and political and ethnic violence are tearing the country apart.

The former minister however stressed the "personal" nature of his decision. "I discussed it with nobody," he said, adding that he had not quit his position "to join any extremist group".

Asked about his personal safety, Mgendahayo said he was living "with friends" in Johannesburg and was more worried about "the safety of all Burundians". "That is much more important than the life of one person," he noted.

He refused to say whether he was planning to apply for political asylum to the Pretoria government. "I do not wish to comment on that issue," he said.

PANA HAT/KIB/SJD/DS 29June95

Africa News


June, 1995


Deadly Clashes In Western Cameroon


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Yaounde, Cameroon (PANA) - Clashes between Bamoun farmers and Bororo shepherds in the Cameroonian village of Nkoumdoum, about twenty kilometres from Foumban in the north, have left seven people dead and about thirty wounded.

The two communities, who have normally lived together in peace, are now clashing over land ownership. 

The Bamoun farmers are blaming Bororo shepherds for the destruction of their fields by the latter's cattle.

The clashes began after the Bamouns blocked off a stream to enable their herds have more water.

The Bororos, a nomadic people who are becoming more sedentary, took the case to the administrative authorities.

The situation exploded when an administrative mediation commission tried to settle the dispute on the ground.

The two communities clashed using firearms and other weapons. The clashes raged for three days -- from Monday to Wednesday -- killing seven people and wounding about thirty.

The state sent in the police and paramilitary force to calm the situation.

PANA-CAMNEWS AVE/SG/SJD/DS 29June95

Africa News


June, 1995


Zambia's Ruling Party Faces Split


LENGTH: 600 words


 

by Musengwa Kayaya, Pana Staff Correspondent

Lusaka, Zambia (PANA) - Two former senior members of Zambia's ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) of President Frederick Chiluba in Lusaka Thursday announced that they will lead a splinter party from the MMD which they accused of incompetency and mismanaging national affairs.

MMD former deputy treasurer Dean Mung'omba and party deputy national secretary Derrick Chitala who were last week expelled from the party said Thursday that they intended to form a rival faction committed to the MMD"S original ideals of transparency, honesty and competent leadership.

They claimed that the ruling party had been subverted by "spineless opportunists, drug-traffickers, common crooks and yes-sayers" who allegedly were out to purge "independent-minded" patriots committed to serving the cause ofthe people. 

MMD national secretary Brig. Gen. Godfrey Miyanda last Saturday announced the two men's expulsion by the party National Executive Committee (NEC) for allegedly bringing the organisation into disrepute by their constant public attacks of its policies.

They had earlier been suspended for similar reasons.

Mung'omba had announced earlier this year that he was to challenge Chiluba for the MMD presidency at the party convention scheduled for 1996.

Both Mung'omba and Chitala had earlier been sacked by Chiluba as deputy ministers in charge of national planning and in the presidents office respectively.

At a press briefing Thursday Mung'omba accused Chiluba of "hood-winking" the public by declaring Zambia a "christian nation" which he said was mere smokescreen to hide government corruption, incompetence and mismanagement.

The two spoke out strongly against government's alleged misapplication of the IMF-World Bank Structural Adjustment Programme (SAP) which they said had brought misery to the people.

"They (MMD government) lack the capacity to stretch matters further on SAP. All they are able to do is sell state companies but fail to plan for the welfare of the people affected," said Mung'omba.

Mung'omba and Chitala are founder-members of the MMD formed in 1990 to spearhead the campaign for the introduction of multiparty politics in Zambia.

Over 20 former senior MMD government leaders have left Chiluba's government since 1992 after either being sacked or resigning. Almost all have cited rampant corruption, drug-trafficking and incompetence in the system.

PANA MK/PM/DS 29June95
