39 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


Zambia's Kaunda Retakes Party Reins


LENGTH: 587 words


 

by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Kenneth Kaunda, Zambia's former president, was re-elected Wednesday as leader of the country's major opposition United National Independence Party (UNIP).

He beating incumbent party head Kebby Musokotwane during elections at the party's congress in Lusaka.

Kaunda received 1,916 votes against Musokotwane's 400 to grab his former post he had relinquished in 1992 when he "retired" from partisan politics. 

He had, earlier in 1991, lost the country's presidency to Frederick Chiluba and his Movement for Multiparty Democracy.

Kaunda, 71, came out of his brief political retirement in 1994 saying he wanted to wrestle power from Chiluba's government, which he accused of mismanaging the country.

His return caused divisions within the former ruling party between the pro-Kaunda faction and Musokotwane supporters, forcing the latest elections, which party members and supporters had said could help heal the rift.

Kaunda had led UNIP since he formed it in 1960 to spearhead the country's independence movement from Britain. That was achieved in October 1964.

Musokotwane has been voted out of power along with several of his supporters within the UNIP central committee. They includ his general secretary, the retired army lieutenant general, Benjamin Mibenge. Mibenge's post was scooped by Sebastian Zulu, a lawyer and Kaunda supporter.

UNIP Vice President Patrick Mvunga, who had himself campaigned for the Kaunda camp, lost to Inyambo Yeta, senior chief of the Lozi ethnic group in western Zambia and son of the "Litunga" Ilute Yeta.

The Litunga is the region's equivalent of a paramaount chief.

Members of the Lozi royal establishment are calling for some administrative autonomy for the region, in line with the "Barotse agreement" signed between Kaunda, the British and the Lozi kingdom in 1964.

The agreement quaranteed limited autonomy to the former British protectorate at its incorporation in the new independent Zambia in 1964.

Kaunda never quite honoured the agreement during his 27 years in power and his choice of the litunga's son as possible future republican vice-presidential candidate is seen by political analysts here as a ploy to win political favours among the Lozis.

PANA MK/OSS 29JUNE1995

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


40 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


The Nightmare of Covering an OAU Summit


LENGTH: 1067 words


 

by Maliwerere Bwititi, PANA Correspondent

Addis Ababa, Ethiopia (PANA) - The 256 journalists covering the 31st summit of the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) in Addis Ababa collectively heaved a huge sigh of relief Wednesday when Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi struck the hammered the gavel to signal the end of the annual continental meeting.

For journalists it was the end a week of hell.

"I am glad it's all over now. I will go to the nearest bar and drink myself to nothing," South African-based Carlos Henriques of Channel Africa said. "And I hope to get the next plane home." 

Henriques spoke for virtually every journalist here.

Many had to put up with maddening bureaucracy and tight security in this East African nation of 60 million people.

First, the problem was to get accreditation. On arrival journalists were supposed to first get registered with the information ministry before proceeding to another venue for accreditation.

This seemingly simple procedure could have taken less that 15 minutes. But after shuttling back and forth several times from one place to the next, at one's own expense, the journalist finally gets two press cards. The hope is that the holder of one card could attend the 62nd session of the council of ministers and the other, one is convinced, would give you access to the opening session of the African heads of state and government summit.

However, no sooner the journalist gets his press badges the journalist realises problems are just beginning.

Try going to a nearby hotel for an interview with the minister from your country. It is a five-minute walk. With your press card securely clipped to your lapel you do not expect problems.

As you walk a few minutes to your destination, you become a little apprehensive when you see a crowd of people and the inevitable policemen or two seemingly in charge. An armed soldier hovers nearby menacingly, his eyes missing nothing.

You bulldoze your way into the crowd and find yourself faced with a policemen. you politely tell him you are going for an interview with the minister. He tells you firmly and impolitely that you cannot.

Why?

"Because there will be a head of state arriving two hours from now," he says.

Again politely, you tell him that in during that period you will have finished your interview and probably be back at your hotel.

"Can you be let through?" you ask, almost pleading now.

"Impossible!" the officer says and looks yonder.

You learn later that when an Ethiopian policeman says "Impossible", apparently one of the few English words he can speak, he means it.

So, you take the nearest taxi to your hotel. That 10-minute drive takes you 55 times as long because all roads have been cordoned off.

On the day of the summit's opening security is even tighter. Despite your accreditation badge you are told you cannot enter the hall.

"I have never seen anything like this in 20 years as a journalist," a journalist for an international news agency told the Zimbabwe Inter Africa News Agency, ZIANA.

"You wonder why they gave us the press cards in the first place. If this is the type of organisation all over Africa, then I wish you guys a lot of luck," he said.

Journalists complained of harassment by police in trying to get news to the outside world.

Zimbabwe Broadcasting Corporation's Obriel Mpofu was nearly beaten by a policeman at the airport Sunday when he tried to force his way to cover the arrival of President Robert Mugabe.

He and other colleagues from Zimbabwe had been waiting four hours to cover the arrival of the leaders. They had been promised by Ethiopian security that they would be allowed in later. This was never to be. Police had become notorious for promising to help and not delivering.

"Officials here seem to run around very much pretending to be busy but they really do nothing," another African journalist said.

"That we have managed to write something at all about this conference should be the eighth wonder of the world," he added.

After hours of chasing a story and finally getting it, the problems is not over. You can take up to two hours, or more, trying to file. This is because of antiquated equipment and the few telephone and telefax lines available for use by journalists.

So if you are a journalist and want to cover an OAU summit when it comes back to Addis Ababa, one can only wish you Good Luck. Hopefully Cameroon, the next venue, will be a better experience.

PANA-ZIANA MB/NDN/OSS

Africa News


June, 1995


U.S. Offers Help In Search for Mubarak's Attackers


LENGTH: 387 words


 

by Peter Mwaura, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - The United States has offered to help search for the gunmen who carried out an unsuccessful assassination attempt against Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak in Ethiopia, Washington Line reported Thursday.

The bulletin, issued by the U.S. Information Agency, said that President Bill Clinton called Mubarak Monday and offered United States help to Egypt and Ethiopia. 

Neither Egypt nor Ethiopia have asked the United States for any specific assistance in the investigations, the publication said.

Speaking at 26 June ceremonies in the Western American city of San Francisco, marking the 50th anniversary of the United Nations, Clinton urged the UN to take up the mantle in the fight against terrorism around the world.

Mubarak narrowly escaped death when his armour-shielded Mercedes Benz saloon was raked with automatic weapons fire as he was being driven from Bole International Airport in Addis Ababa, to the opening of an annual Africa summit in the Ethiopia capital.

Police in Addis Ababa are still hunting for the surviving gunman who fled the scene.

Egyptian Foreign Minister Amre Musa said Wednesday in Addis Ababa that investigators from Cairo were expected in the Ethiopian capital soon to assist local police.

PANA PM/OSS 29JUNE95

Africa News


June, 1995


Sudan Accuses Neighbours


LENGTH: 587 words


 

by Gabu Amacha, PANA Staff Correspondent

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Sudanese president Omar El-Bashir Wednesday accused Egypt, Eritrea and Uganda of conspiracy to destabilize it by supporting the country's opposition forces.

"There is a plan to isolate Sudan from its neighbours", Bashir told a News Conference in Addis Ababa at the end of the 31st Summit of the Organisation of African Unity (OAU), which ended in the Ethiopian capital Wednesday.

"The recent meeting in Asmara of Sudanese opposition was a conspiracy against Sudan". 

"Opposition elements of Sudan have offices in Cairo and Kampala where they get support and protection from the authorities of the two countries", he said.

Eritrea in December 1994 severed relations with Sudan, accusing the Khartoum government of training terrorists to undermine its security. Sudan denied the charge.

Bashir regretted the Eritrean decision to host the opposition meeting, saying Sudan stood by Eritreans when they fought for self-determination against Ethiopian rule.

Recently, Uganda broke-off diplomatic relation with Sudan accusing it of supporting opposition forces fighting the government of President Yoweri Museveni. Sudan has also accused Uganda of supporting the rebel Sudanese Peoples' Liberation Army (SPLA) which has been fighting Khartoum governments since 1983.

Egypt also points accusing fingers at Sudan following Monday's assassination attempt on President Hosni Mubarak soon after he arrive in Addis Ababa for the Summit.

The Sudanese leader denied that his country was involved in the incident and told Egyptian authorities not to attack other countries for its internal political problems.

"There already exists problem between islamic fundamenta- lists and the Egyptian authorities, leading to deaths of which no government in Sudan has anything to do with. We reject the name of sudan being associated with political terrorism", said Bashir.

He added that there was no proof that his country supported terrorism, saying Khartoum condemns all forms of violence and "prefers dialogue instead of violence to resolve disputes".

PANA GA/FON 28June95

43 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


Clinical Trials Reverse AIDS Symptoms


LENGTH: 360 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The Zimbabwe National Traditional Healers Association (Zinatha) has said aids clinical trials conducted last year had so far been successful with all the 120 AIDS patients still alive, more than two years after the trials started.

Peter Sibanda, Zinatha secretary for legal affairs and culture said in an interview the CD4 cell count of all the patients had increased from about 100 to 600 and more and symptoms of AIDS such as weight loss, diarrhoea and various dermatological signs had disappeared. The cd count is measure of the level of infection.

Sibanda said, however, although the symptoms had disappeared, the patients had remained HIV positive.

The patients involved in the trials had come forward with severe diarrhoea and abdominal pains, among other complaints.

The trials, which began in October 1993, were conducted to quantify the extent and potential benefits of some herbs in the treatment of aids.

Sibanda said Zinatha and Zimbabwe's Blair Research Institute had agreed that the herbal concotions that were being used by traditional healers now be tested in the laboratory.

The tests would indicate exact components that are able to reduce infection and raise the white blood cell count.

PANA-Ziana /DS 28June95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


44 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


Sudan Fights Iodine Deficiency


LENGTH: 347 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - Nine machines to iodize salt have been installed in the Sudanese Red Sea port city of Port Sudan.

The machines have been put in place as part of the national effort to control widespread iodine deficiency. 

According to the World Health Organisation, iodine deficiency is endemic throughout Sudan, except for the eastern zone.

It is known to cause inflamation of the lymphatic gland as well as retard mental and physical development.

Radiologist Siddiq Mustafa of Sudan's National Centre for Tumours says while iodine deficiency is a problem, the body is capable of regulating excess intakes of the chemical.

Apart from taking iodized salt, the chemical can be administered through iodized oil capsules. These are widely used in parts of western Sudan.

Campaigns to educate the population on the need to take idodized salt have also been launched throughout the country.

Iodization of table salt is done simply by mixing iodine with the table salt prepared for sale.

Sudan is a major table salt producer. Its salt is produced by simply evaporating the saline water of the Red Sea.

PANA YH/DS 28June95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. 45 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


Zimbabwe Lacking Political Will to Curb AIDS


LENGTH: 547 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe's National Aids Control Programme (NACP) coordinator Everisto Marowa said on Thursday Zimbabwe lacked political commitment in trying to curb the spread of the killer disease, AIDS.

In an interview, Marowa said aids prevention and control programmes could never be successful without political support and commitment.

He said political leaders had an obligation towards the community and should, therefore, treat aids as an important issue which required their maximum support in controlling the spread of the disease in their provinces. 

The ministry of health and child welfare has already proposed that AIDS should be accorded a "national priority" but government has been slow in responding.

AIDS has claimed more than 38 552 lives in Zimbabwe since the first reported cases in 1987. it also believed that more than 60 000 children have been orphaned as a result of the deaths.

NACP is currently holding a 10-day national training course to improve the the management of AIDS and sexually transmitted diseases (STD) prevention and control programmes at non-governmental organisations, the private sector, government and provinces.

The course, being attended by 30 people involved in AIDS/STD prevention and control activities, is being funded by the World Health Organisation.

Sixty percent of people with sexually transmitted diseases and tuberculosis have been found to be hiv positive.

"We are holding a multi-sectoral national course, but I think there is a lot that still needs to be done. There is need for maximum political commitment in our efforts to curb the spread of AIDS."

"We want politicians to regard AIDS as an important aspect affecting human and social development. It is fine that we are training people at different levels, but it has to be supported by an explicit political commitment," Marowa said.

He said ways that political leaders could show their commitment was by providing channels of correct information about AIDS and STD, encouraging people to change their behaviour and providing necessary support to people with hiv and AIDS, their families and orphans.

PANA-Ziana FZ/MP/DS 27June95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Africa News


June, 1995


Riot Calm Returns To Riot-Torn Zambian Town


LENGTH: 494 words


 

by Stephen Kazeze, PANA Correspondent

LUSAKA, zambia, (PANA) - Calm returned to Chingola on Wednesday, after thousands of residents rioted on Tuesday to protest the high crime rate in the Zambian copper mining town in the Copperbelt Province.

Copperbelt Police Chief, Martin Nasilele said on Wednesday that Chingola which had been rocked by sporadic gunfire throughout Tuesday as policemen fought the rioters was quiet on Wednesday morning.

The riot in which thousands of residents fought pitched street battles with police was sparked off by the shooting to death of a 22-year-old man in the early hours of Tuesday by suspected armed bandits. 

Unconfirmed reports say the man, Boyd Mmwanza, may have been shot by police anti-robbery squad at around 02.00 hours (00.00 gmt) at his home. The gunmen left after killing him in front of his family without stealing anything.

Police shot two 15-year-old schoolboys, Mode Kalembe and Godfrey Chifulo, in the legs on Tuesday as the residents went on rampage, partially burning a Post Office, looted a hotel and bar and stoned a police station.

The enraged residents who accused the police of conniving with bandits in commiting crimes, rushed the two boys to a hospital.

But they blocked doctors from treating the boys whom they later took on a stretcher to a police station where they stoned the policemen and shattered the building's window panes.

The policemen, outnumbered by the rioters, fired tear gas cannisters at the rampaging residents in Chabanyama, Chiwempala, Maiteneke and Chikola townships as they fought running battles.

Nasilele said on Wednesday that police arrested 36 people during one of the worst rioting in the town which is home to one of the world's largest open pit Copper Mines.

He said police would investigate complaints by the residents that the local policemen connived with bandits to commit crimes in the town.

PANA-ZANA MM/SKLK/FON 28June95

Africa News


June, 1995


Burundi President Denied Special Powers


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Bujumbura, Burundi (PANA) - The chairman of the main opposition Union for National Progress Party, (UPRONA) in the Burundian parliament, Frederic Ngenzebuhoro, has expressed dismay at the rejection of President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya's request for special powers to help restore peace in the strife-torn country.

The refusal, he said, was paradoxically supported by members of the ruling FRODEBU (Front for Democracy in Burundi) in the parliament.

In a statement made public immediately after the negative vote of the 38 FRODEBU MPs (against UPRONA's 13), Ngenzebuhoro denounced "the MPs' hostility to measures simply aimed at restoring peace in a country which is openly at war". 

He asked the President to use "all his constitutional prerogatives so that parliament can never again be an obstacle to the smooth operation of government".

For his part, the minister of institutional reforms and relations with parliament, Therence Sinunguruza, regretted the astonishing collective vote of FRODEBU MPs against the exceptional measures which were submitted to him, given that an MP's mandate is individual.

He added that the government must go all out and institute exceptional measures, even if it meant dissolving parliament to give itself the means to manage the situation. Meanwhile, the Prime Minister has warned that he "will assume his responsibilites when necessary, should the parliament vote against the demand.

The chairman of the FRODEBU parliamentary group, Corneille Budigiye, said his party was against the request on the grounds that "the army should not be given exceptional powers as it played a major part in the current political and ethnic crisis".

On 21 June, the President asked parliament to allow him to "rule by decree for a period of three months".

The request mainly concerned political, administrative and legal institutions, as well as guarantees for citizens' fundamental rights and obligations.

It would also include changing the Burundian passport, abolishing radio broadcasts of party political programmes, media censorship, a country-wide dusk-to-dawn curfew, ban on demonstrations and the issuing of passes for movements from one province to another.

PANA FB/SG/SJD/FON 28June95

June, 1995


Angolan Refugees Waiting To Go Home


LENGTH: 347 words


 

by Stephen Kazeze, PANA Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Some 26,000 Angolan refugees in Zambia hoping to begin returning home Wednesday (today) woke up to a rude shock.

A meeting of officials from Angola, Zambia and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), who are to control the operation, has still not be held. 

The commissioner's representative in Zambia, Abou Moussa, said in Lusaka Tuesday that although Zambia and the his agency had finalised plans for the repartriation, the Angolan government had proposed 4 July for the final meeting.

Moussa said Zambia has rejected the date because it coincided with major public holidays.

"We are yet to agree on fresh dates," He said.

Moussa said after repartriating the refugees at two camps in North-Western Zambia, several other refugees dotted in areas near the Angolan border would assembled and sent home.

The refugees, who fled a civil war, are now able to return following a peace accord signed between the Angolan government and Jonas Savimbi's National Union for the Total Independence of Angola.

June, 1995


African Summit Ends 25 Million Dollars Richer


LENGTH: 307 words


 

by Hamadoune Toure, PANA Staff Correspondent

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - The 31st Organisation of African Unity summit ended Wednesday about 25 million dollars richer because debtors paid contribution arrears under the threat of sanctions by the 53-member body.

The organisation, whose long-term goal is to unite member countries under a single continental government, has had its duties curtailed severly by a lack of funds. 

But after the threat in 1994 to punish defaulter the arrears, which peaked at 64 million dollars before the summit, were reduce to 38 million dollars Wednesday.

Leader adopted resolutions to be published later Wednesday. Their discussions behind closed doors focused on Africa's numerous conflicts. They urged all warring parties end fighting and compromise to attain lasting peace.

They also examined Africa's social and economic problems, especially since the introduction of economic structural adjustment programmes in many countries.

Africa News


June, 1995


Zambia and Zimbabwe told conserve electricity


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Harare, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Ministers of energy from Zambia and Zimbabwe have appealed to consumers in both countries to conserve electricity as the water level in Lake Kariba, which they share, is critically low due to a bad 1994/95 rainy season.

In a joint communique from the Zambian capital Lusaka on Wednesday after the 14th meeting of the council of ministers of the Zambezi River Authority, the two ministers said the water situation in the Zambezi basin was the worst since 1907, resulting in little water being collected in the Kariba Dam for hydro-electric power generation. 

The normal inflow in the Kariba dam is 1 100 cubic metres per second but the flow in the 1994/95 rainy season has been 450 cubic metres per second.

The communique said the two countries would have to import electricity from neighbouring states.

PANA MP/MUH/DS 28June95

Africa News


June, 1995


Unsafe Births Take Toll on African Women


LENGTH: 400 words


 

by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Higher mortality rates or lowered life expectancy caused partly by unsafe birth practises and lack of financial control of health care expenditures have been cited by a population expert as the most critical health problems for most African women.

Khadijat Mojidi, deputy director of African programmes at the Centre for Development and Population Activities has advocated the training of traditional midwives in addition to economic empowerement of women as part of the solution to the problem. 

Mojidi said that higher mortality rates for women in Africa were disabling for their families and had incalculable effects on the community as a whole, the "Washingtoin Line" reported wednesday..

"Women die in the prime of their lives and they are responsible for so many other members of the community. That means they are unable to realise their own potential and not able to participate in national development," she said.

She said part of the solution should be to remove what she called gender inequities between men and women in Africa. She said these tended to favour men in income generation.

Mojidi urged linking health programmes with other social community activities in which women are involved to gain basic knowledge on healthcare.

Such a system is said to be bearing positive results in some parts of Nigeria.

PANA MK/PM/DS 28June95

June, 1995


Students Clash With Riot Police


LENGTH: 427 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Riot police clashed with University of Zimbabwe students on campus as some students boycotted classes over what they said was a cut in their payouts.

Police in full riot gear fired tear-gas as students hurled stones at them.

Hundreds of students gathered outside their halls of residence as riot police sealed all entrances to the Campus barring both resident and non-resident students from leaving. 

Students living on campus said they had been given ZD 2,700 (USD 337) instead of the promised ZD 4 000 (USD 500) while students who live outside campus were given ZD 3 800 (USD 475) and not the ZD 5 000 (USD 625) they expected to get.

They said University authorities had not informed students they were not in a position to promise them the remaining money.

"The Ministry of Higher Education and the administration are giving us conflicting statements and we want the truth," said one student.

On Tuesday, Higher Education Minister Ignatius Chombo is reported to have told student representatives that their payouts would come in two tranches with the second tranche supposed to have been given to students on Wednesday.

The students on Tuesday held a peaceful demonstration over the inadequate payouts. They however said the UZ administration was not being open about the matter.

Some of the student had wet towels to try and keep the teargas away from their eyes, while others sang songs and hurled insults at police.

PANA-ZIANA MUH/FON 28June95

53 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


African Spokesman Warns on Deteriorating Situation in Burundi


LENGTH: 547 words


 

by Gabu Amacha, PANA Staff Correspondent

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - As Burundi's political and security situations continue to degenerate, the Organization of African Unity (OAU) has warned the country's leaders that Africa will no longer sit by and watch the killings and exodus of people from the Central Africa State.

"Africa and the International Community should not allow the recurrence of the war in Rwanda" where the world stood-by and watched thousands of people being massacred last year, the Secretary-General of the OAU, Salim Ahmed Salim said at a News conference in Addis Ababa on Wednesday.

The Burundi situation, he popinted out, has no clarity where the country is going, and warned: "I shall include nothing and exclude nothing depending on the development of the situation in Burundi". He would not say whether this meant sending an intervention force into the country should the situation deteriorate further. 

African leaders, in a resolution on Burundi at the end of their Summit, condemned the militarization of the Burundi society which they said had resulted in the proliferation of Militias.

The leaders asked Salim and the OAU Central Organ for Conflict Resolution to monitor the situation and to take whatever decision is appropriate in conformity new developments.

Burundi was thrown into ethnic violence after the assassination in October, 1993 of the country's first democratically elected President, Melchior Ndadaye of the majority Hutu ethnic group in a failed coup attempt by elements of the army which is dominated by the minority Tutsi tribe.

The country's Foreign Minister resigned over the week-end, saying the government had failed to provide security to all the people of Burundi.

Salim said Africa's expectation was that the Burundi political and military institutions should work in the interest of the people and not at cross purposes as leaders of Hutu, Tutsi or Twa, the three ethnic groups of the tiny Central African Nation.

Salim said the African leaders decided at the end of their Summit that all the Burundi political leaders be invited to Addis Ababa, to meet the current chairman of the OAU, President Meles Zenawi, to examine possibilities of resolving the crisis.

PANA GA/FON 28June95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


54 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


OAU Leaders Committed to Stemming Conflicts


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - The 31st Organisation of African Unity (OAU) summit ended Wednesday with renewed commitment by leaders of the 53-nation grouping to end conflicts and bloodbaths on the continent.

Burundi, slowly degenerating into anarchy, was given a thinly veiled threat by OAU leaders who said they would not stand by while Africans massacred each other.

"We will do what we can through diplomacy," said OAU Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim at a closing press conference, adding: "But beyond that we...exclude nothing."

Africa would again not stand aloof if a fresh bloodbath, like the one which killed over a million people in neighbouring Rwanda, broke out. 

Salim, who described this year's summit as the most "profound" in trying to address conflicts in Africa, said the African leaders had shown more commitment to prevent further conflict on the continent which has seen over seven million people escaping to neighbouring countries as refugees.

He said all leaders of rival parties in Burundi would be summoned to the OAU headquarters in Addis Ababa to explain their positions and the OAU would then decide what action to take.

"They (Burundians) must live beyond ethnic affiliations," said Salim. "We cannot let the situation degenerate. Everything that needs to be done will be done."

He said, however, it was the United Nations which had the mandate of peacekeeping throughout the world and the OAU had never discussed the issue of a peacekeeping force although it would be happy to be a peacekeeping observer.

He said the OAU's emphasis was on diplomacy and not sending in troops. This had been endorsed by the heads of state who agreed to strengthen the mechanisms of preventing conflicts.

A central organ would be established to monitor the situation in Africa and take "whatever decisions in conformity with the developments of any country in order to avert a deterioration of the situation".

Salim had been mandated by the leaders to monitor the situation closely in Africa.

The OAU secretariat would establish a management centre for conflict prevention and early warning systems would be put in place to avert conflicts.

Member countries were expected to contribute not less than USD 1 million towards the organisation's peace fund. Other donations were being sourced from other nations and organisations throughout the world, said Salim.

The summit, he said, would be remembered as the one where heads of government came out with more determination to stem conflicts in Africa.

It would also go down as one which enforced mechanisms for prompt payment of contributions.

Before the summit, the organisation was owed USD 64 million but this has been reduced to USD 38 million after members were threatened with sanctions which included being denied the right to speak at oau fora.

Already some USD 3 million had been collected for the fiscal year 1995/96.

Salim was firm in denying that the OAU would be happy with a stand-by force, ready to pounce on any truant member country.

"Nothing of that sort has ever been proposed by this Secretary-General," he said.

The role of peacekeeping was left to the United Nations, but as happened in Rwanda when the un "firmly but politely" declined to send a peacekeeping force, the oau would be left with no choice to ensure a stop in a possible escalation of conflict.

The OAU would do what it could to calm down the situation in Sudan and Eritrea, which have been at each other's throats with Sudan accusing her neighbour of harbouring islamic extremists bent on overthrowing the khartoum government.

"Africa has nothing to gain but everything to lose in the case of escalation of conflict between Sudan and Eritrea," Salime said.

Meanwhile, Sudanese President Omar Mohamed Hassan al-Bashia has strongly denied that Sudanese were involved in the attempted assassination of Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, minutes after arriving for the OAU summit meeting on monday morning.

He said to the contrary, his country wanted to co-operate closely with the Cairo government.

Meanwhile, African heads of state were leaving Addis Ababa after the end of their three-day summit described as "frank, businesslike and profound" by Salim.

PANA-Ziana MB/TM/NDN/DS 28June95

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


55 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


Southern Africa Lacks Vibrant Capital Markets


LENGTH: 694 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabawe (PANA) - The development and expansion of capital markets in Eastern and Southern Africa has been discouraged by the absence of a vibrant private sector, a senior government official said on Wednesday.

Opening a two-day seminar on the development of capital markets in Eastern and Southern Africa in Harare, Industry and Commerce Minister Herbert Murerwa said there were only seven capital markets in a region of more than 20 countries.

"The development of capital markets is, in many ways, tied up with the development of enterprises," Murerwa told the 100 participants from the 23 Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA) member states. 

"As banks and advisers on financial matters, you are all in influential positions to assist enterprises to develop and grow into entities that can qualify for stock exchange listing", he said.

Domestic savings in the Sub-Region were too low, and the gap between savings and investment continued to increase, despite implementation of the International Monetary Fund-inspired economic reforms by countries in the region, he added.

"It will be worthwhile for you to consider the availability of investible funds and the strategies that can be adopted by capital markets to increase savings in order to match investment," said Murerwa.

There was also the need to encourage the culture of paper investment in the region, and educate the general public in the virtues of investing in securities.

The Sub-Saharan Africa region had only seven established capital markets located in Johannesburg, Nairobi, Harare, Port Louis, Swaziland, Lusaka and Khartoum.

Apart from Johannesburg, the stock markets were weak and underdeveloped with no more than 90 securities listed on each of the stock exchanges in Nairobi and Harare - regarded as more developed capital markets in the region.

Meanwhile, over the past two decades, Africa's share of foreign direct investment remained stagnant, hovering around ZD one billion (USD 125 million) and declined by 7.8 percent as a percentage of total resource inflows.

Figures compiled by the United Nations showed that Sub-Saharan Africa's capital stock plummeted from ZD 168 billion (USD 20 billion) in 1980 to ZD 10.9 billion (USD 91.56 billion) in 1990, said Murerwa.

"In the view that domestic savings are low and foreign investment is getting more and more difficult to attract, our Sub-Region must move quickly to establish formal capital markets...strengthen existing ones," he said.

Meanwhile, COMESA Secretary-General Bingu Wa r Mutharika told participants that lack of capital markets in Eastern and Southern Africa was a major obstacle to development and poverty alleviation in the region.

The seminar was jointly organised by the COMESA Bankers Association and the Zimbabwe Stock Exchange.

PANA-ZIANA ET/STC/FON 28June95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). 56 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


Commentary: An Unlikely Democrat


LENGTH: 1387 words


 

Newswatch (Lagos)

June 26, 2995

by Dan Agbese

Trying to turn Abiola into a symbol of democracy is like putting lipstick on a frog"--an unnamed "specialist in Nigerian politics" quoted by Time magazine in its issue of April 3, 1995.

An unkind cut? Maybe. But truth be told, Mashood Abiola was an unlikely candidate for confronting the military's usurpation of political power for 25 of the nation's thirty-five years of independence. He has no track records as a fighter for democracy or civil rule in Nigeria. Nothing he did or said in public marked him out as a particular hater of military rule. He wined and dined with the military. He was always their willing emissary in sticky situation. 

The military more or less made Abiola. He made most of his money through them. Umaru Dikko (no love lost between them) accuses him of financing the 1983 coup against president Shehu Shagari. And the one against Muhammadu Buhari which brought his own friend, Ibrahim Babangida, to power. Discretion must have advised him not to deny the charge. The manipulation of the transition programme by the military enjoyed his overt support. His newspaper chain canvassed that position. It worked to his personal gain and gave Abiola the opportunity to contest the presidential election of June 12, 1993. He had refused to join either of the two political parties, NRC or SDP because he said he was through with politics. But by January, 1993, he changed his mind. Babangida's ban on all the 23 presidential aspirants cleared the way for Abiola. He joined the SDP for the singular objective of contesting the presidential election as the party's candidate. The party gave him the thumbs up. Many people saw a carefully choreographed ploy by the military to hand over power to their trusted friend, Moshood Abiola.

It all looked like a sick joke. Not many people gave him much chance at the polls. They did not reckon with God's penchant for the mysterious. As it turned out, Abiola, the unfancied horse in the presidential race, sprang the kind of surprise that always brings the carefully stacked dominoes tumbling down. And the friend became the Nemesis, a fish bone in the throat of the military and a millstone on Nigeria's neck. Because of Abiola, Babangida left office in rather shabby circumstances. Because of Abiola Ernest Shonekan, head of the Interim National Government, was in power all of three months. A record. Because of Abiola Nigeria has not quite known peace for two years now. And the nation feels like a country condemned to live under the Sword of Damocles.

Abiola. Whoever thought this would happen, that twenty-five years after the civil war to keep the country together, Nigerians would still be wondering if their country is a united nation or a patchwork of tribal enclaves held together with the thin thread. Before June 12, 1993, the political history of Nigeria could have been written entirely with Abiola's name absent. Unless, of course, one took note of his role in the Second Republic in diluting the political influence of that Yoruba icon, the late Obafemi Awolowo. June 12, 1993, changed all that. Nothing has been quite the same in Nigeria. Not politics. Not the economy. Abiola looms large in the contemporary political history of Nigeria. Talk of disintegration? Abiola. Talk of confederation? Abiola. Humpty Dumpty was allowed to fall and the prized wisdom of our politicians and academics is at a loss for a satisfactory answer. Logjam.

Luck? Fate? Whatever you choose to call it, it reminds us that there is irony in the affairs of man. Change sometimes comes from unlikely sources. A dirt poor boy became a wealthy philanthropist. And a dark horse was galloping home with the ultimate prize when the military struck with the annulment. Oh, how it passes all the understanding!

Is Moshood Abiola a symbol of democracy? The answer depends on what you make of symbols. Positive, if symbol means someone as the fulcrum of a certain cause of action. Negative, if symbol refers to someone who has spent most of his life, a la Nelson Mandela, in the vanguard of a struggle for the greatest good of the greatest number of people. Or, at least, to change an unhealthy, inhuman system to a health, human system.

We must settle for a middle ground. The fight for civil rule in Nigeria centres on Abiola, the victim of a perceived political injustice. It was he who contested and won (?) the election which was annulled. You can't take that from him. When labour went on its first political strike last year, the demand was for an Abiola presidency. Pro-democracy movements, individuals and organizations, local or international, fight on his side. Whatever was his past, whatever was his record, all is forgotten, all is forgiven.

To be sure, he is not a perfect symbol for democracy or even civil rule. There is the taint of his relationship with the military and his loud silence on the democratic process in an endless transition. But more importantly, there is the vagueness of where he can be found in politics--with the hound or with the hare. No one knows for sure what he stands for in politics. When he campaigned for the presidency, his manifesto was remarkable for its inarticulateness. He promised to banish poverty in Nigeria but he had no clue on how to work the magic all nations would be glad to buy from him. His political ideology suffers from the same lack of definitiveness. In the Second Republic, he was in the National Party of Nigeria, NPN. Right of centre. In the Third Republic, he was in the Social Democratic Party, SDP. Left of centre. He moves, it appears, where the spirit of political ambition pushes him. But no one can tell you not buy a used car from him.

In the peculiar politics of Nigeria, Abiola as a symbol of democracy is diminished by primordial politics and ethnicism. He is not the defining agent of a resurgent democratic yearning in a country with its remarkable ambivalence about its form of government. As a symbol, he should enlarge the Nigerian nation. Instead, there is a contradiction imposed by the blurred vision of ethnicity. As a symbol, he should mean the same thing to most people. But he does not because the tribe refuses to make way for nationalism. His pronouncements have been those of an injured, tribal man. Not of a statesman. These stain the symbol. It is not his fault. It is in the peculiar habit of fate not to always have a banner without stain. But for Nigerians, even of time and circumstance distant from June 12, 1993, the date and the man still remind us that even in the admittedly murky world of third world politics, there is sometimes not enough sand to cover the murk.

Newswatch is published at P.M.B. 21499 Ikeja, Nigeria. Tel: 4960950 Fax: 962887 Telex:27874

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


57 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


Foundation Fosters Growth at the Grassroots


LENGTH: 3000 words


 

by the African Development Foundation

ADF FOSTERS SUSTAINABLE ECONOMIC GROWTH THROUGH DIRECT AID TO THE GRASSROOTS

Congress, recognizing the need to establish a small, flexible agency to provide development assistance directly to grassroots communities in Africa, created the African Development Foundation (ADF) as an enterprising, value-added alternative to traditional assistance programs.

Where traditional development agencies typically provide assistance to central governments to carry out large capital-intensive projects, ADF works directly with grassroots people to reduce poverty and effect positive social change through small, local, private sector development projects that deliver lasting benefits long after ADF ceases its involvement.

Since FY 1984, ADF has funded more than 500 small-scale, private-sector development projects in 26 African nations. Many of these projects have served as laboratories for innovative, cost-effective approaches to development-- testing strategies to maximize sustainability, local control, and capacity building--that often have been adopted by other development agencies.

Employing a participatory, "bottom-up" approach to economic development, ADF supports African grassroots recipients:

* In their own efforts;

* To design and implement their own strategies;

* To resolve their own problems; and

* To promote their own economic progress. 

Consequently, ADF-funded projects focus on inducing lasting, self-sufficient economic and social outcomes.

Today, with a modest annual budget of $16.9 million, ADF continues to successfully fulfill its Congressional mandate. By focusing on achieving attainable goals in countries most likely to benefit from U.S. development assistance, ADF concentrates on alleviating poverty and creating durable, small-scale, market economies in desperately poor, mostly rural areas of Africa where no such economies previously existed.

In short, ADF demonstrates appropriate and responsible use of limited foreign assistance dollars that helps promote a U.S. foreign policy committed to promoting democratic participation, self-sufficiency, and income generation.

TYPES OF PROJECTS FUNDED BY ADF

ADF responds to project proposals designed by grassroots African community organizations, providing grants to local cooperatives, farmers' associations, youth organizations, community service associations, women's groups, and others in the local private sector.

Because of the small size and non-bureaucratic, non-governmental nature of ADF-funded projects, the U.S. government can readily see where and how its money is being put to good use.

ADF primarily supports income-generating projects in five areas:

* Micro-enterprise development,

* Agriculture and animal husbandry,

* Credit,

* Irrigation and water supply, and

* Energy and the environment.

By law, ADF cannot fund any of the above activities for an amount greater than $250,000.

WHAT ADF DOES NOT FUND

* Government organizations

* Organizations not based on the African continent

* Capital intensive projects that emphasize large-scale building and construction

* Relief activities

* Development grants for private individuals

* Major infrastructure projects; and

* Scholarships.

AFRICANS WORKING TO HELP AFRICANS

Unlike traditional development agencies, ADF does *not* incur the expense of maintaining expatriate staff in the field. Instead, supporting ADF grantees are Country Liaison Officers (CLOs).

In each country, the CLO is a highly trained and experienced African development specialist, who works directly with, and for, grantees and potential grantees.

The CLO assists grantees and potential grantees in:

* Drafting project proposals;

* Identifying competent technical assistance providers among local development experts and organizations;

* Obtaining any available assistance from their own governments; and

* Monitoring projects.

In short, each CLO is a cost-effective, value-added liaison between private-sector grantees and ADF, helping to insure that U.S. dollars are being used wisely and providing maximum benefits for grantees.

WHY ADF IS A UNIQUE ALTERNATIVE TO TRADITIONAL FOREIGN AID

ADF provides assistance directly to the private sector-- local cooperatives, farmers' associations, youth organizations, community service organizations, women's groups, and similar organizations--not to governments or state-owned enterprises.

ADF grants range from $700 to a maximum of $250,000; average FY 1994 development grant, $124,000.

Every ADF project must have an income-generating component to foster long-term viability of the project.

Instead of funding national, capital-intensive projects, ADF supports small, limited projects that directly address the specific needs of local peoples in their communities.

Rather than incur the expense of supporting expatriates abroad, ADF keeps project costs down by employing highly trained and experienced African development specialists.

ADF SEEKS EVEN GREATER EFFICIENCY AS A STEWARD OF SCARCE U.S. FOREIGN AID $$$

In October, 1993--prior to Vice-President Gore's call for a National Performance Review and before the 104th Congress set forth its new priorities for U.S. foreign aid--ADF launched a self-initiated ten-year self-assessment.

To maximize objectivity, the evaluation was conducted by an "Assessment Review Committee" composed of Congressional staff, academicians, and representatives from the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), the General Accounting Office (GAO), and Office of Technology Assessment (OTA).

ADF's principal reasons for undertaking this assessment were to:

* Evaluate the broad impact of its programs;

* Determine which aspects of its programs and procedures work best;

* Systematically document and share its "lessons learned."

The Committee oversaw the review of more than 200 ADF grants and found that the vast majority of ADF projects were meeting their stated goals and objectives. The assessment found that ADF's program is working well and documented that:

* More than two-thirds of ADF projects produce increased income and/or needed services for participants.

* More than half of ADF projects increase the skills and knowledge of participants through training and technical assistance.

For the vast majority of ADF projects, participants are actively involved in implementation of project activities.

Most ADF projects produce sufficient income and possess management capabilities to continue to produce benefits for participants long after ADF funding has ended.

In addition, ADF contracted with an international management consulting firm to explore ways ADF can streamline its operations, both at ADF/Washington and in the field.

As a result, ADF's board of directors has established the following goals for the Foundation:

* Reduce the number of active countries to which ADF extends grants by at least 20 percent in FY 1996.

* Reduce the number of employees at ADF by at least 17 percent in FY 1996.

* Reduce ADF's overhead expenses by at least 16 percent in FY 1997.

Since 1984, ADF's goal has been to continuously improve its operations to maximize the benefit of limited dollars available for U.S. foreign aid. And it will continue to do so.

A TYPICAL RURAL ADF-FUNDED PROJECT

The Kalijiisa Blacksmith and Farmers Association Project typifies a rural ADF-funded project.

Location: Kalijiisa, a remote village in the Upper East Region of Ghana, 725 miles north of Accra, Ghana's capital

Grant recipient: Kalijiisa Blacksmiths and Farmers Association (membership: 78 men; 50 women).

Project funded: In 1990, ADF granted the cooperative $148,000 to:

* Build and equip a workshop

* Begin a reforestation program

* Increase agricultural production

* Purchase a grinding mill

In 1993, an additional $81,000 was granted for:

Purchasing a tractor

* Building a storage facility for farm produce

* Building classrooms

Results: Four years after the original ADF funding:

* Kalijiisa is the region's top cultivator of rice.

* 800 trees have been planted.

* Local children and adults are receiving literacy training.

* Ten additional townsmen have been trained as blacksmiths.

* In addition to hoes and plows, blacksmiths now produce cooking pots, bicycle carts, and iron furniture.

* Using their earnings as capital, cooperative has expanded into a chain of small retail outlets.

* Last year, the cooperative earned more than $10,000, an enormous sum of money for the region.

Today, Kalijiisa's quality products are in high demand in northern Ghana.

The capital provided by ADF helped this group turn a traditional activity into a thriving business.

A TYPICAL URBAN ADF-FUNDED PROJECT

The Spring Cabinet Furniture Manufacturing Project typifies an urban ADF-funded project.

Location: Harare, the capital of Zimbabwe

Grant Recipient: Spring Cabinet Cooperative Society, Ltd. (original membership: 10 men)

Project Funded: In 1987, ADF granted the cooperative $217,035 to:

* Provide low-cost, quality wood furniture for consumers

* Employ craftspeople and provide vocational training opportunities for recent school graduates

* Purchase machinery, tools, timber for furniture making

In 1989, an additional $25,542 was granted for the purchase of a sawdust exhaust system.

Results: Eight years after the original ADF funding:

* Spring Cabinet was named Zimbabwe's 1993 Small Business of the year.

* Earnings have risen dramatically, from nearly $700,000 in 1992 to more than $1 million in 1994.

* Profits have been reinvested, qualifying Spring Cabinet for an overdraft credit line with a local commercial bank.

* Spring Cabinet's payroll has risen from 10 to 178 employees; and with the construction of an expanded facility, the group continues to expand its operations.

Today, Spring Cabinet produces dressers, bedroom suites, dining room suites, and cabinets from locally available wood. It also imports fabric and oak from the United States. Originally targetting its products for low-income consumers, Spring Cabinet's quality furniture is now purchased by upper-income consumers, government offices, and private business.

ADF's minimal investment provided the necessary start-up capital for this group to become one of Zimbabwe's major furniture suppliers.

ADF AT A GLANCE

Created by U.S. Congress, 1980; began assistance to African grassroots organizations, 1984.

Current annual budget, $16.9 million.

Makes grants directly to local private sector organizations, not through governments or state-owned enterprises.

Overseen by seven-member Board of Directors: five uncompensated members from the private sector, appointed by President of the United States with advice and consent of U.S. Senate.

Mission:

* Provide support to small, private sector development efforts;

* Support long-term local development strategies;

* Support research on grassroots development issues by African researchers working directly with local peoples; and

* Facilitate dissemination of development information at community level throughout Africa.

Since 1984, ADF has funded 415 development projects and 123 research projects in 34 African counties. Average FY 1994 development grant: $124,000. Average FY 1994 research grant: $25,000.

Generally, development projects involve from 10 to 2,000 participants, with up to 10,000 beneficiaries for largest, most comprehensive local or regional undertakings.

ADF supports small, limited projects that directly address the specific needs of local peoples in their communities.

Because of the non-bureaucratic, non-governmental nature of ADF-funded projects, the U.S. government can readily see how its money is being put to good use.

ADF supports U.S. foreign policy by fostering sustainable economic growth through direct aid to the grassroots.

African Development Foundation, 1400 I St. NW, 10th Floor, Washington, DC 20005. Phone: 202-673-3916. Fax: 202-673-3810.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).

58 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


Africa Foundation on Chopping Block


LENGTH: 320 words


 

by Washington Office on Africa

June 30, 1995

With a $16.9 million budget for Fiscal Year (FY) 1995 and $17.4 million proposed by the Clinton administration for FY 1996, the federally funded African Development Foundation (ADF) is a small, innovative and effective agency with an distinct mandate to support grassroots development. But if the direction set by votes so far this year in the House of Representatives is maintained, the ADF will suffer drastic cuts over the next two years, and be phased out entirely in FY 1988. 

The appropriations bill passed by the House of Representatives last week (HR 1868) includes $10 million for ADF in FY1996, a 41 percent cut from this year's budget. The authorization bill passed earlier by the House (HR1561) further specifies a cut to $4 million in FY 1997.

The Senate will be considering parallel action in July and August, possibly continuing into September.

This material is made available by the Washington Office on Africa (WOA), a not-for-profit church, trade union and civil rights group supported organization that works with Congress on Africa-related legislation. Reposting or reproduction (with acknowledgement) is welcomed. Washington Office on Africa 110 Maryland Ave. NE, #112 Washington, DC 20002. Phone: 202-546-7961. Fax: 202-546-1545. Email: woa@igc.apc.org.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).


LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


59 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June, 1995


Document--An Appeal From The Family Of The Former Nigerian Head-of-State General Olusegun Obasanjo


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Secret Trial Raises Fears For The Safety Of Respected Statesman

We the family of General Olusegan Obasanjo are asking the international community to intercede with the Nigerian authorities to demand the release of this respected statesman, who is chairman of the African Leadership Forum and a trustee of the Ford Foundation.

Under arrest in Nigeria on unspecified charges, the general may be undergoing a secret trial and could be facing execution by the dictatorial government currently ruling the country.

An outspoken critic of continued military rule and advocate for democracy, General Obasanjo initially was arrested on March 13, then released at the behest of former President Jimmy Carter and other international figures on March 22 and confined to his home. 

Allowed no access to outside communication, he was allowed to see only his wife and children until he was picked up again on the night of June 13 and taken to an undisclosed location. No word of his fate was given us until Sunday, June 18 when he was examined by a doctor at a military site and the doctor reported to us that he had lost considerable body weight, was excessively fatigued, and was suffering from high blood pressure.

Since his initial detention, the general has not been formally presented with any accusations.

We are demanding his release, or, if the authorities persist in holding him, an open trial with representation by a lawyer of his choosing and with international observers in attendance.

General Obasanjo served as military leader in Nigeria from 1978 to 1980, during which time he voluntarily organized democratic elections and handed over to an elected, civilian government. Since then, he has served on numerous international panels and commissions.

June 22, 1995

Issued on behalf of the family by:

Dr. Iyabo Obasanjo (daughter)

Tel: (910) 659-4935

Fax: (910) 764-5818

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).


LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


60 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


SA trade with India booms


LENGTH: 1695 words


 

Weekly Mail and Guardian

July 7, 1995

by Reg Rumney

Indian economic involvement in South Africa has mushroomed.

The purchase by Indian brewery United Breweries Investments (UB) of a 30 percent stake in National Sorghum Breweries -- reportedly for R70-million -- is the most visible sign of the growing economic co- operation between South Africa and India.

UB had previously bought Mabula Game Lodge in the Northern Transvaal.

Trade and business delegations from India have been streaming in since 1993, according to India's Deputy Consul General in South Africa, TP Seetharam. 

Despite the presence of the Indian community in South Africa, the country is something of an unknown quantity to Indian investors. "There is a lot of interest, much of it exploratory. There is an information gap because of a lack of contact for four decades," says Seetharam.

Several major business chambers have visited South Africa, and have met counterparts in national and regional chambers such as the South African Chamber of Business, the National African Federated Chambers of Commerce as well as localised forums of Indian businessmen in Durban and Cape Town. Interest ranges from pure trade to investment from, and in, Indian business. In South Africa, the Indexpo '94 exhibition at Nasrec, in which 300 Indian companies took part, attracted 50 000 visitors.

As India continues with the liberalisation policy started in 1990, it is encouraging investment overseas. Barriers to capital outflows have been scrapped, along with other restrictions on business. This has paid off, says Seetharam. Foreign exchange reserves have increased by $20-billion in the past year.

One major Indian conglomerate, Tuta, already has motor assembly operations in Southern Africa, making small trucks, and Seetharam says it has registered a company in South Africa.

For potential Indian investors, Seetharam indicates decisions will be shaped by the special role the five or six major conglomerates play in the South African economy. Certainly, the UB investment will be watched to see how NBS fares in competition with natural monopoly South African Breweries. But some Indian firms may want to take advantage of the dominance of the conglomerates by entering into partnerships.

Opportunities for investment from South Africa abound as India opens up its once protected economy to the outside world. With around 900-million people, India is a vast market, with a legal system which won't be unfamiliar to South Africa, and with English as the language of business. On top of this there are various investment incentives, such as Export Processing Zones where wholly owned firms are tax exempt.

Individual South African firms and individuals, rather than trade delegations, have visited India, says Seetharam.

There are opportunites, for example, for private sector investment in the building of toll roads, and guarantees are being given of a return on investment in the power sector.

South African investment in the mining sector is a natural development, and India has resources which Seetharam says could be more efficiently mined. De Beers is looking at a diamond mine, he says, and the Chamber of Mines has sent a delegation to India to look at coal mining.

The extent of general economic involvement is best reflected in the trade figures. Trade has grown dramatically since 1990, off a low base.

In 1994, imports from India totalled R406-million; exports to India from South Africa totalled around R488-million.

Exports from South Africa tend to be raw materials: imports from India tend to be manufactured goods.

Despite the myriad delegations, the trade balance is favourable to South Africa. Seetharam adds that it is even more favourable if exports of gold through London and diamonds through the Central Selling Organisation are added in. India is a big buyer of small diamonds. This is not surprising since gems and jewellery are the biggest export category, with an 18 percent share of all exports at $3 991-million in 1992-93. Pearls, precious and semi-precious stones rank third, with an 11 percent share of imports at $2 641-million in that period.

Economic involvement doesn't stop at trade and investment. India's Housing and Development Corporation is to help in encouraging and training communities to get involved in low-cost housing, Seetharam says, the idea being that housing is not a product which governments deliver but a process which government starts.

Another area in which he says South Africa can learn some policy lessons from India is in small- and medium- scale enterprises (SMEs) -- and he emphasises that this is not restricted to low-tech or informal sector operations. Many goods now produced by big companies can be outsourced to small companies. Moreover, such goods are not restricted to the local market. Seetharam says around 45 percent of Indian export earnings come from goods made by SMEs. Indian companies and agencies can help South Africa stimulate the small business sector.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: August 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


61 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Women first choice for ministers' posts


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Weekly Mail and Guardian

July 7, 1995

by Gaye Davis

DEPUTY President Thabo Mbeki has pledged that a woman will be first choice to fill any minister's or deputy minister's post that becomes vacant in future.

Mbeki made the commitment when addressing women from NGOs countrywide, who gathered at Midrand last weekend in preparation for a global forum on women, which starts in Beijing at the end of August.

Mbeki also said the government would try to ratify the United National Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women (Cedaw) by August 9 -- Women's Day. And he said the proposed Office on the Status of Women -- long-awaited national machinery to promote women's advancement -- would be based in the Office of the State President. 

His pledges were met with delight by delegates. Nomtuse Mbere, convenor of the non-governmental organisation (NGO) planning committee for Beijing, said while the name of the Office on the Status of Women could change, it would "ensure all ministries work towards the advancement of women" by liaising with ministry-based gender desks and scrutinising budgets. Women wanted it based in the President's office, she said. "If it was a separate ministry, it would not have enough power."

About 1 300 NGOs are accredited for a global NGO forum to run from August 30 to September 8 at Huairou, a Chinese resort town some distance from Beijing. It is designed to complement the United Nations-sponsored Fourth World Conference on Women in Beijing's Asian Games Village, which runs from September 4 to 11.

"Beijing will be a conference of commitment on the part of governments, which will set the agenda as far as women are concerned for the next 10 years," Mbere said. "The Midrand conference was a chance for women in civil society to identify what they want the government to commit to." Major areas of concern included the burden of poverty borne by women, the need for economic empowerment, employment creation and affirmative action.

Proposals would go to the National Preparatory Committee for Beijing, chaired by deputy minister of welfare Geraldine Fraser-Moleketi.

The 30-strong South African government delegation, to be led by Speaker of the National Assembly, Frene Ginwala, will include a number of reserved places for NGO representatives.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

62 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Goldstone report that was kept secret


LENGTH: 1547 words


 

Weekly Mail and Guardian

July 7, 1995

A Goldstone report urging action against police 'dirty tricks' was never released by president FW de Klerk.

by Stefaans Brummer and Eddie Koch

THE Mail & Guardian today publishes a secret Goldstone Commission report, sent to former President FW de Klerk weeks before the April 27 election, and which urged immediate action to "neutralise" police security structures involved in "murder, fraud, blackmail and political disinformation".

The report recommended that then-police chief General Johan van der Merwe and senior generals be "effectively relieved of their positions forthwith", saying it "is a bleak prospect that this country enters its first democratic election with this security structure in place".

De Klerk failed to act against Van der Merwe and the police branch which Judge Richard Goldstone implicated, the Crime Intelligence Service (successor to the security branch), and Van der Merwe retired only in March a year later. While Van der Merwe maintained his resignation was voluntary, the M&G has information that he was forced out by Safety and Security Minister Sydney Mufamadi. 

The explosive document -- to which President Nelson Mandela's office and key government of national unity figures had access, but which was never made public -- was given to the M&G by former security policeman Paul Erasmus this week.

"The report corroborates statements I have made over the last three weeks and rebuts claims by FW de Klerk and a senior member of the police that they were unaware of or not involved in covert actions against the liberation movements," Erasmus said. "The reports show these activities included bombings and other Third Force activities that continued well after the release of Mandela and various agreements with the ANC to end them."

The report raises serious questions about the role of De Klerk, who appears to have handed his successor a political hot potato, despite the urgent request from Goldstone that "immediate steps must be taken to neutralise the activities of the CIS" before the election.

It may also be asked why the ANC-led government of national unity did not release the report publicly after the elections. And why it took a year before Van der Merwe was forced out and new police commissioner George Fivaz appointed. Sources suggest Mandela's concerns about a possible police revolt may have caused him to sit on the report.

Fink Haysom, legal advisor to Mandela, yesterday said Mandela's office was "not in a position to respond" to the report. Although it had been made available to Mandela, "this office has never received it as an official report. It appears to be Goldstone's advice to the office of the previous President."

De Klerk, who is abroad, was unable to respond at the time of going to press.

Goldstone is known originally to have favoured the public release of the report, like the 47 other reports he authored during the commission's three-year mandate to investigate violence. Goldstone was apparently convinced otherwise, but, betraying his strong feelings, said in November: "The information, I imagine, will go to the Truth Commission. The information should be made public then. If it's not made public, I will do so ... as a citizen."

The document was completed in the month before the April elections last year after lengthy investigation and evidence taken by Goldstone from a number of police witnesses who were kept in Denmark for security reasons. It said Van der Merwe -- and former Police Minister Adrian Vlok -- would have been aware of the criminal activities outlined in the report.

"An unfortunately large number of police officers currently holding high office, including the Commissioner of Police, were not only aware of some of the earlier criminal activities, but must have approved them and the funds which were neccessary to have made them possible. So, too, according to the commission's evidence, the then Minister of Law and Order, Mr A Vlok," the report says.

"It is a bleak prospect that this country enters its first democratic election with this security structure in place," it adds

Goldstone handed the report to the international investigating team under Transvaal attorney-general Jan D'Oliveira, charged with bringing security force members involved in criminal activities to book, after it had been made available to De Klerk and Mandela.

D'Oliveira's team may use affidavits contained in the report in evidence against Eugene de Kok -- the former commander of the security police Vlakplaas unit now on trial for multiple murder and corruption -- and in prosecutions against other security force members. Erasmus asked that the affidavits be withheld from publication in order not to prejudice court proceedings.

The evidence contained in the report, some of which provides further corroboration of Goldstone's earlier "Third Force" report, relates inter alia to:

-Large quantities of arms transported from Namibia to Vlakplaas, and arms delivered by Vlakplaas police to Inkatha in the run-up to the elections. Implicated are Celani Mtetwa, now KwaZulu/Natal MEC for Justice, and IFP leaders Themba Khoza, Victor Nlovu and James Ndlovu.

-The bombing of Khotso House and Cosatu House in the late 1980s.

-Vlakplaas "hit squad" activities.

-Interference in March 1994 by former Vlakplaas operatives and senior serving police officers, with the apparent knowledge of Van der Merwe, with a witness of the Goldstone Commission.

-Vlok's knowledge of the bombing of Khotso House and the Namibia arms cache at Vlakplaas.

-A network of Inkatha soldiers in Johannesburg.

-Security police disinformation, torture, and assault. The death of activist Stanza Bopapi would have been the result of police assault.

-How police practised in a mock-trial to prepare for the inquest of Dr Neil Agget, who died in detention.

-The blackmail of a senior clergyman of the South African Council of Churches.

-The near-fatal poisoning of Reverend Frank Chikane in 1989.

-Operation Romulus, a disinformation campaign to destabilize the ANC.

-A relationship between the security police and the Returned Exiles Committee, an organisation ostensibly of former inmates of ANC detention camps.

-That the Support the Police Action Group was a security police front.

-Links between the security police and the Confederation of Employers of South Africa (Cofesa).

-The shredding of about 135 000 security police files after the Inkathagate scandal in mid-1991.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


July, 1995


Economic alarm bells sound in South Africa


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Weekly Mail and Guardian

July 14, 1995

by Reg Rumney

Alarm bells have begun to ring for the economic outlook for South Africa. As the election "miracle" begins to be discounted, doubts about the underlying soundness of the economic structure have begun to mount.

It is not only that economists are by nature pessimists -- not for nothing is economics known as the dismal science. The hugeness of the economic challenge is beginning to become apparent. Lurking problems include:

-A mediocre growth rate in a country with an estimated formal unemployment rate of around 43 percent will not even mop up 

-New entrants into the job market.

-Added to this, the union movement is pushing, in its proposed amendments to the draft Labour Bill, for less flexibility, with more and stricter government regulation of the labour market. Inflexible labour markets are likely to deter new foreign investors and add to South Africa's uncompetitiveness.

-Foreign direct investment, at about R800-million last year, has picked up, but is by no means a flood, and is concentrated on buying existing businesses rather than on greenfield projects.

-The glowing export performance of past years has been shown to be less than miraculous, in the light of the ease with which export income has been overtaken by spending on imports, spurred by economic growth. For the second month this year, the trade balance -- exports minus imports -- went R135-million into the red in May.

-A lack of movement on the delivery of basic needs in terms of the Reconstruction and Development Programme threatens stability.

-South Africa has found itself in what is arguably a "debt trap", where money has to be borrowed to pay interest on loans already raised, adding to the debt in a snowball effect. The interest burden of government debt this year is projected to be 18,5 percent of total government spending. Put another way, around R1 out of every R5 of taxpayer's money is spent on servicing the debt.

-Little progress has been made in spelling out government policy on privatisation of State assets, which could be used to run down government debt.

-A forecast Budget deficit for this fiscal year -- the gap between government revenue and spending, which has to be borrowed -- is beginning to look high at 5,8 percent, after two years of economic recovery. The Department of Finance appears to be looking at a Budget deficit of five percent next year.

-No obvious progress is discernable in bringing down the high crime rate, which is a deterrent to domestic and foreign investment.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

LANGUAGE: English
