64 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


What SA's De Klerk really knew about 'dirty tricks'


LENGTH: 1627 words


 

Weekly Mail and Guardian

July 14, 1995

High level approval of police dirty tricks has been revealed in new documents, writes Stefaans BrUmmer

Docyments given to the Mail & Guardian this week provide fresh evidence that police dirty tricks in the run-up to the 1994 elections were sanctioned at the highest level.

This will increase pressure on former president FW de Klerk to explain what critics charge was his government's "duplicity" in negotiations with the ANC, as revealed by the Mail & Guardian in the last fortnight.

While former security police operative Paul Erasmus gave new documentary proof that post- 1990 operations against the ANC and its alliance partners were approved at police headquarters, ex-police chief General Johan van der Merwe this week confirmed that two cabinet committees under De Klerk were briefed on covert operations during the post-1990 negotiations.

Van der Merwe's assertion, and Erasmus' evidence that operations aimed at destabilising the ANC alliance were part of a well co- ordinated strategy, cast a pall over De Klerk's defence that rogue elements within the security forces, bent on sabotaging his reform initiatives, should bear sole responsibility for post-1990 "dirty tricks".

Many of De Klerk's critics accept he would not have been party to decisions to eliminate opponents and instigate violence -- but doubts remain, on the one hand, about his knowledge of such matters, and on the other hand about his active or tacit approval for "soft" projects against the alliance partners. 

President Nelson Mandela is known to believe that De Klerk's government played a duplicitous role during the negotiations that followed Mandela's release from prison in February 1990. "Mandela has always worked on the basis that (De Klerk's government) knew ... Either he was incapable of dealing with the problem, or they (the security forces) were doing what he wanted them to do," a source close to Mandela said this week.

Erasmus' documents include:

- A signal, dated July 15 1991, from Lieutenant-Colonel Alf Oosthuizen, chief of intelligence at police headquarters in Pretoria, to police Crime Intelligence Service (successor to the Security Branch) branches countrywide.

The signal, headed "Romulus: covert ad-hoc action to put pressure on the ANC/SACP", orders an immediate campaign to "make the SACP a millstone around the neck of the ANC". Erasmus says Operation Romulus was part of a wider "Project Wigwam" aimed at influencing political tendencies.

Issued shortly after elections for the ANC National Executive Committee, the order asks that the "SACP's influence in the ANC" be pointed out, that the SACP and ANC be "typified as one and the same organisation", and that "economic policy differences between the ANC and SACP be driven to a head". It tells police to "launch the action with all capabilities at your disposal", but suggests pamphleteering, the use of front organisations, media contact and dissemination by sources, agents and co- operators.

-A commendation of Erasmus, dated May 20 1991, from Major-General PJ Viljoen at Crime Intelligence Service headquarters in Pretoria, for "an ad-hoc action launched to attain the aims of Operation Romulus". It says Erasmus "has with great effort and enthusiasm launched actions which caused a great stir in Britain" and that "it had positive results for the government and will definitely add to the success of later actions which will be launched".

Supporting documentation makes it clear the "actions" involved the discreditation in Britain of the ANC, among other means by getting at Winnie Mandela. One document refers to "the specific objective of using the Winnie Mandela "saga" to discredit the ANC as a whole".

-A document dated October 24 1990, signed by Oosthuizen on behalf of the head of the Security Branch, about the planning under "Project Jackal" of a "covert Stratcom (strategic communication) operation aimed at radical teachers' associations".

The document says the ANC-aligned South African Democratic Teachers' Union (Sadtu), entailed "dangers" including "the broadening of the SACP/ANC power base". The operation would be co-ordinated by the intelligence section of the Security Branch at Pretoria headquarters and proposed the formation of a "loose umbrella organisation front" to counter Sadtu and others.

The operation would be presented to then-Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok for approval in December 1990, the document says. Further documentation shows final implementation plans starting January 1991 for "Operation Tutor", under "Project Jackal", which includes plans for the establishment of a teacher body that would be a police front, the infiltration of other teacher organisations and "continuous discreditation actions against Sadtu". Erasmus says the project was implemented.

-A document setting out the implementation from January 1991 of "Operation Gordian" to influence and "minimalise the effect" of the ANC Youth League and the ANC-aligned South African Youth Congress. It proposes donors be "influenced" to stop or decrease funding "administrative sabotage", the creation of division within the organisations and the "neutralising and discreditation" of leaders.

- An information note from Oosthuizen to the head of the Security Branch, dated November 8 1990 and bearing what appears to be the signatures of Vlok and General van der Merwe, on a media conference where two Returned Exile Co-ordinating Committee (Recoc) members would "reveal the ANC's undemocratic policy, ethnic divisions in the organisation and the existence of conditions in the Mbarara detention camp in Uganda".

The note says that "Recoc as an organisation acts wholly independently, although this office co-ordinates its actions", and that "the South African Police involvement will in no way be revealed".

De Klerk acknowledged on Sunday that his former ministers Gerrit Viljoen, Kobie Coetzee and Barend du Plessis had served on a cabinet committee dealing with Stratcom after 1990. "The terms of reference of the committee were not to approve of specific Stratcom projects. It was a mechanism which I created to phase out specific projects which were decided upon in a previous era."

Van der Merwe confirmed the existence of the committee, chaired by Du Plessis. "The committee was supposed to report fully to the former state president, Mr De Klerk."

He said another cabinet body, the Security Information Committee, was headed by Coetzee. It co-ordinated "all security matters" and "especially a person like Mr Kobie Coetzee ... was completely informed of what was happening on ground level".

Van der Merwe said De Klerk "had the view that no Stratcom project should be to the detriment of a political party. It should, however, be kept in mind that we were dealing with an extremely complicated political and security situation." The ANC's own Operation Vula showed the ANC had "not been honest" in its actions after 1990 "and that there were forces at work which clashed with the spirit of the negotiations".

A noted public figure who had contact with De Klerk after 1990 this week said his impression was that De Klerk had had little grip on covert security structures when he inherited them from PW Botha. "Later I got the impression he knew what was going on, but that he was not really doing anything about it. Watergate-type destabilisation he did not really think was a problem... FW, as things moved along, realised more, but did less."

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: August 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


65 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Winnie Mandela said to have ordered 1989 killing


LENGTH: 1214 words


 

Weekly Mail and Guardian

July 21, 1995

by Stefaans Brummer

More allegations linking Winnie Mandela to the 1989 murder of teenage activist Stompie Seipei and other crimes emerged this week as she prepared to sue former President FW de Klerk for a police discreditation campaign against her.

Trainer of the controversial Mandela Football Club, Jerry Richardson, jailed in 1990 for the murder of 14- year-old Seipei, has reportedly spoken out in jail for a second time, claiming Mandela ordered the murder.

And Xoliswa Falati, estranged friend of Mandela, allegedly claimed she had taken the rap for Mandela in their 1991 trial for the kidnap and assault of Seipei, where Mandela was sentenced to a R15 000 fine on appeal. Mandela failed in an interdict attempt in June last year to gag Falati from speaking out. 

Both allegations were published this week in the Dutch news journal Nieuwe Revu, days after the Afrikaans Sunday paper Rapport said that Richardson had claimed from Leeuwkop Prison that "a person" had given him the fatal order.

Meanwhile, Mandela, fired as a deputy minister by her estranged husband President Nelson Mandela earlier this year, and ANC MP Peter Mokaba are planning to sue Deputy President FW de Klerk for a police smear campaign against them after 1990.

Details of the campaign, which Mandela is understood to blame for her fall from grace and the break-down of her marriage, were first published by the Mail & Guardian three weeks ago.

The report, based on confessions and documentation provided by former security police operative Paul Erasmus, detailed a 1991 operation, sanctioned at security police headquarters in Pretoria, to publicise in the international media "abuses" of the Mandela Football Club and allegations of Mandela's marital infidelity.

Former police commissioner General Johan van der Merwe subsequently said De Klerk's cabinet had full knowledge of covert police operations.

Erasmus said information fed to the media was partly true, partly distortion. The extent of the distortion remains unexplained.

Nieuwe Revu journalist Helene Schilders said in her article that she visited Richardson in Leeuwkop Prison, where he told her: "I called her 'mommy'. I wanted to do everything for her. That is why I gave her a cover. I would still protect her if she had shown interest in me, but now I feel used.

"Soon I will be going to the Truth Commission. Then I will tell what really happened. Perhaps I will get amnesty ...

"I murdered Stompie. But during the trial I said that it was my own initiative, while in truth it had been an order of Winnie's. She heard from an important ANC member that he was an informer. She was always extremely scared of spies ... Stompie was detained in the house of Winnie. Everyone who entered used him as a boxing ball, Winnie too. He was already in a bad way when I took him to a field to murder him."

Richardson also claimed, according to the article, that on Mandela's orders he had stabbed another member of the football club "who had wanted to inform the secret police" and that he had petrol bombed houses of "people who did not want their children to go with the football team". The football team member survived.

The journal quoted Falati as saying: "During the (1991) court case, I took the responsibility for the abuse of Stompie and the other youths on me. That was an order of Winnie and her daughter Zindzi. Otherwise, something would have happened to me. Winnie did not ask, she ordered. She never thanked me. She would have had my house restored."

Falati and Richardson's new evidence is bound to pour cold water on a Department of Correctional Services statement this week that it had a sworn affidavit from Richardson that he had told the Rapport journalist no more than that he was prepared to testify to the Truth Commission.

Police have confirmed that they are investigating several unsolved crimes in connection with the Mandela Football Club and that detectives have travelled to London to interview British MP Emma Nicholson, who has claimed to have tape recordings of confessions by Katiza Cebekhulu, a member of the football team who was spirited away to Zambia before he could testify in Mandela's 1991 trial.

Mandela refused to respond to Mail & Guardian inquiries this week. Mokaba, widely regarded as her political ally, said: "I will not speak on behalf of Winnie. I believe we all need to stand up to what we did. There has to be a mechanism to investigate such allegations."

Mokaba confirmed he and Mandela had met with their lawyer and Erasmus earlier this month with a view to instituting civil action against De Klerk for damages arising from police discreditation campaigns against them. He argued the Truth Commission would not have the "teeth" to expose the full truth.

"I don't think we should simply punish the footsoldiers -- but the commanders. We want to protect the Government of National Unity, but it cannot be protected with lies."

He said: "We are certainly going ahead (with a civil suit) to expose everything. The legal route is better because it has teeth. At the Truth Commission, people must volunteer information."

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: August 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


66 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Cape Town Steps Up Olympics Pursuit


LENGTH: 1374 words


 

Weekly Mail and Guardian

July 21, 1995

by Julian Drew

CHRIS BALL believes the 2004 Olympic Games "is quite simply the biggest economic opportunity that South Africa will ever have".

It is for this reason that he decided to apply for the position of CEO of the Bid Company. Ball, former chief executive of First National Bank, likes to talk about the economic multiplier effects of the Olympic Games. "In terms of the Olympic Games, the pre-multipliers are real and particularly clear in terms of South Africa. 

"The Games would change the view of the world towards South Africa. It would be a technical award made to South Africa which would say that the world believes we can in fact stage the Games. This in itself would produce direct foreign investment in South Africa and change the level of confidence in the country.

"Then you would get a very dramatic increase in tourism from the time we start bidding for the Games. This would increase significantly when the Games are awarded. So the return on investment expenditure, on a national basis, is extremely high and there is every justification for saying that the expenditure should in fact be made," says Ball.

But while Ball's fiscal background may lead him to stress the economic benefits of staging the Games, he is acutely aware that they are not the only ones. "You can take a broad view of the Olympics which is what the President has done. President Mandela thinks the impact of the Games will be substantial.

"I like to use the term transformational because the Games will impact on attitudes; they will assist the process of nation building; they will change the view of the world towards South Africa and they will have a major economic impact," he claims.

The bad publicity caused by all the infighting over the bid earlier this year is now behind us, Ball believes, and since his appointment he has concentrated on getting the right team together to get the process on track again.

"What we've done in the last two weeks is to refocus the bid. We have the beginnings of a strategic concept that now needs to be agreed to by the constituents, including the board of directors. We have a budget for the Bid Company which will be published in about a week's time as soon as it is approved by the board. We have a management team in place. We have shifted the physical identity of the bid by redesigning the bid logo and we have set in motion the planning process. So there has been a significant amount of activity in this period," says Ball.

Although the new logo cannot be published yet, it gives the bid a stronger African identity as opposed to the previous logo which focused on Cape Town through its depiction of Table Mountain.

The question which begs to be answered, however, is whether we now have sufficient time left to put together a winning technical proposal by the August 15 deadline next year after losing six months earlier this year. "I think we can still meet the deadlines, but the main thing is that we must put forward a pragmatic proposal," says Ball

"It must be a very practical Games with practical facilities which are going to be used thereafter. It is on that basis that we are putting the proposal together."

The Interim Bid Committee, which employed private consultants to do the planning work, did a lot of groundwork and that is now being reviewed by the new team. "The work that's been done so far is conceptual rather than detailed engineering. There has been a benefit from what has already taken place but all of it has had to be reviewed. What we will produce is a new plan but naturally it is based on an awareness of the previous work.

"One of the problems with the previous concept is that it was done without reference to the council and the council has to approve the plan. There will be a fresh plan with council people involved which will be fully costed and we are doing that work as quickly as we can," revealed Ball. One hundred and fifty Western Cape organisations have been invited to a conference taking place this weekend in Cape Town to discuss the concept of the Olympics and the process that will be followed.

Ball sees the immediate targets for the Bid Company as raising the money for the bid, completing and costing the new plan, carrying out the economic impact study of the Games on South Africa as a whole, liaising with the international federations to ensure that they are up to date with all the latest requirements and communicating with the International Olympic Committee (IOC) members in preparation for the actual bidding process.

While the budget for the bid should be ready in about a week and the strategic plan in about a month, the Bid Company aims to have the new technical plan and the economic impact study available in three months' time which, as Ball says,"is a big, big exercise".

Ball is extremely optimistic about Cape Town's prospects of winning the bid. "We have four very strong elements out of which to build a platform to launch our bid. Cape Town's physical environment is the key but we also have the present goodwill towards South Africa personified by President Mandela's standing in the world. Then there is the African factor which is very important because Africans have nearly 20 percent of the IOC votes, and finally there is the development factor.

"I actually believe that Cape Town could put on simply the most enjoyable Olympic Games imaginable and with the natural environment of the Western Cape I can't think of anywhere else in the world where people could have more fun," says Ball.

There is certainly a very strong case in favour of Cape Town but one of the first tasks now will be to reconvince a rather disillusioned local populace who have been fed an unhealthy diet of selective disinformation over the past six months.

Then there is the "big, big exercise" to get to grips with and, finally, the small matter of convincing the IOC's 106 members that Cape Town is the place they would best like to spend a three-week vacation in nine years' time.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: August 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


67 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


South Africa's poor get poorer


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Weekly Mail and Guardian

July 21, 1995

by Reg Rumney

Between 1990 and 1994 the income of squatters in Gauteng declined in real, or adjusted-for-inflation, terms while that of hostel residents stayed much the same and those living in houses were much better off.

This is the finding of a Unisa Bureau of Market Research report on income and spending of black households in Gauteng.

Squatter households were 11,7 percent worse off in 1994 than in 1990; hostel residents' incomes rose 1,6 percent; and households in houses were 35,3 percent better off - all in real terms. 

This is not to say blacks living in houses are exactly wealthy. In 1994, the average black man and woman earned R21 555 and R20 884 respectively. The average black household had an income of R24 416.

And the BMR reckons the average income of a black person in Gauteng was R7 455 -- around R720 a month.

Single black people, however, are estimated to have on average a much higher annual income, of R16 220. For households with with six or more members the the income per person is R3 651.

The income per person in households with six or more members living in houses is lower at R4 079 than that of households with three members living in squatter shacks, at R5 132.

Disparities of wealth are large even among blacks in the richest South African province. The survey shows that in 1994 annual the household income of squatters was around R14 000. This is less than half the income of households living in houses, of around R32 000.

Black households in Gauteng, according to the BMR, spent 26,1 percent of the cash income on food. Income tax made up 9,1 percent, and housing 9,0 percent of their cash spending.

Shack-dwellers spent 37,1 percent of their total spending in cash and kind on food, compared with 28,9 percent for hostel dwellers, and 23,6 percent for those living in houses.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

LANGUAGE: English

68 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


South Africa must avoid the aid debt-trap


LENGTH: 640 words


 

Weekly Mail and Guardian

July 21, 1995

by Karen Harverson

South Africa will not accept foreign aid unless it can afford to finance the follow-through infrastructure or it will end up like the rest of Africa -- full of half- built hospitals and unfinished roads, said Finance Minister Chris Liebenberg.

Speaking at a recent business breakfast, Liebenberg said South Africa had a reputation for being difficult when it came to accepting foreign aid. "Donors often insist that aid is used to build something like a hospital or township but forget that the government is left to put in the infrastucture and maintenance which puts a tremendous strain on the Budget which is struggling to meet basic needs." 

He said the government will spend six times more on interest payments this year than it will on the Reconstruction and Development Programme (RDP).

"Ninety-one percent of government income is spent on salaries, paying interest and welfare payments with a mere nine percent left for everything else."

Besides meeting the demand for basic needs within fiscal constraints, South Africa needs to increase its growth levels, improve its savings rate, become more investor friendly and improve its competitiveness.

He called on business to stop waiting for the economic miracle to happen and work with the government to maintain fiscal discipline and encourage growth.

"We need a savings rate of 22 percent for the economy to grow 3,5 percent but while private sector savings are already at this rate, government dissaves by 4,5 percent leaving a dismal rate of 17,5 percent."

Liebenberg said that although the quickest way to increase the savings rate was to contain government spending -- positive savings from the government would only be a reality by the year 2000.

"In the meantime, we could use other people's savings to improve the growth rate to five percent which is why we must become investor friendly."

He said South Africa had to identify its pockets of competitiveness and create opportunities and put in infrastructure to grow these further.

"Our lack of competitiveness is due to structural, environmental, skills and attitude factors. Something is drastically wrong when it costs a company exporting to Tokyo more to rail goods from Johannesburg to Durban than the sea freight there."

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: August 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


69 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


South African Telkom's sheltered days are numbered


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Weekly Mail and Guardian

July 21, 1995

by Leon Perlman

Despite Post and Telecommunications Minister Pallo Jordan's nyet to allowing competition with state telecommunications monopoly Telkom, insiders say it's now not a matter of whether, but rather when and how much.

The recently released Green Paper on Telecommunications is the initial step to formulating a White Paper on telecommunications policy and eventual legislation, which is expected to go through Parliament early in 1996.

It is designed to elicit the public's views on the best policy framework for telecommunications and its regulation, and so asks more questions than it answers. Jordan, however, provided some answers when he released the Green Paper at the Carlton Hotel in Johannesburg. 

His comment that, "it is not in the national interest to bring competition against Telkom," at first seemed slightly out of sync with international trends and even with his own Green Paper which states: "Competition in the telecommunications sector can bring costs down and hence prices to customers. New operators can bring additional investment into the sector."

Jordan seemed to be warning off United States Telecommunications giant AT&T, which is eager to be that "new operator". "AT&T and other international competitors will be cherry-picking. There will be no Telkom left. It will be subversive to the interests of the country, so I will not even think about it."

Observers believe Jordan is being pressured by elements within the African National Congress and the South African Communist Party to keep Telkom's monopoly intact. "Telkom is the collective property of the people of the country. We must involve the millions of South Africans who are its principal beneficiaries," he said.

The apparently bemused head of AT&T South Africa, Frank Coleman, who was in the audience while Jordan expressed his forebodings, responded by saying: "You give us far more credit than we deserve."

That is too modest. AT&T is a major player in the Southern African telecommunications sector. It is the progenitor of the Africa ONE initiative to ring the African continent with a high-capacity, fibre-optic cable. Observers believe AT&T is poised to clinch the major portion of the R6-billion "MegaLine" tender to supply some one million new lines to (mainly) rural areas. That puts Jordan's comments into context.

Insiders say Jordan's caveat about the "danger of competition" is directed more at concerns about the degree of the direct competition for Telkom's fixed- line service, than a categorical dismissal of the possibility of any competition.

Before a formal decision on the equity of Telkom can be made, the objectives and visions that will emerge from public and parliamentary discussion on the Green Paper will have to be studied.

Jordan gave the assurance that competition would be welcomed once telecommunications were accessible to all South Africans. With the MegaLine initiative promising to do just that, the long-awaited competition for Telkom could be here sooner than some would like.

Comment and proposals about the Green Paper must be made in writing by September 15. Jordan will hold a live Internet discussion, via the Internet Relay Chat facility, on the Green Paper on August 15.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: August 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


70 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


South African gold mining in crisis


LENGTH: 1094 words


 

Weekly Mail and Guardian

July 21, 1995

by Karen Harverson

South Africa's gold mines, plagued by low productivity, labour unrest and diminishing cost competitiveness, faced their worst year in 1994 with production dropping below 600 tons for the first time since 1958.

This year, production seems unlikely to improve, with a fall of nine percent recorded in the first quarter of the year.

Production in the second quarter may prove even worse if the recently released June quarterly results of Gold Fields of South Africa (GFSA) and Gencor are anything to go by: both companies recorded losses.

GFSA's gold production dropped 9,2 percent in the June quarter, compared to the first quarter of this year, while Gencor reported a 2,5 percent drop in total gold production for the June quarter. 

In contrast, Anglovaal minerals division's (Avmin) quarterly results, released this week, show a one percent rise in gold production, owing to a good performance from Eastern Transvaal Consolidated Mines' Loraine Gold Mine, which boasted a profit for the first time since the first quarter of last year. However, Avmin's main gold producer, Hartebeestfontein, disappointed, with production falling 143 kilograms.

The decline in gold production this quarter has been attributed to the increased number of public holidays - - six this quarter compared to three in the first quarter -- lowered productivity linked to labour unrest, and deteriorating cost competitiveness as mining depths increase.

Mintek president Dr Aiden Edwards predicts that within five years as many as a third of South Africa's gold mines will close. "The only way to remain profitable is to work the high-grade deposits only, which will shorten the life of a mine."

Gencor, the fourth largest gold producer in the world, is looking at other African countries and abroad for future growth in gold mining, even though the Witwatersrand Basin still holds more than 40 percent of the world's reserves of gold.

This week, Gencor chairman Brian Gilbertson said its gold division, Gengold, had failed to match the progress and growth seen in the group's other businesses. "Our production, mirroring that of other South African producers, is in decline, from 85 tons in 1990 to 68 tons this year to a forecast 65 tons in 2000."

He said the company, through its Billiton acquisition, was broadening its horizons to include different types of gold deposits elsewhere in the world, mainly smaller, shallower and easier to mine deposits in Turkey, South America, Ghana and Indonesia.

On the local front, in a bid to increase the competitiveness of its 10 gold mines, Gencor has decided to free them to operate more independently than they have under the traditional mining-house hierarchy.

Mine managers will now be responsible for restructuring operations. The restructuring will include continuous work, extended shifts at the mine face, multi-skilling, and productivity-based pay, to increase competitiveness.

Avmin, while not involved in gold operations abroad, is developing its copper operations with grass roots exploration projects in Zambia and Namibia. Locally, the company is investigating setting up a R400-million greenfields underground coal project in the Eastern Transvaal coalfields.

Avmin is also involved in a nickel, copper, cobalt and platinum exploration project near Slaaihoek in the Eastern Transvaal.

Anglo American already operates two gold mines outside of the country, Navachab in Namibia and Sadiola Hill in Mali. Sadiola, which is due to come into production in 1997, is expected to become an important contributor to Anglo's earnings in the medium term. The company is also prospecting for gold in Botwana, Senegal, Cote d'Ivoire, Niger, Ghana, Burkino Faso, Tanzania and Kenya. It spent R150-million on prospecting for the year ended March 1995.

JCI is pursuing mineral investment opportunities in several African countries including gold exploration and mine development activities in Ghana. The company has embarked on a substantial exploration programme on a variety of gold prospects in Tanzania and Swaziland. It recently entered into a joint venture with Ashanti Goldfields for the redevelopment of the Kalana gold mine in Mali.

"We anticipate a minor fall in the output of group gold mines which will be compensated for by increasing production outside of South Africa," says corporate affairs manager Marc Gonsalves.

He adds that the recently opened South Deep complex at Western Areas Gold Mine, which has the largest mineable gold ore reserves in the world, will substantially boost production. It is expected to be on stream by 2000 with a lifespan of more than 40 years.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


71 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


National Problems Undermine Integration Efforts


LENGTH: 1187 words


 

by Mawusi Afele Pana Correspondent

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - The 18th Summit of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) opens here on Friday against the background of dismal economic performance of the sub-region and apathy of its leaders towards integration.

The two-day meeting, which is expected to be attended by all 16 Heads of State, coincides with the 20th birthday of ECOWAS which was formed in 1975 amidst high hopes of building a strong economic sub-regional grouping.

"I am sure that we would be the first to admit that this is not a 20th anniversary that we can celebrate with a flourish of trumpets", said Kwesi Botchwey, outgoing minister of finance, in a speech at 37th session of the Council of Ministers in Accra on Monday.

On the contrary, "it is time for sober reflection, and a candid assessment of the impact the ECOWAS on the integration of the sub-region and, more importantly, the economic development of member states", he said. 

The sub-region has been plagued by natural and man-made disasters which have had serious adverse effects on the economies of the various countries.

According to Botchwey the overall econmic performance in the sub-region over the past one-and-a-half decades has been "disappointing".

Real gross domestic product (GDP) for the sub-region averaged 2.5 per cent a year during 1986-94 which is well below the average population growth.

"Per capita real GDP declined further, even though at a slower rate than the rate of decline in the 1980-85 period", the Ghanaian minister said.

In his report for 1994-95, the Executive Secretary of ECOWAS Edouard Benjamin also painted a bleak picture of the sub-regional grouping saying that its economic performance for 1994 was "generally poor".

"There was notable reduction in economic activity within the region as a whole despite the relatively favourable condition in the UEMOA (West African Monetary Union) countries".

He attributed this to the considerable fall in production in Nigeria, the sub-regiona's economic giant which contributes 55 per cent to the region's GDP, and the protracted civil wars in Liberia and Sierra Leone.

Other growth-inhibiting factor in West Africa, according to Benjamin, included the inadequate reforms undertaken in some countries, the difficulty in mobilising external resources in an increasingly competitive world environment and the inability of the region to strenghten its competitive position on the goods and services market.

"Growth prospects in the region remain dependent on internal political factors as well as extraneous factors such as climate, prices of raw materials and the demands for goods exported by member states". Also, Benjamin was not happy about the slow pace of integration which he blamed on lack of commitment of member states. "The lethargy that has descended on the community is in sharp contract to the enthusiastic support worldwide that regional cooperation continues to enjoy..." he said. Citing instances, Benjamin said one year after the Abuja Summit that took "a number of positive decisions at both the council and authority levels", very little improvement has been recorded.

The revised ecowas treaty has still not entered into force for lack of the requited number of ratifications, he said. He said there has been no significant improvement in the rate of application by member states of community acts and decisions, and the community institutions have not been able to implement the approved work programme for lack of resources. According to Benjamin, there has been "near total paralysis", of operations of the community institutions because financial contributions from member states "have been a mere trickle during these first six months of the year". The community has witnessed considerable lack of commitment and determination to implement ECOWAS integration programmes", he said.

The performance of the institutions of the community has been seriously affected by a president cash-flow situation. However, Benjamin points out that growth in West Africa in 1995 and the ensuing years will remain contingent upon a number of factors, such as the world economic growth rate, the evolution of commodity prices and financial flows. Endonenous factors which will influence the regional environment, and particularly the growth prospects... will include the adoption and continuation of economic reforms, increase in the rate and viability of investments, alleviation of domestic political crises and consolidation of the regional integration process. As Botchwey told his colleagues, it is important to identify and discuss reasons for the limited impact of ECOWAS on the life of the ordinary citizen and on the West African business community as a whole. Benjamin calls for the involvement of all functionaries at the different echelons of government, raising of regional integration to the top of the national agenda and elimination of duplication in the regional integration arrangements. Protocols and conventions should be ratified, the national capacity for implementing and monitoring community acts and decisions must be strengthened and outstanding contributions settled. Twenty years after the establishment of ECOWAS, the will and desire for the regional grouping to succeed is absent because neither a true assessment of the regional integration option has been made at the national level nor a serious attempt made to exploit the potential on a sustained basis, noted Benjamin. He added that out of such an assessment would emerge the true worth if regional integration and the urge to give it serious consideration. "It is only when the relevance of the community has been determined would member states develop the will to support it", he added. PANA-GNA MA/FT/FON 27July95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: August 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


72 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Zambia Honours National Heroes


LENGTH: 494 words


 

by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - The Zambian government says it is renaming the country's main university, the airport and air services institute after three of the country's departed personalities in recognition of their contribution to the development of Zambia.

In a statement released Wednesday, Zambia's Information and Broadcasting Services Minister, Amusaa Mwanamwambwa said the University of Zambia in Lusaka will be renamed 'Harry Mwaanga Nkumbula University', in remembrance of the man widely acknowledged as the 'father of Zambian Nationalism'.

Nkumbula was the leader of the African National Congress (ANC) in what was then called Northern Rhodesia, the first nationalist movement to spearhead the country's campaign against British colonial rule. 

He later became the first African Minister of Education in 1962 in a nationalist coalition government of the ANC and the break-away United National Independence Party (UNIP) of Kenneth Kaunda who was the ANC's general secretary.

Apart from his contribution to the independence movement, Nkumbula is also credited with laying the foundation of democracy in Zambia. He died in October 1983 at the age of 67.

Lusaka airport will henceforth be known as 'Simon Mwansa Kapwepwe International Airport', in honour of kapwepwe, another veteran nationalist and one-time Vice-President of Zambia.

The air services institute will become 'Valentine Shula Musakanya Air Services Training Institute' in remembrance of Musakanya, a former minister who set it up.

Musakanya, as Minister of State for Technical Education, soon after independence in 1964, was instrumental in establishing the institute for the training of local commercial pilots. The institute has since been turned into a Southern Africa Development Community (SADC) regional training centre for pilots and other aviation staff.

PANA MM/MK/FON 27July95

LOAD-DATE: August 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

73 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Intelligence Boss Leaked Mugabe Wedding Story


LENGTH: 1107 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwean Intelligence Chief Elleck Mashingaidze allegedly leaked information, later proved false, about a secret wedding between President Robert Mugabe and one of his secretaries, a Magistrate's Court was told here on Wednesday.

Trevor Ncube, editor of the independent weekly Financial Gazette, denying criminal defamation charges arising from the publication of the story, told the court that he did not doubt the veracity of the story because the informant was a high-ranking senior government official who had talked to his deputy, Simbarashe Makunike, who wrote the story.

Ncube is jointly charged with Makunike and Modus publications Chief Executive and Publisher of the Financial Gazette, Elias Rusike, on two counts of criminal defamation.

The charges arise from complaints by High Court Judge Paddington Garwe and Minister of Public Construction and National Housing, Enos Chikowore, following published articles which purported that they were at Mugabe's alleged secret wedding to Grace Marufu during the Easter weekend. 

The Financial Gazette later retracted the story and apologised to the two but after writing two other stories in which had insisted that the wedding took place.

Ncube, who, along with Rusike, is mounting a defence separate from that of Makunike because of differences in approach to the case, denied during his evidence in chief and under cross examination suggestions that by repeatedly publishing the story without official confirmation or proof, he was reckless and unprofessional.

Led by advocate Erik Morris, instructed by Innocent Chagonda of 'Atherstone and Cook', Ncube also said that there was nothing unethical about revealing an informant (the Intelligence Chief) who had made "deliberate efforts to mislead".

Under cross examination from Makunike's lawyer, Jonathan Muganhu of 'Gollop and Blank', Ncube said Makunike had told him he was related to Mashingaidze and that they had met at a family function where the intelligence officer talked about attending Mugabe's wedding.

Makunike, Ncube said, had gone to write the story and allegedly got an undertaking from Mashingaidze that copies of the marriage certificate would be supplied in a "khakhi envelope".

"He was my right hand man. I had no reason to doubt him. All I did was to tell him to verify certain facts," he said.

While Garwe and Chikowore could not be reached immediately, makunike had allegedly verified the story with one Clive Broe, a British expatriate working at the justice ministry.

Asked by Ms Bambi Hammond of the Attorney-General's office as to whay why Ncube had not confirmed the wedding with Ms Marufu before publishing the story, the journalist said that had not occurred to him at the time.

"The most important thing was that the source, who was a relative (of Makunike) was at the wedding...it didn't occur to me that she (Marufu) was a key person at the ceremony," he said.

On why he had not contacted the president to confirm the information, Ncube said efforts were made to contact his office but officials had referred him to direct his question to the president himself or his relatives on the matter.

"For your own information its difficult to get anything from the president's office. It would have taken years...you can't reach the president directly. You go through officials and we did that."

On why he had not contacted Marufu's relatives, Ncube said there was no need to go that far, saying "who would doubt the Director-General of the CIO (Central Intelligence Organisation) when he says he was at the wedding".

When Hammond suggested to Ncube that he had been reckless to the extreme by publishing a story without any proof, Ncube replied: "it's your opinion."

On why he had not retracted the story after Mugabe, Garwe and Chikowore had denied that the ceremony took place, Ncube said at the time he had no reason to doubt Makunike and his source and denials by public officials were "normal".

He said he suspected the denials were because of the circumstances surrounding the marriage.

Asked to elaborate, he said the story was that Mugabe had married his former secretary and already had two children with her, one of whom was born while the former first lady, Sally Mugabe, was still alive. Sally Mugabe died on january 27, 1991.

He also said he believed the denials could have been to discredit the financial gazette because Mugabe and other senior government officials had expressed discomfort with the existence of the newspaper.

Earlier in the day, senior magistrate William Cutler, turned down Makunike's application for a separate trial and change of plea to that of guilty.

Cutler turned down the application on procedural grounds, noting especially that the application was made after the state had closed its case.

PANA-ZIANA EMM/NDN/PBM 26JULY95 ENG004

Africa News


July, 1995


Science and Technology Summit Ends


LENGTH: 494 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - The Third Presidential Forum on Science and Technology end here Tuesday with a communique which recognised that "basic food and nutritional security has become the priority in Africa."

"The basic food and nutritional security crisis in africa cannot be addressed in isolation from the poverty problem," said the document, read out by former Zambian President Kenneth Kaunda.

Speaking before the two-day meeting closed in the Ugandan capital, Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe called for enhanced scientific research in Africa to ensure adequate production of nutritious food. 

He said scientific research, particularly in drought-stricken southern Africa, should emphasise on producing early maturing crop varieties.

Mugabe urged scientists in the region, where there were weather fluctuations characterised by periodic droughts, to develop varieties of crops which could mature in at least two months in order to offset food shortages.

He regretted the fact that agricultural research tended to benefit the commercial sector at the expense of other agricultural sectors.

"Research for its own sake is not that useful. it must benefit all," he said.

Mugabe also called on african governments to tackle the drought problem.

"Yes we can pray to the almighty and traditionalists can play their part. But we must do something as nations to conserve water," Mugabe said.

He said water was not being adequately conserved to the extent that it "just flows into the oceans", adding that Zimbabwe had adopted the building of dams as a major priority.

Speaking at the same occasion, Malawi's President Bakili Muluzi supported mugabe's call to conserve water in the region.

He acknowledged that water was available but should be used more efficiently, for instance in irrigation projects.

Mugabe was expected back home on Tuesday evening.

PANA-ZIANA GM/GTM/NDN/PBM 25JULY95

Africa News


July, 1995


Mozambican Grave-Diggers Postpone Strike


LENGTH: 520 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - The 160 grave-diggers and other workers at Maputo's main cemetery called off a strike they had planned to start Tuesday, for fear of repression by the Mozambican police.

The workers' demands to the Maputo City Council include a revision of their wage structure, overtime pay, danger money, length of service bonuses and free medical care.

But when the cemetery workers' ad-hoc commission met on Monday with Maputo mayor Joao Baptista Cosme, he reportedly threatened to send riot police against them. 

In an interview Tuesday, Carlos Matsinhe, a member of the ad-hoc commission, told the Mozambique News Agency (AIM) that when this was reported back to the workers this morning, they decided not to push ahead with the strike.

"We're not stopping work because we're afraid of being beaten by the police' , said Matsinhe. "The mayor threatened to use a police unio against us. We're afraid of being jailed, so we're resuming work unsatisfied".

"Cosme said he wouldn't recognise our strike because the law forbids strikes in essential services' , added Matsinhe.

The 1990 Mozambican law says strikes are permitted in essential services, provided the strikers allow a basic minimum of work to continue.

Cosme reportedly also claimed that the cemetery workers are not recognised as civil servants by the ministry of state administration. this is presumably why they are treated as casual labour, with each of them receiving the same pay packet of 215,000 meticais (about 23 US dollars compared with the minimum wage of 16 US dollars) a month.

Matsinme said the workers would now appeal to Prime Minister Pascoal Mocumbi.

He warned that the strike has only been postponed.If the problems were not addressed, "sooner or later we'll go on strike, and if we have to die, then we'll die".

Burials were continuing as usual this morning, while Cosme refused to speak to journalists about the matter

PANA-AIM BA/PF/PBM 25JULY95

Africa News


July, 1995


Kenya Holds Business Week in Mauritius


LENGTH: 440 words


 

by Percy Kamanah Pana correspondent

PORT-LOUIS, Mauritius (PANA) - Kenya has since Monday been holding a business week in Port-Louis, Mauritius, as a way of boosting trade exchanges between the two member states of the 23-nation Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA).

Through the event,Kenya hopes to improve its balance of trade with Mauritius, currently in favour of the Indian ocean island state. 

In 1993, Kenyan exports to Mauritius amounted to 12.6 million US dollars compared with imported goods worth 3.4 US dollars brought into Port Louis from the East African nation.

Cement represents 76 per cent of Kenyan exports to Mauritius which plans to hold a reciprocal business week in Nairobi soon.

Opening the Kenyan business week Monday, the Mauritian Industry and Tourism Minister, Nde Ah Qwet Lee Chong Lem, said his country was attracted by the liberalisted African export market.

He said Mauritius and Kenya were also exploring possibilities of promoting themselves abroad as joint tourist destinations.

Meanwhile, Kenya's trade and industry minister, Kirugi M'Mkindia, invited Mauritian businessmen to take advantage of the political and social stability prevailing in his country.

He refered to Nairobi's favourable conditions for foreign investors, particularly in terms of infrastructure and fiscal policy.

At least 10 Kenyan businesspeople are participating in the promotion week in Mauritian capital, where they are exhibiting products like detergents, textiles, leather products, biscuits, handicrafts, cooking ustensils, rubber and plastics.

77 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Twenty-Seven African States Among 100 WTO Membership


LENGTH: 574 words


 

by Felix Njoku, PANA Staff Correspondent

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Twenty-Seven African States were among the 100 which have become full members of the World Trade Organisation (WTO), the body which replaced the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in January 1995.

According to a WTO Newsletter made available to PANA "membership ... rose to 100 on 1 July 1995 with Egypt, Poland and Switzerland becoming the most recent countries to join."

Apart from Egypt, the other Africans include Botswana, Burkina Faso, Central African Republic, Cote d'Ivoire, Djibouti, Gabon, Ghana, Guinea-Bissau, Kenya and Lesotho. 

The rest are Malawi, Mali, Mauritania, Maurituis, Morocco, Namibia, Nigeria, Senegal, South Africa, Swaziland, Tanzania, Togo, Tunisia, Uganda, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

According to the Geneva-based organisation, two African states -- Algeria and Sudan -- were among 28 others which have formally applied to join.

On the other hand, 15 of the 29 countries which were yet to join the organisation are African. They are Angola, Benin, Burundi, Cameroon, Chad, Congo, Gambia, Guinea, Madagascar, Mozambique, Niger, Rwanda, Sierra Leone, Togo and Zaire.

Meanwhile, WTO Director-General Renato Ruggiero has announced allocation divisional responsibilities among his four deputies as follows: -- Chulsu Kim, former Korean Minister of Trade, Industry and Energy is responsible for accessions, trade policy review, textiles, and translation and documentation. -- Anwarul Hoda is in charge of agriculture and commodities, council, market access, personnel, and rules. -- Warren Lavorel -- finance and general services, intellectual property and investment, legal affairs, services, and trade and environment. -- Jesus Seade is responsible for development, economic research and analysis, external relations, statistics and information systems, and technical cooperation and training.

The WTO replaced GATT on 1 January this year after the endorsement of the Uruguay Round of Global Free Trade Agreements in Marrakesh, Morocco in April 1994.

WTO is expected to supervise and enhance global trade almost in the same way the Word Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) husband development and international Finance.

PANA FON/JE 25July95

Africa News


July, 1995


Ethiopia earns $66 Million from Hides


LENGTH: 347 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Ethiopia earned more than 66 million US dollars from Hides and Skins export in the 1994-95 fiscal year, the National Bank of Ethiopia said.

The Ethiopian News Agency (ENA) qouted the head of the bank's foreign Trade Division, Amoraw Eshetu, as saying six governmental and three private exporters earned some 9 million dollars from the export of skin alone. 

Hides exports brought in some 57.5 million dollars into the country during the period, he added.

Amoraw said exporters were being encourage to work harder poinging out the amount each businessman could obtain in hard currency had been increased from 60 to 250 dollars. This, he said, would facilitate their transactions.

Meanwhile, the Ethiopian Skin Processing plant has said the price of hides and skins was on the down side in the international market.

Haile-Selassie Derso, the General Manager of the Addis Ababa-based plant said the price of a sqauare feet of goat skin and hide had dropped from 65 to 55 dollars.

The price of sheep skin and hide also fell by 10 dollars to 85 dollars.

Hides and Skins processing is one of Ethiopia's main industries with imputs mainly from its large livestock farms.

PANA-ENA AT/MG/FON 25July95

Africa News


July, 1995


Science and Technology Forum Begins in Kampala


LENGTH: 507 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - The third Presidential Forum on management of science and technology in Africa opened here on Tuesday with a challenge to African Scientists to put continent at the centre stage of scientific inventions.

The theme of the summit, which is being attended by the presidents of Botswana, Malawi, Mozambique, Rwanda and Zimbabwe and the Prime Minister of Burundi, is a ' Strategic Framework for Basic Food and Nutritional Security, 1995-2005' .

Host President and Chairman of the Forum, Yoweri Museveni, said African scientists should focus on improving yields of nutritional traditional foods such as millet, sorghum and peas. 

He said Africans must cast away the inferiority complex they inherited from colonialism and avoid despising their scientific innovations.

Just about 2,600 years ago, we possessed enough technology to extract iron from its ore and use it to make tools. Now our tools are implements. The time has come to change that," He said.

Zambia's representative and former President Kenneth Kaunda said science-led development on the continent depended on the availability and accessibility of "brain power".

He appealed to African governments to use the scientific and technological knowledge of ethnic Africans for the development of the continent.

Kaunda presented the paper in his capacity as the chairman of the task force for the implementation of the programme on distressed and expatriate scientists and scholars from Africa (DESSA).

The director of the Research and Development Forum for Science-led Development in Africa (RAND-FORUM), Professor Thomas Odhiambo, said Africa should design, locate and develop market-oriented technology in order to meet the demands of biotechnology, which includes food processing, livestock disease treatment agents and drug production.

A joint communique is expected to be issued at the end of the meeting on Tuesday.

PANA-ZIANA GM/GTM/NDN/FON 25July95

Africa News


July, 1995


Commonwealth Aid Management Seminar Opens


LENGTH: 414 words


 

by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Developing countries need to use foreign aid to build strong economies and develop the necessary skilled manpower to sustain development after aid money dies up, Zambian Finance Minister Ronald Penza said Monday in Lusaka.

Opening a three-day seminar on ' Effective Aid Management in Commonwealth African Region,' Penza said that while it was true that foreign aid tended to create a dependency syndrome among recepient developing countries, it was possible to utilise the aid to attain the capacity to support self-development. 

With specific reference to Zambia, Penza said that the country needed foreign aid to strengthen key economic institutions and enable Zambians acquire skills needed to manage a sophisticated and competitive economy.

Zambia's external debt currently stands at 7.3 billion US dollars. The Minister said Zambia needed more foreign funds to restructure the economy and lay the foundation for future growth.

Critics blame foreign aid for increasing dependency by recepients on the donors, distortion of developing economies and failure to effectively reduce poverty, among other disadvantages.

Fifteen Commonwealth African countries are attending the Lusaka meeting which will discuss, among other subjects, ' disbursement of aid and links between aid management and public expenditure.

It is expected to make recommendations to governments on proper utilisation of aid money.

PANA MM/MK/FON 25July95

81 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Ghana's Foreign Debt Balloons to Five Billion Dollars


LENGTH: 400 words


 

ACCRA Ghana (PANA) - Ghana's foreign debt at the end of last year stood at five billion dollars, up seven per cent on the 1993 figure, the Institue of Economic Affairs said.

In a publication entitled ' Economic Review and Outlook' released at the week-end, the Institue regarded at the nations's think-tank on economic and development issues, said Ghana currently spends 30 per cent of its earnings on debt servicing per year. It said the increase in the debt stock was a result of persistent balance of payment deficits and too much reliance on foreign support.

The West African State has received billions of dollars from bilateral and multilateral donors in support of its economic recovery programme launched in 1983. The Institute said in view if the increasing debt, the country must free itself from external support and prevent the situation from degenerating into severe economic hardships when the external inflows cease or are sharply reduced.

The document said domestic debt went up by 12.3 per cent to 531.1 billion Cedis (1,116 Cedis = 1 USD) in the past year. It said the high levels of the domestic debt stock and high cost of borrowing have resulted in high interest payments on domestic debt.

Ghana, constantly held up for admiration by the International Monetary Fund and the World bank as an example of the success of Structural adjustment programmes, recorded 3.8 per cent economic growth last year, the worst performance since 1990.

PANA-GNA MA/FON 25July95

July, 1995


Eleven People Killed in Bujumbura


LENGTH: 307 words


 

by Ferdinand Bigumandondera, PANA Staff Correspondent

BUJUMBURA, Burundi (PANA) - Eleven people were killed while 15 others sustained serious injuries in Burundi on Monday, when a group of unidentified persons threw hand grenades at a commuter bus along the airport road in Bujumbura, State Radio reported.

A cameraman of the national television, Abel Katiyunguruza, was among the people killed on their way to Buterere, a northern suburb of the capital, the Mayor of Bujumbura, Pie Ntiyankundiye said. 

The ambush is the first of its kind to take place along the airport road compared to other main roads leading to the capital which have been constantly attacked by armed groups.

About fifty people have been killed on two other national highways in the past three weeks, Police said.

The attack on Monday night ended a two-day calm which followed the mayhem unleashed at the ' Kiriri' Campus of the University of Burundi in which six people -- four students and two lecturers were killed.

July, 1995


Stockmarket Awaits 1996 Budget


LENGTH: 414 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwean stocks opened the week directionless as investors await the outcome of the 1995-96 national budget to be announced on Thursday afternoon, market analysts said Tuesday.

Quincor stockbrokers (PVT) Ltd said "we would not be surprised to see the market generally directionless this week as it marks time ahead of the budget on Thursday". 

The prevailing high real interest rates oscillating around 12 percent coupled by uncertainties in the local economy had resulted in potential investors becoming preoccupied with the lucrative short term money market.

"This has had an adverse impact on the stockmarket in terms of equity financing as companies have found it difficult to hold new and rights issues," said a market analyst.

Presently, interest rates were hovering around 33 percent, with the annualised inflation rate marginally tumbling 0.1 percentage points in May to 19.9 percent as of June.

A downsurge in interest rates to the low twenties or teens - with a more downtrend potential - would be the major trigger for a sustained stockmarket performance.

The government was faced with the mammoth task of presenting a privatisation friendly national budget, at the same instance curtail the traditional horrific government overruns on expenditure.

Meanwhile, until the real interest rates decline by more than six percentage points, investors would continue their exodus into the money market and derailing productive investment on the local bourse. PANA-ZIANA ET/STC/FON 25July95

Africa News


July, 1995


Rawlings Pleads for African Women


LENGTH: 600 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Ghana's President Jerry Rawlings Monday called for practical measures to relieve the African woman of her hardships and involve her in decision making.

This, he noted, would be more preferable to songs and poems portraying her beauty, dignity and wisdom. "I am fairly sure that the average African woman would rather see some modest practical changes which would relieve her hardships and involve her in decision making than to hear a dozen fine poems about the "tears of mother africa", he stressed. President Rawlings said this when he opened the Accra consultative meeting, called to polish unresolved issues in the African Platform for Action (PFA) to be presented at the Fourth World Conference on Women, taking place in Beijing, China in September. 

The document was originally produced at the November 1994 Regional Women's Conference in Dakar, Senegal but the adoption of certain clauses fuelled some ill feelings from certain quarters. The meeting, which will also consider the formation of a lobby group to work towards the inclusion of common positions in the PFA, is being attended by 50 participants from Benin, Cote d'Ivoire, Gambia,Ghana, Kenya,Liberia, Namibia,Niger, Nigeria, Senegal, Sierra Leone and Togo. President Rawlings said one of the greatest inequalities on the African continent is unequal access to education.

"Education is the key to the future, and as long as our cultural attitudes deprive girls of equal opportunities for education and self-development, we will not see the full potential of our nations, our continent and the world, "he added. Even in those African countries where approximately equal numbers of boys and girls begin primary education, he said, the proportion of girls steadily declines through secondary and tertiary education.

To address this problem, Rawlings said, Ghana's ministry of education targetted some rural areas with an exceptionally high rate of female school drop outs for a pilot scheme in which school girls were provided with notebooks, pen, pencils and other very elementary needs. The result made a remarkable improvement in the rate of girls completing their courses, out of all proportion to the small assistance given.

"This challenges our use of the word drop out. We borrowed this word from the west where it implies a voluntary action. Our girls do not voluntarily drop out of school. They are either withdrawn by parents and pushed into work or marriage, or are trapped by pregnancy.

"It also shows that for parents living close to the poverty line, even the minimal expenses required to keep a girl in attendance at our tuition-free state schools present a serious difficulty to the household," he added.

PANA-GNA AA/PBM 24JULY95

Africa News


July, 1995


Shake-Up in Mozambique's Frelimo Party


LENGTH: 840 words


 

by Paul Fauvet, PANA Correspondent

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - The Central Committee of Mozambique's ruling FRELIMO has appointed Manuel Tome as the Party's General Secretary, only second to President Joaquim Chissano. In a major shake-up announced early Monday morning, the committee completely reshuffled its executive body, the Secretariat, removing five out of the six old members.

A statement issued at the end of the committee's seven-day meeting at dawn Monday, showed that the only surviving member is Tome, who was promoted from the post of Secretary for Mobilisation and Propaganda. He replaced Feliciano Gundana, a veteran of the independence struggle, and one of the first FRELIMO guerrillas who received military training in algeria in the early 1960s, to combat Portuguese colonialism. 

Tome, 42, is a journalist by profession, who has held the jobs of Chief News Editor on the daily paper ' Noticias' , General Secretary of the Mozambican Journalists' Union, and General Director of Radio Mozambique.

Five new members were elected to the Secretariat. They are the former governors of Tete and Niassa provinces, Cadmiel Muthemba and Julio N'chola, Laurinda Kanji, who used to manage a major state-owned engineering factory in Maputo, Veronica Macamo and Alcindo Cumba.

Others off the Secretariat are the former secretaries for organisation, Rosario Lumbela, for administration and finance, Eduardo Arao, for foreign relations, Alberto Sithole, and for manpower and training, Guidion N'dobe.

There had been criticism that ths secretariat under Gundana had lacked dynamism and had been conservative in its approach.

Tome told a press conference this morning that on Saturday, to facilitate the committee's work, the entire secretariat had resigned en bloc, putting their positions at the committee's disposal.

Meanwhile, the Frelimo Central committee has set up a working group, led by Political Mommittee member and former Information Minister Rafael Maguni, to present, within 60 days, a proposal for restructuring the rest of the party apparatus which has 3,000 employees. The committee also decided to postpone the Seventh FRELIMO congress, due to be held next year, to 1997 so as to allow the party to concentrate on the local elections scheduled for 1996.

The main debate over these elections is whether they should take place in the entire country, as the former rebel movement RENAMO, now the country's second major party, demands, or just in a few of its 23 cities and 128 districts.

The central committee said it had looked at the possibility of nationwide elections and had decided against. It recommended instead that the elections should be held gradually, as the administrative system is restructured, and as the necessary staff are trained.

Given FRELIMO'ss parliamentary majority, this is virtually certain to be the position that the assembly of the republic will adopt when it votes on local election law later this year. It means that the 1996 elections will only be held in those places which have already been designated as municipal districts. Currently there are just 11 of these - maputo and the other ten provincial capitals.

By the time of the elections, several other places that already have a functioning administration, and where there is sufficient economic activity to generate a local tax base, could also be upgraded into municipal districts. But large swathes of the war-devastated countryside will clearly not attain this status within the next 12 months. Mozambique gained independence from Portugal on 25 June 1975. A year later,rebels calling themselves RENAMO funded by the white minority administration in neigbouring Zimbabwe (then Rhodesia) launched a disastrous war that only ended with the signing of a peace agreement in Rome in October 1992.

PANA-AIM PF/PBM 24JULY95

86 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


African Leaders Adopt Food Security Programme


LENGTH: 720 words


 

by Moses Draku, PANA Correspondent

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - African leaders Tuesday ended a two-day forum in the Ugandan capital, Kampala, with a commitment to pursue a 10-year multi-sectoral programme of action to achieve food and nutritional security.

Presidents Ketumile Masire of Botswana, Burundi's Prime Minister Antoine Nduwayo, Malawi's President Bakili Muluzi, Mozambique's Joachim Chissano, President Pasteur Bizimungu of Rwanda, Yoweri Museveni of Uganda and Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, were here to attend the Third Presidential Forum on the Management of Science and Technology in Africa.

In a communique issued at the end of the forum, the leaders appealed to African policy organs to translate policies into pragmatic actions to promote the sectors that support food production. 

They cited seed industry, recapitalisation of African soils through phosphate fertilisation, environmentally friendly pest and disease management, and the fostering of a robust intra-african network of food markets.

The leaders said basic food and nutritional security has become the priority of priorities in Africa."It is not only a question of Africa's self-worth and political prudence, it is now a question of Africa's very survival."

The communique said "food and nutritional security is a major roadblock that has to be completely cleared in order to give way to other pressing priorities for africa's economic growth and social development."

It observed that 30 years ago, Africa was self-sufficient and a net exporter of food. Africa has lost that capacity to feed itself and more of our people go hungry.

The African leaders said unless the production trends of decline are altered, africa will be producing less than 75 per cent of its food requirements by the year 200.

"Mass starvation in Africa will be averted when Africa begins once again to give due emphasis to the traditional food staples of millet, sorghum, peas, roots and tubers by enhanced technologies for production, processing, and distribution".

The presidents attributed food and nutritional crisis on the continent to lack of commitment to implement realistic visions and policies to guide the agricultural and food sector.

They urged African governments to pay attention to and begin acting on the advice of their own private sector, research and development experts, policy analysts, technology practitioners and the traditional community leaders, who know a great deal about strategies for comunity-based food security.

At the end of the Forum, the leaders endorsed the establishment of the African Foundation for Research and Development (AFRAND).

The Fund, to be based in Malawi, will be charged with the task of mobilising African scientific talents to contribute to human capital for the continent's economic and social progress.

However, President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe questioned its relevance, suggesting that its activities could be handled by existing organisations.

PANA MD/DK/PBM 25JULY95

Africa News


July, 1995


Leaders Question Relevance of New Research Board


LENGTH: 507 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - One year after its formation, the African Foundation for Research and Development (AFRAND), came under the spotlight here Tuesday with Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe questioning its relevance.

Addressing the Third Presidential Forum on management of science and technology in Africa, which established the Fund in Maputo, to spearhead science-led development on the continent,Mugabe said some of its functions could be better handled by existing organisations.

He suggested that AFRAND's programmes such as food security be handled by existing organisations like the Southern African Development Community (SADC). 

Although he lauded the Fund's objectives, he said the political framework of the organisation's operations vis-a-vis, for example, the Organisation of African Unity (OAU), was still unclear.

The Forum's closing session was delayed by about an hour because of discussions on the relevance of AFRAND.

Mugabe said: "this proliferation of bodies...I find it confusing. My country is looking at development in the context of regional organisations."

He said he wondered whether AFRAND would work within existing bodies or as a separate entity.

A Zambian delegate said AFRAN was a costly body and was merely duplicating "efforts" of other bodies.

But Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni, the Forum's new chairman, said it was his understanding that AFRAND was an autonomous body formed by African scientists who had grown "impatient" of being marginalised by existing bodies.

However, he promised to look into the relationship between afrand and other regional bodies.

At the inauguration of AFRAND in Maputo last year, South African President Nelson Mandela declined to join, saying it was a costly organisation and that he needed to "give a chance to our new generation of scientists in south africa to study it (AFRAND charter) and put forward their own concerns".

The AFRAND Charter was signed by 15 countries, including Zimbabwe.

PANA-ZIANA GTM/NDN/PBM 25JULY95
