Africa News


July, 1995


Diouf Says He Knows Nothing of Missing French Tourists


LENGTH: 547 words


 

By Aly Coulibaly PANA Correspondent

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Senegal's head of state received the anxious relatives of four French tourists who went missing in strife-torn Casamance province and declared, regretfully, he had no clues as to their fate.

President Abdou Diouf, addressing the three visitors at State House yesterday, said he had no information whether they were alive or dead in a disputed region claimed by separatist rebels.

The two French couples, on a vacation in the tropical Atlantic Ocean resort of Cape Skirring, disappeared April 6. 

Since then, thousands of Senegalese troops have been hunting for the tourists amid speculation they were abducted by guerrillas or accidentally killed by government troops.

Dakar newspapers reported today that French President Jacques Chirac personally appealed to Diouf to do everything possible to find the tourists. Chirac was on his first official visit to Senegal at the weekend since he won elections at home.

The newspapers said Diouf told the visitors, "I can assure you that all I know, you know it now. And I can guarantee that none of those who are present here knows anything else that what I have told you."

Those at the meeting included Senegal's Prime Minister Habib Thiam, cabinet ministers, military chiefs and French ambassador Rene Ala.

According to the independent daily Sud Quotidien the relatives feared the two couples were dead but said, "We at least want to have their bodies."

In a desperate 11th-hour bid for information about the fate of the four, the relatives are scheduled Thursday to meet the leader of the guerrilla-backed Casamance Democratic Forces Movement, Catholic Father Diamacoune Senghor, in Ziguinchor, capital of Casamance some 450 kms south of Dakar.

Senghor, whose guerrillas are fighting for independence, has been under house arrest since April 21.

President Diouf's government previously barred any contacts between the relatives and the rebel chieftain.

Senghor, aged 70, has been directing the war since 1982.

Several hundred people have been slain in the conflict.

PANA AC/SG/PAP/JE 25July95

Africa News


July, 1995


Gabonese Voters Endorse Constitutional Reforms


LENGTH: 360 words


 

LIBREVILLE, Gabon (PANA) - Voters in Sunday's referendum in Gabon endorsed, by 96.48 per cent, proposed changes in their country's constitution, to legalise power sharing agreements reached by the ruling and opposition parties in Paris last October.

According to the results announced Monday by Interior Minister Louis Gaston Mayila, 96.48 of the voters cast ' Yes' ballots compared with 3.52 per cent who said ' NO' . The voter turnout rate was 63.45 per cent.

The definitive results of the referendum are expected to be proclaimed by the constitutional council in the coming days. Ppolling went on smoothly but aparthy was evident in the Central African country's urban centres.

Although the ruling party of President Omar Bongo, the Gabonese Democratic Party and opposition parties campaigned for a "YES" vote, the population in both urban and rural areas did not grasp the rationale for a referendum.

The massive positive vote will pave the way for the integral implementation of the Paris accords signed by representatives of Government and the Opposition, grouped under the High Council for Resistance (HCR).

The Paris accords called for the respect of the rule of law in Gabon, alternance in power and electoral transparency.

The two sides also agreed to streamline the electoral law to prevent fraud when polls are held in 18 months time.

PANA-AGP-GAB JPL/MP/LMM/FJG/PAP/PBM 25JULY95

Africa News


July, 1995


Weekly African Money Rates


LENGTH: 307 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The New Zaire (NZ) seems set for a nose-dive like its predecessor having depreciated by nearly 2500 per cent in less than two years. Reports from Kinshasa said the NZ which exchanged at three to one US dollar in October 1993 when it replaced the Zaire, now exchages at a a mean rate of 70,000 to the American currency. The Zaire was replaced on 6 October 1993 after it collapsed to eight million to one dollar.

Other African currencies such as the Leone in Sierra Leone and the Guinea Franc are also headed for a crash with the Leone now exchanging at the rate of 820 to one Dollar, and the Guinean Franc at 1000 for one Greenback.

Only the CFA of the Franc zone, which was devalued by 50 per cent last year seems to be weathering the storm to the extent of appreciating by 20 per cent since then. The CFA continued its upward trend against the dollar, powered by the French franc, opening on Tuesday at the nomional rate of 481 to one dollar from 485.4 last week and 487.3 to the greenback three weeks ago. In Dakar Tuesday, the CFA exchanged at 466 (buying) and 497 (selling) from 470 (buying) and 500 (selling) to one dollar on 17 July.

PANA FON/PBM 25JULY95

91 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Proposal for Southern African Maritime Policy


LENGTH: 627 words


 

by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Southern African Development Community (SADC) member-states have recommended the establishment of a sub-regional maritime policy to facilitate efficient port and shipping operations in the region.

The proposal is contained in a working document tabled at the ongoing Southern Africa Transport and Communications Commission (SATCC) meeting, which opened in Lusaka Monday.

In the document, the 11 SADC states speak of the need for a regional maritime policy to address various issues, including ownership options, commercialisation and the role of the private sector in ports and shipping operations. Other issues to be addressed in the proposed policy include administration of inland lakes and waterways. 

Environmental concerns, pollution and safety in the shipping industry are some of the other issues to be defined in the proposed policy, according to the document. A SATCC working group has already approved terms of reference for the policy study expected to be completed by April 1996 and funded by the Nordic Trust Fund. Among the terms of reference for the SADC maritime policy is definition of minimum port, ship as well as infrastructure and equipment standards.

This is meant to safeguard against technology dumping and ensure that sub-standard ships outlawed in developed countries are not diverted to ports in the region.

The region has a number of well developed ports which include Dar es Salaam in Tanzania, Durban in South Africa, Maputo in Mozambique and Walvis Bay in Namibia.

Zambia, generally regarded as a ' landlocked' country, in 1994 had its Mpulungu port on the southern tip of Lake Tanganyika, upgraded as a fully-fledged port with the necessary infrastructure to handle international freight.

The port's facilities were upgraded to carter for large volumes of famine relief food destined for war-ravaged Rwanda and Burundi.

The five-day lusaka SATCC meeting is expected to, among other recommendations, spell out modalities for co-operation within specific areas of roads and road transport, railways, ports and shipping, civil aviation, telecommunications, postal services and meteorology.

The SATCC, headquartered in Maputo, Mozambique, is responsible for coordinating the development, management and operations of the regional transport and communications sectors for the 11-member SADCC grouping. The SADCC comprises Angola, Botswana, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Swaziland, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

PANA MK/PBM 25JULY95

Africa News


July, 1995


Rape Cited as Major Cause of AIDS in Africa


LENGTH: 587 words


 

by Peter Mwaura, PANA Staff Correspondent

KITWE, Zambia (PANA) - Rape is a significant route of HIV transmission in communities already heavily infected with the virus which causes AIDS, especially where it is commonly practiced.

A workshop on aids was told Wednesday that the scale of rape is enormous in many parts of the world and was causing concern because of the aids epidemic.

Nearly 370,000 women are raped every year in South Africa, a country said to have the highest incidence of rape in the world, according to a paper presented at the workshop. 

"Twenty thousands Muslim women are said to have been raped in Bosnia's civil war. Studies in the USA show that one in five American women is likely to be raped", Jackson Mbwewe, the workshop's coordinator said.

In Zambia there are approximately 32 reported rape cases and experts say many more cases go unreported.

Eleven million out of the 18 million adult HIV infected persons are in Africa, according to World Health Organization figures.

Between 70 and 80 percent of HIV infection world-wide is caused by sexual intercourse.

Mbewe said the campaign against AIDS has yet to take into account the reality of rape and efforts to inform people about HIV and how to protect themselves "are irrelevant to those forced to have sex against their will".

Opening the seminar Monday, Kitwe mayor William Nyirenda said it was not enough to advise people to use condoms when many women have no say in their partners' sexual behaviour and when child-bearing defines a woman's identity and status.

He said the technically simple means of using a condom was culturally unacceptable to many people.

"Complex behavioural and social difficulties abound. these have worked to defeat the technically simple means of using a condom to stop the virus from spreading because they are often culturally unacceptable.

"Poverty and cultural restraints continue to deprive people of control over their own lives and the power to protect themselves".

The Bishop of Ndola, Dennis de Jong told the workshop that there was need to protect the woman and to build up the moral values of our society which in the long term "will help us to face the cirisis of aids".

The three-day workshop was attended by journalists, nurses, aids workers and docotors. It was sponsored by the German Ecunemical Organisation, Missio.

PANA PM/PBM 19JULY95

Africa News


July, 1995


Zimbabwe Investigates Allegations of Discrimination


LENGTH: 520 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe's Education ministry is investigating allegations that certain private schools were discriminating against black students by charging fees most Africans in that country cannot pay.

This was said here Wednesday by the Deputy Education Minister, William Gumbochoma, when replying to a parliamentary question asked by Glen View's Member of Parliament, Clive Chimbi.

The parliamentarian had said that racial discrimination was prevalent at some private schools, especially Eaglesvale. 

In his response, the Deputy Minister said the ministry was aware of discrimination at some schools but not at Eaglesvale, as purported by the member of parliament.

Chimbi had said some white pupils at Eaglesvale had on two occasions carried out experiments on a black child, burning him around the neck.

Gumbochuma conceded that on 29 June, a white pupil pressed a hot spoon used for lifting bee wax against a black boy's neck. But he said this was an accepted school boy prank.

The Deputy minister said it was only when it had happened the second time in an art lesson that the black pupil reported the matter to the deputy head and senior master, after which the white pupil was beaten up and informed that any medical bill incurred would be met by him.

The white pupil was also told he would be expelled if what he did happened again.

"It pains me to refer to the colour of the people's skins in an independent Zimbabwe, but I am at loss as to whether one would describe the above incident as racial discrimination being practised at Eaglesvale.

"However, if the MP's have evidence of racial discrimination at some private schools, they should bring this to my ministry for investigations," said the Deputy Minister said.

He added that "at the moment, we are investigating allegations of racial discrimination at two private schools who are making a concerted effort to discriminate against blacks by hiking fees. I promise to work as expeditiously as possible on the matter."

PANA-ZIANA FZ/NDN/PBM 19JULY95

July, 1995


American and Senegalese Businessmen Meet in Dakar


LENGTH: 614 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - A planning meeting is taking place in Dakar Wednesday to prepare for a big trade mission from the American state of Louisiana, is expected here 8 to 13 October.

The preparatory meeting is being attended by a number of Senegalese businesspeople and their counterparts from Louisiana in Southern United States.

The forthcoming trade mission is among the first concrete actions after last May's African-African American Summit, during which the need for stronger trade ties between African countries and the USA was emphasized. 

At a news conference Tuesday, the visitors, invited by the Dakar-based Afro-American Business Centre affirmed their desire to invest in Africa.

They said their priority remains Senegal because the West African's businessmen and embassy in Washington have maintained contacts and calls for investments from the US business community.

"Senegal is our primary objective because this country has huge opprtunities that warrant its development for 150 years",said Mr. William G. Fousch, a specialist in international investment at the Economic DevelopmentD ivision of the state of Louisiana.

But, he added, "The choice of Senegal does not meant hat we shall not go anywhere in Africa."

Fousch and Rouse Caffey, Chancellor of the State University of Louisiana noted that some countries in the continent are on the point of attaining their development goal as they have succeded in improving their economy and reached a high standard of living.

"We have invested , they affirmed, in field Science and education in Ghana, Liberia, Nigeria, Cote D'Ivoire,S ierra Leone which bought tetanium, a metal used under water to develop agriculture.

Besides Senegal, the American Businessmen said they had already taken contacts in Mali, Uganda and Kenya where they hope to be in a position to work with local partners.

According to Mr. Malick Diop, the President of the Afro-American Business Centre who announced the forthcoming opening of similar centres in Abidjan (Cote D'Ivoire), Lome(Togo) and Libreville (Gabon), Africa must now start working towards changing trends in the relations between the Continent and the United States.

In May this year, Dakar hosted the Third African-African American Summit during which Mr. Ronald Brown, American Commerce Secretary, had asked his compatriots and businessmen to come and invest in Africa, which he described as "a promising continent".

PANA AC/HAT/PAP/PBM 19JULY95

Africa News


July, 1995


Zambia's Under-23 Team to Play in Saudi Arabia


LENGTH: 467 words


 

by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Corrrespondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - To prepare for September's All Africa Games in Zimbabwe and the Africa cup of Nations in South Africa next January, Zambia's Coach Roald Poulsen, is next weekt o lead an 18-man under 23 squad to Saudi Arabia for a series of practice matches.

Football Association of Zambia officials said Thursday that the team will play two major games against select Saudis ides on 31 July and 3 August.

Zambia is grouped with Zimbabwe and Egypt in the All-Africa Games soccer final draws, for which the Zambians qualified after beating South Africa 2-1 on goal aggregate. 

Poulsen's junior crack team to Saudi Arabia mainly comprises senior national team regulars, including current local premier league top-scorer Mwape Miti who stars for 1994 league champions, Power Dynamos. Others are national team defenders Hillary Makasa, Michael Jones Mwewa, Kingsley Masabula and Alex Namazaba. Also to travel are midfielders Arthur Lungu, Changa Chaiwa, Vincent Mutale and Bilton Musonda and strikers Douglas Mwamba, Lewis Mulenga and Dennis Lota.

Third choice national team goalkeeper Davies Phiri of premier division Kabwe Worriors will be assisted by Fred Mwalewho plays for City of Lusaka.

Poulsen, who took charge of Zambia's national soccer team in 1994 is currently grooming the under-23 side into the future national squad.

Zambia lost almost the entire original national soccer team in a plane crash two years ago and has since been experimenting with a mixture of "surviving" old players and a new crop of juniors.

The senior team last weekend in Lusaka formally qualifiedfor the January 1996 Africa Cup soccer finals to be played inSouth Africa. Zambia's replacement "miracle team" had in 1994 emerged second best continental footballers to champions Nigeria at the Tunis finals.

PANA MK/PVM 20JULY95

Africa News


July, 1995


Nigeria Under Mounting International Pressure


LENGTH: 667 words


 

by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Pressure is mounting on Nigeria's military ruler Gen. Sani Abacha to show clemency for a group of military officers and civilians reportedly sentenced in connection with an alleged 1 March 1995 coup plot. The annoucement by the Defence Headquarters last week in Lagos of the undisclosed sentences, to be confirmed Abacha's supreme ruling organ, the Provisional Ruling Council (PRC), has raised international concern and pleas. Defence spokesman Brig. Gen Fred Chijuka confirmed that 40 of the 50 people who faced trial had been convicted, but he declined to give details. Coup plotting carries a maximum death sentence in Nigeria, which has seen some 10 failed and successful coups since its independence from Britain in October 1960. 

The international community has particularly raised a hue and cry over the fate of Nigeria's former military ruler Gen.Olusegun Obasanjo, who appeared before the Lagos military tribuanl along with his former Deputy, Maj.Gen. Shehu MusaYar'adua. Obasanjo is the only Nigerian military ruler in the country's almost 26 years of army rule, to have handed over to elected civilians in 1979. Reactions to the reported sentencing of the coup plotters have come from the United Nations, the Vatican, the Commonwealth of Nations, the United States, Japan, South Africa and the European Union.

A UN spokesman Ahmad Fawzi said in New York Tuesday thatSecretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali was "very much concerned" over the sentences and had contacted the Nigerian authorities on the matter. A French foreign ministry spokesman said Paris and its European partners had consulted on the issue and summoned the Nigerian ambassador in each country to express their concern. The Catholic pontiff, John Paul II, has sent a delegation to Abacha pleading for clemency, while the Swiss foreign ministry issued a commmunique reminding Nigeria that it was a signatory to international laws covering civic and political rights. A statement by the Canadian High Commission in Lagos said "Canada seriously questions the credibility of the sentences" while Commonwealth Secretary-General, Emeka Anyaoku, a Nigerian, said in South Africa that commonwealth governments were "deeply concerned" and would discuss ways to help alleviate the crisis.

A delegation of the Commonwealth Human Rights Initiative visiting Nigeria urged Abacha in a letter to exercise "sensitivity, generosity and leniency" over those convicted of trying to overthrow him.

The PRC "has now a unique opportunity to demonstrate to the watching world its magnanimity and that it is indeed dedicated to putting a stop to the depressing and self-perpetuating cycle of coups, arbitrary arrests and state executions," the letter added.

But a warning by the British Overseas Development Minister Baroness Lynda Chalker that Abacha might not be welcome to the November Commonwealth summit in New Zealand unless Nigeria improved its human rights record has met with strong reaction from the military administration.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

Africa News


July, 1995


Former US President Carter on Peace Shuttle in Sudan


LENGTH: 547 words


 

by Yahya El Hassan, PANA Correspondent

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - Former US President Jimmy Carter is flying to the Southern Sudan town of Juba Thursday in another attempt to bring a ceasefire in the civil war between government troops and rebels fighting for autonomy from Khartoum. Carter, who arrived here Wednesday afternoon, is also to continue efforts by his organisation "Global 2000" to fight guinea worm infestation in that part of the country.

The former President had earlier brokered a two-month ceasefire agreement between the government and the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) which expires 28 July. The warring parties agreed to the ceasefire to enable medical workers to travel to guinea worm-infested areas in the south. 

In an arrival statement, Mr Carter said he will be seeking a renewal of the ceasfire agreement, hoping that the government and the rebels "who have seen the benefits of temporary peace can agree to a new ceasfire that could lead to permanent peace." He said he will meet the Sudanese President Gen. Omar elBashir and will confer with health officials on the eradication of the worm.

From Juba, the former US President is to fly to neighbouring Kenya for discussions with President Daniel Arap Moiwho has been leading mediation efforts in Sudan under the region's Inter-Government Authority on Drought and Development(IGADD).

Carter said he will also fly to Kampala, Uganda to meet SPLA leader John Garang and President Yoweri Museveni, who is suspected by Sudanese leaders of being the major backer of the southern rebels. Kampala also accuses Sudan of harbouring rebels who are still active in Northern Uganda. The mutual accusations led to a diplomatic rupture between the two countries in May this year. However, the relations have been mended after mediation by Malawian President Bakili Muluzi, current Chairman of the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa. The civil war in Southern Sudan, Africa's longest, has been on and off since the 1960s when guerillas known as "AnyaAnya" in the mainly non-muslim area started fighting forautonomy from the Arab dominated central government in Khartoum. The current war under John Garang's SPLA started in 1983.However, the SPLA has of late been hit by internal bickering, which split the movement into several rival groups which sometimes fight each other, giving the government an upper hand.

PANA YH/PBM 20JULY95

Africa News


July, 1995


U.S. To Close Three Diplomatic Posts In Africa


LENGTH: 334 words


 

by Peter Mwaura, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) -- Three diplomatic posts in Africa will be among the 19 posts around the world that the UnitedStates plans to shut down.

The posts to be closed in Africa include those at Lumbambashi (Zaire), Malabo (Equatorial Guinea) and Victoria(Seychelles). The posts will be closed during the fiscal year that will begin 1 October 1955, the 'Washington Line', a publication of the United States Information Service reported Thursday.

A State Department spokesman said the closures were necessary because of "critical budget deficit problem".

Some of "our very large embassy staffs in Europe" will also be downsized and U.S. ambassadors and chiefs of missions have been instructed to find "a way to conduct American diplomacy on a less costly basis", he said. Diplomatic posts to be closed in East Asia include Apia (Western Samoa), Brisbane (Australia), Cebu (Philippines), Medan (Indonesia), and Udorn (Thailand). In Europe the posts are Bilabao (Spain), Bordeaux (France), Florence (Italy), Edinburgh (UK), Poznan (Poland),Stuttgart (Germany), and Zurich (Switzerland). In Latin America the posts are Curacao (Netherlands Antilles), Hermosillo and Matamoros (Mexico), and Porto Alegre (Brazil).

PANA PM/FON 20July95

Africa News


July, 1995


Africa's Debt Crisis Affecting Consumers


LENGTH: 467 words


 

BLANTYRE, Malawi (PANA) - African consumer movements should take the worsening continental debt crisis seriously as it has adverse effects on consumers, said a document prepared by the Consumers International Regional Office for Africa.

The document being circulated at the five-day African Consumers Organisations Workshop being held here, said Africa's debt servicing obligation was making the continent drift further into debt crisis thereby plunging the populace deeper into hardship.

It said in 1980, Sub-Sahara Africa's debt absorbed 29.1 percent or 56.2 billion United States dollars of their combined gross national product (GNP) of 192.8 billion USD. 

Today, the combined GNP for these countries had fallen to 168.5 billion dollars which was not enough to meet their present debt obligation which recently climbed to 183.4 billion dollars.

According to the document, Africa's current debt constitutes 108 percent of its GDP compared to 37.6 percent in Latin America and the Caribbean, 36.3 percent in South East Asiaand 27.9 percent in Asia and the Pacific.

From being self-sufficient in food production 10 years ago, the document said the continent had now become a net importer of food. The recently concluded Uruguay agreement on global free trade managed by the new World Trade Organisation(WTO) would not help the continent's situation, it added.

Whereas free trade would result in the world benefitting to the tune of 292 billion dollars by the year 2002 in terms of the Uruguay agreement Africa was the only continent expected to suffer a net decline of 3 billion dollars a year during the same period.

This, the document said, required that African consumer movements be concerned about the continent's marginalisation and the effects of Structural Adjustment Programmes on the people.

PANA-ZIANA SM/MP/FON 20July95

July, 1995


President Chirac To Meet 14 African Leaders


LENGTH: 454 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - French Presidnent Jacques Chirac who arrived in Rabat on a State visit to Morocco on Wednesday, is due to meet at least 14 French-speaking African leaders before he concludes his tour of the former French colonies.

From the Moroccan capital, Chirac will travel to Yamoussoukro, capital of Cote d'Ivoire, where he will meet the Presidents of Cote d'Ivoire, Benin, Burkina Faso, Niger and Togo.

The French President will then travel to Gabon for meetings with heads of state of Gabon, Cameroon, Central Africa,Congo and Chad in Libreville. 

His last port of call will be Dakar, Capital of Senegal for meetings with the presidents of Senegal, Guinea, Mali and Mauritania.

Chirac's entourage includes 82-year-old Jacques Forcart, one time Adviser on African affairs to former President Charles De Gaulle, and former French ambassador in Senegal, Fernand Wibaux.

Observers say the newly elected President's shuttle is aimed at assuring the former colonies that they would still enjoy the usual priority in France's external relations.

Most of Francophone Africa was disillusioned by the 12 January 1994 50-per-cent devaluation of their currency, the CFA franc whose stability and convertibility had been guaranteed by thefrench treasury since 1948.

Critics interpreted the devaluation inspired by the World Bank and the International Monetary fund (IMF) as an indication that Paris had lot interest in the former colonies.However, some Western Powers expected the move to break french business monopoly in the countries thereby opening them up to other partners.

Chirac is expected to take all these in stride before he returns to Paris on Sunday.

PANA-APS-SEN MA/SG/FJG/FON 20July95

July, 1995


UN Peace Team in Lusaka


LENGTH: 347 words


 

by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Senior officials from the United Nations Verification Mission in Angola (UNAVEM) are in Lusaka consulting Zambian authorities about the size of the country's contingent to the proposed 7,500 peacekeeping force to be sent in the neighbouring country.

The UN team, led by Col. Bento Soares, was Thursday expected to finalise discussions with Zambian defence authorities on the soldiers' deployment in Angola. 

Zambia is expected to contribute some 600 military personnel to the force the UN plans to send into Angola to oversee implementation of that country's transition following the 1994 peace agreement between the Angolan government and former rebel Unita movement.

The two sides have since last November maintained a ceasefire in their 19-year-old civil war under the "LusakaProtocol" on Angolan peace brokered during one UN-supervised talks in the Zambian capital.

A Zimbabwean military officer, Maj. Gen. Phillip Sibanda has been appointed the overall commander of the multinational peacekeeping force.

Zambia has undertaken similar peace-keeping missions in neighbouring Mozambique and in Rwanda as well as in Somalia.

July, 1995


Chinese Vice-Premier In Harare


LENGTH: 467 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - China's Vice-Prime Minister Zhu Rongji is expected in Harare Saturday to start a five-day visit for talks with senior Zimbabwean government officials.

From Zimbabwe he will tour six other Southern African Development Community (SADC) countries of Angola, Botswana, Mozambique, Namibia, Tanzania and Zambia.

A statement issued by the foreign ministry here Thursday said China and Zimbabwe enjoyed excellent political relations which needed to be transformed into expanded economic co-operation. 

"Zimbabwe and China have excellent political relations which go back to the days of our liberation struggle when the People's Republic of China gave us the much-needed material, moral and diplomatic support to execute the war."

"These relations have continued to be maintained and strengthened to this day, for the mutual economic benefit of our two peoples," said the statement.

High-level exchange of visits had been going on over the years between the two countries with President Robert Mugabe visiting China in 1991. Former Chinese premier Zhao Zhiyang visited Zimbabwe in 1981, a year after the country's independence.

Total trade between the two countries in 1994 stood at 30.9 million US dollars and had reached 11.4 million US dollars by the first quarter of this year.

The foreign ministry said last year China was the second biggest investor in terms of value of approved projects.

Among other projects, China helped Zimbabwe to constructits 5.6 million national stadium through a loan facility.

The Chinese government has also provided Zimbabwe with three coaches and equipment for gymnastic, swimming and table tennis to help in preparations for the September All Africa Games.

PANA-ZIANA MP/PBM 20JULY95

103 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


UNHCR Needs 44m Dollas for Angolan Repatriation


LENGTH: 667 words


 

by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) is asking donors to provide 44 million US dollars to finance the repatriation and rehabilitation of about 300,000 Angolan exiles now living in neighbouring African states and elsewhere.

A senior UNHCR official, Abou Moussa, told Thursday here the first tripartite meeting between the governments of Angola and Zambia and the UN refugee agency that only about 83,000 Angolans were likely to be involved in the repatriation exercise. The UN says Zaire with 200,000 has the largest number of Angolan refugees. Zambia has 96,000, Congo 12,000 while about 1,000 are registered in Namibia and 15,000 others in 32 other countries. 

A UNHCR spokesman based in South Africa Yusaf Hassen said Thursday that out of the estimated budget required for the exercise, 7.1 million is expected to be spent during the current year, 28.3 million in 1996 and the remaining 8.5 million dollars in 1997 for various purposes.

Some five million dollars will be used for transport and other logistics, 6.8 million on health and nutrition, 2.7 million for domestic needs, 1.9 million for community service, 1.2 million for crop production and one million for water facilities, according to Hassen.

He said that about 6,000 Angolan refugees in Zaire have already returned to Angola on their own after the November 1994 Lusaka protocol was signed. An average of 10-12 persons are everyday leaving Zaire for Angola, he added. Hassen said just about 4,000 refugees in the neighbouring countries have said they wanted to be assisted to leave for home immediately while the majority would want to go after harvesting their crops. UNHCR has decided to start the exercise in June/July 1996.

He said that the majority of the Angolan refugees to be repatriated will be settled in Moxico province which shares borders with both Zaire and Zambia. The repatriation of the Angolan refugees is expected to be the second major operation conducted by UNHCR in Southern Africa. In 1994 the UNHCR repatriated 1.7 million Mozambican refugees in the first largest repatriation exercise ever to be undertaken by United Nations agency in Africa.

The two-day tripartite Lusaka meeting will work out the repatriation plan for some 26,000 Angolan refugess now settled in Meheba camp, northwestern Zambia and Mayukwayukwa in Kaoma, western Zambia. About 74,000 other Angolan refugees are settled in areas close to the Zambia-Angola border.

The Lusaka protocol of 1994 ended 20 years of civil war that left an estimated 600,000 people dead and three million others displaced.

At the current talks,the Angolan delegation is led by Social Affairs Minister Albino Malungo while that of Zambia is headed by Home Affairs Minister Chitalu Sampa. The former rebel National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA) of Jonas Savimbi, a signatory of the November 1994 peace agreement, is also represented at the meeting.

PANA MM/MK/PBM 20JULY95

Africa News


July, 1995


Africans Urged to Re-Evaluate Economic Reforms


LENGTH: 454 words


 

BLANTAYRE, Malawi (PANA) - African governments need re-evaluate the impact of International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank prescribed economic reform programmes if the standards of living of their people are to improve, Director of Consumers International's Regional Office for Africa, Joshua Gwitira, said on Thursday.

In an interview with the Zimbabwe Inter-African News Agency (ZIANA) in Malawi's commercial city, Blantyre, Gwitira said the foreign prescribed economic structural adjustment programmes (ESAP) had brought enormous suffering to the African consumer as removal of subsidies made food and essential service sunaffordable.

He said for any economic structural adjustment programme to succeed its should be tailored to suit the economic conditions of individual country and its level of socio-economic development. 

"The World Bank/IMF prescriptions do not take into account our level of development and our needs as nations. Wha twe urgently need now is to have a complete re-evaluation of our structural adjustment programmes.

"These adjustment programmes must be home brewed and should result in the re-instatement of subsidies on food, health and education until such a time as our economies become self-supporting,"Gwitira said.

He said the World Bank/IMF prescribed structural adjustment programmes had serious impact in West African countries some of which had reached unacceptable levels of importing goods.

"Under such circumstances, Africa should not be seen to cling to these programmes but to have each country look at its own needs and situation and make its own programme which will not cause unnecessary suffering of the people," Gwitira said. He suggested the adoption of home-grown structural adjustment programmes to promote individual countries'self-sufficiency instead of making them import-oriented. PANA-ZIANA SM/FS/PBM 20JULY95

May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

Africa News


July, 1995


Zaire to Compensate Widows of Ebola-Killed workers


LENGTH: 560 words


 

by PANA Correspondent

KINSHASA, Zaire (PANA) - The Zairean government has said it will pay compensation to widows and orphans of the medical staff who died in the fight against the Ebola epidemic that killed more than 230 people in Kikwit, Bandundu Province, 450 km from here.

Doctors, nurses and other health workers who touched blood or fluids of people infected with the Ebola virus were among the first to die when a haemorrhagic fever epidemic broke out South East of the Zairean capital of Kinshasa between April and June this year.

The decision was announced Tuesday by Prof. Tamfumu Muyembe, Chairman of the anti-Ebola International Technical and Scientific coordination committee. He was speaking to journalists after briefing Prime MinisterKengo Wa Dongo on the situation relating to the epidemic. 

Muyembe said that after hearing the complaints of lack of electricity in Kikwit, the Prime Minister has allocated40 barrels of diesel to ensure that the area gets power on a regular basis.

He also hinted that the prime minister had promised to pay up salary arrears owed to Kikwit health workers and a special bonus to the members of the international committee against the epidemic, based in the same town.

On the current situation on the ground, Dr Muyembeconfirmed that the disease is totally under control, except for one or two cases being monitored at the hospital in Kikwit after surviving the epidemic.

Meanwhile, the Institute of Tropical Medecine in Antwerp, Jean-Pierre Lahaye of the Belgian medical cooperation in Zaire,the World Health Organisation and the United Nations DevelopmentProgramme have been awarded the "Zairean Livre-Foundation Prize" (PRIZALI) for their "remarkable contribution in the fight against the hemorragic fever caused by the Ebola virus in Kikwit".

PIZALI-Foundation is a recently founded Zairean NGO.

It also awarded a Prize to President Mobutu Sese Seko and Dr Muyembe for their respective contributions to the maintenance of peace in the world and to the protection of mankind.

The award winners not only contributed to the eradication of the epidemic but they also promised to set up research centres in addition to a modern media facility to educate the populations concerned.

PANA LAPS/SG/SJD/PBM 20JULY95

106 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Mozambique Unhappy with South Africa's Dam Project


LENGTH: 747 words


 

by Paul Fauve, PANA Correspondent

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Mozambican authorities are fuming with anger over South Africa's intention to construct adam at Injaka on the Sabie river, despite being told that this will worsen water shortages in the south of the country.

The Sabie rises in South Africa and flows into Mozambique where it joins the Incomati, to become the largest river in southern Mozambique. Without the water from the Sabie, the lower reaches of the Incomati could be reduced to a trickle, wit hsevere consequences for agriculture. 

According to a report in Thursday's issue of the Maputo paper 'Noticias', the matter was raised on Monday at a tripartite meeting on water resources between Mozambique, South Africa andSwaziland, held in Boane district, about 40 kilometres west of Maputo.

The South African delegation reportedly treated the construction of the new dam as a decision that could not be changed, and turned down all requests from the Mozambicans to reconsider the issue.

According to Luis Elias, the Director of Mozambique's National Water Board, who chaired the meeting, the South Africans claimed the dam was an old project and was needed to satisfy the basic needs of people in the Transvaal.

Elias suggested that the South Africans were lying, and that the dam was really intended to benefit agro-industries, rather than to provide drinking water. "We know that this wateris intended, not for public consumption, but for irrigation",' Noticias' quoted him as saying.

"We told South Africa that we don't agree with the unilateral decision to build a dam on an international river, and without Mozambique's approval", he said.

The South Africans have promised to allow 0.3 cubic metres of water to flow along the Sabie into Mozambique, but Elias said he does not believe this. He pointed out that the current flow was already inferior to that.

A further bone of contention is an environmental impact study on the Incomati basin, which the South Africans promised to finance. The study is not finished and the South Africans say they have run out of money.

"On the one hand, the South Africans stop funding the environmental studies in the Incomati basin, but on the other they begin to build a dam at Injaka', protested Elias.

In recent years, Mozambique's water supply was threatened when authorities in neighbouring Zimbabwe hatched plans to launch major projects to divert the Pungue river for agricultural purposes and to supply the Eastern city of Mutare. Mozambican protests have so far prevented the start of such projects because the country's second largest city, Beira on the Indian Ocean, depends on the Pungue for its drinking water.

The use of the Pungue will be under negotiation at a meeting between the Mozambican and Zimbabwean water authoritiesto be held shortly.

An angry Elias remarked that, as regards the rivers in the South of Mozambique, 'the countries upstream do what they like, and it's we who suffer'.

In early 1992, a major water conference held in Dublin,Ireland, which prepared the June 1992 Earth Summit that too kplace in Brazil, proposed that countries enter into agreements to avert future conflicts on the utilisation of shared river and lake waters.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

Africa News


July, 1995


Tobacco Growers Revise Crop Output


LENGTH: 507 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Tobacco growers have revised the expected output of flue-cured tobacco this year to about 194 million kilogrammes up from the previous estimate of 186 millionkg.

"Growers' second and final assessment indicate a crop of about 194 million kg which will earn the country nearly ZD threebillion (USD 353 million)," Zimbabwe Tobacco Association marketing director Pat Davies told said in an interview.

He said the tobacco marketing board's second estimate however still maintained the expected output at 190 million kg. 

Last year 169 million kg of flue-cured tobacco - thecountry's largest export earner - were auctioned bringing in ZD2.3 billion (USD 271 million) in hard currency.

Davies said the industry still remained buoyant, with the average price already above ZD 17 (USD 2) per kg. As of Wednesday, 95,679,857 kg representing about 50 percent of the expected output had been sold at an average price of ZD 17.07(USD 2.03) per kg since auction floors opened on April 25.

Provided prices continue to soar, some analysts have already forecasted that the average price would reach zd 18.26(USD 2.15) per kg when auction floors close in the early week of October. This compares with an average price of ZD 14.71 (USD1.73) last year.

Davies said the auction season was proceeding well with a lot of cheaper offshore funds available to finance the crop.

Shipments of tobacco to overseas markets was expected to pick up in September. There was currently heavy demand for superior quality tobacco in the export markets, a situation that would help boost the Zimbabwean economy as the crop which had been produced this year was of a higher quality.

The ZTA had already recommended a 10 percent increase in hectarage to satisfy the expected jump in demand.

A larger crop size of 210 million kg was expected to be produced in the coming season.

PANA-ZIANA JM/STC/FON 20July95

July, 1995


University Student Leaders Suspended


LENGTH: 547 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - University of Zimbabwe student leaders and workers representatives were suspended indefinitely on Thursday by Vice-Chancellor Gordon Chavunduka in the wake ofunrest at the institution.

Letters of suspension served on the 15 students said the Student Representative Council leaders had been suspended for continuing to incite disturbances that disrupt the University's teaching programmes.

Another 15 members of the Executive Committee of the Workers Union were also suspended indefinitely. 

Furthermore, Chavunduka said Halls of Residence which accommodate more than 5,000 students and the Students Union building had been closed indefinitely.

He said resident students should find alternativ eaccommodation.

"I reiterate my call for other students of the university to end the class boycott and for all other workers to return to their duties

"The university has put in place mechanisms to ensure the safety of those students and workers who may have felt intimidated by the defiance campaign that was so clearly evidenton the campus today," Chavunduka said.

He said appropriate action would be taken against students who continued to boycott and disrupt teaching programmes.

The suspensions came barely a day after Chavunduka's warning on Wednesday that he would flex his muscles after students, lecturers and workers marched into the city centre on Wednesday demanding his suspension to facilitate investigations into alleged maladministration.

The university has been rocked by demonstrations and clashes with riot police resulting in a week-long closure about two weeks ago over discrepancies in payouts since it opened forthe second term on June 26.

Several students were injured during the clashes, buildings damaged while riot police, widely criticised for the heavy handed manner in which they handled the demonstrations,wantonly fired tear gas canisters into administration offices and halls of residence.

After being served with their letters of suspension, the tudents, at a general meeting held on Thursday afternoon, agreed to continue to boycott classes in solidarity with their suspended leaders.

The Association of University Teachers pledged its support for the student leaders and was expected to meet later Thursday to decide on the next course of action. PANA-ZIANA FZ/NN/FON 20July95

July, 1995


Burundi's Exams Proceeded Without Trouble


LENGTH: 360 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi (PANA) - Hutu extremists did not make good their menace to disrupt Burundi's 19940-95 secondary school entry examinations which were held in this ethnic war-threatened country Thursday.

The extremists had threatened to prevent pupils from taking the exams and have in the past months been trying to close schools on allegations that they only catered for children of them inority Tutsi tribe, their arch enemies. 

Satisfied officials from National Examination Commission reported no incidents throughout Burundi and commended the event's good organisation.

The government deployed large numbers of security forces ahead of Thursday in the country's trouble spots and along all major roads.

Education authorities asked all exam centres to allow pupils to sit for the exams in stations of their choice"given the difficulties in the movement of people caused by the crisis in the country".

But this led to overcrowding in certain centres while others were poorly attended.

About 90,000 primary schools pupils took exams in arithmetic, the Kirundi vernacular and French, in centres heavily guarded by the army.

Only 10 per cent of these will be admitted to secondary schools while the rest will seek for places in the newly established communal colleges for a four-year course.

July, 1995


Zambian Wildlife Officials in Jigsaw Puzzle


LENGTH: 454 words


 

by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Wildlife policemen in Zambia's northwestern Mwinilunga District bordering Angola are faced with a dilemma of how to stop a thriving barter trade in poached game meat believed to be from the neighbouring country.

The dealers in the suspected poached meat have defied the authority of local wildlife police to arrest them, claiming that Zambian police do not have the powers to catch them for trading in "foreign animals."

"All the wild animals are depleted in Mwinilunga and why should we be harassed when even the wildlife policemen know th esource of the meat (in Angola)," one man is quoted as saying Friday by newspapers here. 

Wildlife Police Officer-in-Charge for Mwinilunga Dexter Ilukena is said to have confirmed Thursday that some Zambians were engaged in barter trade for game meat supplied by Angolans at various border areas in the district. He vowed to punish all those invloved.

"We shall continue to deal ruthlessly with anyone found with game meat," Ilukena is reported to have said.

But the border area Zambians who are said to be exchanging sugar, salt, soap and secondhand clothing, among other items, for the meat are reportedly adamant.

Most game meat "traders" quoted by local dailies are said to have insisted that there was no logic in Zambian police"involving themselves" in their "normal business" and threatened to deal with any wildlife policeman who would stand in their way.

Ilukena has maintained that there was no way his men could distinguish between "Angolan and Zambian meat" and will go ahead to arrest anybody found with meat or firearms without licence.

PANA MK/PBM 21JULY95

July, 1995


Sudan Relectant About Another Ceasefire


LENGTH: 680 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - The Sudanese government has shown reluctance to accept former US President Jimmy Carter's call for an extension of the two month ceasefire agreement it entered with southern rebels.

According to Dr.Ghazi Salhuddin, Sudan's Minister ofState for Foreign Affairs, the government had told Mr.Carter it does not see any progress towards peace in the country. "Sudan was reserved towards Carter's request to extend the ceasefire in the south," the minister of state said at the end of talks between the former American President and the Sudanese leader, Gen. Omar El Bashir here. The ceasefire brokered by Carter, which took effect 26 May, ends in a week's time. Carter flew into Khartoum last Wednesday in the hope of building upon the cease fire. He also came to inspect a project his organization 'Global 2000' is undertaking to eliminate guinea worm infestation and river blindness in southern Sudan. But, according to the minister of state, the government told the guest that it was not happy with the ceasefire arrangement because the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army(SPLA) disrespected and even benefited from the ceasefire. 

He said the SPLA violated the ceasefire and cited an incident last month "when the rebels hijacked a UN plane carrying Sudanese relief workers and forced it to land in a rebel-held area."

However, Carter did not seem to be discouraged by the reservations of the Sudanese government. Speaking to news men Thursday on his arrival in the southern city of Juba, the former US President said he will be going to Nairobi to meet Kenya's President Daniel Arap Moi to further discuss the peace process in Sudan. Moi who leads a mediation effort under theInter-Government Authority on Drought and Development (IGADD), an Eastern African organisation whose members are Eritrea, Ethiopia, Kenya, Somalia, Sudan and Uganda. IGADD has so far convened two unsuccessful rounds of peace talks between the rebels and the government.

Reporting from Juba, the Sudan News Agency (SUNA) quoted Mr.Carter as saying he will be flying to Kampala to meet SPLA leader John Garang and Ugandan President Yowei Museveni, as part of the search for peace in southern Sudan.

SUNA said Carter had acknowledged the Sudanese governments search for the stability of southern Sudan. He expressed the hope that "the other parties to the southern Sudan dispute respond to the peace effort and allow innocent children and disabled citizens to benefit from the efforts now underway to eliminate guinea worms and river blindness in the south." He did not name those other parties. However, this could mean the various SPLA factions.

Mr Carter said he will be returning to Khartoum to inform Sudanese officials on the outcome of his talks in Nairobi and Kampala.

Carter was in Juba to review the progress reached in the eradication of guinea worms by his organisation 'Global 2000'.Southern Sudan has one third of the world's cases of Gunea worms. Entire districts in southern Sudan are also infected with river blindness, recent government reports indicated. PANA YH/PBM 21JULY95

July, 1995


Fugitive Meridien Boss Denies Fraud Charge


LENGTH: 614 words


 

by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Andrew Sardanis, the former Chairman of the collapsed Meridien BIAO Bank (Zambia) being sought authorities in Lusaka for suspected fraud, has denied theallegations and said he will return to Zambia next August.

In a statement issued from New York Thursday and widely quoted by the local press Friday, Sadanis denied that he and his bank directors had fraudently transfered 90 billion Kwacha to unidentified foreign accounts, as alleged in a recent audit report released by Zambian President Frederick Chiluba.

Sardanis, a major shareholder in the defunct bank, said he was confident that upon a complete and full investigation, he will be exonerated.He welcomed Chiluba's decision to hire international investigators to further probe the scandal. 

On Monday, Chiluba told a news conference here that the government had engaged security experts to trace Sardanis for possible prosecution and enable the Zambian government retrieve public funds advanced to the bank in an earlier failed bid to bail it out of its liquidity problems.

A report by KPMG, an accountants firm, presented to government last week, indicated that some 90 billion kwacha had been fraudently transfered to unidentified foreign accounts. (915kwacha=one us dollar).

The firm had been commissioned by Zambia's Central Bank to study reasons that had led to the collapse of the bank.

It said that only a paltry 4.3 billion kwacha of the 39 billion kwacha depositors funds was recoverable and blamed its collapse mainly on mismanagement and fraudulent activities by shareholders. But Sardanis in his statement Thursday noted that he had not received a copy of the report but that the figures "bandied about cannot possibly correspond to reality."

He attributed the failure of the bank to a number of factors which included 'civil wars, currency devaluations and unfavourable economic conditions in a number of African countries and hostility from several British institutions.' BIAO's branches in several African countries have faced similar problems prompting governments to step in.

The Zambian government had earlier this year pumped in 8.4billion kwacha to try and prevent the collapse of the private-ownedmultinational bank but the funds went into an abyss. Later, Finance Minister Ronald Penza tried to merge the instituion with the state-owned Zambia National Commercial Bank but the move was rescinded by cabinet.

The Meridien Bank had been the fourth largest bank in Zambia with over 100 billion kwacha worth of assets and about 40 000 depositors. PANA MM/MK/PBM 21JULY95

July, 1995


Salim Sends Message to Abacha Pleading For Prisoners


LENGTH: 427 words


 

by Gabu Amacha, PANA Correspondent

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - The head of the 53-nation Organization of African Unity has joined world leaders and human rights movements in appealing to Nigeria's military leader for the release of recently convicted political prisoners.

In particular, OAU secretary-general Salim Ahmed Salim told reporters today, he personally wrote to Gen. Sani Abacha seeking clemency for some 40 Nigerians including former head of state Olusegun Obasanjo secretly sentenced last week in connection with an alleged coup plot.

Salim, in his July 17 message, warned that those sentenced by a military tribunal -- most to life imprisonment, some to death -- could affect the stability of Nigeria and its international image. 

"I wish to draw particular attention to the case of General Olusegun Obasanjo ... who even after leaving office had acquired the status of an African and world statesman," he said.

The secretary-general dismissed suggestions that the pan-African boy was not concerned about events in Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation.

"We are concerned about crises in our continent," he told a news conference.

Obasanjo, who was reportedly sentenced to 25 years imprisonment for links to a military-led coup attempt against Abacha, played a key role in steering South Africa to democracy.

Salim said in his message to Abacha that "you will be assuring a place for yourself in history by being magnanimous inthe greater interest of Nigeria, its unity, cohesion and reputation and, indeed, the larger interests of our continent."

PANA GA/JE 21July95

Africa News


July, 1995


OAU Planning Extraordinary Session on Burundi


LENGTH: 694 words


 

by Gabu Amacha, PANA Staff Correspondent

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - The Organisation of African Unity (OAU) is planning to hold an extra-ordinary ministerial session next month to discuss ways of resolving the ethnic and political conflict in Burundi.

Announcing this at a news conference in Addis Ababa Friday, OAU Secretary General Salim Ahmed Salim said ministers in the continental organisation's central organ on conflict resolution will meet 29 August.

He said that in view of the deteriorating security situation in Burundi, the OAU is to send a delegation to visit countries neighbouring Burundi to discuss with the leadershio on measures to be taken to resolve the crisis. 

The Secretary General said proposed mission to Rwanda,Tanzania, Kenya and Uganda is to assess the Burundi situation and see what measures can be taken by African states in collaboration with the United Nations, to end the Burundi crisis.

"There is a serious element of insecurity in Burundi"and there is a need for Africa to make sure that the situation which occured in Rwanda (last year) is not repeated in Burundi",Salim told journalists in the Ethiopian Capital.

Salim did not specify when the delegation will leave forthe Great Lakes area or its composition, but said it would be sent in the "very near future".

A meeting on Burundi was supposed to be held in Addis Ababa from 27-28 July but it has been called off following strong objections by several Burundian political parties which insisted such a meeting should take place within the country.

The proposed meeting between leaders of 13 political parties as well as the military hierachy, was supposed to promote peace and national reconciliation.

Salim regretted the cancellation of the meeting, saying"the OAU had placed a lot of expectations on the meeting".

The OAU Executive warned Burundi leaders that a foreign military intervention should not be ruled out in case of chaos.He urged the leadership in Bujumbura to take the concern of Africa seriously.

"Any attempt to remove the government (by the military)", he reiterated,"will create more problems, leading to more disaster".

An attempt by the OAU to send a 200 strong military force was resisted by opposition parties. But the OAU maintains an observer mission of about 60 people in the central African state.

Burundi is still suffering from the backlash of thea ssassination of Hutu President Melchior Ndadaye 21 October 1993,only three months after being elected in the country's first multiparty polls.

Revenge killings between the majority Hutu and Tutsi tribesmen have led to an estimated 100,000 to 150,000 deaths.Several hundreds of Burundians have fled into exile in neighbouring countries, particularly Zaire.

A former minister of the interior has gone underground and his group is waging an on and off guerilla war against positions of the Tutsi-dominated army.

PANA GA/PBM 21JULY95

115 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Southern Senegal's Separatists Strike Again


LENGTH: 560 words


 

by Aly Coulibaly, PANA Correspondent

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Rebels fighting for the separation of the southern Casamance region from the rest of Senegal wounded three government soldiers and an eight year oldgirl in a surprise attack against a military camp there.

Reporting Friday, a privately-owned daily, Wal Fadjri, quoted unidentified military source who attributed the attack Wednesday, 45 km south east of the regional capital of Ziguinchor, to guerillas of the Casamance Democratic Forces Movement (MFDC) . The incident was the third of its kind since Monday when the MFDC fighters reportedly gunned down a government soldier andseriously wounded four others. 

The government has sent a large force in Casamance to search for four tourists who disappeared in the area on 6 April and have not been seen ever since.

The daily quoted the unidentified military source as saying " because of the pourousness of our borders, we cannot control those who come in or go out. That's why the rebels hold such a large quantity of arms and ammunition."

Guinea-Bissau said last Monday that it will not permit the entry of MFDC into their territory because they had now resorted to looting food from the population.

The continued attacks show that some MFDC fighters operate independently from the movement's Secretary General, Catholic priest Diamacoune Senghor, who was to meet Friday with relatives of the missing tourists.

The priest has since 21 April been placed under house arrest after he accused the French and Senegalese governments of hiding the said tourists, in a conspiracy to send in large numbers of soldiers to crush the MFDC.

The two government denied the allegations and the European country has sent into Casamance policemen to help in the search for the missing two couples.

Since 1982, the Southern region of Casamance, whose capital is 450 km from Dakar, has been rocked by a guerilla war waged by the MFDC which is calling for the area's autonomy from the rest of the country.

Several thousands of rebels, government soldiers and civilians have been killed in the region, a major tourist destination in this West African state.

In a 50-page document, Father Diamacoune Senghor denies that Casamance has never fallen under French rule, despite documentary evidence produced by a French expert in 1994 to prove him wrong.

PANA AC/PBM 21JULY95

July, 1995


Three Lesotho Ministers Sworn in


LENGTH: 454 words


 

by Leloko Mohale, PANA Correspondent

MASERU, Lesotho (PANA) - Lesotho's Acting Chief Justice Baptista Moali Friday swore in three newly appointed cabinet ministers at the Royal Palace in Maseru.

They Sekoala Toloane (Health and Social Welfare), Pasho Mochesane (Tourism, Sports and Culture) and Mopshatla Mabitle (Agriculture). 

The three raised the number of Lesotho's cabinetministers to 15.

The new ministers were appointed Tuesday by Prime Minister Ntsu Mokhehle, who also announced the dismissal of the ministers of foreign affairs and transport and telecommunications, Mpho Malie and David Mochochoko,respectively.

Under the reshuffle, education minister PakalithaMosisili who was moved to the new ministry of home affairs while retaining the post of Deputy Prime Minister.

This is the second cabinet reshuffle since the governmentof Dr Ntsu Mokhehle came to power in 1993.

The first was in February which transferred the then minister of information Mpho Malie to foreign.

From the look of things, every reshuffle has affected Mrmalie who has now been sacked.

Malie and the man who replaced him, Kelebone Maope, spent four months in self-exile in South Africa last year after the government of Basutoland Congress Party BCP) of Prime Minister Mokhehle was dissolved by the then King Letsie III, in August last year.

The men remained in the self-exile for another three months after constitutional order was restored in September following mediation by the presidents of Botswana, South Africa and Zimbabwe.

July, 1995


American Company Invests In Zimbabwe


LENGTH: 480 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - North Carolina-based Dudley Products Inc, owned by successful American businessman JoeDudley, has signed agreements with the Ministry of Higher Education to train Zimbabweans in cosmetology, with the first intake starting in September.

The relatively unfamiliar discipline which deals with cosmetics will be taught at Harare Polytechnic and Chinhoyi Teachers College.

"We have signed agreements with the Ministry of Higher Education and we hope to start with the first intake in September. We are ready to go and we are presently working on the applications," said Dudley after a short meeting with President Robert Mugabe at State House in Harare. 

Dudley would not disclose the number of applications so far received. However, he said three trainers were presently on hand to train the first group.

In addition, 10 Zimbabweans would be trained each year in North Carolina who would in turn train local people in cosmetology.

Dudley products manufactures and distributes hair and personal care products and runs a cosmetology university in Kernersville, North Carolina.

Dudley said he was working on a five-year investment plan in Zimbabwe estimated to cost about 6 million dollars which would include manufacture and distribution of cosmetics locally.

Dudley was Mugabe's host during a visit to the United States in May.

Meanwhile, Spanish Tourism Minister Javier Gomez Navarroalso called on Mugabe on Friday Morning.

Zimbabwe and Spain on Thursday signed general protocol agreements worth ZD 100 million (USD 11.7 million) under which two medical chambers would be built in Harare and Bulawayo, as well as a hotel in the resort town of Victoria Falls.

Mugabe told Navarro that Zimbabwe and Spain were presently very good friends. "We naturally want to see more co-operation between us," he said.

PANA-ZIANA TM/NDN/FON 21July95

July, 1995


Zambia's Defender Litana to Join Saudi Soccer Club


LENGTH: 360 words


 

by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambia's national team dependable defender Elijah Litana has signed up with a Saudi first division soccer club, Al Hilal, his Tunisian agent Zarouk Lotfi confirmed in Lusaka Thursday.

Litana was to leave for Riyadh Friday. However,there were no immediate details from his former club, Power Dynamos, about the length of his playing contract and the player's remuneration.

Litana has of late been the target of at least four foreign clubs including a top Argentine side which had expressed interest in signing on the lanky defender, described by some soccer commentators at the 1994 Tunis Africa cup finals as among the most intelligent African full-backs.

He is best remembered for his thunderous header against Nigeria scored during the Africa cup finals, won by the West Africans.

Zambia has over ten professional soccer players campaigning abroad. These include national team skipper Kalusha Bwalya in Mexico, Harrison Chongo and Evans Sakala (Saudi Arabia), Joel Bwalya (Kalusha's younger brother), Lucky Msiska and Stone

Nyirenda who play in Belgium.

Others are Zeddy Saileti (Finland), Johnson Bwalya (Switzerland), Maybin M'gaiwa (Morocco) and Kenneth Malitoli in Tunisia.

Africa News


July, 1995


Threat of Strike in Mozambique


LENGTH: 427 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - The Secretary-General of

Mozambique's Trade Union Federation (OTM), Soares Nhaca, warned Thursday that his organisation will call a general strike if by15 August government has not either met its demands, or resumed negotiations.

Interviewed by Mozambican Television, Nhaca said that in June the OTM had presented a series of proposals to the government, including a substantial increase in the statutory minimum wage, amendments to the labour law, and measures to protect workers from mass redundancies under the privatization ofpublic companies imposed by the World Bank and the InternationalMonetary Fund (IMF).

A week ago the union's leadership met with government representatives and demanded 'specific measures' to meet the trade union demands, and the resumption of negotiations by 15 August. 

"If there is no reaction from the government by then, when the OTM's relevant bodies meet the decision will certainly be to call a general strike", said Nhaca.

The last tripartite negotiations between the government,the unions and employers' associations took place in February,but ended without agreement.

The government gave a 35 per cent increase which raised the monthly industrial minimum wage to 158,650 meticais - now worth less than 16 US dollars.

The unions had wanted an 85 per cent increase, but eventually dropped their demand to 40 per cent while the government would not budge from 35 per cent.

The OTM says its calculations show that the current minimum wage can only cover 26 per cent of the basic monthly food needs of a worker.

PANA-AIM SJM/PF/PBM 21JULY95

120 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Government to Protect Angolan Returnees


LENGTH: 600 words


 

by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - The Angolan government has undertaken to provide protection to the 26,000 Angolan refugees to be repatriated from Zambia, a senior United Nations official said in Lusaka Friday.

Briefing the press on deliberations of the first tripartite meeting on Angolan refugees, Regional Public Information Officer for United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Yusuf Hassan said the Angolan government will provide security for the refugees to aviod any possible harassment or intimidation.

He said that the refugees will also be given access to land. On claims to property, Hassan said the Angolan government could not commit itself to give the refugees back their properties since the property might have been destoryed during the war. 

Hassan said the UNHCR will soon embark on information campaign on the dangers of land mines in Angola estimated to be between 10-20 million.

The two-day meeting between the Zambian and Angolan government and the UNHCR considered an operational plan for the repatriation of 26,000 angolan refugees now settled in Maheba, North-Western Zambia and Mayukwayukwa in Kaoma, Western Zambia which harbours some 3,000 refugees.

About 74,000 other angolan refugees are settled in areas close to the Zambia-Angola border.

The meeting also looked at the transportation of the refugees, registeration and documentation, border entry and exit, customs and immigration formalities.

The repatriation of some 300,000 Angolan refugees in neighbouring African countries and elsewhere is expected to start in June 1996. UNHCR has asked the donor community for 44 million United States dollars to finance the repatriation and rehabilitation of the refugees. About 83,000 Angolan refugees were likely to be involved in the repatriation exercise.

The money is meant for transport and other logistics, health and nutrition, other domestic needs and community service for the returnees.

Other projects needing finance include agriculture and water supply.

Hassan had said Thursday that the repatriation of the Angolan refugees is expected to be the second major operation conducted by UNHCR in Southern Africa.

In 1994 the UNHCR repatriated 1.7 million Mozambican refugees in the first largest repatriation exercise ever to be undertaken by the United Nations Agency in Africa.

PANA MM/MK/FON 21July95

Africa News


July, 1995


Africa: Weekly Press Review


LENGTH: 1134 words


 

by Kibaniakina M.N., PANA Correspondent

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Conflicts and refugees in Africa, a looming political crisis in Niger and the Vatican's view on the role of women in modern society are some of the issues discussed in African newspapers this week.

Refugees remain "a cause for concern" for the continent in general and countries in the Horn of Africa in particular, the 'Ethiopian Herald' said.

According to the paper, large numbers of people continued to cross the Ethiopian border from the east and the influx was far from diminishing.

The Herald reported a similar trend in western Ethiopia along the border with Sudan saying "It is a pity to see such situations taking place when Ethiopia itself has returned to peace and begun resettling its own refugees back from neighbouring countries." 

The paper attrributes this to continued fighting in neighbouring countries such a s Somali and Sudan pointing out that it was time the international community paid attention to the problem of conflicts and refugees in Africa.

Newspapers in Burkina Faso and Senegal joined the LibyanNews Agency (JANA) in criticising the continued imposition ofsanctions against Tripoli and the political stalemate in Niger.

"The United States of America, the greatest power in the world, does no hesitate to accuse Libya, a small country of four million people, located over 10,000 miles of its coast, of threatening its national security," JANA said in an editorial.

Reacting to president Clinton's decision to extend by six months the embargo against Libya, the agency which generally expresses government opinion on issues, "absurd and unfounded" accusations of official Libyan involvement in the bombing of a PanAm jumbo jet over Lockerby in Scotland in 1988 in which hundreds of of people died.

JANA claimed there was a strong link between the U.S embargo, in force since 1986, and the UN Security Council sanctions implemented since 15 April 1992, "under U.S

pressure".

It urged Washington to consider dialogue with Tripoli and abandon its policy against "the independence, freedom and progress of small countries".

DAKAR, Senegal - 'Le Pays', a newspaper based in Burkina Faso took issues with the political squabbles in Niger, wondering whether democracy was not under threat in the country considering the seriousness of the conflict between president Mahamane Ousmane and prime minister Hama Amadou?

The inability of the two men to work together underscores the deep-seated antagonism between the two major political groups in Niger, one led by the head of state and the other by the prime minister whose party won a majority in the parliament in early election held in January, it added.

'Le Pays' described the crisis as a "political guerilla war", adding "the turn taken by democracy in Niger is becoming a cause for concern".

"For a country whose economy is already suffering, this is enough to ... create an explosive social situation,." the paper warned.

A satirical weekly based in Ouagadougou also discussed the crisis, saying in spite of the mediation by former president Amadou Toumani Toure of Mali, the ultimate could be the return of a military regime similar to the one headed by late Gen. Seyni Kountche from 1974 to 1987.

But Senegal's official 'Le Soleil' newspaper was not that pessimistic. "The initiative holds a glimmer of hope," it said.

Gen. Toumani Toure's "personal initiative" provides Niger politicians "an opportunity to settle their dispute without losing face", the paper said.

'Sud Quotidien', an independent daily, commented on the recent African tour by United Nations Secretary General Boutros-Ghali, focusing on his visit to Angola.

"The meeting (with Jonas Savimbi) in Bailundo (UNITA stronghold in south-central Angola) was significant, since the mediators in the Angolan civil war have always refused to visit the rebels' headquarters", the paper noted.

In Kampala, 'The Monitor' commented on Pope John Paul's (new) views on the role of women in modern society in a letter by Pope John Paul II apologising for the Catholic Church's role in oppressing women.

"The pontiff made a very stout defence of equal pay for equal work, protection for working mothers, fairness in career advancement, equality of spouses with regard to family rights, and the recognition of everything that is part of the rights and duties of a citizen in a democratic era", the paper noted.

It noted that, "The traditional view of the Catholic establishment has been that women should stay home, rear childern - very many at that - cook, and knit their men's socks and shirt collars", hoping that ongoing repentance at the Vatican would

change all this.

Even now, the paper said, "his position on abortion, for example, is very extreme."

And the Pope's letter maintained the See's anachronistic position that women will never be ordained priests", it added.

PANA PAP/KIB/SJD/FON/JE 21July95

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). LANGUAGE: English

122 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Bureaucrats Refuse to Release Life-Saving Landmine Detectors


LENGTH: 627 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - While every day Mozambicans run the risk of being blown up by landmines planted in the civil war customs officers refuse to release donated equipment designed to clear minefields -- and save lives.

Twelve French-made mine detectors, a gift from the Paris government, have been held up at Maputo Airport since they arrived in March, the semiofficial Mozambique News Agency reported today.

They are intended for Mozambique Army sappers who were trained by French experts. 

On March 28 the French Embassy sent a letter to the foreign ministry with a copy to the defence ministry, alerting the government to the need to clear the equipment through customs.

This should have been a simple formality, since defence equipment is exempt from paying import duties under a government decree of 1988, the Mozambique agency said.

The foreign ministry declared the detectors should be cleared duty free. The customs department ruled that the defence ministry should seek the exemption. All the French Embassy's relevant documents were meantime delivered to the army's general staff officer in charge of engineering.

But nothing happened. Noone claimed the detectors, and storage charges mounted.

Regularly French diplomats would telephone the defence ministry, reminding it of the need to take the equipment out of the airport. Even the minister himself, Aguiar Mazula, was directly informed of the problem. Still nothing happened.

Eventually, after three months, the French Embassy issued an ultimatum: either the ministry clear the detectors through customs, or France would withdraw the equipment and give it to some other deserving country.

Now, deputy defence minister Antonio Hama Thai has contacted the embassy to ask for another set of copies of the documentation concerning the equipment.

The defence ministry now promises that the detectors will be out of the airport by early next week.

Yet life-saving equipment, which cost Mozambique nothing, has sat uselessly in a customs warehouse for almost four months, the Mozambique agency said.

Insensitive bureaucratic procedures and straightforwarddisorganisation are constant headaches in Mozambique, against which businessmen, diplomats, and even government ministers frequently complain.

President Joaquim Chissano himself earlier this week spoke of the need to make the state apparatus more efficient, more responsive to public needs.

In this instance, the habitual lethargy of the Mozambican bureaucracy may have cost lives.

PANA AIM PF/JE 21July
