Africa News


July, 1995


Deputy Editor Changes Plea to Guilty in Mugabe Marriage Case


LENGTH: 427 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - One of three Zimbabwean newspaper executives on trial over a false report about President Robert Mugabe's marriage today opted to distance himself from the other two accused and pleaded guilty to defamation.

The deputy editor of the Financial Gazette, a privately-owned weekly often critical of Mugabe's government, said he wanted a speedy conclusion to the case as he had no money to defend himself.

Simba Makunike, instead, pleaded guilty to a charge of criminally defaming a judge and a cabinet minister by reporting erroneously that they played a role in a wedding between Mugabe and secretary Grace Marufu last April. 

Mugabe has angrily told journalists that reports he had secretly married the secretary after the death of his Ghanaian-wife, Sally, were none of their business.

But both High Court Judge Paddington Garwe and Public Construction Minister Enos Chikowore have denied Gazette accounts saying they witnessed a formal ceremony.

Magistrate William Cutler said he will decide on July 26 whether to split up the trial -- one for the deputy editor and another for chief executive Elias Rusike and executive editor Trevor Ncube, both of whom pleaded innocent.

When the trial opened early this month all three accused conceded the stories were false but pleaded not guilty, saying they did not intend to defame anyone.

Other newspapers and magazines have reported that Mugabe secretly married Ms. Marufu, saying she had borne him two children before and after the death of his wife.

PANA Ziana EMM/NDN/JE 21July95

Africa News


July, 1995


Condoms Handed Out to Weekend Bathers


LENGTH: 347 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - Tunisia's Mediterranean beaches have long been hailed for sun, sea, sand and surf.

Now a fifth ingredient has been added -- condoms. 

The privately-funded Association against AIDS and Sexually Transmitted Diseases kicked of a nationwide campaign on Saturday by handing out the rubber protectives, free, to bathers at Sfax Beach some 275 kms southeast of Tunis.

It will spread to all Tunisia's east coast beaches through the northern hemisphere summer, administrators said.

It's the first campaign of its kind in Tunisia, an Arab nation dominated by Moslems, and it's rare in the Arab world where any form of birth control is frowned upon.

The association says it will start operating condom vending machines early next year.

Officials figures show that about 6 million condoms are used annually in this nation of some 8 million.

At mid-June, 586 HIV positive cases and 221 cases ofAIDS were reported in Tunisia.

17July1995

PANA 17Jul95

125 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


North, West and Eastern Africa Under Locust Threat


LENGTH: 627 words


 

by Peter Masebu, PANA Staff Correspondent

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Locusts that escaped survey and control in spring breeding areas of North-West Africa are bound to spread into Central and Southern Mauritania as well as in Northern parts of Mali and Senegal between now and mid-August.

The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) says two swarms that crossed into northern Senegal in late June and others have crossed the southern border of Mauritania into western Mali.

In a bulletin issued to PANA Friday, Fao said additional locust swarms were expected between now and mid-August in Central Mauritania and north Mali's Nioro and Nara areas. 

It predicted a few additional groups in the Adrar des Iforas and Tamesna and in western Mali where they will mature rapidly and lay with the onset of summer rains.

"By the end of the forecast period, hoppers bands are likely to form on a small scale," said the document, adding that locusts are expected to mature and lay rapidly in northern Niger's Tamesna and Air areas.

The destructive insects are also expected to appear in North Chad's Bet area with the onset of rains while a few additional adult groups and swarms of locusts are likely to appear in northern Senegal. These are expected to multiply rapidly with the onset of rains, FAO said.

Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Cape Verde, Gambia, Guinea-Bissau and Guinea Conakry are out of the locust threat.

In Algeria and Morocco, FAO predicts a further decline in locust infestation due to control and emigration as well as worsening ecological conditions for the insects.

However, the UN agency says adult locusts will persist in Algerian areas that might remain green, primarily near Adrar, in Salah and in the Wadis near Hoggar Mountains as well as in Morocco's Atlas Mountains.

In Eastern Africa, scattered groups of adult locusts are believed to be present in Sudan's northern Kordofan, northern Darfur and White Nile Provinces. Fao says laying is expected when rains start and that hoppers will be there by mid-August.

Scattered adults are expected in the few areas that receive rain in Eritrea's western lowlands and in northern Somalia's western coastal plains.

Djibouti, Ethiopia, Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania are out of danger during the forecast period.

However, following a locust invasion in the Lake Nakivale area of southwestern Uganda, the government of President Yoweri Museveni recently set up an Emergency Anti-Locust fund dotted with 300,000 US dollars.

PANA 17JULY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: August 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


July, 1995


Mali Licks Botswana 4-0


LENGTH: 294 words


 

BAMAKO, Mali (PANA) - The Malian national football team beat Botswana 4-0 Sunday in Bamako in the 9th elimination round of the 20th Africa Cup of Nations whose finals are due to be played in South Africa in January next year.

The Malian goals were scored by Djibril Diawara (11th and 46th minutes), Seyba Lamine Traore (49th minute) and Oumar Bagayogo (83nd minute). 

Despite this victory, Mali may still not qualify for the finals in South Africa.

The victory of Mozambique which is leading group six with (13 points) against second-placed Angola (12 points) Sunday in Maputo further complicates the situation for Mali, who are 3rd with 11 points.

The Malians will play their last match against Guinea on 30 July in Conakry. Coach Mamdou Keita still nurses hopes.

"We still think we can qualify. We are fighting for that, to the end", he said after the match against Botswana.

PANA 17Jul95

Africa News


July, 1995


Chiluba Spares Controversial Finance Minister


LENGTH: 600 words


 

by Mildred Mulenga and Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondents

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambian President Frederick Chiluba monday retained his embattled Finance Minister Ronald Penza, sacked Works and Supply Minister Andrew Kashita and re-assigned Foreign Minister Remmy Mushota.

Chiluba told a news conference in Lusaka that he had no reason to sack Penza, whose was roundly criticised for his handling of the collasped privately owned Meridien BIAO bank.

The new Foreign Minister is Lt.Gen. Criston Tembo, a former Zambian Army Commander under former President Kenneth Kaunda. The retired General was until Monday Minister of Tourism. 

Tembo's portfolio has been taken over by former Higher Education, Science and Technology Minister Gabriel Maka.

Also moved in the reshuffle is Information Minister Keli Walubita who now becomes Minister of Mines. He is succeeded by Amusa Wanamwabwa, formerly of legal affairs.

The full list of Zambia's cabinet is:Agriculture, Food and Fisheries - Simon Zukas

Vice-President - Brig. Gen. Godfrey Miyanda

Commerce, Trade and Industry - Dipak Patel

Transport and Communication - Dawson Lupunga

Community Development - Paul Kaping'a

Defence - Ben Mwila

Education - Alfeyo Hambayi

Energy and Water Development - Ms Edith Nawakwi

Environment and Natural Resources - William Harrington

Finance - Ronald Penza

Foreign Affairs - Lt. Gen. Christon Tembo

Health Michael - Sata

Home Affairs - Chitalu Sampa

Information - Amusa Mwanamwambwa

Others in the cabinet list are:

Labour and Social Security - Newstead Zimba

Lands - Luminzu Shimaponda

Legal Affairs - Remmy Mushota

Local Government - Bennie Mwiinga

Mines - Keli Walubita

Higher Education - Dr Kabunda Kayongo

Sport, Youth and Child Development - Lt.Col. Patrick Kafumukache

PANA 17Jul95

128 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Zambia Commissions Experts to Locate Meridien Boss


LENGTH: 627 words


 

by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambia has engaged security experts to trace fugitive former Meridien Bank BIAO Chief Executive Andrew Sardanis who is suspected of commiting fraud that led to the collapse last May of the local branch.

At a news conference here Monday, President Frederick Chiluba also confirmed that the government had requested expert financial investigators from a friendly country to conduct further inquire into the bank's financial scandal.

He did not name the friendly country but said the experts invited were expected to help bring culpits to book and retrieve public funds extended to the bank in an earlier futile bid to bail it out. 

"Government's main concern in the Meridien is to recover all government money and to make those responsible answerable," said Chiluba, who absolved his government of any blame in the collapsed bank's affair.

He insisted that shareholders had been responsible forthe bank's collaspe through defrauding depositors.

Chiluba had said last week that an initial audit reporthad indicated that some 90 billion Kwacha had been fraudently transfered to unidentified foreign accounts. (1$=915 Kwacha).

He conceded that government's attempt to bail out the bank had bust this year's national budget.

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) criticised the move and has since withheld further aid until government institutes other measures to raise additional local revenue to balance the budget.

But the President told newsmen his government was almost succeeding in keeping expenditure within limits of available revenue and that the IMF will be reviewing its assistance to the country this September.

Finance Minister Ronald Penza had early this year pumped some 8.4 billion kwacha into the cash-strapped privately-owned Meridien bank in a failed bid to salvage it.

He later announced its closure and that he was merging it with the government-owned Zambia National Commercial Bank (ZANACO).

The zambian cabinet over-turned the proposed merger, saying it was illegal.

The Meridien bank had been the fourth largest bank in Zambia with over 100 billion Kwacha worth of assets and about 40,000 depositors.

Last February, most depositors around the country closed their accounts following rumours of its financial crisis.

Sources within the collapsed bank have said that Sardanis, a Greek-Cypriot Zambian financier, had transfered large sums of money to Europe and America.

PANA 17Jul95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). 129 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Mauritania Inaugurates Butane Gas Filling Centre at Assaba


LENGTH: 360 words


 

KIFFA, Mauritania (PANA) - A butane gas depot filling centre was officially inaugurated Saturday at Kiffa, southern Mauritania, by the country's Water and Energy Minister, Mohamed Lemine Ould Ahmed.

With a capacity of 2,500 cubic metres, the complex has three reservoirs of 30 m3 each, a generator and a 47-m3 cistern. Construction work lasted nine months and

cost 85 million ouguiya (1usd = 130 ouguiya), totally funded by the Mauritanian Gas Company (SOMAGAZ).

According to the minister, the centre is capable of supply the Assaba disctrict with butane gas,thus enabling each household to save at least 15,000 ouguiya.

Lemine Ould Ahmed stressed in his speech that the generalised use of butane gas could reduce tree felling for charcoal.

A tonne of butane gas is equal to 10 hectares of forest, he explained.

Butane gas consumption in Mauritania rose from 5,000 tonnes in 1988 to 13,000 tonnes in 1994.

The construction of the gas depot centre in Kiffa follows the building of water and electricity distribution facilities. The minister said it is part of an "ambitious

programme aimed at improving the populations' standards of living".

PANA 17Jul95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

130 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


When African Ostriches Become Chinese


LENGTH: 400 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The 62 black ostriches transported from a north African desert two months ago to Qindao in northern China have reportedly rapidly acclimatized and some have even started laying eggs.

The African black ostrich, which weighs between 120 and kg by the first anniversary, is the biggest among the bird species and can live for 70 years. 

In a year, a female ostrich lays about 100 eggs, out of which only 50 to 60 of which hatch.

It is because of its rapid reproduction characteristics and longevity that several countries have imported the African ostrich which is also easy to tame, reported the Chinese News Agency 'Xinxhua' in a dispatch received by PANA.

Ostriches are famous for their meat which contains little fat and cholesterol and is rich in protein. Its skin makes good quality leather, characterised by its lightness, durability and beauty.

China currently has only 2,000 ostriches, but ostrich breeding is being encouraged under the 'Torch' research project on the virtues of the world's largest bird.

A first group of 36 ostriches imported from Southern Africa to north China's Shandong Province reportedly quickly adapted to the area's harsh weather.

The second biggest ostrich breeding centre in China is at Rongcheng.It cost about 2.5 million US dollars to establish and stretches over 40,000 square metres. It is only second to that of Guangdong in southern China.

PANA 17Jul95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

July, 1995


World Food Summit in the Pipeline


LENGTH: 294 words


 

ABIDJAN, Cote D'Ivoire (PANA) - The United Nations plans to hold a world summit on food next year in Rome, it has been announced here.

The proposed meeting was announced in the Ivorian capital of Abidjan Saturday night by the Director General of the Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO), Jacques Diouf, at a news conference to conclude a two-day visit. 

Without giving exact dates, Diouf told journalists the summit's main aim will be to sensitize world leaders on the very high risks of food crisis and famine.

While in Abidjan, the Senegalese FAO Director General held talks with Cote D'Ivoire's President Henri Konan Bedie.

He signed two agreements with the Ivorian government on exchange of experts among developping countries and the use of retired agricultural experts. A similar agreement was signed between FAO and Senegal recently when Diouf visited Dakar on his African tour.

PANA 17Jul95

132 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Zimbabwe Imports More Power from Zaire, Zambia


LENGTH: 614 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Persistent drought has obliged Zimbawe to double its power imports from neighbouring Zambia and Zaire to a total of 300 megawwats effective 1 July.

The electrical power imports are expected to enable the Zimbabwe Electricity Supply Authority (ZESA) maintain normal supply services following a drastic drop in Lake Kariba's water level from where most of the country's power is generated.

In a statement Friday, the power utility appealed for voluntary energy conservation measures by all consumers. 

"Efficient utilisation will not only assist in mitigating the adverse impact of the drought but also makes financial sense as customers can avoid unnecessarily high electricity bills," said ZESA.

In a normal year ZESA's Kariba South Power Station can provide at least one third of the country's requirements, the rest coming from the four thermal power stations at Hwange,in the northwest, Harare and Munyati in Central and Bulawayo, South Western Zimbabwe.

The Bulawayo power station's output has also been reduced to less than one third of its output due to water rationing.

ZESA said the Kariba River Basin recorded the worst rainfall this rainy season since the collection of records began on 1907.

Below average inflows have been recorded into the lake since the 1981/1982 season resulting in low reservoir levels at the Kariba hydro complex on the border with Zambia.

"As a result the energy available for both Zimbabwe and Zambia from the Kariba complex has to be a limited to a maximum of 4 000 gigawatt hours for the year 1995/96.

"This energy is shared equally between ZESA and ZESCO (Zambia Electricity Supply Commission). This leaves an energy deficit of 1 000 gigawatt hours for each utility for the year to be met from imports and energy conservation measures," said ZESA.

The current allocation would leave the Lake Kariba level at 476,6 metres by November 1995, about one metre above the minimum operating level of 475,5.

The new inter-connector between Insukamini in Zimbabwe and Matimba in South Africa, expected to come into service by December 1995 or January 1996 is also expected to mitigate the impact of the drought.

Meanwhile the Authority has so far spent 4.2 million US dollars) to refurbish its power line carrier (PLC) system which is used to transmit speech, telex, fax, control and equipment protection data to various generation and transmission centres.

PANA-ZIANA MUH/TM/PBM 14JULY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. 133 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Africa Weekly Press Review


LENGTH: 1934 words


 

by Kibaniakina M.N, PANA Correspondent

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA)- African newspapers this week swung their attention towards development needs, regional cooperation, the United Nations role in peacekeeping and the political scenario in Zaire.

The Ethiopian Herald said that in the 53 Organization of African Unity (OAU) member states, efforts made for development were being hampered by serious domestic conflicts whereas Ouagadougou's daily Le Pays contended the obstacles were caused by Western-imposed structural adjustment programmes.

Under the headline Peace for Development, the daily noted that "developments during the past few years show that conflict situations continue to occur at a speed greater than the capacity of peace forces to contain them".

"This is particularly true of Africa where new hotbeds of tensions breed with each passing time in spite of the commitment and resolute determination shown by African

countries to curb such a trend," it added.

The OAU, the paper declared, "has been created to bring peace and security in Africa within a global framework of development momentum." 

"Time has come for the OAU to embark on such a mission. Africa has suffered a lot and people can no longer bear the consequences of other bloody wars like that which is looming in Somalia and other countries," the daily said.

For the Addis Ababa based paper "undeniably, the issue of conflicts is the most pressing of all challenges facing Africa today."

The conflicts cast a "dark shadow over the prospects for a united, secure and prosperous Africa which we seek to create," said the Herald.

"Conflicts have already cost the continent enormously. Men, women and children have been uprooted, dispossessed, deprived of their means of livelihood and

thrown into exile," it added.

It denounced the "dehumanization of a large segmentof the African populations" by the conflicts. And it added that the situation was "unacceptable and cannot be allowed to continue "otherwise Africa will continue to be mired in

confusion and its people condemned to misery and suffering".

"It is the duty of the OAU and all peace forces to assist in bringing peace and restore hope to people," the Herald said.

It lauded the actions of the continental body and all other groupings which "made efforts to look for solutions to conflicts in the continent."

"The OAU leaders and all concerned groups have intervened constructively in conflict situations with a view to promoting their peaceful settlement," the Ethiopian paper

concluded.

In Kampala, the New Vision urged Kenya to appoint the Secretary-General of the East African Cooperation Secretariat for the region to revive the defunct East

Africa Community.

DAKAR, Senegal - According to the Ugandan state-owned daily Kenyan Foreign Affairs Minister Kilonzo Musyoka had "for the first time admitted over the weekend that it was Kenya which has delayed the appointment of the Secretary-General for the

Cooperation Commission."

Several months of consultations between Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania led to formal agreement to launch the bloc in Arusha, Tanzania, in March.

"This was the sign that leaders had pushed aside their differences and that the region had finally embarked on an irreversible march to the full revival of the still cherished, but defunct, East African Community," the Kampala paper said.

The paper said "Kenya's foot-dragging attitude towards this cherished goal, threfore, comes a slap in the face of the people of the region."

In Burkina Faso, the Le Pays neswpaper focused also on development in Africa commenting that the next visit of the new French head of State would be to some African countries.

"How to lay emphasis on democracy in Africa if the vital issue of economic development is not taken into account," said the paper in a editorial untitled Chirac and Useful Africa.

Sticking to the "unavoidable" Paris-Rabat-Dakar-Libreville axis, Chirac had not innovated relations with Africa as his predecessor had done, the paper said.

Like President Francois Mitterrand, Jacques Chirac chose to devote his first African visit to the countries where French interests are paramount.

Aid, the paper said, was conditioned by the strict observance by the Africans of the "injunctions" of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.

"In the name of wild liberalism which has created artificial barriers between economic, social, ideological and political issues adjustment plans have contributed to further impoverish the Africans," it noted.

The daily makes a "critical assessment" of that policy. The Bretton Woods Institutions, it said, "in encouraging export crops mainly to enable poor countries to pay their debts at the expense of food crops, have by the same token made any hope of food security vanish among the populations."

"Cash crops, which are bought at the lowest price, help develop some kind of international trade dominated by the deliberate will of Africa's external partners to get rich to its detriment," Le Pays concluded.

A Dakar daily, commenting on a decision by Zaire's parliament to extend the the transitional period by two extra years, was highly critical of the attitude of " a

radical opposition claiming for its right (approved by who?) to rule the country."

"After all," Wal Fadjri said, Presidewnt Mobutu Sese Seko demonstrated that westerners "often base their assessment of political situations obtaining in Africa on the stays which they offer to some opponents known for their rhetorical talents which they enjoy displaying in the African programmes of international radios."

DAKAR, Senegal - For the newspaper, "the transition had no effect on (Zairian) political life".

"The economic situation keeps getting worse" fraught with all sorts of possible "dangers", the independent daily said.

"When the discredit of the political class leave no one in doubt, uncontrolled revolts might well replace the secret talks Mobutu is having with his opposition. Then it would be too late to ensure a smooth transition to democratic institutions," Wal Fadjri (Dawn, in Arabic) concluded.

Under the title "Zaire: A New Crisis Defused?", the Burkina Faso daily Sidwaya observed that this country, which for five years had been shaken by "confusion, social unrest and political crisis" seemed to have escaped a new crisis following the two-year extension of the political transition period.

"Is Prime minister Kengo Wa Dongo going to stand firm in the face of the combined attacks of a coalition of the radical opposition and President Mobutu's barons?" the pro-government Ouagadougou paper wondered.

The head of government, " severely criticised by the opposition", according to its leading article, will attempt after all to restore the authority of the State in compliance with constitutional rules.

Marshal Mobuutu was "unmovable", the paper Journal du Jeudi, published in the same city, was happy to point out.

"With his thirty years of autocratic rule, Mobutu can decide to proclaim himself as the life president or even the emperor of Zaire and very few people would be surprised," the satirical Burkina Faso weekly added.

Elsewhere, the UN Secretary General's African tour could not have passed unnoticed in view of the fact that it is undertaken on the spur of "urgent questions that call for immediate decisions," according to the Senegalesedaily Le Soleil, quoting Boutros Boutros-Ghali himself.

Upon his arrival Thursday afternoon in Kigali, the UN leader could do nothing but to "note the failure, or at least, the total powerlessness of the world body, through the United Nations Mission in Rwanda (MINUAR)," another Dakar-based independent paper, Sud-Quotidien said.

This situation was at the origin of the "strong hostility" shown by Kigali towards the 5,500 UN soldiers MINUAR whose withdrawal was being asked by the "regime's strong man ", Paul Kagame, defence minister and vice-president, the paper commented.

Le Soleil said that of the countries Boutros-Ghali was visiting in Africa, none was "conspicuous for its audacity" except perhaps in Angola.

The daily compared the UN leader's role in Africa to the world body's influence in Bosnia.

"Mr. Boutros Boutros-Ghali visibly does not feel the war raging in Bosnia," the paper said.

"The man who, during the initial months of the conflict, had been the focus of the anger of Muslims by castigating what he called "a war of the wealthy", will not be held in greater esteem after its decision to continue its African tour," the semi-official Le Soleil added.

PANA PAP/KIB/PAP/JE 14July95

Africa News


July, 1995


Africa gets 2.5 Million Dollar From IFAD


LENGTH: 347 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) and the Organization of African Unity (OAU) Friday signed a grant agreement for 2.5 million US dollars agreement to help finance the second phase of the Agricultural Management Training Programme for Africa (AMTA II).

The six-year new programme will benefit 200 project managers, 1000 senior project staff, 1000 middle-level project staff, 1200 senior policy makers, 400 technical directors and 160 national trainers. 

An IFAD statement faxed to PANA Friday said the agreement was signed in rome by Mr Tawal Al Sultan, Fund's President and Prof. J.A. Ekpere,the Executive Secretary of OAU's Scientific, Technical and Research Commission (STRC) on behalf of the OAU Secretary General, Salim ahmed Salim.

AMTA was establihsed in 1984 to help increase the availability of trained African managers in the agricultural and rural development sector.

The programme's first phase from 1984 to 1992 covered 27 sub-saharan african countries, trained 700 people and benefited about 80 agricultural and rural development projects.

Mr Al-Sultan reiterated the importance of the second phase in creating what he described as the "critical mass" of managers and management trainers for the agricultural sector in the participating countries.

PANA PBM 14JULY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. 135 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Zambians to Debate Draft Constitution


LENGTH: 800 words


 

by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - A Zambian civic pressure group-Forum for Democratic Process (FODEP)- is this month to launch a public debate on the country's draft constitution ahead of its adoption by a Constituent Assembly.

FODEP Spokesma, Bishop John Mambo, said in Lusaka Friday that his organisation is currently distributing free copies of the draft in all the country's nine regions to acquaint the public with the proposed constitution before the formal debates.

The pressure group's first live studio discussion has been scheduled for 18 July in Lusaka for legal practioners. 

"We want as many Zambians as possible to understand the proposed constitution and make personal contribution to the final document," said Mambo today.

President Frederick Chiluba in November 1993 appointed a constitutional review commission to gather public evidence for a new constitution which he said should be non-partisan and "stand the test of time" and in line with the country's new multiparty political order.

The commission submitted its findings to the president last month after countrywide tours.

Some sections of the draft constitution have attracted heavy criticism from the opposition led by former President Kenneth Kaunda and other sections of the Zambian community.

Among the most controversial is the proposal that only Zambian-born citizens whose both parents were born in Zambia should in future qualify to hold the office of Republican president.

They have charged that the clause is specifically aimed at preventing Kaunda to contest the scheduled 1996 Presidential and General elections and that this sparked of discrimination against citizens of immigrant parentage.

Kaunda, who wants to challenge Chiluba in the forthcoming polls, was last june re-elected to lead his former ruling United National Independence Party (UNIP), currently the country's main opposition party.

Kaunda was born in Zambia by Malawian parents who had come to settle in northern Zambia at the close of the 19th century as missionaries of the Church of Scotland.

He has vowed to "fight to the bitter end" to block adoption of the discriminatory clause in the final constitution.

Chiluba's own ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) had in its submissions to the commission recommended that only "second generation Zambians" should hold the office of president to safeguard national integrity and sovereignty.

The draft has yet to be ratified by a Constituent Assembly and possible national referendum.

Meanwhile, traditionalists of the Barotse royal establishment in western region, which is agitating for autonomy, have also threatened to reject the new constitution unless their demand is met.

They are demanding the restoration of the 1964 "Barotse Agreement" which had guaranteed the area some administrative autonomy and a local treasury for the former British Protectorate in a new independent Zambia.

The agreement was signed by Kaunda, the British Foreign Office and the Lozi King as part of the terms for integrating the region into Zambia at independence in 1964.

Kaunda had himself abrogated the agreement and the new draft has recommended that Zambia shall remain a unitary state.

PANA MK/PBM 14JULY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

Africa News


July, 1995


Africa Urged to Introduce Satellite Education


LENGTH: 360 words


 

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe (PANA) - To keep pace with their developed counterparts in technological development, African countries have been advised to introduce satellite distance education.

The suggestion was made in Bulawayo, southwestern Zimbabwe, by a South African educationist, Dr Dawie de Villiers who described that type of teaching a cost effective, production time-saving manpower development concept. 

In a statement, de villiers, said satellite distance education was the only way African countries could compete with developed countries in keeping pace with

technological development.

The South African is expected as a guest at the Zimbabwe International Trade Fair's "Scholastica Exhibition" at the end of the month.

He said telecommunications technology was fast becoming essential in training methodology given the increasing need for accelerated manpower development demanded by ever changing business cultures.

"Economic pressures demand that employees remain productive while at the same time continuously developing new and additional skills and knowledge which necessitates a policy of taking training to the employees instead of vice versa," said Dr de Villiers.

PANA-ZIAN IM/MP/PBM 14JULY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. July, 1995


Massive Exam Fraud in Cote d'Ivoire


LENGTH: 307 words


 

ABIDJAN, Cote D'Ivoir (PANA) - Cote d'Ivoire's Education Ministry has ordered 67,750 of the 140,000 candidates in the Abdijan Region to re-seat this year's high school exams in Math, Physics, Natural Sciences, History and Geography because of

widespread fraud.

Making the order, the country's Education Minister, Prof. Pierre Kipre, said 80 of Abidjan Region's 112 examination centres participated in the cheating. 

The greatest number of cases were found in Yopougon, in the northern suburb of Abidjan, where 15 centres were affected.

A commission of enquiry set up by the inspector general's office at the education ministry "is working hard" to establish the origin of the leaks, said Pr Kipre at a news conference.

The minister denounced parents who helped their children in the exam cheating, adding that in future, examinations will be set on a regional basis to "reduce the risk of fraud".

PANA MK/AME/LMM/SJD/PBM 14JULY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. 138 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Algeria and Libya Sign Agreement


LENGTH: 400 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (Pana) - Algeria and Libya have signed in Algiers co-operation agreements in the fields of health, communications, culture and telecommunications.

At the end Tuesday of the 9th Session of their Joint Committee in the Algerian capital, the two neighbouring states also decided to step up reciprocal industrial investments,increase trade exchanges and to develop their respective border areas. 

According to a final communique released simultenously Wednesday in Algiers and Tripoli, the Algerian President, Liamine Zeroual, reaffirmed his country's support towards Libya over the 'Lockerbie' affair.

Libya is locked in a dispute with the United Sates, France and Britain which allege that its secret agents planted bombs which destroyes a PANAM passenger plane over Lockerbie, Scotland in December 1988 and a French UTA plane over Niger in 1989.

The three countries have demanded that the suspects be transfered to one of them for trial. However, Libya refused saying they cannot receive a fair court hearing.

These Western powers convinced the UN Security Council on 10 May 1992 to impose an air, military and diplomatic embargo against Libya.

The Algerian President pleaded for a negotiated settlement,stressing that sanctions imposed on Libya seriously affected the countries of the region and the Arab Maghreb Union (UMA), the communique added

The meeting was chaired by the Secretary of the Libyan People's Committee, Abdelmaguid Gaoude, and the Algerian Prime Minister, Mokdad Siffi.

July, 1995


Mali beat Guinea 91-72 in All Africa Games Qualifier


LENGTH: 294 words


 

by Mamadou Kouyate PANA Correspondent

BAMAKO, Mali (PANA) - The Malian men's basketball team beat Guinea 91-72 (49-26 at half-time) Tuesday in Bamako in the Zone II qualifying matches for the All Africa Games to be held from 13 to 23 September in Zimbabwe.

However, Mali's Coach Alassane Kanoute said after the match that "some of my players played below capacity while others thought they had won it and thus lost concentration". 

A former Malian international, Kanoute took over from Moussa Sogore who resigned on 10 July following a dispute with the team's management after they wanted to impose on him a central player, Habib Maiga.

Conceding defeat, the Guinean coach said "the Malian victory was logical.Individually and collectively, they were superior to us", he commented.

The secound round of the tournament on Wednesday will feature matches between Mali and Senegal (women), as well as Senegal and Guinea (men).

PANA MK/IS/LMM/SJD 12JULY95

Africa News


July, 1995


Foot and Mouth Disease Breaks Out in Zambia


LENGTH: 254 words


 

by Musengwa Kayaya PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Foot and mouth cattle disease has broken out in the Livingstone area of Southern Zambia, according to veterinary officials in Lusaka Wednesday.

Senior Veterinary Officer Bruce Mukanda said today that vaccination teams had been sent to the area to treat affected animals and that precautionary measures had been instituted to prevent the disease from spreading to other parts of the country. 

Botswana has since announced a ban on the importation of beef and beef products from Zambia following the outbreak two weeks ago.

Officials at the Export Board of Zambia (EBZ) which coordinates non-traditional exports said in Lusaka Tuesday that Gaborone had informed them the ban will stand until the disease was brought under control.

Mukanda confidently told PANA Wednesday that his department had mobilised adequate resources to contain the outbreak within the shortest possible time.

Although Botswana exports a lot of beef and beef products, it also buys substantial quantities of them from Zambia.

PANA MK/PBM 12JULY95

July, 1995


French Envoy Visits Congo


LENGTH: 334 words


 

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo (PANA) - French President's Adviser on African affairs Fernand Wibaux Tuesday made a brief visit here for a meeting with Congo's Head of State, Pascal Lissouba.

The envoy told reporters later that he had brought the Congolese leader "a message of friendship in which President Jacques Chirac wanted to express his feelings towards Africa and provide help within the limitations of our means". 

"Africa will not be forgotten in the actions which President Chirac intends to carry out," he added.

But Congo is not among African countries to be visited by Mr Chirac on his first African tour from 19 to 23 July.

He is scheduled to visit Cote D'Ivoire, Gabon and Senegal.

France, through its oil company,elf, has major stakes in Congo's Petroleum industry.

At one time two years ago, France battled it out to make sure President Lissouba cancelled an oil- extraction deal his government had entered with an American oil company, Oxy.

The American company had given Lissouba's political party an advance payment which enabled it to win the elections.

142 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Benin Worthy of Closer Ties with U.S.


LENGTH: 680 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Benin has become a "wedge for American ideas in Francophones West Africa" and is worthy of closer political and trade ties with America, the U.S. ambassador to that country, Ruth Davis, told reporters Tuesday on the eve of the Beninese President's visit to Washington D.C..

"Benin has modeled its government after American models", Davis was quoted as telling reporters at foreign Press Center in Washington.

"I think that is very important because it has given them a different and a broader perspective on issue related to government. I think that will help the country flourish in terms of their effort for creating a very stable democracy". 

'Wireless File' a news bulletin of the U.S. Information Servie made available to PANA quoted Davis as saying "not only has Benin become a wedge for american ideas in francophone west Africa, it is also a potentially fertile market for U.S. investment and export".

She said President Soglo will be seeking more American Investment during his July 12 to 15 Visit, which includes talks with President Bill clinton.

Investments in the areas of oil, gas, agriculture, fisheries, and textiles, are especially welcome, Davis noted.

While Benin currently has a "weak industrial base", Davis told reporters, the country is "working towards solving" all of its problems in that area.

While having a population of only about five million, Benin is especially important, she stressed, because it stands at the "crossoads between Francophone and Anglophone West Africa".

Benin is also important to the United States because it is a longtime ally, closely cooperating with the WAshinton on issues of inportance in the international community and in the areas of cultural links as well.

"In the height of the slave trade, one and a half million slaves, at least, were taken from the coast of Benin, that means that in the United States, there is a decisive cultural link with African-Americans and the Beninese, and the Beninese are very proud of that link...", Davis said.

"They want to exploit and encourage trade and cultural relationships that enhance that very important linkage", she added.

Davis said benin is especially impressive because "it has taken on economic and political reform -- and has been successful" at streamlining its governement bureaucracy and military, revising its investment codes, improving the management of public finances, and restructuring the country's banking system.

"After 17 years of a Marxist-Leninist regime, the whole place was in complete collapse... it so collapsed, as a matter of fact, that I think that they were... able to make a peaceful transition (to democracy) -- which is the thing that we are so proud of".

Davis also said she would like to see more emphasis being given to the success stories in Africa than to the non-success stories adding, "I think we have a success story to tell when we talk about Benin".

PANA CWC/IS/FON 12July95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

143 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Lusaka to Host Meeting on Angolan Refugees Repatriation


LENGTH: 507 words


 

by Mildred Mulenga PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Representatives from Angola, Zambia and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) are to meet here 20 July to arrange the repatriation of Angolan refugees.

UNHCR's Representative in Zambia Abou Moussa told PANA Wednesday the three-day meeting will, among other issues, discuss the modalities of the repatriation exercise planned to start in July next year.

The UN refugee agency has said there are over 100,000 Angolans in Zambia's Western and Northwestern regions.They left their country to escape a civil war which has been raging since 1975. 

About 30,000 of them are accommodated at Meheba refugee camp in Northwestern Zambia.

Moussa had said recently that the success of the repatriation exercise would depend on how seriously the belligerents- the Angolan government and the former rebel National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA)- take the peace agreement they signed late in 1994.

Under the agreement brockered by the UN in Lusaka, the warring sides pledged to observe a ceasefire to end almost two decades of civil war since the country's independence from Portugal in 1975.

UNITA leader Jonas Savimbi has reportedly agreed to become one of the two vice presidents to President Jose Eduardo Dos Santos in a proposed new government of national unity.

The move is part of efforts to foster national reconciliation after the civil war described by the international community as the bloodiest on the continent.

Over one million Angolans are estimated to have died and thousands maimed in the conflict.The UN says about three million others have been displaced and need immediate humanitarian aid, including food and medicines following the ceasefire.

The world body is to deploy a 7,500-strong peacekeeping force, including civilians, to oversee the pacification process.

PANA MM/MK/PBM 12JULY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Africa News


July, 1995


Mandela Addresses Lesotho Parliament


LENGTH: 654 words


 

by Leloko Mohale PANA Staff correspondent

MASERU, Lesotho (PANA) - Visiting South African President Nelson Mandela says closer cooperation between Lesotho and South Africa remains one of the priorities of the Government in Pretoria.

Mandela made the assertion on Wednesday when addressing the Joint Session of the Lesotho parliament shortly after his arrival in the Southern African mountain kingdom, which is completely surrounded by South Africa.

The President who is on a two-day State visit to Lesotho said both countries need to cooperate closely. 

"It applies to trade and industry, job creation, economic growth, educational and cultural exchanges, agricultural cooperation, transfer of technology and stability within this region," Mandela said.

South Africa was mindful of strife faced by Basotho migrant mineworkers, he said, adding that the risks should be reduced.

"For this reason one of the main areas of official south african development assistance to lesotho is in the retraining of retrenched mineworkers," he added.

Mandela said the extradition treaty signed last month between the two countries was just one example of their common resolve to fight crime. This should reinforce the effort of the combined security forces in combating cross border stock theft and drug trafficking.

He noted that the multi-billion highlands water project between Lesotho and South Africa stands as a towering example of cooperative infrastructural development. "It will if completed and managed according to plan, bring immense benefits to each country," he observed.

Lesotho and South Africa have joint multi- billion water projects, whereby Lesotho will supply South African industrial heartland of Gauteng province with water.

According to Mandela, South Africa was pleased to have been able to contribute, along with other Southern African states, to the peaceful resolution of differences which threatened to undermine democracy in Lesotho last year.

He thanked the Basotho Nation for the support and understanding of the South African people's struggle. They will not forget the sacrifices that Lesotho had to endure during those years, he added.

"For the succuor you gave to our sons and daughters, for your solidarity and self-less commitment to our freedom, you paid a fearful price," Mandela said.

Mandela is due to meet with political parties later on Wednesday. He departs for home Thursday after laying wreaths at the graves of African National Congress (ANC) members who were brutally killed by the apartheid South African Defence force in Maseru on 9 December 1992.

PANA LM/FON 12July95

145 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Telecoms Far From Satisfactory, Says Mugabe


LENGTH: 734 words


 

MAZOWE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - President Robert Mugabe said on Wednesday despite progress made so far, Zimbabwe's telecommunications needs are immense and far from being met.

Mugabe, who was commissioning the Zimdollars 113 million (USD 13.3 million) second Mazowe earth satellite station, said, however, the telephone penetration rate of 1.32 per 100 subscribers was better than that of most African countries.

"Although our penetration rate of 1.32 is better than the average african telephone density, it is still well below the level required for economic development. 

"Eeven after the planned major investment of ZD 6.5 billion (USD 764 million) is realised by the year 2,000, there will still be a gap between supply and demand," said Mugabe.

He said other means of accelerating investment in the sector had to be found. Mugabe also called on the posts and telecommunications corporation (PTC) to pay attention to the quality of its service.

"There have been numerous complaints that our system has too many faults and cases of inaccurate bills and misdirected calls due to crossed lines," said Mugabe.

Zimbabwe's first earth satellite station was commissioned in August 1985 and operates to the Atlantic ocean's region satellite covering countries in western and central Europe, United States, the United Kingdom and Canada.

The second satellite will enable Zimbabwe to communicate directly with countries in the indian ocean region instead of going through third party countries, an exercise which Mugabe said was expensive.

"We will now be able to link up directly with astern countries such as Japan, China, Indonesia, Malaysia and Australia as and when agreements are reached with the governments of these countries.

"The transit costs will now be reduced substantially as direct links are set up with these countries," said Mugabe.

He said the countries of south-east Asia had economic importance.

"They are the fastest growing economies in the world and they have managed to break loose from the vicious circle of under development," Mugabe said.

Addressing the same function, Inforomation, Posts and Telecommunications Minister, David Karimanzira said the PTC had set a target 40,000 lines to be connected in Zimbabwe in the coming calendar year in order to achieve the goals set for the year 2,000.

The goals included the improvement of the penetration rate to 2.77 telephone lines per 100 by the year 2,000.

"Once achieved, this would wipe out the current waiting list of over 100,000 customers within the same period. thereafter the PTC will be able to supply services on demand," said Karimanzira.

He said the vision of the PTC was to build a network that not only catered for the basic telephone needs, but also offered a variety of top end commercial services.

"I am confident that this is achievable given the envisaged policy shifts and strategies which have been identified by the corporation," said Karimanzira.

PANA-ZIANA TM/MP/NDN/FON12July95

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). July, 1995


Zambian Families Evacuated From Shaba


LENGTH: 347 words


 

by Musengwa Kayaya PANA Staff Correspondent

Lusaka, Zambia (PANA) - Zambia's foreign ministry has evacuated families of diplomatic staff at its Consulate in Lubumbashi, capital of Zaire's Southern Shaba Region in the wake of reported political disturbances in the area, the official Zambia News Agency (ZANA) has reported.

It quoted the Pwermanent Secretary in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Amon Chibanda as saying that women and children of Zambian diplomatic staff had last saturday been moved to nearby copperbelt region for safety. 

Chibanda could not immediately give details of the feared troubles of the politically volatile Shaba province but Zambian immigration officials at the northern border post of Kasumbalesa have of late reported of a large influx of zaireans crossing into Zambia.

The Zairean government in Kinshasa early this year recalled the Shaba governor reportedly following information that he was a sympathiser of a secessionist movement agitating for autonomy for the mineral-rich region.

A secession bid in the early 60s by late Moise Tshombe sparked off civil war in the country then known as Belgian Congo.

The Zairean embassy in Lusaka could not comment on the present situation in the region.

July, 1995


Political parties, Unions gagged


LENGTH: 427 words


 

by Amadou Oumar Seydou PANA Staff Correspondent

NIAMEY, Niger (PANA) - The Supreme Council on Communication (CSC) in Niger has forbidden any comment on public or private radio stations of statements by political parties, trade unions or associations on ongoing political crisis in the country.

The ban is to prevent incidents which could "exacerbate the very high social and political tension" or "harm national unity" in the West African State, according to a government statement broadcast Tuesday in Niamey.

The CSC, which regulates public and private media activities, said the ban will last "until the institutional crisis in Niger came to a happy end". 

The broadcast recalled that on Thursday last week, the Head of State refused to preside over the Council of Ministers meeting which was to examine appointments of managing directors of public companies and general secretaries in districts.

The refusal was aimed at "blocking" the institutions, "hampering economic recovery, and prevent the signing of agreements with international financial institutions, it added.

In protest against the President's action, Prime Minister Hama Amadou suspended the managing directors appointed by the presidential coalition when it had majority in parliament, in disregard of presidential prerogatives.

Riot police are still on guard at the head offices of several state companies to implement the suspension order issued by the Prime Minister.

Parliament speaker Mahamadou Issoufou, received at an audience Tuesday afternoon by the president, has started mediation efforts between the two parties.

PANA AS/IS/SG/SJD/FON 12July95

Africa News


July, 1995


SADC Trade Unionists Meet


LENGTH: 427 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (ZIANA) - Southern African trade union leaders are meeting in Harare this week to discuss the implications of regional economic integration on the labour movement.

The five-day meeting, which began in Harare on Tuesday, brings together over 25 trade union leaders, economists and health and safety workers from the 11 member countries of the southern african development community (SADC).

Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Union (ZCTU) Secretary-General Morgan Tsvangirayi said the trade unionists would discuss ways of strengthening the labour movement in each of the SADC countries. 

"We are looking at the regional economic integration taking place now and the introduction of free trade in most economies in the region, and how these affect the labour movement, which is at different stages of development in the sadc countries and should be brought to the same level," he said.

When established, it was the duty of trade union leaders to ensure that its policies were accepted in the different countries.

The workshop would look at policies on aids and employment based on the code of practice adopted by the SADC labour desk. it was also expected to develop a regional programme of action to support national and regional priorities.

The workshop is hosted by the Southern African Trade Union Co-ordinating Council (SATUCC).

Countries represented are Angola, Botswana, Namibia, Malawi, Tanzania, South Africa, Mozambique, Lesotho, Swaziland, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

Public Service, Labour and Social Welfare Minister, Nathan Shamuyarira will speak at the workshop on Friday.

PANA-ZIANA FS/NDN/FON 12July95

Africa News


July, 1995


Government Steps Up Bid To Cage Kaunda


LENGTH: 614 words


 

by Mildred Mulenga PANA staff correspondent

Lusaka, Zambia (PANA) - The Zambian government Wednesday dissolved the National Health Immunization Committee a day after it ordered the closure of a Technical College, all in a bid to minimize former President Kenneth Kaunda's influence in the polity.

Health Minister Michael Sata charged in Lusaka Wednesday that Kaunda had infiltrated the Immunization Committee and was distorting information on figures of childrens' deaths for political purposes.

The former President is said to have obtained figures which showed that more children were dying of malnutrition and preventable diseases in Zambia from a senior member of his United National Independence Party (UNIP) who serves on the Committee. 

"The government will take tough measures if Kaunda continues to disturb our programmes," said Sata who added that the new Committee will now comprise sympathisers of the ruling Movement For Multiparty Democracy (MMD) of President Frederick Chiluba and Non-Governmental Organisations (NGOS).

On Tuesday authorities ordered the immediate closure of Northern Technical College (NORTEC) in the northern copperbelt town of Ndola following monday's student's riot, said to have been precipitated by Kaunda's "secret visit" to the institution last June.

A statement from the Ministry of Science and Technology in Lusaka said that Monday's disturbances at the college were mainly caused by an unauthorised visit to the campus by Kaunda on 17 June.

The statement said that investigations by college authorities revealed that student union leaders and Kaunda's party supporters had organised the secret meeting for Kaunda to talk to the students.

There were no details of what Kaunda had told the students who on Monday damaged college property while protesting alleged poor diet.

Kaunda is campaigning to challenge chiluba in Presidential elections scheduled for 1996.

He was recently reported to have said that many Zambian children were dying of malunutrition and other "poverty-related diseases" due to the high cost of living caused by the government's Structural Adjustment Programme (SAP).

Kaunda has targetted university and college students including retrenchees, among other groups, in his campaigns promising that he could create jobs for them if he came back to power.

Chiluba's government is pursuing the IMF-driven adjustment involving privatisation and liquidation of government firms which has led to hundreds of workes being thrown out of jobs.

PANA MM/MK/FON 12July95

July, 1995


RANGOLD May Up Invesment in Senegal


LENGTH: 454 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - South Africa's Mining Conglomerate, RANGOLD, says it would invest as much as 250,000,000 dollars in its Mining operations in the West African State of senegal, if initial investment in the sector proves rewarding.

"Mineral exploration is a time-consuming venture which requires big money, equipment and Labour", the company's Managing Director, Mark Brisatow told a Senegalese News Agency (APS) reporter in Dakar at the Week-end.

RANGOLD is has been engaged inthe exploration of precious metals at Souroumdou in the Kedougou area of South-Eastern Senegal in collaboration with a local company -- the Senegalese Transaltlantic-West Africa Transport Company (CSTTAO). 

Initial investment in the venture was not specified but could range between 500,000 and 1,000,000 US Dollars.

"There are no activities as conducive to a country's development as the mining sector. If the mining sector develops, the country follows suit", Bristow said.

He said the company, which entered into an agreement with the Senegalese Government on 24 September 1994, does not rule out the possibility of spending up to 250,000,000 dollars if ongoing operations proved rewarding.

Bristow said since the positive development of the political situation in his country, he had decided to put his company's century-long experience in mining at the disposal of Partners in West Africa.

RANGOLD has been studying the Mining laws of Senegal, Mali, Ghana, Cote D'Ivoire, Niger, Guinea and Burkina Faso, where small scale mining had been going on for years with less sophisticated equipment.

RANGOLD, said to rank sixth among South African mining firms, produces 45 tonnes of gold each year and employs 27,000 persons.

PANA-APS MD/CTN/KIB/PAP/FON 11July95

Africa News


July, 1995


Sudanese Doctor Defends Quinine


LENGTH: 440 words


 

by Yahya El Hassan PANA Staff Correspondent

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - Contrary to past suspicions that the increase in cases of kidney failure in Sudan was due to overuse of quinine, a doctor has confirmed here the drug actually cures the disease.

A Pharmacologist at Khartoum University's Faculty of Medicine, Dr Omar Zayed, recently told a medical gathering here that many of the reported kidney failure cases resulted from acute malaria rather than the intensive use of quinine as some people had been led to believe.

"Chloroquin is an effective drug for the treatment of malaria and should not be done away with unless the plasmodium virus causing malaria proves to be very resistant to it,"he said. 

"After a review of all what had been written about the malarial drugs , I have discovered that none of them causes kidney failure In fact,studies have revealed that kidney failure could be the cause of long-neglected malaria,especially acute malaria," Dr.Zayed told his audience.

He said that quinine was in fact, a life saving medicine in case of malarial complications ,including kidney failures.

Dr. Zayed further explained that "to save the victim of acute malaria accompanied with kidney failure ,we should give him quinine and only quinine."

"This is contrary to the old theory that quinine causes kidney failure ," Dr.Zayed told the symposium on "Malaria and The Kidney", organized by the Association of Sudanese Internist Doctors last week.

He said local studies have proved no direct link between quinine and kidney failures.

"Quinine was in fact found to be very useful and safe in the treatment of patients operated for kidney transplants ,"he asserted.

PANA YH/PBM 12JULY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

July, 1995


Burundian President Visits Zaire


LENGTH: 307 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi (PANA) - Burundian president Sylvestre Ntibantunganya left Bujumbura on Wednesday for Gbadolite, Zaire, on a two-day official visit, according to a statement from the President's office.

The statement did not indicate the objective of of the visit, Ntibantunganya's fourth in Zaire this year. 

But observers say it may not be unconnected with the situation of hundreds of thousands of Burundian refugees who fled the bloody ethnic fighting in their country in October 1993.

What to do with rebels of the majority hutu population who infliltrated the camps and launch sporadic raids into Burundi, especially in the border province of Cibitoke (Northwest) may also feature at talks between the two presidents.

Violent clashes recently took place between Zaireans and the refugees at the Ruvunji camp, in the South Kivu region of eastern Zaire.

About one hundred refugees died in the clashes, according to the Burundian Minister of Home Affairs and Public Security, Gabriel Sinarinzi.

PANA FB/LMM/SJD/FON 12July95

Africa News


July, 1995


Mortality Higher Infant Mortality in Luanda's Sambizanga


LENGTH: 214 words


 

LUANDA, Angola (PANA) - The maternity ward in Luanda's Sambizanga slum area recorded higher infant mortality rates in the first quarter of 1995 compared with the same period last year.

The maternity's Chief Obstetrician, Mrs Julia de oliveira, said 20 deaths were recorded among the 73 newly born children during the period. 

She said that 87 other serious cases were transfered to the main "Augusto Ngangula" maternity ward in the angolan capital.

She attributed the high infant death toll to the inadequate supply of amniotic fluids among pregnant women.

PANA-ANGOP ADR/ZL/PBM 12JULY95

154 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Chiluba Orders Probe in Meridien Bank Swindle


LENGTH: 507 words


 

by Musengwa Kayaya PANA Staff Correspondent

Lusaka, Zambia (PANA) - President Frederick Chiluba has instituted further investigations into alleged massive fraud which led to the collapse of Meridien BIAO Bank in Zambia, while the release of an earlier investigation is expected next week.

A Spokesman in the President's office said Tuesday Chiluba will Address a Press Conference on the Meridien Bank Saga on 17 July.

The International Monetary Fund (IMF), which is backing Zambia's Economic Recovery programme said last month it was withholding further aid to Lusaka until it rectified certain mistakes in the implementation of the Structural Adjustment Programme (SAP). 

The IMF particularly criticised government's subventions to the Meridien in a futile bid to bail out the privately-owned bank as breach of one of its conditions for aid.

Finance Minister, Ronald Penza, earlier this year pumped in some 8 billion kwacha (About 8 million dollars) into the Meridien to save the cash-strapped financial institution.

His decision later to merge the troubled bank with the government-owned Zambia National Commercial Bank was rejected by the Cabinet as illegal and ill-advised.

The cabinet has also directed the Central Bank to retrieve all public funds, estimated by some independent sources at 50 billion kwacha (about 50 Million dollars), from the ill-fated bank.

An initial audit report published Wednesday said that the bank had been defrauded of 90 billion kwacha (About 90 Million Dollars) partly due to mismanagement. Some fraudulent share-holders were also said to have transferred large sums to unidentified foreign accounts.

The "Meriedien scandal" had led to calls, from both the opposition and some government leaders for Penza's resignation.

Chiluba, who some critics have accused of personal collusion with Penza in the bank's saga has not commented on the affair.

PANA MK/PM/FON 12July95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. 155 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Healers Call to Modify Zimbawean Traditional Practices


LENGTH: 654 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwean traditional healers and leaders in Zimbabwe have been urged to spearhead the battle of changing some cultural practices, such as polygamy, to promote safe sexual behavior.

Speaking Monday here at a workshop on aids, the Zimbabwe National Traditional Healers Association (ZINATHA) President, Gordon Chavunduka, said while some local cultural practices, such as widow inheritance, were not easy to discard, they could be modified.

The one-day workshop was convened to facilitate networking among organisations involved in aids prevention and care efforts in the country. 

Chavunduka said rather than discourage widow inheritance, the use of condoms among such couples could be encouraged and non-sex inheritance can also be advocated for.

He said instead of trying to stop polygamy, safe sex practices within a polygamous union could be emphasised.

The ZINATHA President said while there were isolated cases of traditional healers charging patients exorbitant consultation fees, many of them charged nothing or very little.

He said the association discouraged its members from charging high prices and those found to be doing so were brought before a disciplinary committee.

The majority of traditional healers, he said, remained poor because they charged very little for their services, yet they were providing a vital service to the community.

"Many traditional healers do not charge at all for their services because they feel they are providing a community service. That is why traditional healers are very poor yet they run "surgeries", said Chavunduka.

Although the relationship between modern health practitioners and traditional healers had improved, Chavunduka said there was still very little understanding by modern practitioners of the importance of the spiritual dimensions of traditional healing.

"There is the tendency among modern practitioners and academics to ignore or trivialise the spiritual aspects of traditional healers' work," he said.

He said the difference in opinion regarding the cause of certain illnesses was one of the reasons ZINATHA recently rejected the proposed health professions bill.

Chavunduka said the proposed integration of traditional and modern medicine at the proposed levels would undermine the traditional healers.

The Zimbabwe Health Ministry has in recent years involved traditional healers in the treatment of aids patients.

The traditional healers later claimed they had reversed some of the aids symptoms among some of the patients they were given.

However, the Ministry said none of such patients had tested negative of the HIV virus which leads to aids, after attending clinics run by the healers.

PANA-ZIANA MUH/NDN/PBM 12JULY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

Africa News


July, 1995


Sudan Accuses Egypt of harassing Diplomats


LENGTH: 440 words


 

by Yahya El Hassan PANA Staff Correspondent

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - Sudan has accused Egyptian authorities of renewed harassment of its diplomats at the embassy in Cairo.

In a statement issued here Tuesday, Khartoum's Foreign Ministry claimed Egyptian authorities have since Sunday been trailing and threatening the Sudanese military attache and three Counsellors in Cairo.

The statement alleged that an Egyptian securityman deliberately rocked the car of one of the counsellors while he was on his way home . 

Early last year, Sudan had complained that accused the Egyptian security of provoking and harassing staff at its Cairo embassy.

Today's statement said "the Egyptian security that used to harass and beat members of the Sudan diplomatic mission in the past,are now taking a new course ,they have started harassing wives of diplomats via telephone calls and by keeping a continuous presence in front of the houses of diplomats and using obsene language whenever they caught sight of any one of the diplomats' wives."

"The "Egyptian regime should shoulder its responsibility towards the security of the Sudanese diplomats and stop those irresponsible provocations immediately," it added.

Relations between Sudan and Egypt have seriously deteriorated since 26 June when an attempt was made to assassinate President Hosni Mubarak in Addis Ababa where he had gone for the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) summit.

Egypt immediately accused Sudan's islamic government of Gen. Omar Bashir of being behind the plot. Khartoum denied the accusations.

The two countries have even exchanged fire along their common border in the Halayib Region whose ownership is still claimed by both.

PANA YH/PBM 11JULY95

Africa News


July, 1995


Call for Higher Investment in Women


LENGTH: 694 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA) has called for increased investment in people, gender equity and equality, saying they are the key factors to achieving sustainable development and poverty eradication.

UNFPA said this in a report to mark this year's World Population Day on Tuesday, which stressed the need for more equality between women and men to end poverty and improve the overall standard of living worldwide.

The document said women should have more control and fewer health risks associated with reproduction and sexuality in order to have better health and the freedom to choose whether and when to have children. 

"Investing in people, in broadening their opportunities and enabling them to realise their potential as human beings is the key to sustained development, as well as to balanced, sustainable population growth.

"Empowering women is an important end in itself, as well as a key to improving the quality of life of everyone. without full and equal participation of women, there can be no sustainable human development," it said.

The theme of the report is 'Gender Equity and Reproductive Health', concepts which were central to the agreement reached in cairo at last year's International Conference on Population and Development.

Gender equity and reproductive health are expected to be high on the agenda of the Fourth World Conference on Women to be held in Beijing, China, in September.

While levels of education had risen and the gap between males and females narrowed, there were still 960 million illiterate people worldwide, of which two thirds were women and some 130 million children, including some 90 million girls who were denied access to primary education.

The report said there should be equal access to training, credit, property, natural resources, education and better-paying jobs between men and women.

"These inequalities must be redressed to fulfil women's human rights and enable countries to progress towards sustainable development.

"Towards this end, all forms of discrimination should be outlawed and opposed in civic life, traditional laws and practices which enforce women's subordination must be challenged," it said.

The report said there was need to set a minimum age of marriage to protect young women from dangers of early child-bearing and allow them to take advantage of options beyond motherhood.

In most developing countries women often have one role in society, which is reproduction.

The report said one way to empower women was through education, which is "the most important intervention to break the vicious cycle of low status, poverty and large families

"There is a direction connection between education for girls and women's ability to escape from poverty, education also encourages later marriage and greater use of contraception."

PANA FZ/NDN/PBM 11JULY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

Africa News


July, 1995


European Loan


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Dakar, Senegal (PANA) - The European Investment Bank (EIB), has agreed to provide a total of 30 million ecu (about 37.2 million u.s. dollars) to Ivorian state-owned national oil company of Cote d'Ivoire (Petroci), to prospect and explore oil wells in the the west African country.

According to an EIB release made available to PANA, the loan will help execute the first phase of a project tagged 'lion panther' involving oil wells discovered some 13 km off the shores of Abidjan. 

The entire project is estimated to cost 156 million ecu (about 194 million dollars) of which Petroci is expected to provide 54 milion ecu, the release said.

Apart from eib's contribution, Petroci's participation is being met with 13.5 million ecu from Citibank Abidjan and the West African Development Bank, and 10,5 million ecu from Petroci's own resources, it added.

Established in 1958 by the Treaty of Rome, the EIB finances capital investment projects which further European Union policy objectives among member-satates and within the 70 Africa, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) states associated to the EU.

Development of the Ivorian oil and gas gas deposits will enable Abidjan to reduce imports resulting in substantial savings of foreign exchange. Furthermore, the use of gas to generate electricity will help bring down costs and foster the government's economic recovery plan.

Petroci was established in 1975, to prospect and exploit oil wells off the Atlantic Coast.

PANA IS/FON 11JULY95

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). Africa News


July, 1995


Government Orders Probe on llegal Immigration by Gabu Amacha, PANA staff correspondent


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Addis Ababa, Ethiopia (pana) - Ethiopian authorities have ordered foreigners who entered the country illegally to report to the Department of Immigration and Refugee Affairs within 30 days, warning that legal action would be taken against those who fail to meet the deadline.

"There are many foreigners who entered the country illegally and live in the country without permission or without going through the proper procedures", the department said in a statement.

It added that foreigners living in Addis Ababa, the capital, were involved in business activities without acquiring licences or paying tax. 

The statement carried over state radio Monday night did not give any reasons for the order, but warned that strict measures would be taken against those who were involved in activities that contravene the laws of the country.

Observers say the order may not be unconnected with the failed attempt to assassinate Egyptian president Hosni Mubarak when he arrived in the Ethiopian capital to attend a summit of the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) on 26 June.

Two of the gunmen who sprayed Mubarak's armour-plated car with bullets were killed on the spot along with two Ethiopian security agents.

Addis Ababa said days later that three other suspected assailants were killed during a gun battle with police in their hide-out on the outskirts of the capital.

Ethiopian authorities said all the five gunmen killed were Egyptians adding that it was not clear how they entered the country.

The statement also warned Ethiopians against doing business with foreigners without valid residence or business permits.

Public and administrative bodies at various levels were called upon to cooperate with the new initiative to stem illegal immigration and crime in the country.

PANA GA/FON 11JULY95 = 07111013 LKP017
