160 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


How Long Will Our Luck Hold?


LENGTH: 654 words


 

The Monitor

July 10 - 12, 1995

Editorial -- Uganda's coffee industry is in shock because of the bad news from world market that the price of the commodity has suddenly collapsed.

On Friday (July 7) the London Commodity Exchange closed with coffee futures down to $2,080 (Shs 2m) a tonne from a nine-month high of $4,140 (Shs 4m).

Though the Uganda Coffee Exporters Association Executive Director, Frederick Mulimira Kawuma, put a brave face to this disaster when he said that the plunge in prices was temporary, only a repeat of last year's drought and frost in Brazil can turn prices around. Unfortunately, so far, the speculators have been confounded. 

To compound the problem at the moment, Brazil, the world's biggest coffee producer, and Columbia, another significant Latin American producer, don't want to hear anything about managing prices by the producers cartel. And without the two, any hopes of shoring up prices through stringent quotas application are dashed.

This collapse should be an eye opener to the government which has been lately crowing about Uganda being the thirteenth fastest growing economy in the developing world.

That phenomenal statistic was partly the result of the windfall raked in by coffee exports. It is more likely that the following year Uganda may drop off that top 15 UN listing -- of go up.

Sustainable growth cannot rest on the mercies of weather. Our economy is still too susceptible to natural disasters. For example, in fiscal year 1993/94, the drought and famine in the East and the North poured water on growth trends.

It's not even certain that Uganda's efforts to privatise and attract foreign investors will bear handsome dividends. Most investors are out for a quick return on their capital because long-term political and economic stability -- in Uganda as in most of Africa -- is shaky.

Bureaucratic red tape and the still poor state of basic infrastructure such as electricity and communication are still serious hurdles for investors. And unlike the economies of Southeast Asia where skilled labour is an investment attraction, here we can only offer "cheap" but unskilled manpower.

Quick relief will therefore not come from praying for the next frost in Brazil or waiting for capital inflows from abroad. It is imperative that government pursues policies that encourage value-adding processing and manufacturing industries which will suffer less the consequences of price fluctuations in the international market.

We have been riding this comparative-advantage-of-coffee-blah-blah horse for too long. So as the saying goes, let us make hay while the sun still shines because our luck may soon run out.

The Monitor is published at P.O. Box 12141, Kampala, Uganda. Tel: 236939 Fax: 251352

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: August 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

161 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


It's Final, Movement Gets 5 More Years


LENGTH: 667 words


 

The Monitor

June 30 - July 3, 1995

by Peter G. Mwesige and Kyazze Simwogerere

The Constituent Assembly -- with the multipartyists still boycotting it -- passed an amendment that provides for the Movement political system to apply for the next five years.

The amendment (an insertion now article 99) also provides for a referendum to determine which political system the people of Uganda want to adopt after the five years.

Article 99 (1) says that: "Notwithstanding the provisions of Article 94 the first Presidential, Parliamentary, Local Government and any other Public elections after the promulgation of this Constitution shall be held under the Movement Political System. (2) Two years before the expiry of the term of the first Parliament elected under this Constitution, any person will be free to canvass for support for any political system he or she supports. (3) During the last month of the fourth year of the term of office of the first Parliament, a referendum shall be held to determine the political system the people of Uganda want to adopt. 

This final version was improved by Lt. Col. Kiiza Besigye (NRA), Janat Mukwaya (Mukono South) and Ogwel Loote (Moroto).

Amama said that the CA determines the political system for the next five years because the Odoki Commission had found out that Ugandans wanted the movement to continue for that period.

"I have no problem with a referendum now but since the people of Uganda have expressed themselves already, I find it absolutely unnecessary to go back and ask for their views in a referendum when we know their views," he said.

"We don't have sufficient time to organise a referendum unless the NRC extended the NRM, but this is not likely to be supported."

Amama said Clause (2) and (3) were necessary to level the ground, because there are some people who say they are not free enough today to influence events.

"The Movement should be operational for three years without encumbrances then open up in the last two years. This is a time-table," he said.

Although almost all those present were professed Movementists, there were quite a few voices of unease, with many delegates wondering whether the article was not a transitional matter and therefore, for Chapter 20, while others worried that the time given for canvassing was too short.

Answering to the queries raised about whether NRM was going to continue after the elections, Amama said that it was a Movement political system and not NRM.

Article 99 became part of the new constitution, pending the completion of chapter 20, its likely new home.

The Monitor is published at P.O. Box 12141, Kampala, Uganda. Tel: 236939 Fax: 251352

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: August 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


162 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Back On The Beat


LENGTH: 1507 words


 

Newswatch

July 17, 1995

by Wale Akin Aina

Despite the arrest of Gani Fawehinmi for undisclosed reasons, politicians respond to the lifting of the ban on politics with enthusiasm.

The arrest of Gani Fawehinmi, maverick lawyer and leader of the National Conscience Party, NCP, and moves by political associations to secure alliances and mergers dominated the political scene most of last week.

Fawehinmi, according to a statement for his law chambers was picked at about 9 p.m. July 3 by officers of the State Security Service, SSS. The statement said that the security agents presented no warrant of arrest or a search warrant and offered no reason for his arrest. It adds that by his arrest government had clearly shown that "it has not genuinely lifted the ban on political activities." 

Although there has been no statement from either the government or any of its security agencies, it would appear that Fawehinmi is the first political leader to fall victim of the new ground rules on politicking set by Sani Abacha, the head of state, at the presentation of the draft constitution, June 27. Abacha had announced the lifting of the ban on politics but placed restrictions on political rallies and campaigns. He warned against reckless and provocative utterances. He said the restrictions would remain until a comprehensive political programme is announced in October by the National Electoral Commission, NEC.

Fawehinmi addressed a world press conference July 2 at which he questioned the rationale for the lifting of the ban without allowing political rallies and campaigns. He said he would defy the ban by holding rallies of his political party. He used the press conference to attack the military government. His statement was broadcast on the BBC the same day.

But neither Fawehinmi's arrest not the restrictions placed by Abacha on political activities appeared to have dampened the enthusiasm of politicians. Politicians criss-crossed the country last week, solidifying positions and establishing new contacts. Sources spoke of conclusive plans by progressives to form a grand alliance. A meeting of progressives was scheduled for July 12. Political associations expected at the meeting include the New Dimension, The Eastern Mandate Union (EMU), The Eastern Solidarity Front, the Egbe Omo Yoruba, the resurrected Northern Elements Progressive Union (NEPU) and the Committee of the Afenifere.

This is not the first time an attempt will be made to bring progressives together since the government partially lifted the ban on politics last year. After a series of meetings, the Afenifere led by Adekunle Ajasin, former governor of Ondo State, and the NEPU led by Balarabe Musa, former governor of Kaduna State, met in Owo last May and agreed on an alliance. They agreed to fight for the resolution of the annulled presidential election of June 12, 19934 and the release from detention of Moshood Abiola, the man presumed to have won the election.

Also last year, the Afenifere and the All Nigeria Congress (ANC) began meeting after the partial lifting of the ban on politics. Participants at the meetings were Ahmed Kusamatu, former chairman of the defunct National Republican Convention (NRC); Sunday Awomiyi, former vice-chairman in the defunct National Party of Nigeria (NPN); Bamanga Tukur and Adamu Ciroma, former ministers of industries and agriculture respectively and Lema Jibrilu, former presidential aspirant. Others who represented the Afenifere were Bola Ige, former governor of Oyo State, Olu Falae, former secretary to the Federal government and Ganiyu Dawodu, a top member of the defunct Social Democratic Party (SDP) in Lagos State. The two associations were to meet in Owo July 6.

The Southern Solidarity Forum was also to meet in Port Harcourt, Rivers State, the following day to discuss issues associated with the draft constitution. The meeting was to be hosted by Tunji Otegbeye, a member of the constitutional conference commission and would include representatives form both the Middle Belt and the Northern Elders Forums. Sources said that the meeting would focus on the issue of rotational presidency and revenue allocation and the threat by certain sections of the country to delete the relevant provisions from the constitution.

Last week, the self-styled "concerned elders" group of Musa Karaye, Aminu Idris, Baba Saleh and Baba Karah wrote to the head of state complaining about rotational presidency, revenue allocation and the reduction in size of the armed forces. The "concerned elders" had, at the federal appeal court in Kaduna, appealed against the ruling of the Abuja high court which had thrown out their suit to stop the draft constitution from being submitted to the Provisional Ruling Council (PRC). While the "concerned elders" were still battling to remove certain provisions, the government has ordered that 50,000 copies of the document be printed for distribution in all the states. This is in line with Abacha's statement that the draft constitution be studied within the three months which the PRC would take to decide on the new political programme.

Sources said last week that the new political programme would probably take off with elections into local governments on a zero-party basis. This has made politicians, especially conference delegates who want to go into politics a bit confused about the emerging political arrangement. At the reception organised for them after the presentation of the draft constitution, Abacha gave the indication that government was favourably considering statements by Adolphus Karibi-Whyte, the conference chairman and Mamman Nasir, his deputy, that delegates were still willing to serve the country in any capacity. The head of state did not dissolve the conference.

For now, some politicians and delegates do not know whether to go all out into politics and miss out on what the government might have in store for them. One delegate told Newswatch: "not participating in any local government election or losing one's ward is a sure way of sealing off one's political career in the coming republic."

In order not to be caught unawares, some political associations have begun to restructure their party hierarchy. The Committee for National Consensus (CNC), announced last week the appointment of Abel Ubeku, a conference delegate and former presidential aspirant, as its new chairman. Other officers of the association are Olusola Saraki, former senator and chairman of the conference business committee; Jibrilu Aminu, former Petroleum resources minister and Barnabas Gemade, former secretary of works in the Interim National Government, both are conference delegates. Others were Don Etiebet, former petroleum resources minister, Sunday Adewusi, former inspector-general of police and Emmanuel Iwuanyanwu, publisher of the Champion newspapers.

The CNC also divided the country into six zones -- North-West, Central, Eastern, Western, Southern and North-Eastern for administrative convenience and to ensure enhanced party functions. Similar structures had earlier been adopted by the Afenifere at its August 31 meeting in Ibadan last year and by the Movement for National Reconciliation (MNR), led by Anthony Enahoro, a pro-democracy activist and former information minister.

Newswatch is published at P.M.B. 21499 Ikeja, Nigeria. Tel: 4960950. Fax:962887. Telex:27874

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: August 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


163 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


AFPRC Is Committed To The Advancement of Women


LENGTH: 720 words


 

The Daily Observer

July 5, 1995

by Ibrahim Janko Sanneh

The Armed Forces Provisional Ruling Council (AFPRC) Government is committed to the advancement of women who constitute nearly half of the human capital, and contribute immensely to the socio-economic development of the country. The chairman of the AFPRC and Head of State of the Republic of The Gambia, Captain Yahya Jammeh, has recognised this fact as expressed by him in various fora across the length of the country.

These were the remarks made by the Minister for Local Government and Lands, Captain Yankuba Touray, to more than 100 women at the opening of a four-day workshop at the Rural Development Institute in Mansakonko, Lower River Division in late June. 

The workshop, which had two main items on the agenda, brought women representatives from all over the country, from Koina in the east to Kartung in the west.

It aimed at the making of a women policy document that would be presented to the government for eventual inclusion in the constitution of the country, and to prepare women representatives who would be in Beijing, China on behalf of the rest of The Gambia women in September of this year.

The Minister said the workshop was timely as it proposed to address two critical issues about women's participation in socio-economic development.

One such issue is the democratisation process in which women are given the opportunity by Government to take part in national debate towards the development of the desired structures for a more democratic and just society for all as preparation is made for the Second Republic.

The second important issue affecting the workshop was the finalisation of the country's paper to Beijing. The Minister said for the AFPRC government, Beijing would be a conference with a difference. The Government had already started to undertake certain actions that are in link with the Beijing Global Platform of Action for the Advancement of Women in the 2005. A notable example being the appointment of four women cabinet ministers out of fourteen.

"We all know," he said, "that a lot of service has been paid on the advancement and empowerment of women by the old regime, but this attitude has no place in the society which the AFPRC has vowed to promote."

The Minister of Health, Social Welfare and Women's Affairs, Cumba Ceesay Marenah, who chaired the opening, expressed the hope that participants would coherently discuss issues in preparation for the Second Republic and also for the trip to Beijing.

Amie Joof-Cole, the chairperson of the national Women's Council, in her vote of thanks, said the AFPRC government has established its interests in the advancement of women's affairs in different forms. She advised the women that their role in politics should not stop them from playing the roles of passengers in the next Republic. They should aim at being in the front seats and driving at the wheels.

The workshop was jointly organized by WID, National Women's Council, Ministry of Health, Social Welfare and Women's Affairs and UNDP.

The Daily Observer is published at P.M.B. 131, Banjul, The Gambia. Tel. (220) 490608. Fax: (220) 496878

LOAD-DATE: August 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


164 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


There Are No Shortages In The Gambia


LENGTH: 440 words


 

The Daily Observer

July 3, 1995

by Alieu Badara Njie

The Gambia Chamber of Commerce and Industry (GCCI), have denied rumours that there is a shortage of basic commodities in the market.

According to a press release from the GCCI, "no shortage of rice or any essential commodity has been recorded." The release also states that the price fluctuations affecting these commodities "is a pure reflection of world market conditions which are solely determined by market forces and therefore outside of the control of the business community." 

The release stressed that despite mounting difficulties, the GCCI "will continue to exert maximum effort to ensure that essential commodities such as rice, sugar, flour, tomato paste and cooking oil are available in the market."

It also issued statistics which reveal that a total of 74,200 tonnes of rice had been imported in The Gambia by members of the GCCI fro July 1994 to date.

"This constitutes 84 per cent of total rice imports for the same period," shipped in by the Rice Consortium and T. Massry and Sons, the release adds.

The release however notes that "the Chamber will not comment on the dumping of rice as it is 'sub judice'."

Other statistics contained in the release indicate that from July, 1994 to May, 1995, other basic commodities such as sugar (20,000 tonnes), flour (25,000 tonnes), cooking oil (1,150 tonnes), and tomato paste (3,660 tonnes) were imported into the country.

The release concludes: "The Chamber of Commerce and Industry regrets any false alarm or misinformation that may have sent wrong signals to the public."

The Daily Observer is published at P.M.B. 131, Banjul, The Gambia. Tel. (220) 490608. Fax: (220) 496878

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

LANGUAGE: English

165 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


All African Games: Who Is Who?


LENGTH: 307 words


 

The Daily Observer

July 3, 1995

The draw has been made for the football tournament at the September All African Games in Harare, Zimbabwe, where eight under -23 teams from across the continent will play over a period of 13 days for the coveted trophy. The teams are drawn in two groups of four. 

Group A, based in Harare, consists of host nation Zimbabwe, Egypt, Zambia and Congo.

Group B in Bulawayo features Nigeria, Algeria, Guinea and Mauritius.

The first ever action on September 10 sees of course host nation Zimbabwe locking horns with the North African rival Egypt, in the opening match, followed by Zambia versus Congo.

Nigeria's first opponent on September 11 will be Algeria followed by Guinea versus Mauritius.

Meanwhile, two African players in Europe were awarded European Union status. They are Liberia's George Opong Weah and Ghana's Abedi Pele.

The Daily Observer is published at P.M.B. 131, Banjul, The Gambia. Tel. (220) 490608. Fax: (220) 496878

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: August 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


166 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


TUTU ON RECONCILIATION MISSION TO RWANDA AND BURUNDI


LENGTH: 574 words


 

NAIROBI (APS) 25 July - The Archbishop of South Africa, Rt. Rev. Desmond Tutu, is scheduled to visit Burundi and Rwanda on a mission to support the reconciliation efforts in the two countries. The visit beginning Thursday 27th through Monday 30 July, is organised by the churches in both countries jointly with the Africa Evangelistic Enterprise (AEE).

Tutu who is also the current President of the Nairobi-based All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) with a membership of over 140 Churches and associate National Christian Councils (NCCs) in more than 38 African countries, will arrive in Burundi from Nairobi on July 27 at the head of an AACC delegation to consult with church leaders on the role of the Church in the process of national reconciliation. The delegation will include Micheal Cassidy, Vice-President of AEE. Bishop Tutu will be in Nairobi for a day to address the World Future Studies Conference on Wednesday July 26. 

While in Burundi, Bishop Tutu will preach at different churches on issues related to reconciliation. His sermons will culminate in a public rally and prayers for the nation in the national stadium in Burundi's capital, Bujumbura. He will focus on the general theme "Christ our Hope". Tutu, a Nobel Peace Prize Winner, will also meet with top political leaders, including the Burundian President, Sylvestre Ntibatunganya and Prime Minister, Mr. Antoine Nduwayo.

Bishop Tutu will then proceed to Rwanda on Saturday July 29, on a similar mission where he will address a public rally in Kigali on Sunday 30 July. Tutu's visit to Rwanda comes just one year after the genocide that cost an estimated 500,000-1,000,000 lives.

Bishop Tutu will be visiting Burundi and Rwanda for the first time since he became President of the AACC in 1987. The AACC has engaged in peace initiatives in Burundi and Rwanda since 1988 and 1991 respectively. Working behind the scenes, the AACC played a major role in brokering the 1983 Arusha peace accord between the ruling Rwandese Patriotic Front (RPF) and the then government of Major General Juvenal Habyrimana.

Habyarimana died in a mysterious plane crash on April 6, 1994 along side his Burundian counterpart President Cyprien Ntaryamira, sparking off the genocide in Rwanda, before the Accord could be implemented.

Rev. Jose Chipenda, AACC General Secretary said: "The African Churches wish to show their solidarity with the suffering people of Rwanda and Burundi and to encourage them to reconcile for the good of Africa and for the sake of present and future generations in those countries".

Copyright 1995, All Africa Press Service (APS). All rights reserved by the Africa Church Information Service, Nairobi, Kenya. Tel: (254-2) 442215. Fax: (254-2) 445847. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


167 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


CARTER CENTER STATEMENT ON RECENT PEACE AND HEALTH INITIATIVES IN SUDAN


LENGTH: 854 words


 

ATLANTA, GA.Former U.S. President Jimmy Carter said today upon returning from a trip to Sudan that all sides in that nation's civil conflict had agreed to continue observing the cease-fire as long as good faith talks are being held under the auspices of the Inter-governmental Authority on Drought and Development (IGADD), chaired by Kenya President Daniel Arap Moi.

The cease-fire, originally set to expire July 28, has allowed international health workers to implement interventions to prevent Guinea worm disease, river blindness, and other diseases.

During the trip, President Carter delivered peace talk invitations from President Moi to the Sudanese government, Sudanese People's Liberation Movement/Army (SPLM/A), and the Southern Sudanese Independence

Movement/Army (SSIM/A). All sides accepted the invitations for peace talks to begin soon in Nairobi. 

"All sides agreed to continuation of the four-month cease-fire as long as significant progress was being made toward achieving a lasting peace," President Carter said. "They all also expressed concern about the fundamental issues that continue to divide them and agreed to discuss several principles when talks begin."

Principles for talks outlined in the invitation were:

a) maintenance of a general cease-fire during these peace talks;

b) the general forms of government for Sudan;

c) how political authority will be shared or divided;

d) the make-up of military forces and their status;

e) the sharing or division of regional resources;

f) the length of an interim period during which these issues will be

finalized; and

g) participants who will represent the Inter-governmental Authority on Drought and Development (IGADD) and the Sudanese parties.

President Carter stressed that the 72 Sudanese government soldiers taken prisoner in late March shortly after the cease-fire declaration was an issue of great concern to the Sudanese government and that he will continue to press for their release as part of the peace process. He also emphasized the importance of opening up to relief and health workers airfields to which the Sudanese government had denied access, and he expressed hope that U.N. Special Envoy Traxler will be able to resolve this and other areas of disagreement between the government and Operation Lifeline Sudan at a meeting scheduled for the end of this week.

President Carter said the Government of Sudan, the SPLM/A, and the SSIM/A all supported expanding the health initiatives during a continued cease-fire. "I was pleased that all sides in the Sudanese conflict praised the significant accomplishments of the health projects that began in late March. Access to many areas in the country has been possible only during the last four months of relative peace, and the coordinated work of more than 20 relief agencies is truly heroic," President Carter said.

Progress made during the past four months includes interventions to: prevent Guinea worm in 2,336 villages; treat at least 40,000 persons with the drug Mectizan to prevent river blindness; vaccinate 35,000 people for polio and 40,000 for measles; and distribute 35,000 doses of vitamin A and 9,000 packets of oral rehydration supplements.

During a continued cease-fire, The Carter Center plans a much wider health program throughout the nation that also will include interventions to prevent malaria, leprosy, tuberculosis, sleeping sickness, and other tropical diseases.

The Center also will explore re-establishing a highly successful agricultural project through The Carter Center's Global 2000 Program that was interrupted in 1992 by the civil war.

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE Tuesday, July 25, 1995. Contact:Deanna Congileo, Associate Director, Public Information, The Carter Center. 404-420-5108. Additional information about The Carter Center and its work in Sudan is available on the Internet's World Wide Web at: http://www.emory.edu/CARTERCENTER/

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).


LOAD-DATE: August 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


168 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Washington Office on Africa Update


LENGTH: 1307 words


 

July 14, 1995

The House of Representatives has reduced appropriations for the Development Fund for Africa (DFA) for Fiscal Year 1996 from the $802 million proposed by the administration to $529.5 million, a cut of $272.5 million. House actions also cut the proposed $17.4 million for the African Development Foundation (ADF) to $10 million.

While these figures are still subject to Senate action, and to subsequent compromises, different proposals in the Senate range from almost equally drastic to worse. Meanwhile in a June authorization vote on the defense budget, the House approved $550 million for initial funding for production of two additional B-2 bombers not requested by the Pentagon, more than the combined DFA and ADF appropriations. Each additional B-2 bomber produced will cost an estimated $1.5 billion. The vote, accompanied by intense lobbying by military contractors and former Defense officials, pitted strict budget cutters and opponents of high military spending against not only the usual Defense Department boosters in Congress but also some members heavily influenced by considerations of potential job losses in their districts. Yet the proposed funding for the B-2 program could cover continued support for human needs at home as well as for sustainable development programs in Africa. 

The following alert, prepared by the Friends Committee on National Legislation (FCNL) for a coalition opposing the B-2 funding, is therefore relevant for supporters of Africa as well. House consideration of the appropriations bill is likely to come up before the end of the month, and perhaps as early as the week of July 17.

For additional information, please be in touch with FCNL.

PHONE CALLS NEEDED ON B-2 BOMBER

Representatives John Kasich (R-OH) and Ron Dellums (D-CA) will be offering an amendment to the Defense Appropriations bill to block funding for additional B-2 bombers.

A previous vote was close, and there are many members whose positions might be changed. Phone calls are needed immediately.

BACKGROUND

Representatives Kasich and Dellums offered a similar amendment to the Defense Authorization bill. In a frustrating vote, the amendment was defeated by the very narrow margin of 203 to 219. A number of representatives who normally support arms control efforts voted AGAINST the amendment and FOR the B-2. The (Kasich-Dellums) amendment would have removed a provision from the authorization bill that gets rid of the current cap on B-2 production (a 20-plane, $44 billion limit). The provision also authorizes $533 million to be spent on parts and production costs for 2 more planes. The cost of these planes was based on the assumption that 20 more B-2s would bebuilt. So by voting to retain this provision, the committee was implicitly approving 20 more planes, at an eventual costs of over $31.5 billion. THE PENTAGON DID NOT REQUEST THESE PLANES. THEY ARE NOT AN AIR FORCE PRIORITY. This money could be spent on many other things, but pork barrel politics won out and Northrup's slick lobbying materials paid off. WE CAN STILL STOP THE B-2, though. Kasich and Dellums will try to block funds from being appropriated for the B-2. And in the Senate, Sen. Cohen (R-ME) introduced an amendment to the Department of Defense authorization bill in committee. The amendment passed, 13-8, so there is currently no money for the B-2 in the Senate's version of the authorization bill.Please call as many of the offices listed below as is possible. Ask to speak with the defense aide. Try to cover at least the following basic points:- YOUR ORGANIZATION (OR YOU) OPPOSES PRODUCTION OF THE B-2.- YOU WANT THE REPRESENTATIVE TO VOTE FOR THE KASICH-DELLUMS AMENDMENT AND AGAINST FUNDING OF THE B-2 BOMBER.- THE PENTAGON AND THE ADMINISTRATION DID NOT REQUEST THESE FUNDS.- TO SPEND THIS MONEY ON THE B-2 AT A TIME WHEN HUMAN NEEDS, DISARMAMENT, CONVERSION, ENVIRONMENTAL AND OTHER IMPORTANT PROGRAMS ARE BEING SLASHED IS INDEFENSIBLE. OFFICES TO CALL:(All of the following have voted against the B-2 at some point in the past, but voted for it in June.)

Berman (D-CA) Tel: 225-4695

Fawell (R-IL) Tel: 225-3515

Ewing (R-IL) Tel: 225-2371

Visclosky (D-IN) Tel: 225-2461

Jefferson (D-LA) Tel: 225-6636

Schiff (R-NM) Tel: 225-6316

Ackerman (D-NY) Tel: 225-2601

Traficant (D-OH) Tel: 225-5261

Gekas (R-PA) Tel: 225-4315

Waters (D-CA) Tel: 225-2201

Meyers (R-KS) Tel: 225-2865

Manton (D-NY) Tel: 225-3965

(The following voted against the B-2 in 1992, but were absent for this year's vote.)

Pelosi (D-CA) Tel: 225-4965

Yates (D-IL) Tel: 225-2111

Williams (D-MT) Tel: 225-3211

LaFalce (D-NY) Tel: 225-3231

Boucher (D-VA) Tel: 225-3861

Kleczka (D-WI) Tel: 225-4572

(Prepared by the Friends Committee on National Legislation, 245 2nd St., NE, Washington, DC 20002. Tel: (202) 547-6000; Fax: (202) 547-6019; Email: fcnl@igc.apc.org. Contact: Sarah Warren)

LANGUAGE: English

169 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Nigeria: New Reports on Ogoni Crisis


LENGTH: 2707 words


 

Human Rights Watch/Africa has released a new report with first-hand evidence of military repression in the Ogoni region of Nigeria, including interviews with military personnel. The trial of Ogoni leader Ken Saro-Wiwa by a special tribunal is continuing.

Excerpts from the HRW/Africa press release announcing the report follows below.

The Nigerian military government has been engaged in a systematic and violent crackdown in the Ogoni region of the oil-rich Niger Delta, where indigenous communities have organized in protest against multinational oil companies. In The Ogoni Crisis: A Case Study of Military Repression in Southeastern Nigeria, Human Rights Watch/Africa focuses on the most recent phase of the repression, which began in late May 1994, following the murders of four Ogoni leaders believed to have been pro-government. Human Rights Watch/Africa charges that the Rivers State Internal Security Task Force embarked on a series of punitive raids on Ogoni villages, resulting in extrajudicial executions, shootings, arbitrary arrests, floggings, rapes and looting which violate Nigeria's obligations under international law and the Nigerian Constitution. The new 50-page report also documents attacks by the security forces on other indigenous communities in the Niger Delta, where local residents have begun to emulate the Ogonis' well- organized protests. 

The Ogoni people and other communities in the Delta contend that multinational oil companies, particularly the Shell Petroleum Development Company, in concert with the Nigerian government, have ravaged their land and contaminated their rivers. Shell officials have admitted requesting assistance from the Nigerian military authorities to defend the company's installations. Although oil production in Ogoniland was suspended in mid-1993, the abuses set in motion by Shell's reliance on military protection there continue. Based on its investigation in Nigeria and an ongoing discussion with Royal Dutch/Shell, Human Rights Watch/Africa has devised a set of basic human rights principles, presented in the report, and calls on the multinational oil companies to adhere to them in the course of their business operations.

The Movement for the Survival of Ogoni People (MOSOP), led by Ken Saro-Wiwa, has been at the forefront of the confrontation between the indigenous communities of the Niger Delta, the oil companies and the government. Mr. Saro-Wiwa and other Ogoni activists were detained and are currently on trial before a three-member special tribunal appointed by the Federal Military Government of Nigeria. The tribunal, which has the authority to impose the death penalty, lacks independence and impartiality and has been the subject of intense international criticism. Faced with increasing evidence of the tribunal's bias against the defendants, the defense team has reportedly decided to withdraw from Saro-Wiwa's case -- to avoid "glorifying the tribunal which is set up for a pre-determined purpose," according to one defense lawyer.

During its three-week mission to Nigeria this year, Human Rights Watch/Africa also gathered the first-ever testimony from soldiers who were themselves involved in the military's punitive campaign in Ogoniland. Soldiers described their participation in clandestine military raids designed to appear like communal clashes that would support the government's fraudulent contention that the violence in the region was the product of ethnic strife.

Human Rights Watch offers a series of recommendations to the Nigerian government, the international community and the multinational oil companies in order to improve the human rights situation in Nigeria. Human Rights Watch/Africa calls on the Government of Nigeria to: 1. Order the Rivers State Internal Security Task Force to cease immediately extrajudicial executions, indiscriminate shooting, arbitrary arrests and detention, floggings, rapes, looting, and extortion; 2. Disband the special tribunal established to try those accused of the May 21, 1994 murders of four Ogoni leaders; 3. Facilitate the immediate and unconditional release of all detainees held solely for he non-violent expression of their political beliefs, drop all politically motivated charges against them, and cease arbitrary detention without charge; 4. Convene an independent commission of inquiry to investigate the May 21, 1994 murders; 5. Insofar as credible evidence exists for any defendants accused of complicity in legally recognizable crimes, try them within a reasonable time before a competent, independent, and impartial court in compliance with Nigeria's obligations under international human rights law and the Nigerian Constitution; 6. Convene independent commissions of inquiry to investigate the actions of the Internal Security Task Force in Ogoniland and as yet uninvestigated attacks on other oil-producing communities; 7. Publicly prosecute in accordance with international standards all members of the Nigerian security forces who are implicated in violent human rights abuses; 8. Pending conclusion of the prosecutions, suspend members of the security forces implicated in violent human rights abuses; 9. Open Ogoniland to independent observers and human rights monitors, who should be allowed unimpeded access to the area without military escort; 10. Open the Kpor and Bori detention centers to independent monitors and ensure that detention conditions are consistent with international standards; 11. Provide relief, rehabilitation, and resettlement assistance to residents of oil-producing areas who have suffered losses in government-sponsored attacks.

Human Rights Watch/Africa recommends that the international community press the Nigerian government to implement the above recommendations through public criticism, active monitoring of political trials, and policies of aid and trade. In particular: Member States of the European Union should adopt a legally binding common position, in accordance with Article J.2 of the Treaty of Maastricht, incorporating some of those measures already agreed upon as "politically binding," namely: suspension of military cooperation; visa restrictions for members of the military and security forces who are reliably accused of participation in human rights abuses; suspension of visits by members of the military and intelligence service; imposition of case-by-case review, with a presumption of denial, for all new export license applications for defense equipment; cancellation of training courses for all Nigerian military personnel; review of new European Union aid projects on a case-by-case basis; and suspension of all non-essential high-level visits to and from Nigeria.

The European Union and its member states should also promote compliance by the Nigerian government with international human rights standards by: 1. Pressing the Nigerian government to implement the above recommendations; 2. Publicly naming those members of the Nigerian government to whom visas are denied as a result of their complicity in human rights violations; 3. Freezing all foreign assets of members of the Nigerian government who are responsible for serious human rights violations; 4. Moving beyond case-by-case review, with a presumption of denial, for export license applications for defense equipment to embargoes on the sale and shipment of arms to the Nigerian government; 5. Using their leverage in the World Bank, the African Development Bank, and other international financial institutions to block all non-"basic human needs" loans and disbursements to Nigeria; 6. Publicly raising the issue of political prisoners with the Nigerian government and making efforts to visit prisoners in detention; 7. Sending observers to the trials of Ken Saro-Wiwa and other MOSOP activists charged with the May 21, 1994 murders; 8. Urging their embassies to support the efforts of Nigerian human rights groups by meeting regularly with Nigerian human rights activists and issuing statements condemning human rights abuses.

The United States should promote compliance by the Nigerian government with international human rights standards by: 1. Pressing the Nigerian government to implement the above recommendations; 2. Rigorously enforcing the existing policy of denying visas to Nigerians who formulate or implement policies impeding a transition to democracy in Nigeria or who benefit from such policies, as well as the immediate families of such persons; 3. Rigorously enforcing the existing policy of case-by-case review of commercial military sales, with the presumption of denial, and moving beyond this policy to an embargo of all arms sales and shipments to Nigeria. 4. Implementing other policies consistent with those recommended for the European Union and its member states. (Similar measures are called for by Commonwealth member states, African governments and the United Nations.)

Human Rights Watch/Africa calls on Royal Dutch/Shell and other multinational oil companies operating in Nigeria to adhere to a set of basic human rights principles in the course of their business operations. By virtue of their influence in Nigeria and their participation in joint ventures in which the government is a principal stakeholder, the multinational oil companies are well placed to convey their concern about Nigeria's rapidly deteriorating human rights record in the course of their business dealings with local, state, and federal authorities. Because the Nigerian security forces have often employed grossly abusive measures to quell protests by residents of oil-producing areas against the activities of the multinational oil companies, the oil companies have a particular responsibility to address abuses perpetrated in this context.

Human Rights Watch/Africa encourages the multinational oil companies to: 1. Appoint responsible high-ranking corporate officials to monitor the use of force by the Nigerian military in the oil-producing areas and to denounce the use of unjustified or excessive force; 2. Urge the Nigerian government to allow nonviolent freedom of association and expression, particularly with respect to grievances directed against the oil industry; 3. Publicly and privately call upon the Nigerian government to restrain the use of armed force in the oil-producing aras; 4. Publicly and privately condemn human rights abuses by the Nigerian security forces in the areas where the companies are operating; 5. Urge the Nigerian government to cease arbitrary detention of peaceful protesters and to release all individuals held for the nonviolent expression of their political beliefs; 6. Protest the Abacha government's dissolution of the governing bodies of the oil workers' unions and detention of oil union leaders without charge or trial, and press the government for their reinstatement; 7. Shell and Chevron should refuse to resume production in Ogoniland until the Nigerian government has ceased human rights abuses against the Ogoni, has conducted an independent investigation of military and police activities in Ogoniland, has publicized the results, and has brought to trial those who directed and carried out violent abuses, and has disbanded the special tribunal established to try Ken Saro-Wiwa and other MOSOP activists.

Copies of the report are available from the Publications Department, Human Rights Watch, 485 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10017 for $6.00 (domestic) and $7.50 (international).

A detailed report on the Saro-Wiwa trial was also released in June by Article 19 (33 Islington High Street, London N1 9LH. Tel: 44-171-278-9292. Fax: 171- 713-1356). That report is entitled 'Nigeria, Fundamental Rights Denied: Report of the Trial of Ken Saro-Wiwa and Others', and was written by Michael Birnbaum QC.

Current information and background is also available from "The Campaign for Justice for Mr. Ken Saro-Wiwa" via the World Wide Web at: http://www.the-body-shop.com/action.html

Human Rights Watch/Africa Human Rights Watch is a nongovernmental organization established in 1978. Robert L. Bernstein is the chair of the board and Adrian W. DeWind is vice chair. Its Africa division was established in 1988 to monitor and promote the observance of internationally recognized human rights in sub-Saharan Africa.

Human Rights Watch/Africa 485 Fifth Avenue New York, NY 10017-6104 TEL: 212/972-8400 FAX: 212/972-0905 E-mail: hrwnyc@hrw.org 1522 K Street, N.W. Washington D.C. 20005 TEL: 202/371-6592 FAX: 202/371-0124 E-mail: hrwdc@hrw.org JULY 5, 1995 FOR FURTHER INFORMATION Melissa Crow (202) 371-6592 (w) (202) 234-9031 (h) Kenneth Roth (44-171) 713-1995 (UK) Janet Fleischman (202) 371-6592 (w) (301) 565-5257 (h)

This material is being reposted for wider distribution by the Africa Policy Information Center (APIC). APIC's primary objective is to widen the policy debate in the United States around African issues and the U.S. role in Africa, by concentrating on providing accessible policy-relevant information and analysis usable by a wide range of groups and individuals. APIC is affiliated with the Washington Office on Africa (WOA), a not-for-profit church, trade union and civil rights group supported organization that works with Congress on Africa-related legislation. LOAD-DATE: August 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


170 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July, 1995


Report of The Africa Fund Delegation of U.S. State Legislators to Southern Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 3307 words


 

Trip to South Africa, Namibia and Zimbabwe

Executive Summary: Findings and Recommendations

In May 1995 The Africa Fund organized a visit by three state legislators to South Africa, Namibia and Zimbabwe. This delegation visit was part of a project, made possible by a grant from the Carnegie Corporation of New York, to promote the involvement of U.S. state and municipal officials with U.S. policy towards southern Africa.

State and municipal elected officials in the United States played a critical role in influencing U.S. foreign policy toward apartheid South Africa in the 1980s. Many worked closely with the Africa Fund, frequently turning to it for information and analysis. In the aftermath of South African liberation, leading legislators wanted to maintain their involvement but recognized the need to become familiar with the new issues facing the wider southern Africa region. 

The Delegation

We were privileged to have a team of three distinguished state legislators in this first delegation. Representative Arthur Hamilton of Arizona, Representative Irma Hunter Brown of Arkansas and Senator Virgil Clark Smith of Michigan have over fifty-four years of legislative experience between them, a period far longer than the nations they visited have lived in freedom.

Dumisani Kumalo, Projects Director of The Africa Fund, accompanied the delegation.

In each country visited, the delegation sought to gain an in-depth understanding of the current situation, assessing the changes taking place. They planned to initiate strong contacts with local legislators and exchange legislative experiences and knowledge about drafting laws, constructing budgets and raising revenues. In addition to meeting many individuals, the delegation participated in a number of specially organized regional working forums with legislators in several centers in each country, making formal presentations and engaging in extended dialogue with their counterparts.

"Trying to share the current economic pie with everyone while hurting no one will not be possible. Explaining these facts to all South Africans while making none of them unhappy will not be possible." -- Arthur Hamilton

The Countries

The Africa Fund delegation chose to visit three countries as a means of widening the near total American focus on South Africa to encompass the broader region.

Together, South Africa, Namibia and Zimbabwe reflect the diversity of southern Africa's experience with freedom. South Africa has only been free for a year. Namibia, long illegally occupied by South Africa as a colony, won its independence in 1990. Zimbabwe achieved liberation fifteen years ago.

Common Problems - Challenges Being Met

Even more striking than their differences are the continuing, severe common problems produced by many decades of apartheid, colonial and white minority rule which the delegation observed, in varying degrees, in all three countries visited.

Delegation members were struck by the overwhelming disparity between the haves and have-nots, with the pattern, throughout the region, of continuing white wealth and Black poverty. Fifteen years after independence, Senator Smith points out, almost 70 percent of Zimbabwe's Black population lives in rural areas and is mainly engaged in subsistence agriculture, while most commercial agriculture is still controlled by whites.

Delegation member welcomed the commitment to democracy they found throughout the region, and were impressed by the determination of local legislators to strengthen their capacity to act effectively on behalf of their constituencies. But they warn that the almost complete lack of economic resources, and thus the inability of either central or local government to deliver even such basic needs as adequate schools, sewage and running water poses a serious threat to the building of peaceful, stable democratic societies. As Art Hamilton says of South Africa, at the beginning of his report, "There is a perception in the United States that Mandela is President, the majority rules and democracy is secure. A nice thought but not the truth."

The delegation was frequently asked to discuss issues relating to affirmative action -- which is broadly used to mean overcoming all the inequities, of wealth, education, skills, access to employment, that still characterize daily living for most members of the Black majority in all three countries visited. People long discriminated against, particularly in South Africa, but across the region, are understandably impatient for radical improvements in their lives. They want better jobs, homes and opportunities. The delegation observed that these reasonable desires, unmet, may lead to a loss of confidence in the democratic process. In some ways legitimacy of government is pitted in a race with popular expectations and it will be very important for the people to win some prizes.

"I have been personally touched by returning to the countries of my ancestors."

-- Virgil Smith

In South Africa the delegation was impressed by the idea of the government of national unity and the thrust for reconciliation. But they report frequent signs, in all three countries, of a continued reluctance on the part of the economically privileged white minority to share resources in ways that would most swiftly address Black dispossession.

Across the region the delegation found an eagerness for open discussion, particularly about ways in which democratic participation, popular, local and at national level, could be strengthened and economic progress encouraged.

The delegation also found an eagerness for greater connection and contact with the U.S. Members have made several individual observations about ways this might be achieved and the mutual benefits that such links could generate.

At the same time the delegation underscored the importance of responding to the agenda's being set within each country: As Art Hamilton comments, "The people we met ... want our help, our assistance and our guidance. But they clearly do not want to be dictated to, or told the best way to do things...."

Without in any way wishing to prescribe for the countries they visited the delegation felt that the youngest democracy might in some ways be able to benefit from observing the Namibian and Zimbabwean experiences.

The individual delegation reports stress the importance of perspectives provided by direct contact and communication. Delegation members felt such contact could be usefully expanded. As Irma Hunter Brown comments on her experience : "It is my ... hope that the dialogue ... will develop into long term relationships. I think much can be learned and much can be shared which can benefit us all."

The delegation was excited by the widespread mood of optimism, the willingness to experiment, the enthusiasm they found among most of the elected officials and community leaders they met. Challenges are being met. They see the region as a potential anchor for democracy in Africa with a potential for great economic growth. In this context they urge greater U.S. public and private engagement and investment. In Art Hamilton's words, "We now have an opportunity to help secure democracy in a part of the world that colonial rule made a powder keg. With the rapid growth of the African nations a relatively small investment now will pay huge dividends down the road. This is good government policy and good business."

South Africa

The delegation met with members of Nelson Mandela's government of national unity elected in South Africa's first democratic elections in April 1994 and held working forums with members of five of the nine provincial parliaments. In addition to meetings with leading public officials at the national, provincial and city levels, representing all the leading political parties, the delegation also had extensive discussions with representatives from important sectors of civil society, including the Congress of South African Trade Unions (COSATU), the Black business community, the South African Council of Churches and the Women's Development Foundation.

In addition to the their overall observations set out above, the delegation was impressed by the importance accorded at all levels to the government's Reconstruction and Development Program, which seeks to address the legacy of apartheid through long term comprehensive economic development. The delegation considered that this program provides important priority-setting capabilities. Housing construction and job creation are current key development areas.

"The legislators we met all knew what their needs were. They all had goals. Their difficulty lay in achieving those goals." -- Irma Hunter Brown. Many legislators expressed concern over proposals to cut U.S. assistance to Africa. There is near universal concern with the need to initiate economic growth and considerable enthusiasm for encouraging U.S. investment.

Other concerns frequently raised were how to assure effective affirmative action in favor of the Black majority in all spheres of social, economic and political life, and how to ensure broad democratic participation in government.

As Dumisani Kumalo reports, one of the current hotly debated issues in South Africa is how power will be shared between the central government and the provinces. Namibia

Namibia, after five years of independence, has well defined democratic, national, regional and local government structures, and a feeling of great promise. But the delegation was also struck by extreme difficulties facing the major part of the population, living in considerable rural isolation in the north. The delegation also noted still visible scars of the recent war for liberation.

In addition to meetings in the capital, Windhoek, the delegation traveled to the far north and the Atlantic coast to hold working forums with representatives from several of the most remote of Namibia's 13 elected regional councils.

Major concerns included how, with very limited resources, to effectively direct government services towards those who need them the most. Local leaders described tensions with white tax payers who resent their tax money being spent on people in the Black townships.

President Nujoma summed up his country's priorities for the delegation. "We get concerned when some people in the United States are calling for cutting aid to Africa. American aid is not just money to us. It is ammunition for the toughest fight we are involved in: the fight against poverty and ignorance... We must do something and we need the United States to continue to be on our side."

Zimbabwe

Zimbabwe gained its independence in 1980 and has been grappling impressively with the problems of nation building, economic reconstruction and democratization for 15 years. Yet the delegation observed that this still seemed to be a society actively seeking to define and redefine the nature of its society and the structure of its institutions. As described by Minister of Justice, Legal and Parliamentary Affairs, Mr. Emmerson Mnangagwa, Zimbabwe "began as a socialist government. But now we are changing towards a democratic, market oriented system...."

The delegation met with the Speaker of Parliament, government ministers, Members of Parliament, regional and municipal elected officials. It traveled across the country, west of the capital, Harare, to Mashonaland West and the Victoria Falls. It participated in a legislative forum with the Chinhoyi Regional Council and also met with Zimbabwe's leading human rights organization.

Zimbabwean elected officials frequently raised questions relating to strengthening democratic procedures at local level. They were eager to increase active participation in the democratic process and were interested in suggestions as to how to improve communication with constituents and networking with counterparts.

They were profoundly concerned that Zimbabwe should achieve a level of sustainable development sufficient to improve the lives of the people. They saw this as complicated by World Bank and International Monetary Fund polices that are compelling the government to redirect resources away from social services to encourage growth in sectors of the economy such as export industries.

Recommendations:

The main recommendations of the three delegation members, set out in their individual reports, reflect similar conclusions and can be summarized as follows:

1. U.S. policy should be aimed at helping the governments and people of southern Africa preserve and extend their hard won democracy. Democracy in southern Africa is still fragile. The delegation recognizes that achieving the goals southern Africans desire, establishing a popular culture of peaceful, participatory democracy, with transparency of process and effective mechanisms for constructive criticism, will take time. Its achievement will have valuable consequences for both the U.S. and Africa, and deserves the fullest possible U.S. support.

2. U.S. policy makers should assist the countries of southern Africa address the basic needs of their citizens. This means supporting long term economic growth as well as social programs to heal the wounds of apartheid and colonial rule. The extreme disparity between the haves and have-nots threatens the progress of the new democracies. The delegation urges a long term U.S. commitment involving not only financial assistance but also talent and expertise.

3. U.S. aid to southern Africa should be increased, or at a minimum maintained at the present level. This is both in the U.S. national interest and in the interest of southern Africa. Aid must be given on the basis of the southern African agenda rather than one imposed from Washington. The aid program should support and sustain development strategies defined by the people of the region. The U.S. should ensure that its assistance policies are socially as well as economically responsible and target the poorest of the poor rather than those who are already advantaged.

4. The delegation urges evaluation and monitoring of the effectiveness of assistance programs.

5. The delegation strongly encourages U.S. legislators to work with the National Conference of State Legislatures, the National Black Caucus of State Legislators and The Africa Fund, to swiftly expand legislative exchanges, build direct links and share experiences and expertise which can help enhance legislative capacity in southern Africa. Continuing ties between legislators in the U.S. and their counterparts in southern Africa will help U.S. legislators effectively impact on national policy .

6. The delegation encourages increased trade and investment, which will be mutually beneficial to the U.S. and southern Africa. State legislators can help to identify products and resources within their own states that could be the basis for mutually beneficial trade. They should also encourage socially responsible investment by corporations from their home states.

The U.S. should develop a special relationship with South Africa over the next decade, because a successful transition in South Africa will benefit the entire region. This relationship is rooted in ties that have been built over the last twenty years between the people of the United States and the people of South Africa. It would encompass expanded aid flows, closer political and social relations, and should include the early appointment of an African American Ambassador. A precedent for such a relationship can be found in the U.S. support for the countries that were parties to the Middle East peace process.

Although this delegation was primarily concerned with meeting its counterparts at regional level, the great interest expressed by municipal leaders encourages the delegation to recommend that organizations such as the U.S. Conference of Mayors should undertake programs to strengthen municipal government, especially in South Africa where the first democratic municipal elections are scheduled for November 1995.

Copies of the full text of the report are available for $6.00 in the United States and $12.00 international from The Africa Fund.

The Africa Fund, 17 John Street, New York, NY 10038. Tel: (212) 962-1210

August, 1995


USafrica, Continental Airlines In Joint Venture In Africa


LENGTH: 826 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - USAfrica Airways and Continental Airlines have agreed on a comprehensive marketing and operational alliance in support of plans to re-introduce direct air links between North America and West and Southern Africa.

According to a release made available to PANA by USafrica, Major features of the agreement include code sharing with Continental's code appearing on all flight between the United States and Africa. 

It will also ensure Africa's full participation in continental's one-pass frequent flyer programme, joint sales and marketing programmes, and coordinated operations at continental's Newark/New York gateway, the release said.

The agreement culminates several months of negotiations and represents a signifiant step in the ongoing process of US-Africa's restructuring and resumption of service.

Flights are planned to begin later this year from Newark/New York to Johannesburg, South Africa with an intermediate stop in Dakar, Senegal.The New York Metropolian area is the largest origin and destination market for both African cities.

Continental and its partners offer connecting service from Newark to over 50 cities in the United States and Canada.

"US-Africa sees great value in an alliance with continental and access to its Newark hub.Continental offers the most connecting opportunities in the most heavily populated region of the U.S," said Gregory s. Lewis, President and Chief Executive Officer of US-Africa.

172 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Two State Beermakers Privatized


LENGTH: 534 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Mozambique has privatized two of the country's three state-owned breweries, but the government will still hold 30 percent of the stock in the new holding company, news reports said today.

Industry, Trade and Tourism Minister Oldemiro Baloi announced the sell-off to Indol International, A Dutch subsidiary of South African Breweries (SAB)

Indol will own 70 percent of the shares of the MacMahon brewery in Maputo, the capital, and the Beira brewery, in the northern port city. The two breweries now become a new company Cervejas de Mocambique sarl (Beers of Mozambique, ltd). 

Indol has promised to tranfer seven per cent of the stock to a local partner.

The minister assured brewery workers that "privatisation is not an act of despair", but was necessary to ensure modernisation and increased production.

Indol has paid 14 million US dollars for its share of the breweries, and Indol general manager Andre Parker said the company was prepared to spend more to upgrade them.

Modernization is expected to cost 8.4 million dollars over the next three years.

The managing director of Cervejas de Mocambique, Craig McDougall, told the semiofficial Mozambique News Agency that none of the employees would lose jobs. But they would be retrained to handle new equipment and new work methods.

The breweries will continue to produce Mozambican brands, 2M and Manica, but they will also produce the South African brands Castle and Lion as well as such international labels as as Carling Black Llabel, Chandlers and St Louis.

This is the largest investment so far by a South African company in the Mozambican privatisation programme, and the second largest investment in any former state-owned company.

Increased production from the breweries, and diversification of brands, should pull the rug from under the feet of smugglers who bring South African beer illegally into the country, the news agency sreported.

PANA AIM/JSM/PF/JE 1Aug95

Africa News


August, 1995


Africa Games Organisers Complain About Money


LENGTH: 640 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA)- Six weeks to the start of the 6th All Africa Games, the Zimbabwe government is being blamed for slowness in releasing funds to complete preparations for the events, slated for 13 to 23 September.

Games General Manager Macloud Chaora said in an interview Tuesday that only the quick disbursement of funds would facilitate the completion of final preparations for the successful hosting of the games. Already there was concern that delays in releasing funding to various government departments and parastatals involved in the games could cause national embarassment. 

"There is need for government to quickly disburse the funds which they have set aside for the games. Time is running out and provision of funds is late. If the money is released now, something can be done to salvage the situation," said Chaora.

President Robert Mugabe's government announced in its budget last week that it had set aside the equivalent of six million US dollars for the Sports and Recreation Commission, the body responsible for organising the games.

Chaora said the games were expected to bring together about 5 000 athletes from 42 countries which had so far confirmed their participation.

A report prepared for government on the state of preparations regretted that while millions of dollars have been invested on new facilities and refurbishment of existing ones and yet inadequate funds were being made for the hosting of the event itself.

The document was also critical about inadequate publicity due to lack of funds to carry out a major awarness campaign.

While the games needed to be appreciated as a national event which all citizens and institutions, the report said, the ordinary people think the games belong to the organising committee or just an opportunity for government related institutions to acquire what under normal circumstances they had not been able to obtain.

Despite the criticims, however, the 15 organising sub-committees for the games have made substantial progress towards the preparations.

Parirenyatwa in Hararehas been identified as the games hospital and an exclusive wing will be reserved for use during the games.

The technical rules for all sports have been drawn and approved by the respective continental sports federation.

According to the report, six stamps have been issued by the posts and telecommunications corporation in commemoration of six disciplines.

However, Burundi, Cape Verde, Djibouti, Equatorial Guinea Liberia, Libya, Mauritania, Niger, Sierra Leone and Somalia have not yet confirmed.

Burundi, Liberia and Somali are faced with civil war situations while Libya is suffering from the effects of a United States embargo.

PANA-ZIANA MUH/NDN/PBM 1AUG95

Africa News


August, 1995


EU Aid to Zimbabwe Increasing


LENGTH: 454 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - European Union (EU) aid to Zimbabwe has been increasing over the years and currently the country is benefiting from over 30 projects worth about zimdollars 1 billion (USD 117 million). The EU is currently financing projects in rural development, economic, technical and cultural fields, training as well as food aid, according to documents made available to the Zimbabwe Inter-African News Agency (ZIANA).

The rural development projects that are spread throughout the country include the national tsetse and trypanosomiasis control programme, the smallholder coffee, fruit, irrigated food crops and vegetable projects(semi) small scale irrigation programmes and the veterinary wildlife project. 

The EU is also assisting Zimbabwe with its Structural Adjustment Programme as well as supporting the trade promotion body ZIMTRADE, the Zimbabwe Tourism Development Programme, and the cross-border initiative. The technical aid programmes include the Gokwe and Matabeleland South water supply and sanitation programmes and the Zimbabwe minefields survey.

Culturally, the EU supports Zimbabwe in the production of a film on gender issues, preparations for the Sixth All-Africa Games and programmes for the elderly, among others.

It is also assisting the AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases control programmes.

Zimbabwe is also benefiting from regional programmes which include the SADC food security training programme, Mid-Zambezi valley study phase 11, the SADC foot and mouth disease control project, maize and wheat improvement research network for SADC and the regional SADC wildlife management training project.

Most of the projects are on-going and some have been running since the 1980's.

PANA-ZIANA MP/NDN/FON 1Aug95

August, 1995


Stockmart Opens Week Bright But...


LENGTH: 534 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Trading On the stock market here opened on a bright note Monday with an increase in prices and the market's index despite a slowing down in volume.

The GSE all-share index rose by 1.92 points to close at 311.98 compared with Friday's close 310.06 points. "Prices rode on the wave of impressive corporate performances with the Cedi gaining strenght against the dollar," said a dealer who was confident of an upward market trend during the week. 

In the broader market, Standard Chartered Bank which climbed 100 cedis at 5,500 and Pioneer Tobacco Company (PTC) which rose four cedis at 130 were the market movers on a low volume of 33,430 shares. Friday's volume stood at 557,370 shares. "There were, however, losses arising from a combination of market forces and price adjustment of certain shares", the dealer said.

Those equities affected were Entreprise Insurance Company (EIC) which fell four cedis to 490 and UTC-estates which lost four cedis to close at 75 cedis. The remaining equities maintained their price levels.

Shares offered which closed at 616,020 were, however, far more than those demanded by investors which ended at 262,810, leaving much on the books of brokers. The total market capitalization closed up at 2,326.30 billion cedis from the previous 2,324.47 billion cedis.

The following are the last prices of the listed equities: ABL, 275 Cedis, AGC, 25,200 Cedis, CFAO, 34 Cedis, EIC, 490 Cedis, FML, 217 Cedis, GGL, 210 Cedis, HFC, 118 Cedis, KBL, 622 Cedis, MGL, 130 Cedis, MLC, 55 Cedis, MOGL, 3,900 Cedis, PTC, 130 Cedis, PZ, 540 Cedis, SCB, 5500 Cedis, SPPC, 110 Cedis, UNIL, 841 Cedis AND UTC-E, 75 Cedis.

Meanwhile, there seems to be a halt to the down trend of the Cedi against international currencies like the Dollar, Pound Sterling and the Deutsche Mark at both the official and parallel markets. The Central Bank's average interbank exchange Monday showed a stable Cedi against the three currencies.

For instance, against the dollar, the Cedi closed 1,183.57 for buying and 1,202.14 for selling, while the Pound Sterling was bought for 1,886 and sold at 1,907.86. The Deutsche Mark ended at 840 for buying and 860.71, for selling the same as Friday's close.

PANA-GNA RAY/FT/FON 1Aug95

Africa News


August, 1995


Zambian Kwacha Still In The Doldrums


LENGTH: 427 words


 

by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - The Zambian Kwacha seems to be stabilising after months of wholesale depreciation but currency watchers say they expect the local currency to slide further as shortage of hard currency persists. The kwacha exchanged in Lusaka Tuesday at the mean rate of 963 to one US dollar as against 962 to the greenback last week.

The Zambian economy is mainly dependent on donor aid for foreign exchange. This has been withheld pending a review of the country's Structural Adjustment Programme (SAP), in September by officials of the International Monetary Fund (IMF). 

The IMF early this year suspended aid to Zambia saying government had breached some provisions of the SAP, which it adopted to spur national economic recovery programme. Lusaka still has to decide on the privatisation of its giant mining industry which the donors say should be put into private hands as soon as possible. The government also has yet to undertake a public service reform programme involving retrenchment of thousands of workers in a bid to trim expenditure.

The donors said early this year that they were particularly unhappy about government decision to print money to bail out the privately-owned Meridien BIAO bank which has since been placed under receivership. Finance Minister Ronald Penza has said some 8.4 billion kwacha (about 8.4 million dollars) was pumped into the bank in a futile bid to bail it out its financial crisis.

Some independent sources said as much as 50 billion kwacha (about 50 million dollars) in public funds could have been advanced to the collapsed bank.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

Africa News


August, 1995


Lagos Hit by Kerosene Scarcity


LENGTH: 320 words


 

by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria's commercial capital, Lagos with some six million people, has been hit by acute shortage of kerosine, a major household cooking fuel in the country.

Marketers interviewed by PANA Tuesday blamed the scarcity, which has jerked up the price of the commodity by more than 100 per cent, on inadequate supply. 

Many gas filling stations in Lagos say they had run out of stock, but illicit transaction is said to be booming. Industry sources also said the current scarcity might have been worsened by the recent closure for maintenance, of one of the country's four refineries in the mid-western town of Warri.

A four-litre gallon of kerosine, which sold for 35 Naira a week ago, has shot up to 80 naira (about 1 USD).

Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation with an estimated 90 million people, is an oil-producing country, but experiences sporadic fuel shortages blamed on distribution problems and smuggling.

PANA PE/FON 1Aug95

Africa News


August, 1995


New Zaire Makes Spectacular Gains


LENGTH: 414 words


 

by Rigobert Mukeni Lapess, PANA Correspondent

KINSHASA, Zaire (PANA) - The New Zaire appreciated by more than 40 per cent against the United States Dollar, exchanging in Kinshasa on Monday at the rate of 5,000 NZ to one dollar, from 7,200 NZ to the greenback two weeks ago.

The spectacular rise of the NZ which had persistently declined since it was introduced in October 1993 followed a wide-ranging rescue campaign initiated by the government in collaboration with the bank of Zaire, which included mopping up excess local currency on the market.

Reports of massive speculative sales of dollars by a Lebanese dealer as well as the arrest of senior officials at the New Bank of Kinshasa (NBK) accused of illegal transfer of 8 billion NZ from the Central Bank, also helped to shore up the local currency. In efforts to restore sanity to the country's finance sector, the Deputy Director of current accounts at the Bank of Zaire was arrested last week in Kinshasa for complicity in the illegal transfer. 

But finance analysts say the "artificial" rise of the NZ may not last for too long citing political issues such as the anticipated end of the transistion period on 9 July and a contributing factor. However, the depreciation of foreign currencies, considered as a "safe haven" in crisis ridden Zaire has caused panic among people, especially businessmen.

In reaction to the depreciation of foreign currencies, some diamond dealers in Kinshasa were reported to be reluctant to sell their products for foreign currency. Some readily accepted the local currency while a few others preferred to wait until the situation became clearer.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.
