August, 1995


Shilling Starts Falling Again


LENGTH: 320 words


 

NAIROBI,Kenya (PANA) - The Kenya shilling weakened further against the United States dollar and the British Pound Teusday, as analysts predicted a further depreciation of the local currency following the row between London and Nairobi that appeared to deepen uncertainity sorrounding the currency.

It lost SH 1.02 against the dollar and SH 1.46 cents against the pound sterling according to figures released by the Central Bank of Kenya (KCBK). Analysts said the currency was bracing for a stiffer show given the row between Kenya and Britain over a statement by British Minister for Overseas Development Lynda Chalker on future British assistance to Kenya.

"The threat by government to reverse the reforms is most likely to drive the shilling's fall further by deepening the uncertainity and shattering investor confidence," an analyst who sought anonymity said.

On Teusday the shilling exchanged at the mean rate of 56.85 to the dollar compared to 55.83 on Monday and SH 90.88 against the Pound compared to 89.42 Previously Two Foreign Exchange Bureaus in Nairobi sold the dollar for amounts ranging from SH 56.35 to SH 58.

PANA-KNA RN/SM/FON 2Aug95

Africa News


August, 1995


Nigeria's Population Now 98 Million


LENGTH: 360 words


 

by Nick Ibewuike, PANA Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria's population put at 88.5 million by a national census conducted in 1991, has now risen to 98 million, the National Population Commission (NPC) said here Tuesday.

The NPC Chairman, Chris Ugokwe, who also heads the African Population Commission, told a press conference the figure represents a growth rate 2.83 per cent between 1991 and 1995. 

He dismissed a World Bank figure of 120 million as Nigeria's population. "the World Bank does not conduct census for any country..." Ugokwe added.

Nigeria's constitutional conference, which ended in June had recommended that the 1991 figure be annulled because of objections raised in parts of the country.

But Ugokwe said Tuesday that this was not peculiar to Nigeria. He cited instances in the United States, Britain and Germany where, he said, disputes over census figures had to be resolved at the supreme court. He said the NPC had received requests from a number of countries on the method it used for the 1991 census.

According to him, preparations for Nigeria's next census in 2001 will commence next year.

PANA NNI/PE/FON 1Aug95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

181 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Zambian Police Stop Student Demonstration


LENGTH: 774 words


 

by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Police in the Zambian capital of Lusaka Tuesday blocked a planned demonstration march by university students protesting government's proposed change of name of their campus in honour of one of the country's deceased nationalist leaders.

The students who had gathered outside the campus awaiting police clearance to march to parliament were later told they could not be given a permit to stage the protest. They carried placards condemning the government which they accused of hypocrisy for wanting to use names of national heroes for political expediency. 

One placard read, "UNZA (University of Zambia) to continue, Abash Nkumbula," in reference to late veteran nationalist Harry Mwaanga Nkumbula whose name the government has proposed to give to the university.

Information minister Amusaa Mwanamwambwa announced this week that government would introduce a motion in parliament to rename the university, the Lusaka international airport and the Zambia Air Services Training Institute in memory of Nkumbula, Simon Mwansa Kapwepwe and Valentine Shula Musakanya, respectively, for their great contribution to the freedom struggle and development of the country.

The students, lecturers and researchers unions have opposed the move, saying the university had won so much international repute which they thought could be "diluted" by the sudden change of name.

They and other critics have accused the ruling Movement of Multiparty Democracy (MMD) governement of President Frederick Chiluba of trying to use the names of the fallen national heroes for political gain.

Nkumbula, generally regarded as the founding father of Zambian nationalism had been leader of the African National Congress (ANC), fore-runner of the United National Independence Party (UNIP) which, under Kenneth Kaunda, won independence for Zambia. Kapwepwe once served as vice president to Kaunda and had been a fiery freedom fighter. Musakanya was Zambia's first junior minister incharge of technical education and had been instrumental in setting up the training school for Zambian pilots and other civil aviation personnel.

It has now been turned into a regional training centre for the 11-member Southern Africa Development Community (SADC).

The government-owned influential "Times of Zambia" Wednesday in an editorial also opposed the proposed renaming of the three institutions. "...with the kind of reaction that the suggested changes have met it is clear that there is a strong undercurrent of resistance. it would be wrong to assume that once the changes have been officially effected, resistance will fizzle out," it said. Zambian Police Stop Student Demonstration

Nkumbula hails from Zambia's southern region, recently ostracised by the main opposition,UNIP, by ditching its President Kebby Musokotwane, a southerner, in favour of former president Kenneth Kaunda.

Political analysts say Chiluba wants to use Nkumbula's name to woo southern support for his party and win further political sympathies among the politically militant northerners, the home base of both Kapwepwe and Musakanya. Zambia is scheduled to hold its second multiparty general elections in 1996, and Kaunda has said he will seek a re-match with Chiluba for the republican presidency. The first were in 1991 which brought Chiluba and his MMD to power.

PANA MK/PBM 2AUG95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

182 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Nigeria Opts For Dialogue In Relations


LENGTH: 734 words


 

by Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent NEW YORK, United States, (PANA) - Nigeria's Foreign Minister Tom Ikimi, has called for dialogue between the United States and Nigeria as a way of easing the current tension between them.

"It's time for dialogue and cooperation (between the countries)," Ikimi said at several meetings Tuesday with members of editorial boards of major American newspapers and magazines based in New York. The minister said "we have no interest in having confrontation with a country as powerful as the U.S.," adding: "we have been long-time friends and trading partners and we wish to continue that way." 

Relations between the two countries have been strained largely by what Washington considers lack of progress in Nigeria's democratic process, especially since the last military regime of Gen. Ibrahim Babangida annulled the 12 June 1993 presidential election.

The United States government has imposed limited sanctions on Nigeria because of the annulment and the return of military to Nigerian politics in November 1993.

Ikimi said Nigeria's current head of state, Gen. Sani Abacha, believed in dialogue and was interested in easing the tension between the two countries. Stressing the need for Nigerian government officials to be able to meet with their U.S. counterparts, a situation which is not currently possible because visa restrictions, Ikimi said "how can there be a meeting point without dialogue?" He said "if high-level Nigerian officials cannot come here, how can we discuss with the U.S.?," adding that his visit had been restricted to new York by the U.S. authorities. The minister, however said he had useful discussions with the U.S. Assistant Secretary of State, George Moose, during the last OAU Summit in Addis Ababa, but could not follow up on that now "because my visit here is restricted to the New York area".

"Officials in Washington can't meet with me, which would have been good for the interest of both countries," he said, noting, however, that he had facilitated the visit to Nigeria of many U.S. officials and members of Congress in spite of the U.S. policy.

Ikimi met with editorial board members of the Wall Street Journal, Time Magazine and Amsterdam News, among others. He warned against the imposition of further sanctions on Nigeria, as currently being advocated by the lobby group Transafrica and some human rights organisations. According to him, sanctions would not hurt those in government alone but would affect the 100 million people of Nigeria.

"Sanctions will damage the potential of Nigeria to achieve its economic and political development," said Ikimi, who explained that he decided to meet with the American media to present the other side of issues to them as well as the American people who, he said, had been inundated with "half truths and distortions."

Among issues that featured in Ikimi's meetings were the issue of clemency for those convicted of plotting to overthrow the military government, the annulled 1993 presidential elections and the political transition. They also discussed the fate of detained millionaire-politician, Moshood Abiola who claimed victory in the cancelled poll and Nigeria's battle against drug trafficking and corruption.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

Africa News


August, 1995


Southern Africa Police Chiefs Form Anti-Crime Body


LENGTH: 440 words


 

VICTORIA FALLS, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Southern African Police Chiefs have formed a Sub-regional grouping to co-operate in combating crime among member countries of the the Southern African Development Community (SADC).

The grouping, named the Southern Africa Regional Police Chiefs Conference (SARPCCO), was formed at the end of the two-day police chiefs sub-regional conference here on Tuesday.

Recommendations on how it should operate were presented for debate and possible adoption by the region's ministers in charge of law and order who had a one-day conference on Wednesday. 

The police chiefs, led by newly elected SARPCCO chairman, Police Commissioner Augustine Chihuri of Zimbabwe, agreed that the decision-making and supervisory powers of SARPCCO be vested in the chiefs of Police Council. They also agreed that a secretariat be established as the permanent administration and technical body through which SARPCCO would operate.

The newly created INTERPOL sub-regional bureau in Harare would be used for the purpose of setting up the SARPCCO secretariat. "To ensure the effective functioning of SARPCCO and to avoid duplication of effort and waste of resources and finance, the activity of SARPCCO should be co-ordinated and carried out within the framework of the interpol sub-regional bureau," said a document prepared by the police chiefs.

The same structures would also be used to prepare and co-ordinate a sub-regional police training strategy. "

This strategy should take account of the possibilities which exist within the sub-region but also, where appropriate, those which can be made available through other international organisations and bilaterally by countries which can provide assistance," the chiefs recommended.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

August, 1995


Mugabe Appeals for Regional Security


LENGTH: 734 words


 

VICTORIA FALLS, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbwean president Robert Mugabe said on Wednesday he expects the Interpol sub-regional bureau to be opened in Harare to make a major contribution to regional security and effective crime prevention. Officially opening a conference of Southern African Law and Order ministers who are discussing the establishment of the Interpol office, Mugabe said although the region did not yet face crime problems as serious as those elsewhere, member countries should not be complacent.

He said using up-to-date crime tracing and communication facilities pledged to the harare bureau by interpol headquarters, regional police forces should develop human resources and structures which would enable them to effectively execute co-ordinated strategies for the management and monitoring of all forms of cross-border crime. " 

Those who believe that certain forms of criminal activity are here to stay must be made to swallow their words as the region develops its own capacity to respond to what appears to be an emerging pattern of organised crime," said Mugabe. Zimbabwe has allocated five million US dollars for the construction of the Interpol sub-regional bureau. Other countries would contribute administration funds and manpower for the bureau.

"Properly designed regional police training structures should enable our police forces not only to share perceptions, insights and ideas on topical policing issues, but also to develop research programmes that are appropriate to the policing needs and priorities of the region." Mugabe said he was concerned that specific strategies for crime combat in africa continued to be hampered by inadequate information and communication networks, lack of harmonisation of law and order legislation. Also of concern were the lack of appropriate regional crime prevention policies, capacity to carry out research that would make the region self-sufficient in matters relating to development of investigative techniques, drug detection and analysis and related skills, he added.

"The task before this conference is important from a political point of view. The world is currently focusing its attention on this region as we attempt to articulate appropriate mechanisms and strategies for the achievement of regional security and conflict resolution. "There is need to place the crime combat agenda within the wider context of regional stability, peace and security because there can be no doubt at all that the prosperity of our region depends on them," he said. Mugabe said he was worried that although political stability was almost guaranteed in the region following the democratisation of South Africa and peace processes in Angola and Mozambique, there was still a problem of controlling firearms in private hands.

"Police within the region are expected to develop meaningful strategies to ensure that such firearms are not being turned on the peace-loving peoples of our region through illegal activities such as armed robbery, car-jackings and other terrorist attacks," he said. He supported Interpol's adoption of a resolution which recommended that its 176 member countries should trace all firearms from points of manufacture to purchasers as a way of monitoring arms use.

PANA-ZIANA IM/NDN/PBM 2AUG95

August, 1995


Human Rights Union to Hold Congress in Ouagadougou


LENGTH: 387 words


 

OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina (PANA) - The Inter-African Human Rights Union is to hold its first ordinary congress in Ougadougou starting Thursday.. The meeting is expected to bring together participants from all over Africa who will review "the status of human rights in Africa".

The human rights body is expected to elect a new bureau capable of meeting the challenge of the disastrous situation of human rights in Africa. The Union held its constituent assembly here on 4 July 1992 in the presence of at least 30 non-governmental organisations and human rights groups. It has implanted itself in 37 African countries and brings together 35 NOGs and 14 human rights institutions. Since its inception, the unnion has strived to be present wherever there human rights are violated. It was particularly involved in the attempts to settle the crises in Rwanda and Burundi. It has also contributed to the settlement of the Tuareg issue in Mali and Niger. 

It intervened in various African countries, especially in Senegal and Cote D'Ivoire, to call for the release of jailed opposition leaders. According to the union's Chairman Halidou Ouedraogo, the union has become a reference in the area of human rights in Africa.

Since 1994, it has been publishing, with the help of its sections, a report on the situation of human rights in Africa. He said the first ordinary congress is expected to see the adhersion of several other human rights organisations from English -speaking countries in Southern Africa.

PANA-AIB JD/ZK/SG/SJD/PBM 2AUG95

August, 1995


Cause of Southern African Diseases Identified


LENGTH: 360 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - A Zambian official has attributed the outbreaks of epidemics like cholera, malaria and bilharzia in Southern Africa to the degradation of the environment in the region's countries.

The official, Juliana Chileshe, told a human rights and justice seminar here that these diseases can only be reverse through strategies at national levels to ensure sharing of tasks, information for development and co-ordination of efforts. 

Chileshe said the Southern African Development Community (SADC) region lacked environmental education strategies and programmes to conduct the education in a comprehensive manner that reached all target groups. "The degradation of the environment in the Southern African region has been marked by incidence of epidemics such as cholera, malaria and bilharzia," she said.

A lot of people in the region were not aware of their environmental rights and Chileshe said as a result endured a lot of hardships living in polluted areas. She said local authorities and governments owed their citizens the duty of cleaning up the surroundings as well as management of waste material from industry.

On realising this responsibility, some governments often hid information on the environment, fearing the reaction of the people.

PANA-ZIANA SJM/NDN/PBM 2AUG95

Africa News


August, 1995


Zambia's Infant Mortality for Lack of Breastfeeding High


LENGTH: 440 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - A United Nations official has expressed concern at Zambia's high infant mortality rate of 112 children per 1000 per year before the age of five because mothers ignore the importance exclusive breastfeeding.

Mark Stirling, Zambia's Representative of the UN Children's Fund (UNICEF) said this Tuesday in Lusaka during the launch of activities marking the 1 to 7 August World Breastfeeding week. He said due to lack of breastfeeding, roughly one in every 10 live births in the country die before their first birthday. 

This year, he predicted, about 35,000 Zambian infants will die, most of them within the first few months of their life, of preventable illnesses like diarrhoea, respiratory infections, fevers and malnutrition. Stirling said that while these figures are alarming, they could be changed if mothers fed their children with breast milk for at least six months. He urged feeding mothers to understand the purpose of breast feeding.He called on the families and employers with breastfeeding mothers to give them support and encouragement.

The UN official said the government and UNICEF were working out plans to make at least 40 maternity facilities 'Baby Friendly" by the end of the year.These hospitals will be given the means to encourage exclusive breastfeeding.

Speaking earlier, the Chairperson of the Breastfeed Association of Zambia, Rose Namambo said the mothers' lactating period should be increased from the current three months to at least two years. She also called on employers to provide opportunities at work places that would enable mothers continue breastfeeding their children.

PANA-ZANA LM/RK/PBM 2AUG95

August, 1995


Mozambique Seeks More Buses From Japan


LENGTH: 374 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - The Mozambican government is currently negotiating for a grant of 3.5 million US dollars from Japan to be used in purchasing new buses.

Reporting this Wednesday 'Noticias', the Maputo daily, quoted Transport Minister Paulo Muxanga as saying the government tabled that request during negotiations taking place in the central city of Quelimane. The buses will be distributed among those provinces that did not receive any new buses over the past year.

The last consignment of buses ordered (72, from India, paid for by a five million dollar grant from Japan) were given to the three main cities of Maputo, Beira and Nampula. The minister also said that his ministry was in discussions with the planning and finance ministry to acquire funds to repair dozens of vehicles of the publicly-owned Maputo Bus Company (TPM) that are currently off the roads.

He said this will not necessarily mean an increase in the number of buses in the capital because, as the old buses are reconditioned, the new ones currently operating in Maputo will be redistributed elsewhere in the country.

The minister added that the arrival of new buses will take place simultaneously with the privatization of three state-owned long distance passenger transport companies, Romos, Romoza and Romon. P

Africa News


August, 1995


Zimbabwean Army Reduced by 10,000


LENGTH: 454 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The government has over the past 18 months reduced the size of the army from 51,000 to 41,000, Defence Minister Moven Mahachi said on Monday.

At a press conference launching the Community Assistance Week of the forces, Mahachi said the downsizing exercise was on course, with the army retiring or retrenching some soldiers every month.

"Eighty percent of our budget is spent on wages and salaries, we need to reduce that," he said. 

This year's defence vote of zimdollars 2.025 billion (USD 238 million) is the second largest although the figure represents a 4.4 percent decline from last year.

The government has indicated it wishes to reduce the size of the army to 40,000.

Launching the week, which is a prelude to activities to celebrate defence forces day on August 12, Mahachi said defence forces would be deployed to children's homes and disadvantaged rural communities to carry out wide ranging activities.

"The defence forces' involvement in various local community projects demonstrates the close link and association between our defence forces and the local communities in which they are based. "It also helps improve their public relations with the people in these various locations," said Mahachi.

The forces will repaint schools, construct classrooms and toilets, carry out cleaning exercises and render free health services at some hospitals.

"During this year's community assistance week, a combined United States and Zimbabwe defence forces team will render comprehensive health services to people around selected centres in the country," said Mahachi.

PANA-ZIANA MUH/NDN/FON 7Aug95

August, 1995


Entry Visas Mandatory for Sudan-bound Visitors


LENGTH: 387 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - All foreigners visiting Sudan must with effect from Tuesday (8 August) obtain entry visas, the Official Sudan News Agency (suna) reported Monday.

SUNA quoted a statement from the the Interior Ministry as saying Sunday that the decision is applicable to nationals of all countries excluding states which maintain bilateral agreements with Sudan exempting their nationals from entry visa requirements and those treated on reciprocal bases. Khartoum in March 1990, decided to exclude Arab nationals from obtaining entry visas in the effort to boost solidarity and cooperation among arab people in all fields, the statement noted.

It said that decision achieved positive results in spite of some shortcomings which require some modifications to enhance the measure.

Sudan has been at odds with some of its neighbours who accuse the government of Gen. Omar Al-Bashir of sponsoring Islamic radicals waging campaigns of destablilisation in the countries.

Relations between Sudan and Egypt, its northern neighbour, has remained tense since the 26 June assassination attempt on the live of President Hosni Mubarak in Addis Ababa as his convoy travelled from the airport to the city to attend the summit of the Organisaqtion of African Unity (OAU). The Egyptian leader accused Sudan of implication in the assassination attempt but Khartoum denied any involvement.

August, 1995


Police Arrest former President Kaunda


LENGTH: 374 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) Former Zambian President Kenneth Kaunda was arrested Sunday for addressing a public meeting without police permit at Northern Technical College (NORTEC) in Ndola recently, the official Zambian News Agency (ZANA), reported.

ZANA said Kaunda was arrested and charged for the alleged offence at Lusaka central police station at 14.00 hours local time (about 11.00 Gmt). 

Kaunda's Press attache Muhabi Lungu told ZANA that the former head of state will appear in court on Friday in connection with the alleged offence.

Lungu said kaunda who returned from Zimbabwe by road Wednesday night was arrested at Lusaka international airport were he had gone to receive his wife, Betty, who was returning home from medical treatment in Britain.

"The police have been waiting for Dr Kaunda at Lusaka international aiport for several days... this is victimisation and a breach of procedure. Our lawyers will take up the matter", Lungu said. Contacted, Home Affairs Minister, chitelu Sampa said he had not received a report on the matter.

There was no immediate comment from the police.

Relations between the former President and the government have been at their lowest ebb since Kaunda won election as Chairman of the United Indpendence Party (UNIP) last month. He plans to challenge his successor, President Federick Chiluba in fortcoming elections.

PANA-ZANA KL/FON 6Aug95

192 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Circumcision Recommended as HIV Transmission Reducing Factor


LENGTH: 947 words


 

by Peter Masebu, PANA Staff Correspondent

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Circumcised males face fewer risks of HIV infection than those who are not, according to a leading Senegalese Virologist, Prof. Souleymane Mboup of Cheikh Anta Diop's Faculty of Medicine in Dakar. The doctor is currently researching the possibility that the resistance a group of HIV Type 2 infected Dakar-based prostitutes have shown towards HIV Type 1 infection for a decade could provide a clue for an AIDS vaccine.

In a wide-ranging interview here, however, the military doctor, internationally recognised for his discovery of the less virulent Human Immunodeficiency Virus-Type 2 (HIV 2), said he lacked data on whether female circumcision provided the same protection. He was asked to comment on findings from a 1993 research, conducted on 837 married men in Kigali, Rwanda, which established that 29 per cent of the uncircumcised were seropositive compared with 21 per cent of those who were.The results were published in January by the Journal of AIDS. "These results confirm what we have been saying all along, that circumcision reduced not only HIV infection but also the risk of other sexually transmitted diseases, hence the low infection rate in countries like Senegal where the majority of the population are Moslems," Mboup told PANA. His argument seems to be strong, according to African country by country HIV infection rates published in a book by the Dakar-based non-governmental organisation, Enda-Tiers Monde, in 1993. 

In a 274-page book "SIDA en Afrique. Bilan d'une Decenie" (Aids in Africa. The Results of a Decade) shows that the mainly Christian eastern and southern African countries as leading in terms of HIV infection. The book placed Malawi on top with 13 per cent, followed by Tanzania, Uganda and Zimbabwe (10 per cent each), 9 per cent for Kenya and 7 per cent for Burundi while Rwanda recorded 4 per cent. Cote d'Ivoire led the pack in West Africa with 8.5 per cent.

Low HIV infection rates were recorded in countries with predominantly Moslem populations: Chad (1 per cent), Libya (0.02), Mauritania (0.25), Mali (1.4) Morocco (0), Niger (0.7), Senegal (1) Somalia (0.5) and Sudan (0.2 per cent).

But according to Mboup, Africa and the rest of the Third World are now faced with a catastrophic AIDS situation because those who were infected ten years ago have graduated from the infection into the disease phase, "while continuing to infect others as well." "This is mainly because in the initial stage people ignored to take care of infected persons thinking this was not a priority. But now we shall witness a lot of deaths and very many sick people," he added. The major problem, Mboup said, is the unaffordability of drugs like AZT which prolongs the life of those infected and can block the transmission of HIV from a mother to her unborn infant.

"We lack the means to buy these drugs. In Senegal, treatment with AZT costs 150,000 F CFA (1 $= 480 F CFA) per month. Very few can afford and the drug does not prevent death forever," he told this correspondent. According to the virologist, bactrim is the only affordable anti-biotic which delays the disastrous effects of "opportunistic diseases like pulmonary infections and diarrhoea" and improves the health status of sufferers.

Prof. Mboup, who is a member of a World Health Organisation (WHO) select committee on AIDS vaccines, said none of the 12 that were being tried had yielded the required results before going into Phase III, on humans. "The scientific community is currently very divided on this issue with certain countries and organisations saying Phase III trials should go ahead even before conclusive results are obtained in Phase I and II, as was with the case with other vaccines. Others are saying that, for safety reasons, the trials should only start after the first two phases have given assurances," he said.

As to what was the African position in that controversial issue, Mboup said: "I think we African scientists need to hold serious consultations before entering the final phase. We need to talk the same language to secure the health of our populations." According to him, the forthcoming International African Conference on Aids and Sexually Transmitted Diseases, slated for Kampala, Uganda, in December 1995, will be a good opportunity for Africans to come up with a concise stand on the issue of vaccines. PANA PBM/JE 9AUG95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

193 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Squeeze on Zimbabwe's Health Funding


LENGTH: 494 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwean Health and Child Welfare Minister Timothy is unhappy with this year's inadequate allocation to hospitals owned by local authorities, missionaries and voluntary organisations, saying this will negatively impact on the country's health services.

In the 1995/96 budget announced by Finance Minister Ariston Chambati on 27 July, local authorities, missions and voluntary organisations were allocated the equivalent of 27.1 million US dollars compared with 22 million US dollars last year.

In an interview Wednesday, Stamps said while there were nominal increases in the budget, in real terms the budget was less than last year. The local authorities, missions and voluntary organisations have been lobbying for an increase in government funding to ensure health services do not deteriorate. Stamps said local authorities might be forced to hike hospital and clinic fees during this financial year to meet some of their escalating costs. He said the local authorities, mission hospitals and voluntary organisations, such as St Giles, should have been allocated at least 35.3 million US dollars to operate effectively and efficiently. 

"The allocation to my ministry was not an increase but was, in real terms,( 11.8 million US dollars) less than that of the 1994/95 fiscal year. This means that we will have to cut back in some areas. "The most affected are the missions, local authorities and voluntary organisations. "They need in excess of zd 300 million, not the zd 230 million grant given. I do no want the ministry of finance to get me wrong - I appreciate that there is no money but it is just that the funds would affect health services in the country," Stamps said.

He said the inadequate funding would not affect salaries and wages but would have adverse effects on material things, like drugs and equipment. mission hospitals are already facing a serious shortage of drugs and insufficient equipment.

PANA-ZIANA FZ/NDN/PBM 9AUG95

August, 1995


Abacha Appoints New Petroleum Chief


LENGTH: 280 words


 

by Randy Zormelo, Pana Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria's military ruler General Sani Abacha has appointed Dalhaatu Bayero as the new head of the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation, replacing Chamberlain Oyibo who was sacked last month, state radio announced Tuesday in Lagos.

Oyibo was among 47 senior management officials of the NNPC sacked or retired in an effort to reorganise the corporation responsible for managing Nigeria's oil. 

Oil accounts for more than 90 percent of Nigeria's foreign exchange earnings.

Bayero had been acting head of the corporation since Oyibo's dismissal on 3 July for "irresponsibility". Appointed in november 1993, Oyibo was the fourth NNPC managing director to be dismissed in six years.

Africa News


August, 1995


Shipping Lines Procures New Vessel


LENGTH: 494 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - A Polish-built cargo ship bought by the Ethiopian Shipping Lines at a cost of 7.375 million dollars has become operational. The ship bought from a German company and named 'Admas' will replace the ageing 'Nigiste Saba', which has served for many years, Officials said.

Admas has 9,630 horse power and a capacity to carry 11,573 tonnes of cargo. Transport and Communications Vice-Minister, Ayenew Bitewilign said at the inaugural ceremony held at Assab Port on Monday that marine transport would help promote the country's foreign trade. Ayenew said Admas would increase the shipping capacity of the national carrier from 81,400 tonnes to 93,000 tonnes. 

The new ship, along the company's 30 years experience and its trained manpower would help strengthen not only Ethiopia's but also Africa's marine transportation, he said. The General Manager of the Shipping line, Ambachew Abraha, said 13 boats including the new one would be deployed to north-western Europe, the mediterranian, and countries in Middle and Far-east. He said the ships had been transporting refined petroleum and goods in border areas, adding that 80 per cent of the crew members and all office workers of the enterprise are Ethiopians.

Admas, whose carrying capacity exeeds that of Nigiste Saba by half, has a multi-dimentional service in transporting not only freight goods but also containers and others. Addisu Demissie, manager of the market survey and promotion service of the company, said on the occasion that the enterprise plans to buy better ships to replace old ones.

Apart from the tranports minister, Admas was visited Monday by Gebretsadkan Gebretensay, Chief of Defence Staff and Board Chairman of the Ethiopian Shipping Lines as as well as officials of the Eriterian government.

The company reportedly makes a turn-over of some 300 million birr (about 54 million dollars) every year.

PANA-ENA FT/AKM/FON 8Aug95

Africa News


August, 1995


Zimbabwe: No Rights Issues Expected This Year


LENGTH: 400 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Companies listed on the Zimbabwe Stock Exchange are unlikely to float rights issues for the rest of this year as market sentiment remains depressed by a combination of drought and high inflation.

Stockbrokers said Tuesday said any rights issue would not receive enough support as investors currently preferred the lucrative short-term money market where returns where returns are as high as 27 percent for 90-day paper.

"The market is currently weak for a rights issue," Arthur Mavima of Dataworld Ltd said. He said the market has this year seen only two private placings by TSL and FSI. 

Others, like gold producer Cluff Resources Zimbabwe Ltd, have said they will only float a rights issue when the market recovers.

However, analysts say prospects for meaningful recovery this year are bleak given that inflation is expected to rise to about 25 percent by the end of the year from the current 19.9 percent.

Higher inflation will mean interest rates are unlikely to come down in the near future resulting in a further flight of funds from the bourse to the attractive money market.

Quincor stockbrokers say it is only foreign investors who are currently a bit active in the market. These are however supporting only highly capitalised securities like Delta. Other counters enjoying investment from foreigners include Bindura and Zimsun.

Analysts say a good rain season next year should induce confidence in the market and probably set a bull run into motion. PANA-Ziana JM/STC/DS 8Aug95

197 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Banks Cheated, Interest Rates Went Up


LENGTH: 360 words


 

by Peter Mwaura, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia

(PANA) -- Zambia is now experiencing high inflation and interest rates because commercial banks in the country cheated the central bank over their statutory reserve requirements.

The director of the newly created financial markets department of the Bank of Zambia (BOZ), Situmbeko Musokotwane was reported Tuesday in the local press saying that the commercial banks avoided the the statutory reserve ratio and cheated by disguising their true deposit liquidity positions. The ratio is used to compell banks to lock away 29 percent of their liquid assets in the central bank to infleunce liquidity and achieve macro-economic targets such as reduced inflation. The banks also cheated through the use of subsidiary leasing companies which were conveniently used to shift bank deposits.

BOZ is no longer using the statutory reserve ratio because it was "increasingly getting to be an ineffective instrument of monetary policy".

Situmboko said because of these shortcomings, the BOZ was now using daily open market operations to provide a more flexible instrument for monetary operations.

PANA PM/FON 8Aug95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

August, 1995


Exchange Opens Week In Dull Trading


LENGTH: 400 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Shares on the stock market here ended a dull day Monday, with most investors staying out for fresh market-moving news. The GSE all-share index closed up 0.47 points at 313.08 compared to Friday's close of 312.61 points.

"Trading was quiet as investors seen to be waiting for fresh market movingg news and probably the close of the social security bank's public offer floatation", said a market player. The flotation ends at the end of August. There was not enough buying, to push up prices, dealers said, but they were content with the general market situation of three gainers without a decliner. 

The broader market started the week with Mobil Oil Ghana Limited (MOGL) closing 100 decis up at 4.000. CFAO climbed two cedis to 30 and Home Finance Company (HFC) was one cedi better at 116 after the release of an impressive half-year report. (1,196 cedis = 1 usd)

HFC recorded an after tax profit of 299,255,5000 cedis, representing 128 per cent increase on the previous profit of 78,349,000 cedis. This however, pushed down its price earning ratio from 15 to nine and enhanced its earnings par share to 12.60 cedis from the previous close of 7.75 cedis.

Dealers still have more stock on their books as was reflected in the total share offer of 783,520 and demand of 431,310 of which 33,760 were traded.

"We still have loads of shares waiting to be cleared and we need fresh incentives to bring more local investors to the market", said a dealer. The market capitalization, however, went up to 2,335.51 billion cedis from Friday's 2.334.95 billion cedis.

Africa News


August, 1995


Sudan Government Encourages Wheat Imports


LENGTH: 440 words


 

By Yahya El Hassan, PANA Staff Correspondent

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - The government of Sudan has exempted wheat imports from all taxes, a move considered necessary to make up for a short fall in local production.

The Minister of Industry, Badr Eddin Suleiman, told the official Sudan News Agency (SUNA) the measures also include the liberalisation of wheat distribution and the exemption of local flour mills from all forms of taxes. The move is expected to end the rationing of bread which will henceforth be available at a price determined by the forces of supply and demand, he said. 

Suleiman said the new policy is meant to redress the gap in wheat supply caused by fluctuating local production. He put the country's current wheat consumption at 600,000 tonnes per annum.

Shortages of wheat have have nearly doubled the domestic price of the product since April.

Last week, the Minister of Agriculture, Ahmed Ali Geneif, said wheat producers will be paid the equivalent of USD 254 per tonne in addition to 25 percent subsidy on production cost as an incentive. Meanwhile, the official 'El Sudan El Hadeith Newpaper has said some 200,000 tonnes of wheat were imported into the country last year to meet local shortages. Sudan produced 300,000 tonnes of wheat last year. Figures for this year are not available.

The government in 1991 vowed to produce one million tonnes of wheat on the irrigated farms in central and northern parts of the country. But Farmers were only able to produce 800,000 tonnes of the crop in 1992. Since then production has contined to fall largely due to rising costs and relatively warm weather in wheat growing areas.

PANA YH/FON 8Aug95

August, 1995


Namibia Telecom Receives EU Assistance


LENGTH: 347 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The European Investment Bank (EIB) is providing 12.7 million ECU (about 17 million dollars) to 'Telecom Namibia' for the modernisation of key sections of the country's telephone network.

The EIB, the long-term funding agency of the European Union said in a release to PANA the amount would be disbursed as loan repayable after 15 years. 

Specific projects to be executed with the loan include a digital optic-fibre link from Windhoek, the capital, to the western port town of Walvis Bay and environs.

Construction of a second digital exchange in Windhoek will also be funded with the loan, the bank said.

This is the fourth project that the EIB, based in Luxembourg has financed since it started operations in Namibia in 1992. Three Previous investment funding involved a tannery, a water scheme and a sewage project totalling 16.6 ECU (about 22.2 million dollars).

The promoter, 'Telecom Namibia', was created in 1992 as part of the country's deregulation and liberalisation of the posts and telecomunication sector.

PANA FON 8Aug95

201 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Metroline For Nigeria's Capital


LENGTH: 587 words


 

by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria plans to construct an underground rail transport network or Metroline for its inland capital, Abuja, in what is being seen as a precautionary measure against the transport chaos in the nation's former capital, Lagos. Abuja formally replaced Lagos in December 1991 as Nigeria's seat of government, but the port city remains the country's economic hub.

The Nigerian minister of state for the Federal Capital Territory, Mariam Ikejiani-Clark said at a forum organised by the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) on Sunday the Abuja metroline is proposed for the 1996-1998 National Rolling Plan. She did not elaborate on the cost, but said the decision to commence the construction of the line was to ease transport problems faced by commuters in the territory. Unlike Lagos, harbouring some six million people, Abuja has less than one million inhabitants, mainly civil servants. 

But problems of public transportation are gradually creeping into the city conceived in 1976 to ease the congestion in Lagos. A proposal by the previous civilian government to construct a metroline in lagos in 1982 at an estimated cost of 700 million U.S. dollars was cancelled by a subsequent military regime.

The cancellation cost the state government more than 30 million dollars in default payment to the consortium of french companies, which took the state government to court. Experts consider a metroline project as one of the solutions to the perennial traffic congestion in Lagos, but government officials say the cost has become unaffordable. Abuja's transport problem is compounded by inadequate accommodation, with many of the inhabitants now resident in satellite towns. Ikejiani-Clark said buses previously run by the Abuja urban mass transport company had been grounded by lack of spare parts. Most foreign missions, currently operating from Lagos have been given until the end of 1997 to move to Abuja.

On the problem of accommodation, the minister said some 25,500 plots had been allocated to Nigerians since the creation of the capital territory. But according to the minister, government revoked some of the allocations because of the inability of the allotees to develop them after the statutory period of six years expired. She said she had reorganised the land department of the ministry to stem corruption, adding: "Abuja is the federal capital, so, every Nigerian desirous of land should be able to get it."

PANA PE/FON 8Aug95

August, 1995


Defence, Security Chiefs Support Truth Commission >


LENGTH: 320 words


 

by Lionel Williams PANA Staff Correspondent

PRETORIA, South Africa (PANA) - Six former defence force chiefs and police commissioners under the old South African apartheid regime have pledged their full support for the country's controversial Truth and Reconciliation Commission.

The commission was set up earlier this year to investigate human rights violations during the Apartheid era in South Africa. 

The generals said they would co-operate to ensure that the truth and reconciliation commission was successful.

But they also expressed reservations about who should be responsible for human rights violations of the past, saying the investigation could turn into a witch-hunt against individuals who merely followed orders.

Justice Minister Dullah Omar said at a media briefing follwong a meeting between the generals and President Nelson Mandela that the generals had accepted that there had been violations of human rights in the past which needed to be dealt with by the commission. No specific issues were discussed.

PANA LW/IS/FON 11Aug95

August, 1995


African Women Will Not Be Marginalised in Beijing, Says Mongella


LENGTH: 334 words


 

by Mildred Mulenga Pana Staff Correspondent

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - As the count down to the largest conference ever hosted by the United Nations appraoches, African delegates to the Fourth World Conference on Women say they will stand strong and not allow themselves to be buried or marignalised by other regions.

Conference Secretary General Gertrude Mongella of Tanzania told a 'media encounter' for African journalists to cover the conference in Beijing this September that Africa intends to make its felt at the meeting. Mongella, addressing the meeting in Accra, Ghana, however urged African women not be swayed by problems they could encounter at the Beijing but remain focused on their goals for the empowerment of women.

The Beijing meeting will offer governments, non-governmental organisations, the private sector and individuals an opportunity to review their efforts and renew their commitment to the theme of the conference, 'Action for Equality, Development and Peace.'

The conference will adopt a 'platform for action' on key issues that hinder women's full and equal participation in development.

Prominent Sudan Opposition Figure Defects from Opposition Ranks


LENGTH: 240 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - A prominent figure in the Sudanese opposition General el Hadi Bushra returned home Thursday ending five years of armed rebellion against the government of General Omer el Bashir.

The 51 year old Major General who once headed Sudan's intellegence agency told a press conference at the Khartoum airport that he had defected from the opposition because it no longer believed in a unified Sudan. Sudan has suffered a major rebellion from the Sudanese People's Liberation Army seeking greater autonomy for the South.

Gen. Bushra arrived from Jordan in the company Mahdi Ibrahim, the Sudanese state minister at the presidency.

Africa News


August, 1995


UN Military Chief Confident of Angolan Peace


LENGTH: 440 words


 

LUANDA, Angola (PANA) - the United Nations chief military observer to Angola, Major General Chris Garuba on Thursday expressed confidence in the Angolan peace process despite repeated violation of the cease-fire by both sides and a "food aid" war being waged by the rebel Unita movement.

Garuba told Zimbabwean journalists that cease-fire violations were down to 90 incidents last month compared to 137 a month in the previous two months.

"You can see there is some progress and if the trend continues we are headed for a happy and successful peace process," he said. About 45 percent of the cease-fire violations were attacks on civilian targets designed to either control the movement of food aid in contested areas or to stop people from moving into areas controlled by the other side. Garuba named Jonas Savimbi's Unita forces as being responsible for attacks on civilian targets as they try to control the movement of food aid to famine-stricken areas in the country. 

"It is a new tactic and we have put it to unita that they should desist from this kind of unfortunate action," he said.

In some cases, Major General Garuba said, roads cleared of mines had mines laid again overnight thereby delaying the deployment of un peace-keepers in those areas.

However, only 15 percent of the incidents were military manouvres to reinforce troops or gain territory while the rest were what Garuba said were "very minor incidents that would not derail the peace process".

About 3 664 troops from India, Uruguay and Zimbabwe are already in Angola to oversee the implementation of the peace accord between the MPLA government and Unita to end nearly two decades of civil war. More 350 military observers from all over the world are also in Angola. PANA-ZIANA EMM/FS/DS 10Aug95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

Africa News


August, 1995


Zambian Police Move to Prevent Political Violence


LENGTH: 614 words


 

by Musengwa Kayaya PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambian police are keeping a vigilant eye to avert possible political violence during the ongoing by-election campaigns in the Eastern Luangwa parliamentary constituency.

This past weekend, Police Inspector-General Francis Ndholvu sent re-inforcements to prevent possible clashes between supporters of the ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) and the main opposition United National Independence Party (UNIP).

In what is expected to be a major test of popularity, the two parties are fighting tooth and nail to snatch the Luangwa parliamentary seat during the by-election, scheduled for 25 August. 

Ndhlovu confirmed in Lusaka Sunday that a contingent of police officers had been sent to the area following reports of near confrontation between rival party supporters over rooms at the only rest-house in the area.

UNIP President Kenneth Kaunda was Saturday in Luangwa to spearhead his party's campaign for the parliamentary seat which fell vacant early this year after the death of the party's member of parliament.

MMD supporters reportedly attempted to deny the UNIP entourage accommodation at the local rest house which is owned by a local prominent member of President Frederick Chiluba's party.

The Luangwa by-election is among eight others to be held 25 august in various parts of the country following either the resignation, death or expulsion of incumbents. They include the Mpulungu and Mbala parliamentary seats formerly held by former MMD junior ministers, Derrick Chitala and Dean Mung'omba who were recently expelled from the ruling party. Both Chitala and Mung'omba have declined to recontest the seats saying they still needed to consolidate their newly formed party, the Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC).

They were kicked out of Chiluba's MMD because they openly criticised his management of public affairs. The MMD and UNIP have fielded candidates for all the constituencies. The by-elections are expected to provide an insight into Kaunda's current public rating since his re-election as UNIP President, replacing his former Prime Minister Kebby Musokotwane. Political analysts here say Kaunda is likely to "leave no stone unturned" in his campaigns for the by-elections and is expected to use the results to gauge his party's chances to regain power in the scheduled 1996 general elections.

His party suffered a blow last week when a veteran member and leader of the minority bench in parliament, Dingiswayo Banda, defected to the ruling party.

A by-election will have to be conducted in his former Lundazi Constituency, a UNIP stronghold, also in Eastern Zambia. PANA MK/PM/PBM 14AUG95

Africa News


August, 1995


South Africa to Stock Iranian Oil, Despite U.S Protests


LENGTH: 387 words


 

by Lionel Williams PANA Correspondent

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - South Africa intends to honour an agreement to store 15-million barrels of Iranian oil, despite American efforts to win allies in an embargo against the Gulf state.

The General Manager of South Africa's state-owned Strategic Fuel Fund, Mr. Kobus Van Zyl, says Pretoria may even try to increase the quantity or Iranian crude it is to store. 

During the apartheid era, the strategic Fuel Fund was instrumental in ensuring that South Africa obtained and stocked enough oil, in spite of an international oil embargo.

But recently,the Fund's agreement with the National Iranian Oil Company is believed to have sparked friction with the United States, which imposed a trade and commerce ban on Iran on 6 June this year.

The ban has found little international support as countries like Russia and Japan have resisted Washington's attempts to trade with Teheran because of its alleged support for terrorism. Van Zyl confirmed that South Africa and Iran will market the oil jointly, although the bulk of the trading activity is likely to be organised by South Africa.

Iran supplies 60 to 70 per cent of South Africa's oil needs of some 420 000 barrels a day. Choosing South Africa as a storage site, said Van Zyl, would assure its market here.

PANA LW/PBM 14AUG95

he 57-counter industrial index recorded a modest 18.08 points upsurge to close the day at 3 662.32 amid reasonable trading in the blue-chip Delta Corporation. "A further round of gains counteracted losses in a fairly active sector.

Tender for Cabinda Port Out


LENGTH: 214 words


 

LUANDA, Angola (PANA) - The Angolan government has put out an international tender for the construction of a seaport in its oil-rich North-Western Cabinda Enclave.

The port is expected to be equipped with 596 meter-long vertical anti-flood devices and a 200- meter polyvalent terminal, a source in the Public Works Ministry told the local news agency, Angop Monday. The ministry source said the tender for the works, to be completed within two years, will remain open until 10 October.

Africa News


August, 1995


European Union to Help Comesa Beat Trade Barriers


LENGTH: 347 words


 

by Mildred Mulenga

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - The 20-member Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (Comesa) has asked the European Union to help do away with the multiplicity of documents which act as a "non-tariff barrier" in trade between member states.

Opening a three-day 'single goods declaration' conference in Lusaka Tuesday, Comesa Secretary General Bingu wa Mutharika said Comesa intends to do away with unnecessary customs declaration burdens and instead have only one single common customs declaration. Mutharika said the import, export, transit and warehousing declarations which Comesa states were using were expensive and discouraged trade.

The Comesa member states meeting in Lusaka are discussing the proposal for a standard customs document. The proposed document is based on the European model. The meeting will come up with a report and recommendations to be presented to the customs and trade committee meeting.

Comesa intends to completely remove tariff barriers in intra-Comesa trade and eliminate other disincentives to cross-border trade by the year 2000.

The organization was established in December 1994, replacing the East and Southern African Preferential Trade Area. PANA MM/DS 15Aug95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

Africa News


August, 1995


Brightening Prospects for South Africa by Lionel Williams, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 1172 words


 

by Paul Fauvet PANA Correspondent

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Mozambican Finance and Planning Minister Tomas Salomao has announced simplifications in the procedures for documentation of potential investors in the country. Speaking at a press conference in Maputo, Salomao said there would now be a genuinely "one stop" investment procedure.

Instead of the existing heavy bureaucratic system, investors will now merely have to submit their requests to just one institution, the Investment Promotion Centre (CPI), which would then undertake all the necessary coordination with other state bodies. He said strict time limits were to be stipulated, adding that the finance ministry or provincial governments must give replies to investment requests within 10 working days. 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - South Africa's economic prospects are brightening, according to latest indications from the country's banking sector. In releasing its third-quarter economic outlook, the prestigious Standard Bank expressed the opinion that South African economic growth is set to resume in the second half of this year. This followed a slowdown in the first six months of the year mainly because of the extraordinary pace of expansion after the April 1994 all-race elections which brought democratic governance to the country after centuries of apartheid rule. The bank stated that it expected an increase of three per cent in South African Gross Domestic Product this year, and predicted that GDP for 1996 was likely to rise by four per cent. Like all of southern Africa, said the bank, the South African economy would not escape the effects of drought. Fortunately South Africa has suffered far less than its southern African counterparts, and the drought had been fairly mild. Nevertheless, lower agricultural output as a result of the drought would probably drop economic growth by 0.5 per cent. Accordingly, to Standard Bank, another 0,5 per cent would probably be cut from South Africa's economic growth this year because of a reduction in gold production. Next year, however, as much as 0.7 per cent could be added to South Africa's GDP if the gold mining industry could halt the decline in its productivity and climb back to last year's output levels. Even more optimistically, a return to 1993 gold output levels could add close to one per cent to the GDP. A major factor which led the mining industry to have a negative effect on South African economic growth this year was labour problems. The resultant loss in production had a drastic downward effect on foreign currency earnings. If production levels continued to decline, the bank added, gold mining could become a significant restriction on future economic growth in South Africa. The governor of the South African Reserve Bank, Chris Stals, has warned that the South African government must scale down its budget deficit more rapidly if the economy is to exceed the three per cent economic growth level. "The government needs to do more in terms of rapid restructuring "South Africa's Reconstruction and Development Programme can make a valuable contribution to restructuring by improving educational facilities and standards, and by raising productivity", Stals said but added, "but the benefits take time to filter through". The country's high fiscal deficit, which continues to swallow domestic savings, imposes structural limitations on the ability of the economy to grow without access to foreign capital -- particularly long-term capital. Meanwhile a senior delegation from the International Monetary Fund visited South Africa earlier this month, fuelling speculation that the government is preparing an application for an IMF stand-by facility, in view of the deterioration in the current account of the balance of payments. Economists here say that the balance of payments could end the year with a deficit of about three billion dollars. Stals insists, however, that no such application for a standby facility is being made. There is no need for such action, he says, as capital inflows are more than sufficient to cover the current account deficit. Either way, while predictions of a resumption in economic growth are encouraging, many economists and businessmen are convinced that South Africa faces a prolonged struggle to develop and maintain a satisfactory economic revival. PANA/LW/FT/FON 14Aug95 Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization. Mozambique Simplifies Investment Procedures

In the case of more complex requests, which have to be brought before the full cabinet, the time limit will be 20 working days, the minister said. He added that if no reply was received within the time limit, it would be presumed that the request had been a approved.

Furthermore, minimum values for direct investment have been cut from 15,000 to 5,0o0 dollars (or the equivalent in local currency) for Mozambican investors. The minimum for a direct foreign investment was set at 50,000 dollars. The need for a deposit has been eliminated. In addition, he said, investors will begin to enjoy tax benefits as soon as they present a declaration that they have begun operations.

The National Director of Taxes, Aboobacar Changa, told reporters that, for their first cycle of production, investors will be exempt from import duties, sales and circulation taxes on all raw materials used, including packaging. To obtain these benefits, it will only be necessary to present the customs office with a list of goods to be imported approved by the finance ministry. The exceptional tax breaks granted to "industrial free zones" will now be extended to any company that exports at least 85 per cent of its production.

Salomao said the Mozambican bureaucratic system could not be changed overnight, adding that the government wanted to reach a stage where any investor "just needs to have resources, to be registered, to have a tax number and can then get on with his activity". Businessmen have complained repeatedly over the clumsy, parasitic bureaucracy which Mozambique inherited from Portuguese colonial rule.

The measures are a first step to create a "business-friendly" climate in Mozambique after years of control under a marxist system which was replaced by a democratic government following elections held last year.

PANA-AIM PF/FON 15Aug95

Africa News


August, 1995


Farmers Happy With The Rewards of Reform


LENGTH: 374 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - Kenya farmers say they have begun to see gains from three years'of reforms but want the government to clear the remaining obstacles to enable them reap maximum profits from the sale of produce.

Speaking at a seminar on agricultural liberalisation held at Egerton University near Nakuru town, 157 kilometres from Nairobi, at the week-end, the farmers estimated that coffee production would rise to around 85,000 tonnes in 1995 from 81,000 tonnes in 1994. 

Tea also saw improved production from the 209,000 tonnes produced in 1994, the farmers noted.

But organisations involved in the production of sugar, maize and cotton say they have hardly benefitted from the reform-inspired Agricultural boom.

At best, their activities are barely trying to recover from poor farm policies and excessive imports which haved been their undoing since 1993. "

Declining crop husbandry, poor weeding and fertiliser application, and poor cor-dination between agriculture and processing departments at some of the factories has meant that harvested crops can be of less than optimal quality", the said.

A government policy paper said transparency in parastatal reform and privatisation was elusive and reforms requiring the sale of factories to private investors raised political and equity problems.

PANA-KNA JM/FON 15Aug95

Africa News


August, 1995


Zimbabwe Earns More From Tobacco


LENGTH: 414 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - More than 117 million kg of flue-cured tobacco worth over zimdollars 2 billion (USD 235 million) have been sold at the tobacco auction floors since sales opened in April, the Zimbabwe Tobacco Association (ZTA) said on Tuesday.

ZTA Public Relations Director, Lal Burton-Taylor, said prices, which collapsed in 1993 under the weight of a poor quality crop and over-supply on world markets, had firmed, particularly during the past few months.

For example, a kilogramme of the crop went for zd 20 (USD 2.40/kg) on Monday this week, one of the highest ever paid. Burton-Taylor said by the end of the auction season in less than eights week's time, farmers would have sold an estimated 190 million kg worth more than ZD 3 billion (USD 353 million). 

With processing and packaging costs added, the value of the crop to the country would be much more, she said in an interview.

"We have sold in excess of 117 million kg so far which means we are about two-thirds down the line. We are expecting to sell 190 million kg and at current prices, this could realise more than ZD 3 billion."

Burton-Taylor said farmers had already started preparing for the new season, and indications were that a crop in excess of 210 million kg would be produced in 1995/96.

The ZTA, buoyed by rising demand for high-quality flue-cured tobacco on world markets, this year recommended an annual increase in production of 10 percent over the next few years.

Burton-Taylor said the ZTA was expecting a normal season for tobacco growers provided rains fell during the crucial month of november.

"We will only be in trouble if it does not rain in November," she said. Burton-Taylor also said tobacco farmers had managed to secure cheap off-shore finance from local banks to finance production this season, which, according to estimates made early this year, required ZD 3 billion (USD 353 million).

PANA-ZIANA STC/JM/FON 15Aug95

August, 1995


Ashanti Goldfields Offers Three Million New Shares


LENGTH: 387 words


 

by Mawusi Afele PANA Correspondent

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Ashanti Goldfields Company (AGC), Ghana's biggest goldmine, is placing three million new shares on the London and Accra Stock Excahnages to raise about 60 million dollars, according to an official statement in Accra.

The statement said the money will be used to speed up the exploration and development programme being undertaken by AGC's subsidiary, Ashanti Exploration Limited (AEL). 

The sale will start in London and Accra on August 18 and 25 respectively.

The price has been conditionally placed at 20.75 dollars per share. This new share offer brings the interests of Lonrho and the Ghana government to 41.4 per cent and 28.8 per cent respectively. The directors of the company have subscribed in aggregate for 3,410 shares.

"This programme focusses on prospects outside the company's core operations at Obuasi...," the statement said.

Part of the amount will be directed to principal gold evaluation targets at Kalani in Mali, Mandiana in Guinea, Bambadji in Senegal and Midras and Miradani in Ghana.

The balance of the proceeds will be used to establish and conduct exploration on its own and through joint ventures. AGC is targeting a production of one million ounces of gold this year.

PANA MA/FON 15Aug95

215 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Beckoning On Foreign Investors


LENGTH: 1254 words


 

by Paul Okolo PANA Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - A team of fund managers from Europe and the United states visited Nigeria in June to have a first-hand look at opportunities for investing in the country, arguably, the second largest economy in Africa.

A year ago, this visit by fund managers with up to 40 billion dollars to spend would have been impossible. The Nigerian military government had then reverted to regulating the economy after eight years of Structural Adjustment during which deregulation was the order of the day.

But the 1995 budget changed this. Government came out with measures to place the country back on the path of guided deregulation. 

To make the economy investor-friendly, military ruler General Sani Abacha repealed two laws which discouraged foreign investment. These are the Exchange Control Act of 1962 and the Nigerian Enterprises Promotion Decree of 1989. The former limited the free movement of foreign currency in the country while the latter restricted foreign ownership of some business concerns.

In their place, government last month signed two new statutes into law : the Nigerian Investment Promotion Decree and the Foreign Currency and Capital Investment Monitoring Decree.

According to Finance Minister Anthony Ani, the first law is meant to guarantee foreign investment against nationalisation or expropriation by government and allow foreigners to buy shares in any Nigerian company.

Also, it will now be possible to transfer unconditionally abroad through authorised banks, funds, dividends, net profits, debt repayments and remittances of proceeds from sale or liquidation of an enterprise or any interest attributed to investment.

Under the second law which formalises the Autonomous Foreign Exchange Market, anyone transacting business in the foreign exchange market shall not be required to disclose the source of the hard currency.

"It appears that foreign investors would soon be able to invest in the Nigerian Economy which was closed before," said John Taylor of the UK-based Morgan Grenfell, one of the fund managers who visited the country in June before the new laws came into force.

Experts agree that Nigeria is at last serious about attracting foreign investment. For its part, the Nigerian Stock Exchange (NSE) is bracing up for an upsurge in activities.

The new law has opened the door for foreign stockbrokers to become trading members of the exchange.

Also, shares of Nigerian companies can now be traded simultaneously on other exchanges with which the nse collabotates. Foreigners can now buy shares in Nigerian companies too.

f its recent performance is anything to go by, the the NSE is a safe place to invest. The International Finance Corporation (IFC), a subsidiary of the World Bank, considers it as one of the promising emerging markets.

Between 1993 and last year, the NSE all-share index went up from 1543.8 to 2205, representing a 42.8 per cent rise in local currency terms. In the second quarter of 1994, it gained 6.5 per cent in dollar terms. The mood of the key officals of the exchange is upbeat.

"If we are to go by the results being declared by quoted companies, we are likely to see a continuous growth in both the local index and the IFC index," Pascal Dozie, president of the NSE told PANA. However, one worry of foreign portfolio investors, is the volume of the market. With a market capitalisation of about 1.5 billion dollars, for example, the fund managers who visited in June with an aggregate of 40 billion dollars to spend say what they may be able to invest in the market might be too small to impress their own investors initially.

But they were quick to point out that they could invest adequately when the government decides to embark on another round of privatisation exercises. Huge state-owned utilities like the telecommunication and electricity companies are among those being eyed by investors.

Other problems that foreiners may encounter include the lack of efficient infrastructure. Public utilities such as telephone, electricity and the postal services are very unreliable, inhibiting smooth capital market operations.

The exchange too has its own peculiar problems. "Settlement and custodian problems continue to bog trading transactions. The operations are still manually done," says the IFC.

Trading is via the call-over system whereby the brokers shout their bids and offers across the table in the trading ring while an official of the exchange oversees the proceedings.

However, efforts have been intensified to eliminate the delays caused by the manual operation. A central securities clearing house is to be established before the end of the year, officials say. The NSE has acquired for the clearing system the Canadian Alberta Stock Exchange Software.

"With the new system, the average time needed for clearing should drop to seven days," says IFC experts who recommended the system. While these developments are unfolding, the regulatory authorities are on the alert to ensure that the capital market continues to remain quite healthy.

The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has warned that deregulation does not mean lack of regulation, stressing that it would continue to perform its duties with the interest of the investors in mind.

SEC's Chief Executive, George Akamiokhor, intends to impress on the government the need to further remove the remaining obstacles facing foreign investors.

"The tax regime still needs to be reviewed downwards. In Nigeria, capital gains tax is 20 per cent, corporate income tax is 35 per cent and witholding tax is 10 per cent. Lowering these taxes, will help", says Akamiokhor.

PANA PO/RZ/FON 15Aug95

Africa News


August, 1995


TANZANIA WANTS UGANDA TO PAY FOR GETTING RID OF TYRANT


LENGTH: 414 words


 

by Moses Draku , PANA Correspondent

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - Tanzania has renewed efforts to get neighbouring Uganda to pay off a long outstanding debt -- for getting rid of dictator Idi Amin.

Tanzanian troops, at the request of opposition Ugandan leaders in exile, invaded landlocked Uganda in 1979 and hounded Amin into exile. He remains in Saudi Arabia to this day.

Ugandan state minister for defence Amama Mbabazi confirmed the debt Tuesday when he appeared before the ruling National Resistance Council (NRC) Committee on Legal and Security Affairs to present his ministry's policy statement.

He did not disclose the amount but unconfirmed reports put the figure at 100 million US dollars.

In 1979 Tanzania committed thousands of troops and large arms towards the overthrow of the Idi Amin dictatorsip. After Amin was removed from power, Tanzanian forces remained in the country for two years to help set up the Uganda National Liberation Army (UNLA).

The minister said the debt was negotiated between the Milton Obote government, which succeeded Amin, and Tanzania. "We have to pay these debts inspite of our feelings about them," Mbabazi said. Amin's decade-long reign was one of the bloodiest in recent African history.

The former army sergeant ordered the murders and torture of hundreds of thousands of Ugandans. Many more were detained or driven out of the country. Amin himself personally killed some opponents, and ate their flesh.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.
