217 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


STAGE SET FOR NEW PEACE BID IN LIBERIA


LENGTH: 747 words


 

by Paul Ejime PANA Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Liberian warlords gathered in the Nigerian capital of Abuja today for a fresh round of talks aimed at ending the six-year civil conflict in their country, Africa's oldest republic. There was little room for optimism, based on past records. There have been some 50 similar conferences in the past, and a dozen peace pacts have been torn up. 

The war started in December 1989 as a rebellion by Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) against President Samuel Doe.

Fighting has killed more than 150,000 people and made refugees of about half of the 2.5 million population.

The 16-nation Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas), of which Liberia is a member, has been striving to silence the guns and several warring factions there. Ecowas also has several thousand peacekeeping troops in the territory.

The latest mini-summit of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) is being held against the background of a United Nations threat to pull out its own observers FROM Liberia by September 15 if "there is no concrete progress."

To demonstrate its seriousness, the UN last week withdrew 17 of its remaining 70 peacekeepers from Liberia. There were some 350 UN observers in Liberia by 1993.

After several unheeded warnings to the warring factions, the West African community has had to scale down its force to about 8,000-men from around 15,000 troops in 1992.

Ecowas current chairman President Jerry Rawlings of Ghana is also on record as having warned for the upteenth time that the force could be pulled out for good, unless the warring factions showed serious commitment to peace.

Many had thought that with the murder in September 1990 of Doe, considered the major obstacle then, the Liberian crisis was half solved.

Instead, hostilities among the protagonists have continued giving rise to a multiplicity of factions from three in 1992 to around eight presently.

At least five of the factions are already in Abuja for the Ecowas summit.

They include Charles Taylor, who arrived in Abuja Monday, leading a 40-man delegation, Gen. Ezekiah Bowen of the Armed Forces of Liberia, Francois Massaquoi of the Lofa Defence Force and Roosevelt Johnson, head of another faction.

Tamba Tailor, 90, a representative of Liberia's traditional rulers, and Monrovia politician Oscar Quiah are also attending.

Virtually alienated from the peace process since 1992 when he arrived as an exile in Nigeria is Prince Yormie Johnson, Charles Taylor's rival, whose forces were captured and tortured Doe to death.

Johnson feels strongly about his "marginalisation," and says Liberia would know no peace until he was taken aboard the peace-chasing wagon.

Already, a five-man Ghanaian delegation led by the country's deputy foreign minister, Mohamed Ibn Chambas, has arrived in Abuja.

Former Zimbabwean President Rev. Canaan Banana, a representative of the Organisation of African Unity committee on Liberia, and UN Envoy, Anthony Nyakyi, were also being expected in Abuja Wednesday for the August 20-21 summit. --

August, 1995


U.S. Suspends Aid to Sao Tome and Principe after coup


LENGTH: 267 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - The United States has suspended its assistance programme to Sao Tome and Principe in the wake of the recent military coup on the Island nation off the coast of Gabon. United States assistance will remain suspended "until such time as the coup might be reversed", reported the 'Washington Line', a State Department publication received here Thursday. 

The U.S law requires the suspension of aid when a democratically-elected government is illegally removed from power.

The Sao Tome and Principe military forces ousted and detained President Miguel Trovoada.

"Washinton Line" said the U.S may also withdraw its 20-member peace corps mission. Following the 15 August coup, the peace corps office in sao tome was closed and peace corps volunteers were instructed to stay at home.

PANA PM/PBM 17AUG95

August, 1995


Zimbabwe to Hold Presidential Polls Early 1996


LENGTH: 414 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe is to hold its presidential elections during the first quarter of 1996, it was officially announced in Harare Thursday. The Secretary for Legal Affairs of the ruling Zimbabwe African National Union -Patriotic Front (ZANU PF), Eddison Zvobgo, told a news conference here that "obviously the election must be held in the first quarter of next year. The date will be fixed." 

The presidential polls will be held a year after parliamentary elections because the head of state's term of office is six years while that of legislators is five years, following amendments made to the constitution prior to the 1990 General Elections. Zvobgo re-affirmed the hostility of President Robert Mugabe's government towards the idea of holding an all party constitutional conference, as suggested by several opposition parties. He termed these calls as "foolish requests" from what he called "stupid parties" who were trying to use such a conference lick their wounds after their election defeat. Mugabe's ZANU PF party won 118 of the 120 contested seats in the April parliamentary elections, with two seats going to Rev. Ndabaningi Sithole's ZANU (NDONGA). At least eight opposition parties boycotted the parliamentary elections on claims that the electoral law favoured the ruling party.

Zvobgo said none of the parties had brought any of their concerns about the constitution or electoral act to government.

Opposition parties, he said, only surfaced towards elections."These parties have vanished. You will see them in the year 2,000."

PANA-ZIANA MUH/NDN/PBM 17AUG95

220 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Zambian Govt. Defers Bill to Re-name Univeristy


LENGTH: 614 words


 

by Mildred Mulenga PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Recent student protests and a walk-out by opposition parliamentarians last Friday, seem to have convinced the Zambian government not to push ahead with the controversial bills to re-name the University of Zambia and the Lusaka International Airport. Without saying the idea is buried, Education Minister Alfeyo Hambayi told parliament here Wednesday that the bill that could have facilitated the change of name of the academic institution to 'Harry Mwaanga Nkubula University" in honour of a veteran politican, has been deferred for consultation.

His collegue, Communications and Transport Minister Dawson Lupunga also postponed the aviation bill which was to allow the re-naming of the Lusaka International Airport to Simon Mwansa Kapwepwe, another deceased nationalist politician. 

Last Friday, opposition members of parliament walked out of the House in protest against the two bills when they were presented. They claimed the bills were proposed in bad faith and that no consultations had been made on the issues.

Two weeks ago, students at the University of Zambia rioted after police denied them authorisation to march to parlimentary buildings to petition against government's intention to rename the campus after a fallen national hero.

The students opposed the proposed change of name for their institution to "Harry Mwaanga Nkumbula," one of Zambia's veterans of the independence struggle.

He became Lusaka's first African Minister of Education in the coalition government of 1962, two years before formal independence from Britain in 1964.

The students suspect that the ruling Movement for Multi-party Democracy of President Frederick Chiluba merely wants to exploit Nkumbula's name for political capital.

They have charged that the university has so far won so much international acclaim and did not need to change its identity.

The government had also proposed to change the name of the Lusaka International Airport to Simon Mwansa Kapwepwe International Airport.

Kapwepwe was a firebrand politician in Zambia's struggle for independence and later held several government portfolios including that of foreign affairs minister. He later fell out with President Kaunda, who ruled Zambia for 27 years before being ousted by Chiluba. Kaunda is calling for a re-match in the 1996 Presidential elections.

PANA MM/PM/PBM 17AUG95

221 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Rojukwu Wants Abacha To Respect Transition Programme


LENGTH: 760 words


 

ENUGU, Nigeria (PANA) - Emeka Odumegwu-Ojukwu, leader of defunct 'Biafra Republic' during Nigeria's civil war of 1967-70, has urged the military regime in the country to respect its transition to civilian rule programme.

Speaking in Enugu, about 400 km south-east of Lagos, Ojukwu, a member of the recently dissolved Constitiutional Conference that submitted a draft constitution, said the 1 October date promised by Gen. Sani Abacha to announce the next stage of transition to democratic rule time-table was inviolable.

He said he was saddened by the recent statement credited to the Attorney-General of the Federation, Michael Agbamuche, that the period up to 1 October would be insufficient for the federal government to complete the consideration of the draft constituton. 

Ojukwu, who led the unsuccesfful Igbo rebellion said if Abacha had changed his mind on that date, the reasons should be "so cogent that silly people such as myself, will hear them once and believe." The former Biafran leader is back from a visit to Britain, where he led a government delegation to see ailing Nigerian first president, Nnamdi Azikiwe.

He appealed to the governments of Britain and the United States to stop threatening Nigeria with sanctions to force her to enthrone a democratic government.

According to him, Nigeria is on her way to democracy and cannot be said to be the most undemocratic nation in the world.

"The democratic content" of the nigerian military regime was "infinitely more than that of the Saudi Arabian government", he said, adding: "yet nobody is sanctioning them (Saudi Arabia) for the lack of democracy."

Ojukwu also said there was "nothing democratic about having a queen in England adding "the House of Lords cannot be said to be democratic."

"We grant them their sovereignty, why can't they grant us our own," he said. Ojukwu, however, said it was not his wish that the world should impose economic sanctions on Nigeria or that the country should be expelled from the British-led Commonwealth.

He said Nigerians should go into dialogue with the military to ease them out of the scene and enthrone a democratic governement. Nigerians campaigning for economic sanctions against their fatherland, he said, should be careful so they do not multiply the nation's problems.

"June 12 (the date of the 1993 presidential election annulled by the last military regime), is bad enough, but let us uunderstand that it was not as bad as the pogrom of the 1960s," a reference to the political crisis that led to Nigeria's civil war. Ojukwu added: "we should try to solve problems, not live in problems."

On the health of Azikiwe, who will be 91 in November, Ojukwu said the elder statesman was recovering from an attack of arthritis in a London hospital.

He said he led a three-man government delegation to deliver Abacha's get-well message to Azikiwe, who was flown out a few weeks ago for medical treatment.

Ojukwu, who said the press briefing was to pacify anxieties among Nigerians over the former president's health, declared: "whatever crisis that necessitated his (Azikiwe's) being rushed to england was over when we saw him."

PANA-NAN AAO/MO/SEA/PE/FON 17Aug95

222 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


AFRICAN LEADERS PREPARE FOR SUMMIT ON LIBERIA


LENGTH: 467 words


 

byPaul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nine West African heads of state began gathering in the Nigerian capital of Abuja today to prepare for a summit to end the civil war in Liberia.

Ghanaian President Jerry Rawlings, the chairman, sounded a warning that this could be the last chance for mediation by the 16-nation Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas).

"If I have to put diplomacy aside," Rawlings told journalists, "I will say we have reached the end of our limit." 

The path to peace in Liberia, Africa's oldest republic, is littered with failures by the eight warring factions to bury their differences after six years of sivil war.

There have been some 50 peace conferences, mainly organized by Ecowas, of which Liberia is a member, and a dozen ceasefire agreements have been torn up.

Rawlings and Nigerian military leader Gen. Sani Abacha conferred here Thursday night on ways to make Sunday's summit an exception.

Rawlings said he hoped this would be the last Ecowas meeting on Liberia.

His a statement underlined the frustration felt by Ecowas, several of whose member states are maintaining a costly peacekeeping force in Liberia.

Nigeria and Ghana have the largest number of troops, known by the acronym Ecomog.

Rawlings hoped the next phase in the peace process would involve disarming the estimated 60,000 Liberian combatants who belong to several armed groups.

Leaders of Liberian warring factions, including Charles Taylor, who launched the rebellion against President Samuel Doe in December 1989, began another round of peace talks in Abuja Wednesday. Doe was later assassinated.

Some 150,000 have been killed in the civil war, and many more have been wounded or driven into exile.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

223 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Zimbabwe Government Profits from Peacekeeping ?


LENGTH: 1227 words


 

by Elliot Mahende PANA Correspondent

LUANDA, Angola (PANA) - Zimbabwean troops in the Third United Nations Verification Mission (Unavem III) in war-torn Angola are complaining about the cut in their monthly allowances by almost two-thirds by their government from the standard UN rate and now accuse it of seeking to profit from peacekeeping operations.

Officers interviewed in Luanda complained bitterly about the drastic cuts from the US dollar 988 (Zimdollars 8 398) per man per month contributed by the UN which is reduced to USD 350 (Zd2 975) by the time the money reaches the men in the field.

The disaffected officers, members of an 800-strong contingent in the 7 600-men peacekeeping force, are particularly bitter about the fact that the UN is paying for practically all the expenses incurred by the Zimbabwe government during the operation to oversee Angola's tortuous transition from nearly two decades of civil war.

UN guidelines on payments to governments contributing troops to the force, obtained at the Unavem III headquarters in the Angolan caoital Luanda, showed the governments contributing would be paid the standard rate of USD 988 for each solider every month for all ranks plus a supplementary USD 291 (zd2 473) per for a limited number of specialists. 

Payment for all items of clothing and equipment issued by governments to their troops is paid at a standard rate of USD 65 (Zd 552) per month while that for weaponry and ammunition is fixed at USD (Zd42) a month.

All such equipment and gear is retained by the troops at the end of the mission.

Payment is made directly to the troop contributing governments through their missions at the UN in New Yrk.

The issue of reduced allowances was also raised by Zimbabwean troops who participated in the failed Un operation in Somalia where the government also cut deeply into un allowances for peacekeepers.

Zimbabwe's defence minister Moven Mahachi has justified reducing the allowances for the troops on the grounds that the government continues to pay their salaries back home and that allowances by the UN should be reduced to that -- allowances to buy cigarettes and other things not supplied by the quartermaster in the field.

Mahachi also argued that the government incurred expenses by sending troops into peacekeeping operations.

But the disaffected officers dismissed this saying whatever expenses the government incurred, there was a credit balance for the Zimbabwean government at the end of the day.

"Being deployed here is really not worth the while considering what we are paid and the risks involved," said one officer who spoke on condition of anonymity.

Recently, a Zimbabwean officer, Colonel Bernard Dungeni, tripped a mine in Lunda Norte province and lost his foot.

The Zimbabwean officers said it would be interesting to see whether the government would surrender all the money paid by the UN as compensation to Col. Dungeni.

UN regulations stipulate that the government make a claim to the world body upon the death or disablement of a peacekeeper in the field. What seemed to irk the officers more was that troops from other countries in the Unavem III operation were being given the UN allowances in full. Zimbabwean officers deployed as military observers were also better off than their peacekeeping counterparts since they get an allowance of USD 30 (Zd255) a day, a handsome package by Zimbabwean standards.

The officers also suggested that the Zimbabwean government deposit all extra funds from peacekeeping operations into a defence forces benefit fund if it was not keen to raise allowances for men in the field.

Some officers within the un itself appear to be getting uneasy about governments that cut heavily into allowances provided for troops with some arguing that the world body should not pay anything over and above what it costs the contributing governments to send troops into a peacekeeping operation.

Others outside the UN system but whose governments are influential in determining UN budgets for peacekeeping operations have also expressed reservations about the conduct of some governments that contribute troops to peacekeeping operations.

"Since the UN pays the contributing government (about) USD 1 000 per month for each soldier assigned to peacekeeping operations, many less developed nations have turned to peacekeeping as a source of revenue," said Professor James Corum of the US Air Force School of Advanced Airpower Studies at a recent conference on peacekeeping in Johannesburg, South Africa.

Corum, drawing on experiences from Somalia, also attacked the UN peacekeeping funding system saying it promoted inefficient use of equipment, particulary the fact the UN also assumed the cost of maintaining military equipment provided by the participant nations.

The Zimbabweans came out with decorations in Somalia despite the dangerous situation that prevailed in the lawless country.

But angola, despite pronouncements of commitment to peace by both the Mpla government and Unita, remains a volatile country with a security problem compounded by an estimated 20 million landmines buried in the countryside.

Maximum concentration by the peacekeepers is vital to avoid tripping the treacherous devices and problems of allowances should be the last thing on the mind of a soldier on such a delicate mission.

PANA-Ziana EMM/TGM/DS 21Aug95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

Africa News


August, 1995


09G/01E Nigeria-Democracy Abacha Promises a Return to Democracy


LENGTH: 680 words


 

ABUJA, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigerian military leader General Sani Abacha said on Sunday night his regime is working towards the restoration of democracy in the troubled West African nation. Abacha, who held a three-hour meeting with presidents Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe and Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, said his administration was "leaving no stone unturned" in working toward that goal.

Mugabe and Museveni arrived in Abuja, the Nigerian capital Sunday, adding their weight to international pressure on the military ruler to release former head of state Olusegun Obasanjo and 39 other alleged coup plotters facing sentences ranging from execution to life imprisonment. 

"In this regard we are doing everything possible to establish a lasting basis for participatory democracy, social justice and sustainable growth.

"We look forward to continued co-operation and understanding as we carry on this onerous task," said Abacha at a state banquet he hosted for the visiting leaders.

Details of the three-hour long meeting held at state house earlier on were not immediately known nor did Abacha and Mugabe, who also spoke at the banquet, disclose specifics on the plight of the alleged coup plotters.

Mugabe, who spoke on behalf of his Ugandan counterpart, said suspicions that Abacha was stalling on the issue of restoring democracy were "misplaced".

The West African nation of about 100 million people has been in turmoil since the army annulled the 12 June 1993 presidential elections widely believed to have been won by detained business tycoon Moshood Abiola.

The Zimbabwean leader took a swipe at the international media for "misreporting" the Nigerian crisis.

He said following their "excellent discussion" with Abacha, the two leaders were satisfied that progress was being made towards restoring democracy.

"We did agree that there was a way forward and we would like to support the way forward," said Mugabe.

The Zimbabwean leader said given the diverse ethnic backgrounds of the Nigerian people, the country's problems were appreciable and could not be resolved over night.

Mugabe said the Nigerians should not be detracted from the efforts they were making towards restoring democracy.

He said he would reporting back to the Southern African Development Community (SADC) leaders at their summit in Johannesburg next week on the progress Abacha was making towards restoring democracy.

Mugabe's mission to nigeria follows a resolution at the last Presidential Forum on the Management of Science and Technology held in Kampala, Uganda, last month.

The forum, chaired by Museveni, mandated both Mugabe and Museveni to lead an initiative on Nigeria after Abacha had rebuffed a number of peace envoys.

Mugabe, Museveni and Abacha were expected to continue their discussions on Monday morning.

PANA-Ziana NN/MM/DS 21Aug95

Africa News


August, 1995


Sudan Urges UNHCR to Stop Rebels from Recruiting Refugees


LENGTH: 400 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - Sudan has sent an urgent memorandum to the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), urging it to stop rebels from recruiting Sudanese refugees in neighbouring countries, a government daily reported on Sunday.

The daily, ' El Engath el Watani' , said the secretary general of Sudan's High Council for Peace, Lino Rol Deng, had called on the UNHCR to prevent the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) from entering refugee camps in Eritrea, Kenya and Kenya to recruit refugees to fight government forces in southern Sudan. 

The council was established in 1994 to help bring an end to the 12-year civil war in the south by rallying southerners around the government programmes for peace and development. Deng himself is a southerner.

According to Sudanese government sources there are about 29,000 Sudanese refugees in Kenya.

The number in Uganda fluctuates according to the military situation at the borders. It swells with increased fighting and falls when there is a lull in hostilities.

The Sudanese government at one time estimated there were some 150,000 refugees in Uganda.

Eritrea has generally not been a sanctuary for southern Sudanese refugees.

It is not clear whether the refugees in Eritrea Deng spoke are from the north.

PANA YH/DS 20Aug95

226 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Liberian Warlords Sign Another Peace Accord


LENGTH: 520 words


 

ABUJA, Nigeria (PANA) - Liberia's warring factions signed yet another peace accord in the Nigerian capital, Abuja, Sunday. It was the 13th agreement from 51 peace meetings on Liberia. Africa's oldest republic, Liberia was plunged into civil war on 24 December 1989. 

The latest seven page document brokered by foreign ministers of the Ecowas Committee of Nine as well as OAU and United Nations facilitators, also sets up a six-member interim Council of State to run Liberia for 12 months until national elections are held.

The council is to be headed by an academic, Wilton Sankawolo, 55. The other members will be vice-chairmen of equal status.

They include Charles Taylor of the National Patriotic Front, Gen. Alhaji Kromah of Ulimo, George Boley Sr. of the Liberian Peace Council who is representing the ' Coalition Forces' , and Oscar Jaryee Quiah of the Liberian National Council. The other member of the council Tamba Tailor, who represents the traditional rulers, was earlier tipped to head the body.

Lt. Gen. Hezekiah Bowen of the Armed Forces of Liberia and Maj.Gen. Roosevelt Johnson, who had earlier raised objections to the accord, later signed "in the interest of peace".

On the problematic issue of succession the agreement noted that "in case of permanent incapacitation, a new chairman shall be appointed within the Ecowas framework."

The transitional government is to be in place within 14 days from the signing of the accord while a new cease-fire and cessation of hostilities is to come into effect on 26 August.

The council chairman will not be allowed to participate in the first presidential and parliamentary elections while other interested members must resign their seats three months before the elections in order to be eligible.

Sankawolo was not in Abuja for the meeting, but the consensus among the warring factions as well as other liberian opinion leaders and the peace facilitators was that he would accept the post as a national service.

The Abuja agreement was described as a supplement to the 1993 Cotonou (Benin) and the 1995 Akosombo (Ghana) accords on Liberia.

The cease-fire will be monitored by Ecomog.

The warring factions were notorious for breaking previous accords. It remains to be seen whether the latest document will make the difference in a war that has killed more than 150,000 people and made refugees of almost half of Liberia's estimated 2.5 million population.

PANA/PE/FT/DS 20Aug95


LOAD-DATE: September 1, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


227 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Botswana Govt. Asked to Abolish Death Penalty


LENGTH: 440 words


 

GABORONE, Botswana (PANA) - The Botswana government is being asked to emulate South Africa which recently abolished the death penalty. The latest call to abolish capital punishment has come from a local human rights centre, Ditshwanelo, following reports that President Ketumile Masire had rejected clemency appeals for three inmates-David Kelaletswe, David Bogatse and Tekoetsile Tsiane - currently on a death row.

Ditshwanelo said in a statement quoted by the Botswana News Agency (BOPA), the human rights group noted that the execution of the three men is now imminent while the outcome of clemency appeals for Patrick Ntesang and Obusitswe Tshabang have yet not been publicised. 

The rights centre said adherence to the rights to life and dignity and the right not to be subject to cruel inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment form part of the fundamental human rights.

It regretted that the constitution of Botswana ignores these principles as it permits the use of the death penalty. The centre recalled that two months ago, the constitutional court of South Africa declared that death penalty was unconstitutional. Ditswhwanelo urged the government to recognise this deveopment and to consider similar constitutional amendment.

While recognising the need to punish the perpetrators of heinous crime, the group said that any limitation of a right resulting from the punishment of a crime committed has to be reasonable and justified. "In an open and democratic society which is based on freedom and equality such as Botswana, death penalty is neither reasonable nor justifiable," the human rights organisation said. It expressed hope that clemency appeals by Patrick Ntesang and Obusitswe Tshabang will be considered favourably.

PANA-BOPA NM/KM/PBM 21AUG95

Africa News


August, 1995


Comesa Clearing House Should Redefine Role


LENGTH: 574 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The Harare-based Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa Clearing House should redefine its operations as member states embark on monetary reforms under western-backed structural adjustment programmes, the Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe said on Monday.

Opening a two-day seminar on the future role of the institution in Harare RBZ governor Leonard Tsumba told 60 participants from sub-Saharan Africa that the role of the clearing house was now limited under the current wave of economic reforms sweeping across the region.

"The decline in usage of the clearing house has coincided with the liberalisation of trade and foreign exchange regimes as part of the economic reform measures which many of our countries have been implementing. 

"Under these economic reforms, export receipts no longer have to be surrendered to central banks. They are now retained in the inter-bank market, from which importers can source foreign exchange requirements," said Tsumba.

Regional importers were now able buy foreign currency and pay their import requirements from the market without using the clearing house, he added.

"This development has increased the role of normal banking channels, but in the process, has limited the role of the clearing house," said Tsumba.

Central bank governors from sub-Saharan Africa had already questioned the continued relevance of the present clearing house facility to the region's payments arrangements, amid a decline in the usage of its travellers cheques.

Tsumba said the time had now come for the clearing house to chart the way forward under a liberalised foreign exchange regime in the region.

"The clearing house must increasingly be seen as a mechanism for promoting increased intra-regional trade or as an entity which provides non-traditional services," he said.

"Clearly such functions as are currently performed by the monetary division of the (Comesa) secretariat could be easily carried out by a reconstituted clearing house," suggested Tsumba.

The clearing house was established in February 1984, and operated from Harare under the auspices of the reserve bank of Zimbabwe.

Its main objective was to minimise usage of convertible currencies, and has since its inception been encouraged to accept national currencies in the settlement of trade transactions, and only subject net balances to payment in hard currency.

PANA-Ziana ET/STC/DS 21Aug95

August, 1995


South Africa Refuses to Bow to United States Pressure


LENGTH: 360 words


 

JOHANNESBURG (PANA) - South Africa will not bow to United States pressure regarding its new oil-marketing agreement with Iran, its mineral and energy affairs minister Pik Botha has said.

South Africa "will not reconsider the deal," he said. "I do not understands why the United States should be so concerned about our little bit of business with Iran.'

The United States has expressed disappointment over the agreement, approved in principle last week during a visit to South Africa by Iran's foreign minister Ali Akbar Velayati. The Americans claim Teheran is sponsoring international terrorism and trying to develop nuclear weapons.

Meanwhile U.S. energy secretary Hazel d'Leary, currently in South Africa on a one-week visit, says she will raise the issue "in the appropriate arena".

However, asked whether this issue could have a detrimental effect on South African trade relations with the United States, she said: "Of course it's not a handicap. Never would I dare to presume to dictate to South Africa how they should make their decisions".

Botha said the United States should tackle Iran's allegaed nuclear ambitions with the appropriate international agencies and not in talks with South Africa.

PANA LW/IS/DS 21Aug95

Africa News


August, 1995


Sudanese Opposition Leader Mirghani Wants to Return >From Yahya


LENGTH: 627 words


 

by El Hassan, PANA Correspondent

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - An exiled Sudanese opposition leader Mohamed Osman El Mirghani has reportedly expressed desire to return home, quit politics and terminate his relationship with

Egypt, provided the government of Gen. Omar El Bashir returns his confiscated property.

Quoting what they described as a "well placed political source" Monday, two state-owned dailies El Engaz El Watani and El Sudan El Hadeith and an independent paper, Elra'I Elakhar, said Mirghani had sent an unnamed envoy on a secret mission to convey this message to Sudanese authorities.

Mirghani was leader of the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) which was dissolved when Gen. Bashir came to power in a military take-over on 30 June 1989. 

The dailies said the opposition leader wants to return home because he "got fed up with the long stay abroad and with the bitter criticism directed to him as leader of the opposing national democratic alliance, from the alliance members."

According to the free elections of 1986, the DUP came second in the result of public voting.the party then joined the majority party,the UMMA Party of former Premier Sadiq el Mahdi in a coalition government government ousted by Gen.Bashir.

While welcoming Mirghani's return, the 'political source' is quoted as saying, the government would turn down any pre-conditions for such a return.

The source said handing back Mirghani's property estimated at 25 billion Sudanese pounds (50 million US dollars would be a "difficult" consideration on grounds that he"had accumulated this wealth from the simple followers of his religious sect, the Khatmiya, without practising any activity that could enable him to earn this money."

The source said the opposition leader, who is now in Cairo, undertook in his message to "content himself with leadership of his 'Khatmiya' religious sect and sever all of his existing firm ties with the egyptian regime."

However, the source said the Sudanese government respects Mirghani's religious leadership which,according to the source, has demonstrated its concern with the unity of the Sudan and its refusal to have foreign assistance for aborting the Sudanese Islamic project."

The source claimed he was disclosing Mirghani's story " to prove that the DUP leader is only concerned with his person and with his wealth and to indicate that nobody (from the opposition) should dare to dictate conditions for his rerturn to Sudan."

PANA YH/PBM 21AUG95

Africa News


August, 1995


Nigeria's Detainee Saro-Wiwa Bags Environmental Award


LENGTH: 467 words


 

by Randy Zormelo PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - A detained Nigerian human rights activist and author, Ken Saro-Wiwa, will be among three recepients of this year's British Environment and Media Award for his commitment to raising awareness about environmental issues in Ogoniland.

A release by the director of the award, Amanda Duncan-Smith, made available to PANA in Lagos said Saro-Wiwa was honoured for "his continued commitment to the environment and the great efforts he has made to keep the problems and solutions in the forefront"

"His public commitment and personal sacrifice have been most successful in keeping the debate alive", the release further said. Saro-Wiwa, leader of the Movement for the Survival of Ogoni People (MOSOP), will share the award with Prince Charles of Wales, US Vice President Al Gore and British film producer/director Sir Richard Attenborough who, according to the release, have all made substantial contribution towards increasing public consciousness about environmental problems. 

Conceived in 1988 by Media Natural, a non-profit communications agency, the British Environmental Media Award executes a wide range of media projects and ensures high standards in the communication of environmental issues.

Saro-Wiwa, a television producer and author of several books, has often accused Nigeria's military administrations and oil companies of causing environmental degradation of Ogoninland and genocide against his tribe, the Ogoni, located in the heartland of the country's oil-rich Rivers State.

He has taken his case to the International Court of Justice at the Hague.

Saro-Wiwa is currently being held behind bars for allegedly ordering the murder of four prominent people of Ogoniland opposed to his movement.

The award will be presented in London in October.

PANA RZ/PBM 19Aug95

LANGUAGE: English

232 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Conservations Raise Alarm at Propecting Project


LENGTH: 787 words


 

by Lionel Williams, Pana Staff Correspondent

JOHANNESBURG (PANA)- The South African Department of Mineral and Energy Affairs has granted a prospecting permit to the Duo Corporation of South Africa to search for diamonds in the Matshakatini Reserve on the border with Zimbabwe.

According to David Lindley, conservation ecologist of the Wildlife Society of Southern Africa, the decision poses a threat of enormous long term environmental damage to the area.

The 29-thousand hectare provincial nature reserve in the northern province of South Africa -- also know at the Madimbo Corridor -- borders on the Limpopo River and shares its eastern boundary with the famous one-million hectare Kruger National Park. The reserve is currently controlled and managed by the South African National Defence Force. 

The Matshakatini Reserve forms a vital link in the plans of the 'golden horseshoe", a vision that aims at linking nature reserves in Botswana, Mozambique, South Africa and Zimbabwe. In South Africa this would stretch from the Kruger National Park in the East, along the Limpopo River to the north and down the Western border of the Northern Province with Botswana.

The Wildlife Society says it is extremely concerned the decision to grant the prospecting permit was made without all the facts being known. The society says in principle it is not against mining in the area, but that other options for the alternate land use, such as ecotourism and farming, have been totally ignored. It says the land use must benefit the local people, the province and the country as a whole and take into account the social, ecological and economic environments. Only then can a sound decision be made.

The Wildlife Society says it tried to alert the ministers of environment and tourism and of mineral and energy affairs, as well as defence, as to the importance of the area as early as January this year. However, no reply was received until the decision to grant the prospecting permit had been made.

The Mutelo tribe, who live in the area and who can lay historic claim to the land, was not consulted in the matter, nor were the Kruger National Park authorities and the Northern Province Nature Conservation who, together with the Mutele tribe, favors the ecotourism route.

To complicate the matter, says the Wildlife Society, it appears with growing evidence that the decision to grant the permit was far from transparent and for that reason it had been forced to raise public awareness on the issue.

According to ecologists the area has a 60-kilometre stretch of rare virgin Limpopo River Gallery Forest, a unique pan system on the floodplain, a sensitive sand forest and hundreds of boabab trees more than a thousand years old. In addition it is the migrating passage for wildlife moving to and from South Africa into Zimbabwe. The Wildlife Society says leading South African archeologists are of the opinion that the Limpopo River Valley forms the seat of sub-Saharan African civilization, dating back to the Mapungumwe culture of 600-700 A.D. Excavations in other parts of the valley in the Kruger National Park, as well as in Botswana and Southern Zimbabwe, have revealed strong evidence to support this theory.

The potential the Matshakatini Reserve shows of becomming a treasure trove is indeed great. Stone-age flint knives probally dating back a million years have already been found and pottery discovered in a river bank, most likely fron the period 600 700 A.D.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

LANGUAGE: English

233 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Ecomog Peace Force Needs Logistics Support


LENGTH: 680 words


 

by Paul Ejime PANA Staff Correspondent

ABUJA, Nigeria (PANA) - The West African force in Liberia, Ecomog, badly needs financial and logistics support now that the country's warring factions have signed an agreement to end the civil war, its Commander Brig. Gen.. John Mark Inienger said Tuesday in Abuja, Nigeria.

"We are assuring the heads of state of Ecowas and the international community that we are not lacking in men, but we need financial resources and logistics to support the troops," he told PANA in the Nigerian Federal Capital. 

Under the latest peace accord, the 13th signed by the warring factions Sunday, Ecomog is to oversee the disarmament of an estimated 60,000 combatants belonging to different factions in Liberia.

Inienger said that due to lack of progress in the peace process, the peace force had been cut down to an estimated 8,000 troops from a peak of about 15,000 in 1992.

The United Nations, he said, had also scaled down its observers and threatened to pull them out completely by 15 September.

But the Ecomog commander said with the signing of the new accord, which goes into effect in the first week of September, he "is hopeful" the Ecowas heads of state and the UN would be encouraged to support the peace-keeping force.

On the suggestion that the force should engage in peace enforcement in case of violation of the accord, inienger stated that Ecomog's mission is not to "usurp the sovereignty of Liberia, but to assist Liberians restore peace in their country."

He described the Abuja accord as a "new page in the

peace process," adding that for the first time all the warring factions had undertaken to work for peace.

Reacting to accusations by some factions that Ecomog

was biased against some of them, Inienger said it was normal in conflict situation for parties to seek to protect their interests. The Liberian war, he said, lacks ideology.

"The factions are fighting for jobs and positions, so you should expect such misunderstanding," Inienger argued.

But the Ecomog Commander said with the appointment of a neutral person, 55-year-old lecturer Wilton Sankawolo, to head the transitional council of state for 12 months, he was hopeful of peace in Liberia.

The Liberian war has killed more than 150,000 people, including president Samuel Doe, the target of the rebellion launched by National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) leader Charles Taylor on 24 December 1989.

Inienger, a former state governor in Nigeria, is the

longest-serving Ecomog Commander, having spent some 20 months in command of the force sent to Monrovia in August 1990 by the Economic Community of West African States.

PANA PE/RZ/PBM 22AUG95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

Africa News


August, 1995


Morocco imports 90 Per Cent Of Energy


LENGTH: 240 words


 

RABAT, Morocco (PANA) - Morocco has met 92.5 per cent of its energy needs for 1994 with imports amounting to 10.2 billion Dirhams (1.2 billion USD), according to a report from the Al Maghreb Bank (central bank).

With 9 billion DH spent in 1994, petroleum imports increased by 15.3 per cent compared to 1993, the report said. 

Despite a total energy consumption of 8 million tonnes, representing an 8.4 increase compared to 1993. Local production did not exceed 0.6 million tonnes.

Electricity production, which increased by 11.9 per cent from 1993, was 11 billion kw/h in 1994.

Over nine-tenth of the country's electric energy, representing 10.3 billion kw/h, come from thermal plants, the bank said.

PANA KIB/SJD/FON 22August95

Africa News


August, 1995


US Pledges Help to Botswana's Textile Industry


LENGTH: 587 words


 

GABORONE, Botswana (PANA) - Botswana's declared intention

to enter the textile industry could get assistance from the University of Massachusetts in terms of expertise and machinery, a visiting official from the American state said here Tuesday.

The promise was made by Mr Franklin Ollivierre, a representative of the Massachusetts Governor, who has been leading a trade mission here on a two-day visit.

Ollivierre told the Botswana Press Agency (BOPA) in Gaborone Tuesday that his trip to Botswana was a follow up of a similar trip made to Boston by authorities from the southern African country four months ago. 

He said that when he goes back home, he will help to spread the good word about Botswana's friendly investment climate. "More than anything else people need to know more about Botswana," he said.

He added that the country could attract foreign investors

because of its stable economy and political climate, its peaceful elections and a long history of stability and peace.

He particularly talked of the government's policy of free trade and the tax regime, tare all conducive to foreign investment.

Ollivierre said possible areas of investment discussed with Gaborone's authorities include solar energy, education and training , telecommunications and financial services. He said however, there is need to do follow-up on the last two.

Talking about his mission's tangible results, he said a local businessman interested in solar energy was able to have a business contact in the united states after meeting his delegation Monday.

Ollivierre said his team came to Botswana to reciprocate a visit made by traded mission led by Gaborone's Ambassador to Washington, Kingsley Sebele and the Permanent Secretary to the ministry of Commerce and Industry, Tswelelopele Moremi.

He noted that Botswana and the United States have a long history of co-operation in a number of areas, including political, social and military fields.

Botswana hosted the preparatory meeting for the African-African American summit that was held in Dakar, Senegal in May this year.

At that summit, the US chief representative, Commerce Secretary Ron Brown said his country's businessmen will henceforth compete effectively with those coming from Africa's former colonial powers.

PANA-BOPA NM/KM/PBM 22AUG95

Major Gold Find for Niger


LENGTH: 187 words


 

NIAMEY, Niger (PANA) - A Canadian Firm and Niger's National Board for Mineral Resources (Onarena) have discovered a gold deposit of over 15 tonnes in Western Niger, authorised sources in Niamey announced.

The deposit could in fact be much larger, the sources said. This is, however, yet to be determined by further exploration.

Niger has within the last three months also issued five oil exploration permits to foreign concerns for the Liptako.

237 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Conservations Raise Alarm at Prospecting Project


LENGTH: 814 words


 

by Lionel Williams, PANA Staff Correspondent

JOHANNESBURG (PANA)- The South African Department of Mineral and Energy Affairs has granted a prospecting permit to

the Duo Corporation of South Africa to search for diamonds in the Matshakatini Reserve on the border with Zimbabwe.

According to David Lindley, conservation ecologist of the Wildlife Society of Southern Africa, the decision poses a threat of enormous long term environmental damage to the area.

The 29-thousand hectare provincial nature reserve in the northern province of South Africa -- also know at the Madimbo Corridor -- borders on the Limpopo River and shares its eastern boundary with the famous one-million hectare Kruger National Park. The reserve is currently controlled and managed by the South African National Defence Force. 

The Matshakatini Reserve forms a vital link in the plans of the ' golden horseshoe", a vision that aims at linking nature reserves in Botswana, Mozambique, South Africa and Zimbabwe. In South Africa this would stretch from the Kruger National Park in the East, along the Limpopo River to the north and down the Western border of the Northern Province with Botswana.

The Wildlife Society says it is extremely concerned the decision to grant the prospecting permit was made without all the facts being known. The society says in principle it is not against mining in the area, but that other options for the alternate land use, such as ecotourism and farming, have been totally ignored. It says the land use must benefit the local people, the province and the country as a whole and take into account the social, ecological and economic environments. Only

then can a sound decision be made.

The Wildlife Society says it tried to alert the ministers of environment and tourism and of mineral and energy affairs, as well as defence, as to the importance of the area as early as January this year. However, no reply was received until the decision to grant the prospecting permit had been made.

The Mutelo tribe, who live in the area and who can lay

historic claim to the land, was not consulted in the matter, nor were the Kruger National Park authorities and the Northern Province Nature Conservation who, together with the Mutele tribe, favors the ecotourism route.

To complicate the matter, says the Wildlife Society, it appears with growing evidence that the decision to grant the permit was far from transparent and for that reason it had been forced to raise public awareness on the issue.

According to ecologists the area has a 60-kilometre stretch of rare virgin Limpopo River Gallery Forest, a unique pan system on the flood plain, a sensitive sand forest and hundreds of baobab trees more than a thousand years old. In addition it is the migrating passage for wildlife moving to and from South Africa into Zimbabwe.

The Wildlife Society says leading South African archeologists are of the opinion that the Limpopo River Valley

forms the seat of sub-Saharan African civilization, dating back to the Mapungumwe culture of 600-700 A.D. Excavations in other

parts of the valley in the Kruger National Park, as well as in

Botswana and Southern Zimbabwe, have revealed strong evidence to support this theory.

The potential the Matshakatini Reserve shows of becoming a treasure trove is indeed great. Stone-age flint knives probably dating back a million years have already been found and pottery discovered in a river bank, most likely from the period 600 700 A.D.

PANA LW/IS/DS 18Aug95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar, Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: September 1, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


238 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Election of ADB President Still Dicey


LENGTH: 907 words


 

by Felix Njoku PANA Staff Correspondent

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - An extraordinary meeting of the Board of Governors of the African Development Bank (ADB) begins in Abidjan Thursday for a rerun of polling for the president of the bank, called off in May in Abuja following a deadlock.

A release from the bank's base in Cote d'Ivoire said the board will on 25 August still have to choose from among the three major candidates who failed to clinch the job in the Nigerian capital.

These are Timothy Thehane of Lesotho, currently a Vice-President at the World Bank, Morocco's former Economy Minister, Omar Kabbaj and Seyyid Abdulai of Nigeria, currently

Secretary-General of the Opec Fund for International Development in Vienna, Austria.

Thehane, was leading with 44.59 per cent of the votes against 35.68 per cent for Kabbaj and Abdulahi's 19.73 per cent when polling reached a deadlock in Abuja on 25 May. 

Thehane or Kabbaj needed the support of Nigeria to clinch the job but it refused to give way charging non-regional members of influencing the voting for selfish reasons.

To become President of the ADB, the candidate needs at least 50.1 per cent of the regional (50 African countries) votes, and 50.1 per cent of the Non-regional (26 Non-African countries) votes.

Analysts say Nigeria's behaviour at the Abidjan meeting would determine whether a new chief executive would be found for the continental development bank set up in 1963 by African governments to foster Africa's development.

Nigeria has the highest shareholding of 10.5 per cent at the bank. The government floated one of its two soft loan affiliates ' Nigeria Trust Fund' currently estimated to be worth 400,000 US dollars.

Nigerian officials insist that the non-regional members who did not cast a single vote for their candidate, were bent on hijacking the bank.

"They had tried to do this by a variety of means including starving the African Development Fund (ADF) of resources.

"Now they want to get a subterfuge to convert ADB into some funny sort of World Bank," said a Nigerian official who spoke on condition of anonymity.

"America has a monopoly of the Presidency of the World Bank. Japan Heads the Asian Development Bank; so why will Nigeria be denied the top position at the ADB...?", he asked.

But the non-regional members who provide the quasi-totality of loanable funds of the bank through contributions to the ADF, argue that Nigeria's political and economic credentials were not clean enough to give her top job at the multilateral

bank.

The argument in Abuja was that if Abdulai got the post, he would be under the direct influence of the Nigerian military government and this would discourage international financiers

from doing business with the ADB.

However, some shareholders say these arguments have become irrelevant considering the urgent need to provide the bank with a substantive head to replace Babacar Ndiaye, the Senegalese national who has held the post for more than the statutory two

terms of 10 years.

Ndiaye was due to depart after the Abuja Assembly but was

asked to stay on until 31 August, to allow for the election of a new president.

The ADB, with authorised capital of 23.7 billion dollars (31 December 1994) has had five presidents.

These were Mamoun Beheiry of Sudan from 1964 to 1970; Abdel Wahab Labidi (late) of Tunisia (1970-1976); Kwame Donkor

Fordwor of Ghana (1976-1979); Goodall Gondwe of Malawi who acted from 1979-1980; Wila D. Mung'Omba of Zambia from 1980 to 1985 and incumbent Ndiaye who was elected President in 1985.

PANA FON/DS 22Aug95

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). Africa News


August, 1995


The U.S. Identifies South Africa as ' A Big Emerging Market' by Peter Mwaura PANA Staff Corespondent


LENGTH: 414 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - The Clinton administration has identified South Africa as "a big emerging market".

' Business America' , the Department of Commerce's magazine of international trade, describes South Africa as "the most advanced, broadly-based and productive economy in Africa, with a GDP that is 45 percent of all Africa's". 

In its August 1995 issue, the magazine says South Africa's transformation to a democracy will finally enable it to harness and unleash all of its potential, thrusting the nation

into true bem (big emerging market) status.

"Surprising even his supporters with his pro-market attitude, President Nelson Mandela's ascendance has meant that

not only is the country open for business, it's expanding its hours of operation," the magazine states.

South Africa has a modern infrastructure supporting an efficient distribution of goods to major urban centres throughout the region, and well-developed financial, legal, communications, energy and transport sectors.

The country boasts a global trade surplus of nearly one billion dollars and a stock exchange which ranks among the top 10 in the world.

Significant growth potential, access to other markets in

Africa and the availability of inexpensive electrical power and raw materials add to its economic promise.

President Clinton has called upon American companies to help build the non-racial market democracy in post-apartheid South Africa.

PANA PM/DS 22Aug95

Africa News


August, 1995


Senegalese Minister Denies State Of War Situation


LENGTH: 334 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The Senegalese Minister of the Armed Forces Cheikh Hamidou Kane denied in parliament Monday here that the goverment army was in a state of war in the Souther Casamance region where rebels have been fighting for secession since 1982.

Speaking during question time in the House, Kane said the army was on a mission to ensure the security of the populations and safeguard national integrity. 

Answering a question from an MP, the minister also denied rumours that the death of 28 soldiers in a clash with the Movement of Casamance Democratic Forces (MFDC) on 24 July in Babonda resulted from treason.

However, Mr Kane admitted that there were errors in command, which led to the capture of the commanding officer by the rebels.

The Senegalese army recovered the locality of Babonda, at the border with Guinea Bissau, a rebel stronghold.

The minister reaffirmed the willingness of the government to find a peaceful solution to the conflict, provided this does not disrupt Senegal's territorial integrity.

PANA-APS OD/CTN/SG/SJD/PBM 22Aug95

August, 1995


Mozambique Welcomes End of Coup In Sao Tome


LENGTH: 400 words


 

by Paul Fauvet, PANA Correspondent

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Mozambique on Tuesday welcomed Sao Tome and Principe's return to legality following this morning's negotiated end to the military coup that had temporarily overthrown the democratically elected President, Miguel Trovoada.

"We are satisfied with the outcome', Foreign Minister Leonardo Simao told the Mozambique News Agency, AIM

He congratulated all those involved in the peaceful negotiations that resulted in Trovoada's return to the presidential palace "particularly the angolan mediating team". 

Leading the negotiations was Angolan foreign minister Venancio de Moura had handled two and a half days of delicate discussions between the coup-leaders and the legitimate authorities, culminating in this morning's agreement.

The putschists appear to have won nothing from the negotiations apart from an amnesty.

Simao praised "all those who ensured that the national interests of Sao Tome prevailed".

He said that during the crisis Mozambique had maintained contact with the other Portuguese speaking African countries (Angola, Cape Verde and Guinea-Bissau) as well as with Portugal, the former colonial power.

"We gave our full support to the mediating role of angola", he said.

PANA-AIM PF/PBM 22AUG95

August, 1995


Elections Rights Group Says Zimbabwean Elections Were Rigged


LENGTH: 520 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - A human rights organisation on Tuesday here said Zimbabwe was saddled with an undemocratic government which had rigged last April's parliamentary elections to stay in power.

In a statement, the Southern African Human Rights Foundation (SAHRF), said the nullification of the election results for Harare south constituency confirmed that elections were rigged.

"The Harare south constituency revelations were only the very tip of the iceberg as rigging, fraudulent activities and intimidation of voters in various ways were part of governments broad strategy to stay in power," the rights group said. 

An independent candidate in the elections, Margaret Dongo, won her petition in the high court to have the Harare south constituency's results nullified.

She had sought nullification of the result on grounds that there had been irregularities which distorted the results of the poll in which the candidate of the ruling Zimbabwe African National Union _atriotic Front (ZANU PF), Vivian Wwashita, was declared winner.

SAHRF accused government of promoting what it termed foreign economic colonialisation.

"The real government in Zimbabwe is no longer ZANU PF but the foreign office in London and the state department in the USA," said SAHRF.

The Forum Party of Zimbabwe (FPZ) also said in a statement recently that it believed the elections were rigged.

The party's secretary for publicity and information, James Dzvova, said irregularites that surfaced in the Harare south election were planned and implemented with the full knowledge and connivance by the ruling party.

A constitutional conference, he said should be convened immediately to come up with a new constitution to be followed by fresh elections.

"In the event of ZANU PF refusing to convene an all party constitutional conference, the FPZ will have no alternative but to take ZANU PF to the supreme court for redress,"said dzvova.

PANA-ZIANA MUH/PBM 22AUG95

Japanese Anti-Bomb Pacifists Allowed To Stop Over In Dakar


LENGTH: 214 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Senegalese has given permission for the Kareliya, a Liberian ship chartered by Japanese pacifists, to stop over in Dakar, well informed sources said here Tuesday.

The ship is on a world tour with 350 Japanese members of the peace boat. 

The pacifists, who held an anti-nuclear protest in the French port of Marseille last week, are campaigning to sensitise people on the effects of the atomic bomb in Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

After Dakar, the ship is to sail for Latin America.

August, 1995


Mugabe, Museveni Leave Nigeria >From Randy Zormelo


LENGTH: 414 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Presidents Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe and Yoweri Museveni of Uganda left Monday for home at the end of a two-day working visit to Nigeria during which they discussed with Gen. Sani Abacha the political crisis in the country.

The two heads of state, who arrived in the country's federal capital, Abuja, Sunday, were in Nigeria under a mandate given to them last month in Kampala, Uganda, by leaders of East, Central and Southern African countries to discuss the crisis with Abacha. 

Sources close to the presidency said Tuessady that the three leaders discussed the problem of return of democratic rule in nigeria and clemency for former head of state Gen.Olusegun Obasanjo and more than 40 other soldiers and civilians convicted recently by a special military tribunal for plotting to overthrow Abacha.

The three leaders also discussed the problem of conflict resolution, political stability and the economic integration of the continent.

The visiting presidents were the first official delegation sent in the name of African leaders to the nigerian authorities since the political crisis began.

It was also the first visit by the two presidents to Nigeria since Gen. Abacha came to power in November 1993.

Mugabe said after the talks with the Nigerian leader that he was satisfied that progress was being made towards restoring democracy in Nigeria.

He said the visit was quite positive, giving no other details.

PANA RZ/PBM 23AUG95 E

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


245 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Ecomog Peace Force Needs Logistics Support


LENGTH: 667 words


 

by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent

ABUJA, Nigeria (PANA) - The West African force in Liberia, Ecomog, badly needs financial and logistics support now that the country's warring factions have signed an agreement to end the civil war, its Commander Brig.Gen. John Mark Inienger said Tuesday in Abuja, Nigeria.

"We are assuring the heads of state of Ecowas and the international community that we are not lacking in men, but we need financial resources and logistics to support the troops," he told PANA in the Nigerian Federal Capital.

Under the latest peace accord, the 13th signed by the warring factions Sunday, Ecomog is to oversee the disarmament of an estimated 60,000 combatants belonging to different factions in Liberia. 

Inienger said that due to lack of progress in the peace process, the peace force had been cut down to an estimated 8,000 troops from a peak of about 15,000 in 1992.

The United Nations, he said, had also scaled down its observers and threatened to pull them out completely by 15 September.

But the Ecomog commander said with the signing of the new accord, which goes into effect in the first week of September, he "is hopeful" the Ecowas heads of state and the UN would be encouraged to support the peace-keeping force.

On the suggestion that the force should engage in peace enforcement in case of violation of the accord, inienger satated that Ecomog's mission is not to "usurp the sovereignty of Liberia, but to assist Liberians restore peace in their country."

He described the Abuja accord as a "new page in the peace process," adding that for the first time all the warring factions had undertaken to work for peace.

Reacting to accusations by some factions that Ecomog was biased against some of them, Inienger said it was normal in conflict situation for parties to seek to protect their interests.The liberian war, he said, lacks ideology.

"The factions are fighting for jobs and positions, so you should expect such misunderstanding," Inienger argued.

But the Ecomog Commader said with the appointment of a neutral person, 55-year-old lecturer Wilton Sankawolo, to head the transitional council of state for 12 months, he was hopeful of peace in Liberia.

The Liberian war has killed more than 150,000 people, including president Samuel Doe, the target of the rebellion launched by National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) leader Charles Taylor on 24 December 1989.

Inienger, a former state governor in Nigeria, is the longest-serving Ecomog Commander, having spent some 20 months in command of the force sent to Monvoria in August 1990 by the Economic Community of West African States.

PANA PE/RZ/PBM 22AUG95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

LANGUAGE: English

246 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


University University Head Says All Is Back To Normal


LENGTH: 414 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - University of Zimbabwe (UZ) Vice-Chancellor prof. Gordon Chavunduka said on Tuesday the situation at the institution has returned to normal after about two months of disturbances. 

Chavunduka said in an interview that 12 members of the Students' Representative Council (SRC) and seven other UZ workers whose suspensions were lifted last week were now back on campus.

He said three other SRC members still on suspension would soon appear before the disciplinary committee, although no specific date had been set.

"We have appointed a commission of inquiry which has already started its work and will report back soon.

"They will investigate the causes of the recent disturbances and make recommendations on how (the recent) and other disturbances in the University can be avoided in future, among other things," said Chavunduka.

He said the University had lifted the suspension of the 19 students and workers after the University's legal office found them not directly responsible for disturbances.

Three src members still on suspension are President Obey Mudzingwa, Vice-President Brian Kagoro and the Secretary-General Tinomudaishe Chinyoka, while three other students are also still on suspension as they were suspected of inciting disturbances and disrupting the institution's teaching programme.

The University had been rocked by demonstrations, clashes between police and students, and outright destruction of property.

PANA-ZIANA JIM/NDN/FON 22Aug95

Africa News


August, 1995


Botswana Set for All Africa games


LENGTH: 240 words


 

GABORONE, Botswana (PANA) - Botswana will be represented by a contingent of over 80 athletes and officials at the 10-day All Africa Games that open in Zimbabwe on 13 September.

The team will participate in the athletics, boxing , karate, netball and tennis competitions. 

Sources said all the 60 atheletes to participate in the games would be required to sign a code of conduct in which they will commit themselves to good behaviour and promise not to bring Botswana's name into disrepute.

The whole team will leave for Zimbabwe by road on 7 September and is due back home on 24 September.

248 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Panel Indicts contractors Over Botched Junior World Cup


LENGTH: 374 words


 

FROM Paul Ejime PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria not only lost the right to host the Under-21 world soccer tournament to Qatar, it also lost a substantial amount of money due to mismanagement, a government panel has said.

Presenting its report Wednesday in Lagos, The panel on the cancelled Nigeria'95 local organising committee's activities told Sports Minister Jim Nwobodo that vouchers of up to 807 million naira were reported missing. It said contracts were awarded without proper procedure. (There are 82 naira to one u.s. dollar in the open market).

Four stadia as well as communications, health and transports facilities were upgraded at the cost of millions of dollars for the tournament, which was to have taken place in March.

But the world soccer governing body FIFA cancelled Nigeria's bid citing security reasons. It took the championship to the Gulf state of Qatar. Nigeria lost its protest and appeal for reparation from FIFA.

Nwobodo said at least 63 million naira would be refunded by some of the contractors to government. He also pledged that government would punish anyone involved in stealing funds.

Nwobodo said about 238 million naira was the balance in the comittee's account and a letter of credit with the Central Bank of Nigeria.

PANA PE/OSS 23Aug95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

LANGUAGE: English

249 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Prime Minister Meles Zenawi Elected Executive Prime Minister


LENGTH: 520 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Parliament in Addis Ababa Wednesday elected Mr Meles Zenawi,40, as the Ethiopian Federal Democratic Republic's Executive Prime Minister for the next five years.

Zenawi has for the past four years been heading an interim administration formed by several former guerilla groups which took over power in Ethiopia after the flight into exile of former Marxist leader, Mengistu Haile Mariam in May 1991.

He was nominated by a member of the Oromo Peoples' Democratic Organisation (OPDO) a coalition partner of the Ethiopian Peoples' Revolutionary Democratic Front (EPRDF) which won the majority of seats in the new council, elected 7 May 1995. 

According to the Federal constitution, the Prime Minister is chosen from among a party with majority of seats in the Council of Representatives.

Zenawi was a member, central committee and political bureau member of the Tigray Peoples' Liberation Front (TPLF) between 1974 and 1989. He became chairman of the front in 1989 and assumed the leadership of the EPRDF the same year.

Born in Adwa, Tigray region, Meles Zenawi left his medical studies at the Faculty of Medicine in Addis Ababa to join the Tigray Liberation front in October 1974.

He recently earned a Masters degree in Business Administration (MBA) from the Open University in the United kingdom through distance education which he undertook from 1993-1995.

Meles is fluent in English, his vernacular Tigrigna and Amharic. His hobbies include reading,listening to music and swimming in his spare times.Meles is married with two children.

The new constitution of the Ethiopian Federal Democratic Republic states that the Prime Minister is the chief executive, the chairman of the council of ministers and Commander-in-Chief of the national armed forces.

He shall submit his nominees for ministerial posts for approval by the Council of Representatives. The Prime Minister is free to choose ministers from within parliament or outside.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: September 1, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


250 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Ghana Teaches Brazil Soccer Samba


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

by Vincent Obi PANA Correspondent

LONDON (PANA) - Ghana Starlets return home to a heroic welcome in Accra Thursday after winning the World Under-17 soccer championship in Ecuador, South America.

When they emerged African champions after whipping Nigeria 3-1 in Mali, the Ghanaians left no doubt of their intention to snatch the world championship.

From Mali they embarked on a European tour, winning five of six warm-up matches played before flying to Quito, the Ecuadorean capital, for the world title. They did not lose any of the trial matches. 

From 3-20 August, 16 countries, including ecuador and 15 other qualifiers (three from each continent), began the campaign for the third Fifa Under-17 championship and fifth tournament overall since Nigeria won the maiden 1985 event in China.

Guinea and Nigeria were the other African teams in Ecuador -- Nigeria appearing as Africa's second-best qualifier and defending champion and Guinea, the bronze medalist at Mali '95.

Ghana scored five goals and conceded one in group A matches in which Ecuador, Japan and the United States also played. Ghana bagged the maximum nine points from the three matches, winning 1-0 against Japan, 2-1 against Ecuador and 2-0 against the United States.

In the quaterfinals, the Ghanaians obliterated European champions Portugal 2-0.

Guinea bade farewell to the event during the group B playoffs but not before coming from two goals down to beat Portugal 3-2.

In group C in Rio Bamba, the coldest venue in Ecuador (which in Spanish means equator), defending champions Nigeria struggled to a 1-1 draw with Qatar on 4 August. But Nigeria defeated Oceania champions Australia 2-0 and sent Spain home 2-1 to lead the group.

The Nigerians then travelled to Porto Viejo, a town as muggy as Lagos, only to lose 3-1 to third-rate Asian qualifier Oman. The Omanis had earned the tag "giant killers" for their victory run in the contest.

Nigeria's loss to Oman sent shockwaves around the surviving teams, including Ghana, whose semi-final opponents were the same Omanis.

Ghanaian coach Samuel Arday did not mince words. He paid glowing tribute to the Gulf team but added that he was out to win and, at least, restore the traditional African supremacy at the world youth soccer level.

"We will retaliate on behalf of Nigeria," he told the Pan African News Agency on the eve of the match with Oman.

His prophecy came true. Ghana outplayed Oman 3-1 in Porto Viejo as Brazil surprisingly defeated a very mobile Argentina 3-0 in the other semi-final encounter in Quayaquil.

The final between Brazil and Ghana at the Isidro Romero Carbo stadium -- owned by top clubside Barcelona FC of Quayaquil-- was as magnificent as the 90,000 capacity facility.

Argentina subdued Oman 2-0 for the third-place match before the expected "soccer samba" from the Brazilians.

Despite Ghana's impressive climb to the finals Brazil remained odds on favorites. But the Ghana routed Brazil, beating the colourful South Americans at their own game -- "soccer samba."

In the 38th minute Baba Sule, captain Emmanuel Bentil in the 43rd and David Amoako in the 49th, underlined Ghanaian supremacy over a traditionally world soccer powerhouse, Brazil.

Ghana 3-2 victory over Brazil was not the issue. Rather, it was the lopsided nature of the match in which the Brazilians almost looked liked novices.

The Ghanaian player of note was midfielder Awudu Issaka. He single-handedly tore the Brazilian team into shreds.

On one occasion, the Brazilians were so stunned they lost possession for eight straight minutes as the Ghanaians played ball to the delight of the 90,000 spectators.

Ghana's double victory equals Nigeria's record of winning the trophy twice and runner-up once.

Nigeria won the championship in 1985, was runner-up in 1987 and regained the trophy in 1993.

For the Ghanaians, Ecuador '95 was their third successive final. They won in 1991 and were runners-up to Nigeria in 1993 before this Quayaquil triumph.

One thing remained clear after Irish referee Irvine Leslie blew his final whistle on 20 August: soccer supremacy at the world youth level remains the exclusive preserve of the African continent.

PANA VAO/PE/OSS 23Aug95 ENG022

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.
