Africa News


August, 1995


Abacha Names New boss for Authoritative Daily


LENGTH: 507 words


 

by Randy Zormelo Pana Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria's military ruler General Sani Abacha has appointed Innocent Oparadike Sole administrator of the Daily Times of Nigeria (DTN) company, publishers of the authoritative pro-government 'Daily Times', in replacement of Tunji Oseni.

A statement from information and culture minister Walter Ofonagoro received Tuesday in Lagos said the appointment was with immediate effect.

Oparidike, 45, one-time editor-in-chief of the government owned 'New Nigerian" newspaper and former information and culture commissioner of Imo State in eastern Nigeria, obtained a first class honours degree in mass communications from the University of Nigeria, Nsukka, in 1976 and a masters degree from the University of Lagos in 1981. 

He was a pioneer member of staff of the News Agency of Nigeria (Nan) fom where he went to the now postcribed National Concord newspapers, owned by detained millionnaire businessman Moshood Abiola, where he served as the group political editor.

He became the editor of The Democrat in 1983 and later editor of New Nigeria newspapers, up to 1987, when he moved to the Mass Mobilisation for Social and Economic Reconstrution directorate where he was national director for information and publicity.

Until his appointment, Oparadike was the managing director of Freedom Communications Limited in Lagos.

Tunji Oseni, the outgoing chief executive of Nigeria's largest circulation newspaper, was appointed managing director of the company in 1993 by the shortlived interim national government of industrialist Ernest Shonekan. Although no official reason was given for Oseni's sudden removal, it had been predicted.

'AM News', a daily, in Saturday's issue reported that information minister Walter Ofonagoro, whose ministry supervises the DTN was not "comfortable" with Oseni's activities.

PANA RZ/DS 23Aug95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

LOAD-DATE: September 1, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


252 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Drought to Dominate Sadc Talks


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

by John Makamure, Pana Correspondent

JOHANNESBURG (PANA) - The stage is set for the annual summit of the Southern African Development Community in Johannesburg, where leaders will discuss progress towards regional integration and the effects of the current drought on the fragile economies of some of the 11 member countries.

The summit proceedings, which started on 22 August, will culminate with the meeting of the heads of state and government at the city's World Trade Centre on Monday.

All the Sadc leaders are expected to attend the summit, being held in South Africa for the first since.

Sadc members comprise Angola, Botswana, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Swaziland, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe. 

This year's drought comes after Sadc countries were still recovering from another devastating dry period in 1991/92, which forced member states to import large quantities of food to avert mass starvation.

At the height of the 1992 drought, more than 18 million people in the Sadc needed food handouts and assistance with seed packs and fertiliser to prepare for the 1993 farming season.

The high costs of importing food led to a diversion of large sums of money that could have been used to supported the integration process.

The region's early warning system estimates that this year's cereal harvest will reach only 15.73 million tonnes. Total cereal availability for the 1995/96 marketing year is 19.97 million tonnes.

This will not cover direct consumption needs of 23.34 million tonnes, let alone the additional 3.73 million tonnes needed to rebuild depleted stocks. The overall deficit is therefore 7.1 million tonnes, of which 4.92 million tonnes is maize.

Sadc has already appealed for 0.52 million tonnes of food aid, of which 200 000 tonnes is for programme food aid and 320 000 tonnes is for emergency assistance.

Although the international community is expected to lend a sympathetic ear to Sadc appeals for food aid, the summit is expected to discuss ways of restoring the capacity of the region to cope with the current and future droughts.

This, it is suggested, could be through the improvement of water facilities and the provision of essential inputs for the next season.

To mitigate the harsh effects of future droughts, Sadc is setting up a revolving fund as insurance against droughts.

At least USD 30 million is needed for the fund which will be made available to members for importing food.

The member states have agreed on a revolving fund due to the high costs of keeping physical grain stocks.

Also of critical importance at the Sadc meeting will be the drive towards economic integration and community building.

Sadc executive secretary Kaire Mbuende says a multi-track approach whereby member states would implement a zero-tariff-regime with respect to a wide range of products traded within the community is being considered.

But trade experts say member states seem not to be committed to eliminating tariffs as evidenced by a multiplicity of trade barriers still in place and the low levels of intra-regional trade.

Delays by Zimbabwe and South Africa to renew the outdated 1964 trade agreement which is in the latter's favour is a case in point.

Talks to review the trade agreement have dragged on for nearly three years.

Although the two countries on Tuesday agreed to reinstate clothing and textile duty preferences for Zimbabwean exports to South Africa, industrialists believe the whole agreement needs to be reviewed as a matter of urgency to enable various sectors of the economy enter that lucrative market.

Analysts say despite the formation of a sector on finance and investment co-ordinated by South Africa and the implementation of market-based economic reforms by many member states, Sadc's private sector has not grown to assume its status as the engine of growth.

A stable macro-economic environment within the region is therefore needed to promote private sector investment and achieve sustainable economic growth and support the integration process.

Generating awareness of the importance of integration among people at the grassroots is also seen as crucial to the achievement of community building.

Meanwhile, the summit is also expected to consider an application by Mauritius to join the regional economic grouping as its 12th member.

PANA-Ziana JM/STC/DS 23Aug95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: September 1, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


253 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Picture of Mandela's Holed Sock Wins Honours


LENGTH: 467 words


 

KINSHASA, Zaire (PANA) - The picture showing President Nelson Mandela's torn sock has won the photographer who took it the Best Photo Award for 1994 in South Africa.

Unfortunately, according to the Johannesburg correspondent of a Zairean weekly, L'Observateur (The Observer), the photo-journalist who caught it, Ken OOsterboek, was killed in April 1994 while covering post-election violent incidents in Tokoza Township East of South Africa's economic capital.

The late OOsterboek's camera caught Mandela taking an inaugural shot at the ball during a soccer match. In the process, one shoe slipped off, revealing the sock with a gaping hole through which the president's big toe portruded. 

Gail Kriel, the valet who takes care of Mandela's dressing at the president's official residence in Pretoria has said he was deeply "embarrassed" by the event.

But in his defence, Kriel was quoted as saying Mandela had two other residencies in South Africa."One cannot therefore know for sure from which he was dressed up on that day," he added.

However, Yusuf Surtee, the courturier who has been clothing Mandela since he came out of the apartheid gaols in 1990, told the South African Press Association (SAPA) that Nelson Mandela was very particular about the quality of socks he wore.

And, in a statement published by the mass circulation 'Sowetan' newspaper, which is popular among black South African readers, Surtee claimed that the president had deliberately cut his sock to bring relief to his swollen toe.

The torn sock of Nelson Mandela was in April chosen by the South African media as the best picture for 1994. There is tradition in that country to give awards to the best written articles, reporting or photographs published by diverse newspapers.

PANA LAPS/PBM 24AUG95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: September 1, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


254 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


South Africa and United States Deny Tiff


LENGTH: 294 words


 

PRETORIA, South Africa (PANA) - The reported tension between South Africa and the United States over South Africa's relations with Iran and Cuba has been officially denied.

Following a meeting in Pretoria between South African Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo and the American Ambassador to South Africa, Princeton Lyman, assurances were given that relations between the two countries are as good as ever. 

Lyman confirmed that the question of South African relations with Iran and Cuba had been discussed. The two parties agreed that a difference existed in the way relations with other countries were seen, but that South Africa and the United States had the same goals in international relations.

Nzo agreed, saying the question of South African relations with Iran and Cuba did not change relations between South Africa and the United States. "It was an excellent meeting," he added.

PANA LW/DS 24Aug95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

LANGUAGE: English

255 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Congo To Host First Pan African Festival In 1996


LENGTH: 294 words


 

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo (PANA) - Congo will in August 1996 host the first Pan African Music Festival (FESPAM), following recommendations from the conference of African ministers of culture and the OAU, official sources said Thursday in the Congolese capital.

The festival, to be held in Brazzaville under the theme 'Music And Human Development', will be attended by 4,000 traditional and modern musicians from Africa and the black diaspora as well as the and from Peri-African civilisations (Mediterranean and Indian Ocean). 

"The music carnival, of worldwide dimensions, must be a festival of peace, life and meeting of all cultures," the organisers said.

FESPAM will be launched on 15 August 1996, to coincide with the Congolese National Day. Then the event will be held every two years.

The Congolese government has appointed Charles Tchicou, an academic, as general commissioner for FESPAM 1996.

PANA MB/SG/SJD/DS 24Aug95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


256 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Taylor Commits Himself to Abuja Accord


LENGTH: 307 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Charles Taylor, the man who started Liberia's civil war in 1989, said on Wednesday night that his National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) is committed to the Abuja accord aimed at ending the bloodshed in the war-torn country.

"What is left to be done is the Ecowas (Economic Community of West African States) exerting pressure and its influence on all the other parties to abide by the agreement," he told reporters at the Kotoka International Airport in Accra during a stop-over on his way to his base in Gbarnga. 

Taylor, whose invasion of Liberia in December 1989 started the war, said his NPFL will "do everything in its power... to implement the accord."

The accord, brokered by Ecowas, was signed by Liberia's faction leaders in the Nigerian capital on Sunday.

Mohamed Ibn Cchambas, Ghana's deputy foreign minister, said Jerry Rawlings, Ecowas' current chairman and Ghana's president, will send a delegation to Monrovia to assess the implementation of the ceasefire.

PANA MA/DS 24Aug95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

Africa News


August, 1995

LENGTH: 1027 words


 

by John Makamure, Pana Correspondent

August, 1995


Prime Minister Meles Zenawi Elected Executive Prime Minister


LENGTH: 534 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Parliament in Addis Ababa Wednesday elected Mr Meles Zenawi,40, as the Ethiopian Federal Democratic Republic's Executive Prime Minister for the next five years.

Zenawi has for the past four years been heading an interim administration formed by several former guerilla groups which took over power in Ethiopia after the flight into exile of former Marxist leader, Mengistu Haile Mariam in May 1991.

He was nominated by a member of the Oromo Peoples' Democratic Organisation (OPDO) a coalition partner of the Ethiopian Peoples' Revolutionary Democratic Front (EPRDF) which won the majority of seats in the new council, elected 7 May 1995. 

According to the Federal constitution, the Prime Minister is chosen from among a party with majority of seats in the Council of Representatives.

Zenawi was a member, central committee and political bureau member of the Tigray Peoples' Liberation Front (TPLF) between 1974 and 1989. He became chairman of the front in 1989 and assumed the leadership of the EPRDF the same year.

Born in Adwa, Tigray region, Meles Zenawi left his medical studies at the Faculty of Medicine in Addis Ababa to join the Tigray Liberation front in October 1974.

He recently earned a Masters degree in Business Administration (MBA) from the Open University in the United kingdom through distance education which he undertook from 1993-1995.

Meles is fluent in English, his vernacular Tigrigna and Amharic. His hobbies include reading,listening to music and swimming in his spare times.Meles is married with two children.

The new constitution of the Ethiopian Federal Democratic Republic states that the Prime Minister is the chief executive, the chairman of the council of ministers and Commander-in-Chief of the national armed forces.

He shall submit his nominees for ministerial posts for approval by the Council of Representatives. The Prime Minister is free to choose ministers from within parliament or outside.

PANA-ENA GA/BZ/PBM 24Aug95

259 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Burundi in Civil War, Says Buyoya


LENGTH: 680 words


 

by Ferdinand Bigumandondera PANA Correspondent

BUJUMBURA, Burundi (PANA) - A former Burundi head of state says his country is now in a state of civil war between rival extremists fighting for supremacy -- the majority Hutus on the one hand, and the army-led minority Tutsis on the other.

Politicians and military chiefs have pointedly avoided the term "war" to characterize two years of ethnic conflict, triggered by the assassination of the nation's first Hutu president.

But in a grim analysis of the burgeoning strife that has claimed hundreds of thousands of lives Maj. Pierre Buyoya said in an interview today that ambitious politicians had fanned the flames of feuding into fullscale civil war. 

Buyoya, Burundi's last Tutsi president, identified the two warring factions as:

-- "Hutu militias who wage civil war with a visible aim, strategy and action plan."

-- Tutsi militias which "kill, destabilise and pillage, probably under various commands."

He said politicians were behind the crisis and evidently had "one foot in power and another in the militias."

Buyoya's word carries weight both in Burundi and abroad. After overthrowing Col. Jean-Baptiste Bagaza to seize power in 1987 Buyoya organized the first democratic elections that yielded Melchior Ndadaye as the first Hutu head of state in June 1993.

Ndadaye was assassinated four months later in an attempted military coup led by Tutsi officers.

Buyoya said Burundi was also going through a diplomatic crisis.

"The image of Burundi is disastrous. One has the impression that the country is very seriously attacked. But there is nobody to defend it abroad," he said.

He said Burundi must "develop a strategy for the preservation of peace, strongly fight against warmongers, develop a diplomatic strategy to support peace and end the government indecision."

In a related development, the London-based human rights watchdog body Amnesty International condemned neighbouring Zaire for expelling thousands of refugees from camps there to their homes in Burundi and Rwanda.

"These acts of refoulement constitute a clear violation of international law ... and are certain to contribute to an escalation of tension in the region," an Amnesty statement said.

The organization expressed fears that some of the million or so refugees, mainly Hutus, could face death at the hands of Tutsis on their return. They might also be denied humanitarian aid now available in Zaire.

Amnesty appealed to Zaire to stop the repatriation.

PANA FB/KIB/SJD/DS/JE 24Aug95

August, 1995


Ghana's Ike Quartey Retains WBA Welterweight Crown


LENGTH: 214 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Ghana's boxing champion Ike "bazooka" Quartey woke up again this morning as world welterweight champion.

This followed Wednesday's bout when he stopped Guyana's Andrew Murray in the fourth round of their title fight in France. 

Quartey regained his crown one minute into the round when Murray's conermen called in the ringside doctor to examine cuts Quartey had opened on their ward's eyebrows in the previous round.

The doctor declared Murray unfit to continue the bout.

August, 1995


U.S Commends Angola's Mediation in Sao Tome


LENGTH: 280 words


 

LUANDA, Angola (PANA) - The U.S ambassador to Angola, Donald Steinberg, has said that Angola's successful mediation in Sao Tome and Principle was a victory for the island nation and Africa as a whole.

Angola successfully mediated the end of a 15 August coup d'etat against President Miguel Trovoada. 

"On behalf of my government and of Under Secretary for African affairs Georges Moose, I recognise and commend the Angolan government's efforts to restore democracy in Sao-Tome and Principe", said the American diplomat.

He noted that the mediation under the auspices of Angolan President Jose Eduardo Dos Santos and carried out by Foreign Minister Venancio De Moura "was difficult and magnificent".

Angola has received similar congratulation messages from France, Portugal and the European community.

Africa News


August, 1995


Project on Control of Bushfires for West Africa


LENGTH: 667 words


 

by Matar Gaye, Pana Special Correspondent

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The ecological monitoring centre of Dakar, Senegal (CSE), is developing a West African programme for bushfire control with a test phase involving Guinea, Mali, and Senegal, according to authorised sources in Dakar.

"The sub-regional project results from the combination of the will of donors and Senegalese expertise in the field," according to Racine Kane, a CSE programme manager.

In Guinea, he said, CSE is, in cooperation with local forestry services, conducting a test programme on creating bushfire awareness. 

The project, funded by the Swiss government, uses to a rural radio network to disseminate information on bushfires and data received every day.

In Mali, the CSE initiative has so far resulted in activities including the transfer of data to the various ministries involved.

In 1991-1992, satellite monitoring helped in assessments of the part played by bushfires.

According to Kane, the priority given to Guinea is related to the fact that the basins of the Senegal and Gambia rivers are located in that country which is also crossed by the Niger River.

The frequency of bushfires in the country is a threat to the balance of the ecosystems of the three rivers which are important at the regional level.

The CSE's expertise in monitoring the phenomenon has been developed over the years since 1990 when the centre developed a programme to supplement the efforts of the Senegalese Forestry and Soil Conservation Department.

The monitoring is carried out by satellite and data are collected twice a day by a reception centre in operation in Dakar since 1992.

Prior to the centre's operation, pictures were ordered from the Spanish Maspalomas Centre, in the Canary Islands. But they usually reached CSE after two weeks of having been taken, making it impossible to ensure monitoring in real time. As a result, warnings could not be issued early enough to help put an end to the bushfires.

According to CSE experts, pictures taken at night show clearly where the active fires are whereas pictures taken by day are more useful in assessing burnt areas.

During the dry season 1993-1994 season some 750,000 hectares were burnt with 1,677 cases of bush fires having been reported in Senegal alone.

Fires are more recurrent during the December-January-February quarter when the grass is dense and relatively dry, he said.

The bushfire monitoring project is part of a large-scale programme of cooperation between the United Nations Sahel Office (Unso) and the Danish Agency for International Cooperation (Danida), on the one hand, and CSE and the Senegalese government, on the other.

PANA MG/IS/SG/KIB/OSE/DS 28Aug95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

August, 1995


Kenya Says No To Chemical Weed Control


LENGTH: 334 words


 

by Josephine Mwasi Pana Correspondent

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - Kenya is strongly opposed to using chemicals to kill the dangerous water weed fast engulfing Lake Victoria, a measure being seriously considered by Uganda a scientist says.

Acccording to Dr. Joseph Ojiambo, a Kenyan scientist who heads the country's secretariat on the Lake Victoria Management Programme, focus is being put on "a biological option" using the weevil, a bug. 

He said Kenya would remain cautious to chemical options which Kampala had authorised for immediate trails in the vast fresh water mass shared also with Tanzania.

"Many people are wary of the chemicals in Lake Victoria. This will remain a tricky option," He told the press 21 August in Nairobi.

"Our stand will be known this September in a comprehensive study report on the three options: biological, mechanical harvesting and chemical harvesting in the elimination of the weed known as (the) water hyacith," he said.

Kenya, he added, was also undertaking research in the elimination of the weed through weevils at Lake Naivasha, 85 kilometres west of Nairobi.

PANA KNA JM/OSS 22Aug95

Africa News


August, 1995


Zambian Farmers Urged To Grow Drought-resistant Crops


LENGTH: 600 words


 

by Mildred Mulenga PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambian farmers have been advised to grow drought-resistant food crops to help make the country self-sufficient in food under current dry circumstances.

Zambia's Agriculture, Food and Fisheries Minister Suresh Desai said in Lusaka 22 August that farmers had an obligation to assist the country break its dependence on imported maize, to mitigate the effects of famine due to the drought.

He spoke at a one-day symposium on the the effects of drought on Zambian agriculture, solutions and strategies of soil management. 

Zambia's Southern and Eastern regions, both traditional maize producing areas, have been hit by drought in recent years.

The agriculture ministry has worked out logistics to put in place a new programme called "Zero Tillage". It is meant to boost food output in drought-stricken areas.

Desai said government had already set aside one billion kwacha (about 920 Kwacha = 1 U.S. dollar) for the programme. At least 2,000 farmers in Luangwa, eastern Zambia will benefit from the first phase.

The project will teach farmers to switch to hoe-tilling and thereby reduce ground water evaporation. Crops like sorghum, soya beans, millet and groundnuts are drought resistant.

But speaking at the same meeting the Vice-Chancellor of The University Of Zambia, Andrew Siwela, said government must fashion a long-term solution to the drought problem.

He said it would be more beneficial to invested funds in drought monitoring and research to establish the causes and correct the problem.

"I would recommend that drought relief include support to all these complementary areas rather than just the procurement and distribution of relief food," he said.

In addition, he said government should set up a multi-disciplinary, permanent drought monitoring and research team. Its main task would be to examine the drought problem in detail and recommend practical measures to correct or eliminate the problem.

Government released some 90,000 tonnes of food relief Friday to help at least 1.3 million people in the 31 worst drought hit districts in Zambia.

The Southern, Lusaka, Eastern, Central and Western provinces are also among the adversely hit areas by the drought.

PANA MM/MK/OSS 28Aug95

August, 1995


September Inauguration for Liberia's Interim Governing Council


LENGTH: 334 words


 

by Mawusi Afele PANA Correspondent

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Liberia's new Council Of State will be inagurated by the Chairman of The Economic Community Of West African States (Ecowas), President Jerry Rawlings, Friday in Monrovia, the Ghana foreign ministry said Tuesday.

This follows the signing of the Abuja agreement August 19. Under it, the warring factions have accepted composition of the six-member council that will rule until a new government is elected in 12 months.

The council will be under the chairmanship of university professor Wilson Sankawulo.

Other members are Alhaji G.V. Kromah, leader of the United Liberation Movement; Charles Taylor, leader of the National Patriotic Front Of Liberia; George Boley, leader of the Liberia Peace Council; Oscar Quiah representing civilians, and chief Tamba Tailor, a traditional ruler.

The council's installation is the next stage of the Abuja accord which also stipulates a cease-fire, disarmament, demobilization of troops and elections.

A cease-fire which went into effect Saturday is still holding.

Africa News


August, 1995


Uganda Warns Sudan As Rebels Invade


LENGTH: 734 words


 

by Moses Draku PANA Correspondent

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - Sudanese army units and Ugandan rebels, led by a former minister of dictator Idi Amin, have attacked government soldiers in Oraba, northern Uganda, the state-owned New Vision newspaper reported Tuesday.

It said that the rebels, calling themselves the West Nile Bank and headed by a renegade Colonel, Juma Oris, crossed into Uganda and attacked the border post Sunday. Oraba is about a kilometre South of the common border with Sudan. 

The newspaper gave no figures of calsualties or of the invadors. It said Sudanese soldiers were still in Oraba Monday.

It cited the country's Second Deputy Prime Minster Eric Adriko as saying that army and police units had earlier been withdrawn from the post because of fighting between Sudanese troops and the rebel Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army. They are fighting for control of Kaya, the most southerly Sudanese border town.

Ugandan Foreign Affairs Minister Ruhakana Rugunda handed over a protest note Monday for Sudan to te Libyan ambassador in Uganda, Abdallah Bujeldian. Libya is mediating between Uganda and Sudan and is the trustee of Sudanese interests in Uganda.

"(The) Uganda government calls upon and demands that the Sudan government puts an end to the incursions into uganda," Rugunda said.

"If not, the government will be left with no option but to take whatever actions is deems necessary to counter the provocation and aggression unleashed to the innocent people of Kitgum, Gulu, Moyo and Arua in defence of their lives and property." he added.

He cited incidents when rebels of the Lord's Resistance Army, another group, invaded Uganda from Sudan. It said on July 26 about 500 of these rebels dressed in Sudanese army uniforms and armed by Sudan with anti-aircraft missiles, mortars and personal weapons crossed into Uganda from Palutaka in Sudan and attacked Padibe two days later.

During the attack, he said, three civilians died, four were injured and 10 were abducted. He said homesteads were burnt and merchandise looted or destroyed.

He mentioned many other attacks from Sudan and said that in 1995 Khartoum had directly or indirectly caused suffering to people of Uganda "in well over 50 incidents." It said Sudan trained and gave sanctuary to rebels around Morobo, Mahajub and Alebo.

"Sudan has countinued to provoke, disturb, kill people, violate Uganda's territory, kidnap and sell Ugandan children for guns through her proxies like Joseph Kony," he said.

Rugunda said a peace missions with the arbitration oflibya and Malawi might fail if Sudan continued attacking Uganda.

"The situation, rather than improving has infact worsened," he said.

Uganda severed diptomatic relations with Sudan on April 23, after accusing Khartoum of assisting Kony's rebels who have since distabilised security in the northern part of the country.

Likewise, Khartoum has accused Kampala of aiding anti-government rebels who continue to attack Sudan.

PANA MD/RK/OSS 29Aug95

August, 1995


French to Produce Africa Games Promotion Film


LENGTH: 520 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - A French television crew is in Zimbabwe to shoot a promotional film on the Sixth All Africa Games to be held from 13 to 23 September in this Southern African country.

The 26-minute programme will be screened in all participating African countries and internationally via satellite.

The television crew from Canal France International (CFI) has been in Zimbabwe for 10 days to shoot the games venues, practice sessions and the country's major tourist attractions. 

French embassy counsellor Jean-Loius Rysto said in an interview the programme would be screened two days before the beginning of the continental games.

"These are the most important games in Africa and we felt that they should be able to be seen all over the continent. The video will also promote Zimbabwe as a tourist destination," said Rysto.

CFI has also purchased the rights to broadcast live in Africa the main events at the games, said Rysto.

"The rights we have purchased are only for Africa. We will be working closely with the Zimbabwe broadcasting corporation and the South African Broadcasting Corporation," he said.

CFI journalist Mahm el Mamoun said the first part of the 26-minute film would feature Zimbabwe's tourist areas, the economy and the culture while the second part would focus on the actual games venues and other issues concerning the games.

The film will have a French and English version.

Meanwhile, Rysto said the french government would train 300 athletes from francophone countries, Egypt and Zimbabwe.

"The french government is bringing in coaches this week to help prepare the athletes for the games. There will be coaches for athletics and boxing," said Rysto.

CFI is expected to bring into zimbabwe a crew of about 20 people to film the games, in which over 4 000 athletes are expected to participate.

August, 1995


Sudan Slams United Nations Over Sarajevo


LENGTH: 454 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - Sudan has said it will boycott the 50th anniversary of the United Nations because of what it termed as the world body's inaction in Bosnia.

Reacting to Monday's killing by mortar fire in Central Sarajevo of 30 person and injury of 80, the foreign ministry in Khartoum issued a statement Tuesday saying this " was an indication that the international organisation has failed to carry out its duty towards the protection of the safe heavens it created in Bosnia."

This incident could be rated as a conspiracy on the part of the united nations,even a coordination between the United Nations and the Serb aggressors under a continued arms embargo against the Republic of Bosnia that denied its people the right to defend themselves,"said the statement. 

Sudan "denounces the behaviour of the United Nations and its shameful inability in bosnia despite the potentials put at its disposal."

The foreign ministry said that Sudan will,in the light of these developments ,"boycott the celebrations marking the 50th anniversary of the United Nations."

It expressed support for the call made by the Bangadeshi prime minister for an emergency summit of the Islamic Conference Organisation (OIC) to discuss the situation in Bosnia.

Khartoum also backed the decision of the OIC contact group on Bosnia that urged muslim states to ignore the un arms embargo on that former Yugoslav state.

The ministry said Sudan is now in touch with other muslim states to coordinate policies towards "the serbian aggression and to help the people of Bosnia."

August, 1995


OAU Pledges Support for New ADB President


LENGTH: 347 words


 

by Gabu Amacha Pana Staff Correspondent

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - The Organization of African Unity (OAU) Tuesday pledged to work with the president-elect of the African Development Bank (ADB) in spite of the fact that his country is not a member of the continental-body.

"The OAU will deal with him as an international civil servant regardless of his nationality," OAU spokesman Ibrahim Daggash said. 

Governors of the Abidjan-based African Development Bank over the week-end elected Omar Kabbaj of Morocco president for a five-year term. Morocco withdrew from the OAU more than 10 years ago in protest against the admission of the Arab Republic of Saharawi to the organisation. Morocco claims sovereignity over the territory.

Kabbaj won the bank presidency after nine rounds of voting at the bank's headquarters in Abidjan Saturday.

His closest rival, Timothy Thahane of Lesotho, who had led in the overall vote since the beginning, never managed to get the necessary African votes, after Nigeria, the bank's largest shareholder with more than 10 per cent, withdrew its candidate and then supported Kabbaj to win the seat.

PANA GA/DS 29AUG95

Africa News


August, 1995


Zimbabwean Bank Rejects Drought Scheme


LENGTH: 760 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe (RBZ) has rejected as unjustified a proposal by banks to offer a special financing facility for drought-hit commercial farmers.

Reacting to the proposal, the Central Bank said it will not support a scheme that is both highly inflationary and designed to favour a select few.

The Commercial Farmers Union (CFU), which has been pushing for special interest rates for farmers whose debt exceeds zimdollars 3 billion (253 million U.S dollars), expressed shock at the decision. 

The bank said it was "committed to discouraging support of any action which might have an adverse impact on money growth and, hence, inflation."

The bank said farmers and banks would have to sit down and find other solutions to ease their viability crisis.

The special financing facility was proposed by the Bankers Association of Zimbabwe which had asked the RBZ that banks be allowed to use statutory reserve funds to reschedule the debt of farmers, as well as finance production costs in the 1995/96 season, now less than three months away.

The same funds, the banks suggested, could also finance projects in the small and medium-scale sector.

The farmers had asked for rescheduling, at favourable interest rates, of the equivalent of 94 million U.S dollars out of an accumulated debt of 353 million U.S dollars.

In addition, the farmers said they would require another three billion Zimbabwe dollars to finance production this season.

In its response to the Bankers Association of Zimbabwe President, Sij Biyam, the RBZ said it found it "difficult"' to justify assistance to a particular sector of the economy at the expense of others who were equally affected by the drought and punitive interest rates.

The CFU President, Peter Macsporran, responding to the decision by the RBZ, expressed "deep regret", and told the Zimbabwe Inter-African News Agency (ZIANA) the union was now asking for an urgent meeting with all concerned to discuss the issue.

The RBZ said there was need to formulate and implement long-term, measures to deal with the drought, and suggested that farmers should establish a drought insurance scheme.

The Central Bank said among the proposals by the bankers, there was no mention of "any significant" contribution by the banks towards assisting the farmers, "especially in light of the banks' current favourable

"We suggest that the banks should give consideration to rescheduling the loans and also examine recapitalisation as measures aimed at finding long-term solutions."

The RBZ said banks could also finance farmers from proceeds of selling agricultural bonds, which could have a tenure of up to three years and were issued at favourable interest rates.

In a separate interview, president of the bankers association, Sij Biyam, confirmed their proposals had been rejected by the RBZ and as of now, each individual farmer would be treated on his on merit.

Biyam said farmers had to realise government was against subsidies under its market reform programme, and that the productive sector would have to use their own resources to stay in business.

PANA-ZIANA STC/PBM 29AUG95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

August, 1995


Zimbabwe to Start Export of Ostrich Meat to EU


LENGTH: 334 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe will start exporting ostriches to the lucrative european union market in February year.

In an interview Tuesday, Kerne Mackie of Copro, a trading company of Zimbabwe's Ostrich Producers Association, said the country was waiting for an EU rating following the of an Ostricj abbatoir. 

The abattoir, one of the world's state of the art ostrich facilities, was built to stringent EU standards.

Mackie said Copro was receiving a lot of export enquiries from countries including South Africa. The company last month exported 78 live ostriches to China.

"The industry is growing very fast," she said.

She attributed the boom in demand for ostrich meat for its rich protein but low cholestoral levels, in spite its being red.

The quality is the same of that of super beef,'' she added.

Mackie said Copro was currently slaughtering 54 birds a week for the local market. Output is expected to nearly double 100 birds a week when the EU gives a the go ahead to allow imports from Zimbabwe.

PANA-ZIANA JIM/MUH/MP/DS 29Aug95

August, 1995


Zambia Sticks to Market Prices for Imported Maize


LENGTH: 534 words


 

by Musengwa Kayaya PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - To avert disruption of its liberalised trade policy, the Zambian government has said it will, as far as possible, maintain market prices for imported drought relief maize stocks.

Agriculture permanent secretary incharge of food security,Austin Sichinga said in a statement Tuesday that in with the liberalised agricultural marketing policies being pursued by government, the non-interventionist policy in price setting of maize and other cereals will be maintained unconditionally.

Sichinga said that government will, on its part, tender its maize stocks from the national food security reserve at econimic prices to avoid undercutting private sector business interests. 

The Zambian government has forecast substantial price increases for the staple maize grain during the remainder of the current marketing season from the current 9,000 kwacha average. (965 kwacha=one united states dollar).

Some analysts said Tuesday that prices could go up by as much as 100 percent due to the anticipated shortage and the approaching rain season when some peasants start sowing some the grain stocks.

According to official statistics, this country of nine people consumes some 17.5 million 90 kilogramme bags of maize a year.This seasonLusaka is expected to suffer a of some seven million bags due to partial drought in the maize producing areas.

President Frederick Chiluba's government this month declared 31 districts in five of the country's nine regions as famine disaster areas up to march 1996 and launched a food programme for the over 1 million affected people.

It recently launched a donor-supported "Agricultural Sector Investment Programme" (ASIP) which is aimed at, among other objectives, help establish an eleaborate irrigated agriculture system to mitigate future effects of drought on food production.

Chiluba's Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) government has since 1992 embraced a liberalised economy as of national economic recovery efforts and has done away with government food and other subsidies.

PANA MK/PBM 29AUG95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

Africa News


August, 1995


Tanzania-Zambia Railway Authority In Freight Agreement With Zaire


LENGTH: 387 words


 

by Mildred Mulenga PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - The Tanzania-Zambia Railway Authority, Taraza, has signed an agreement with Sizarail of for freight services under which Tazara will haul 200,000 tonnes of goods for the Zairean company.

Tazara will work jointly with Sizarail to serve both importers and exporters in Zaire. 

The agreement, renewable after three years, is expected to bring Tazara some USD 5-6 million.

The goods to be transported from Zaire to the Tanzanian port of Dar es Salaam through the railway include copper, zinc and cobalt.

Cement, sugar, oil products and fuel will be from Zambia to the neighbouring state.

Taraza managing director Antisne Mweemba and Sizarail director Patrick Claes signed for their respective companies.

Claes said that he anticipated that the agreed special tariffs and transit schedules between the two railways would it possible to exceed the projected 200,000 metric tonnes of traffic to be handled.

Tazara, the 1,800 kilometre long railway from Kapiri Mposhi in the Zambian midlands to the Tanzanian sea port of es Salaam, is jointly owned by the governments of Zambia and Tanzania and is of significant importance to the 20-nation Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (Comesa).

PANA MM/MK/DS 29Aug95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

Africa News


August, 1995


Sadc Economies Grow by 2.5 Percent


LENGTH: 400 words


 

JOHANNESBURG (PANA) - The economies of the Southern African Development Community (Sadc) countries grew by 2.5 percent in 1994, a significant expansion in output compared to growth of 0.5 percent in 1993.

According to the 1994 Sadc annual report, the significant acceleration in growth accompanied a general upturn in the world economy which registered a growth of 3.7 percent in 1994. 

"It was also decisively influenced by higher growth in the South African economy which grew by 2.3 percent in 1994 compared to 1.1 percent in 1993," the report said.

It however noted that in spite the positive ecomomic growth last year, the population had grown by an average of percent, "indicative of decreasing per capita incomes within region".

Inflation had also remained on the high side, with adverse effects on the need to create the macro-economic stability necessary for increased private sector investment.

Lesotho, Namibia, South Africa and Swaziland had experienced the lowest levels of inflation rates in 1994, with single digit consumer price rises. Malawi, Mozambique and had experienced higher inflation while Angola had to contend hyper-inflation both in 1993 and 1994.

A drought again this year, coming at a time when Southern Africa had not completely recovered from another one in was expected to have severe impact on growth prospects this year.

PANA-Ziana JM/FS/DS 29Aug95

Africa News


August, 1995


Donors Pledge to Help SADC States


LENGTH: 480 words


 

JOHANNESBURG (PANA) - Several donors have pledged to help member countries of the Southern African Development Community import cereals to make up for the large shortfalls caused by last drought in the sub-region.

According to a report on the drought discussed by the Council of Ministers session in Johannesburg mid-August, the European Union had confirmed a total of Ecu 65 million for aid to the region.

An additional ecu 317 million will be made available by various non-governmental organisations. 

Sadc has appealed for USD 270 million to help the community to import a total of 7.02 million tonnes of cereals implement various programmes to mitigate the effects of future droughts.

According to the report, food security projections indicated a worsening cereal deficit in the region.

Serious shortfalls were expected in Lesotho, Mozambique, South Africa, Zambia and Zimbabwe due to the late and erratic rains which had adverse effects on crop yields.

Meanwhile, South Africa had called on member states to coordinate their programmes to exploit natural resources so as achieve sustainable development in the region.

"We as south africans believe that the countries of the southern africa region can achieve their full potential only through close cooperation in the exploitation of natural resources in a coordinated fashion," foreign minister Alfred said when officially opening the two-day session.

He said Sadc member states should also harmonise their trade practices and promote economies of scale in the region.

Nzo said the region's economic future would be determined by member states themselves, and not through outside forces.

The meeting was foillowed by a Sadc summit.

PANA-Ziana JM/JNM/STC/DS 29Aug95

Africa News


August, 1995


Zimbabwe's Manufacturing Output Declines


LENGTH: 400 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe's manufacturing production decreased by 14.7 per cent during the first quarter 1995 compared to the same period the previous year, the government-owned Central Statistical Office says.

Reporting this Monday, the Zimbabwe Inter Africa News Agency, or Ziana, said that the textiles, and drinks and groups recorded the largest decreases in output at 65 per cent and at 29 per cent. 

The figures are contained in the Bureau's latest "Stats-flash" monthly publication. It said that the clothing and textiles sector has been also been rocked by high input costs. These have eroded competitiveness in export leading to the liquidation of such major players in the as Cone Textiles. The company laid off at least 6,000 workers in 1994.

"Weak demand on both the home and export markets and cashflow difficulties continued to be the major bottlenecks affecting industry," the Bureau said.

However, the mining sector experienced a 37.1 per cent upsurge in output during the first month of 1995, when to the same period the previous year.

Production of asbestos and gold registered the largest increases in output at 61 per cent and 59 percent.

"Firms in mining indicated higher investment intentions this year when compared to last year while the manufacturing firms indicated the reverse," it said.

The foodstuffs group, which falls under the manufacturing sector, experienced the largest increase in the volume of of 19 per cent.

PANA ZIANA ET/STC/OSS 29Aug95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

Africa News


August, 1995


Africa Stock Market Report


LENGTH: 667 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The Zimbabwen government has stopped selling its shares in blue-chip Delta Corporation to foreign investors, market analysts said Tuesday.

A broker said a feature of last week's trading on the Zimbabwe Stock Exchange was the refusal by government to any more Delta shares to foreigners.

Current legislation allows foreign investors to own up to 25 percent of the companies whose shares are traded on the exchange. 

"Its most likely that the government has lined up a local buyer or a housing facility for the shares," the broker said.

He said however that the shares could be sold to the IFC, an arm of the World Bank. "There are a number of rumours around the market with the International Finance Corporation's name popping up."

The government, as part of its privatisation programme, has so far sold shares worth more than Zimdollars 800 million (USD 94.1 million) out of the 64 million shares it owned in Delta, and its shareholding in the conglomerate was about 11 percent, or 28 million shares.

Foreign investors had bought most of the stock while local purchases were constrained by a lack of liquidity.

Meanwhile, trading on the local equity market was brisk last week amid softening of short term money market interest rates from 25.7 percent to 25.25 percent.

But in Kenya, trading on the the Nairobi stock market hit a record low for 1995 Monday. A total of 76 000 shares changed hands during Monday's session while 106 000 shares were traded Frdiay.

Analysts said investors had turned to government treasury bills.

Meanwhile, trading on the Ghana stock market ended Monday in Accra on an improved volume, pushed by bulk buying of Ghana Limited (unil) shares.

The Ghana stock Exchange all-share index shot up by 0.19 points to close at 314.02. The market's total capitalisation went up ending at 2,398.00 billion cedis, up from the previous 2,388.81 billion cedis (1209.5 cedis = one US dollar).

The 861,100 shares of Unilever and 31,600 shares of CFAO Ghana Limited, which were traded, helped to push the volume to end at 401,740 shares.

Dealers say although the market opened quietly, it is likely to pick up during the week. They said investors to look for Ghana Pioneer Aluminium Factory Limited (GPAF) which started trading Friday.

"The excitement has not waned but trading usually opens very quietly," one dealer said.

On the broader market, Unilever was the only market mover as it went up by three cedis to close at 840. The remaining equities maintained their price levels.

Total shares offered ended at 890,040 against a bid of 642,700 shares.

PANA-Ziana-KNA-GNA ET/STC/JS/KT/DS 29Aug95

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

278 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Zimbabwean Bank Rejects Drought Scheme


LENGTH: 774 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe (RBZ) has rejected as unjustified a proposal by banks to offer a special financing facility for drought-hit commercial farmers.

Reacting to the proposal, the Central Bank said it will not support a scheme that is both highly inflationary and designed to favour a select few.

The Commercial Farmers Union (CFU), which has been pushing for special interest rates for farmers whose debt zimdollars 3 billion (253 million U.S dollars), expressed at the decision. 

The bank said it was "committed to discouraging support of any action which might have an adverse impact on money and, hence, inflation."

The bank said farmers and banks would have to sit down find other solutions to ease their viability crisis.

The special financing facility was proposed by the Bankers Association of Zimbabwe which had asked the RBZ that banks be allowed to use statutory reserve funds to reschedule the debt of farmers, as well as finance production costs in the 1995/96 season, now less than three months away.

The same funds, the banks suggested, could also finance projects in the small and medium-scale sector.

The farmers had asked for rescheduling, at favourable interest rates, of the equivalent of 94 million U.S dollars of an accumulated debt of 353 million U.S dollars.

In addition, the farmers said they would require another three billion Zimbabwe dollars to finance production this season.

In its response to the Bankers Association of Zimbabwe President, Sij Biyam, the RBZ said it found it "difficult"' justify assistance to a particular sector of the economy at expense of others who were equally affected by the drought and punitive interest rates.

The CFU President, Peter Macsporran, responding to the decision by the RBZ, expressed "deep regret", and told the Zimbabwe Inter-African News Agency (ZIANA) the union was now asking for an urgent meeting with all concerned to discuss the issue.

The RBZ said there was need to formulate and implement long-term, measures to deal with the drought, and suggested farmers should establish a drought insurance scheme.

The Central Bank said among the proposals by the bankers, there was no mention of "any significant" contribution by banks towards assisting the farmers, "especially in light of banks' current favourable profitable positions."

"We suggest that the banks should give consideration to rescheduling the loans and also examine recapitalisation as measures aimed at finding long-term solutions."

The RBZ said banks could also finance farmers from proceeds of selling agricultural bonds, which could have a of up to three years and were issued at favourable interest rates.

In a separate interview, president of the bankers association, Sij Biyam, confirmed their proposals had been rejected by the RBZ and as of now, each individual farmer be treated on his on merit.

Biyam said farmers had to realise government was against subsidies under its market reform programme, and that the productive sector would have to use their own resources to business.

PANA-ZIANA STC/PBM 29AUG95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

Africa News


August, 1995


Zambia To Expand Repatriation of Angolan Refugees


LENGTH: 440 words


 

by Mildred Mulenga PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambian says it will include people in villages along its border with Angola in the repatriation of refugees to that country. Zambia's commissioner for refugees in the Home Affairs Ministry, Lameck Waba, said Wednesday in Lusaka that these refugees would be sent home after 26,000 others at the Meheba and Mayukwayukwa refugee camps in northwestern and western Zambia.

The commissioner said that the Angolans were living in border settlements from Mwinilunga to Sinjombela. He did not say how many were there. 

The United Nations High Commissioner For Refugees says it needs 42.4 billion Zambian Kwacha (about 920 Kwacha = 1 U.S. dollar) to repatriate the estimated 100,000 refugees in Zambia.

Mwaba said the initial target for repatriation was for 26,000 but government realised there were more people along border settlements, some cutting across the frontiers. Angola signed a peace agreement with the former rebel movement Unita November 1994 ending almost two decades of civil war and paving the way for refugees to return home. However, Zambian newspapers reported Thursday that eight Zambians had been abducted in the north-western disrict of Mwinilunga by guerrillas thought to be fro Unita. The area lies along the Zambia and Angolan border. Citing Zambia's police acting spokesman, Bbonny Kapeso, Wednesday, it said that six of the abducted villagers were women who were fishing Monday in a river near the Angolan border. Two men who tried to trace them were also reported missing, police said. "We believe the eight were abducted by Unita forces," Kapeso said. "From the police point of view we are taking the necessary steps to establish contact with Angolan authorities." PANA MM/MK/OSS 31Aug95

Africa News


August, 1995


South African Govt To Pensions to Freedom Fighters


LENGTH: 267 words


 

by Lionel Williams PANA Correspondent

CAPE TOWN, South Africa (PANA) - South Africa's plan to pay pensions to some 20,000 freedom fighters who fought for to end aparthied may cost 300 million U.S. dollars, an official said Thursday.

Addressing the media in Cape Town, the seat of parliament, Deputy Finance Minister Alec Erwin said that those who served at least five years in the various liberation movements and are over 60 years old qualify for a pension. It became effective April 1.

The highest pensions will be about 2,300 U.S. dollars per month. The majority of the recipients will get between 300 and 600 dollars monthly.

The bill for the pensions is due to be introduced in parliament next week and should be passed in the current parliamentary session.

PANA LW/FT/OSS 31Aug95

Africa News


August, 1995


Iranian Oil storage deal delayed


LENGTH: 347 words


 

by Lionel Williams PANA Correspondent

CAPE TOWN, South Africa (PANA) - An oil storage and marketing agreement between South Africa and Iran is being delayed for a month until environmental impact studies are complete, officials said Thursday.

The South African ministers for the environment and for energy, Dawie De Villiers and Roelof Botha, said in Cape Town that government would reconsider the agreement at its next meeting September 27. 

They said that the National Iranian Oil Company was fully aware that the agreement was subject to environmental studies. Under the terms of the deal, South Africa would store large quantities of Iranian oil at its Saldanha Bay facility.

South African environmental organisations have expressed concern that increased tankers traffic would result in oil pollution in the ecologically sensitive Saldanha nature conservation area.

Meanwhile, the General Manager of South Africa's Strategic Fuel Fund, Kobus Van Zyl, is in Teheran to sign the agreement. But A spokesman for the minister of mineral and energy affairs said that the accord would still be subject to the results of the study.

PANA LW/FT/OSS 31Aug95

Africa News


August, 1995


TUNISIAN FILM TO BE SCREENED IN VARIOUS AMERICAN CITIES


LENGTH: 640 words


 

"HALFAOUINE" (BOY OF THE TERRACES) will have its US premiere at the NuArt Theatre in Los Angeles, September 8-14 (followed by runs in San Francisco, Seattle, Detroit, Philadelphia, St. Louis and other cities nationwide). (Please check schedule at the end)

The film is distributed by the New York-based "International Film Circuit Inc." which specializes in booking of highly acclaimed foreign films and screening them throughout the country. "Halfaouine" is their first Tunisian film, and they need your support to spread the word to achieve major success for its US premiere. 

According to their press release, "Halfaouine" breaks new ground in Arab cinema with its flank depiction of sexuality. It tells the story of a 13-year old boy who goes to the women's Turkish baths with his mother in Halfaouine, a working-class neighborhood in Tunis. His dawning puberty stirs up the restlessness of being torn between the man's world which beckons him, and the woman's world which still protects him.

The film was written and directed by Ferid Boughedir, one of the most well-known film critics in the Arab world, and features actors from Tunisia's acclaimed New Theater. It is a French-Tunisian co-production. Speaking from Paris where he is editing his new feature film, "A Summer in La Goulette", Boughedir noted that "the film was an enormous commercial success in Tunisia, and although it was shown in neighboring Maghreb nations, Algeria and Morocco, it was banned in all the other Middle Eastern countries, including Lebanon and Jordan. It was even invited to the Damascus Film Festival in Syria, but the authorities would not allow it to be shown." He continues: "There was nearly a riot at the Cairo Film Festival when "Halfaouine" was shown there, and although they had planned to show the film just one time, they were obliged to show it six times. It was subsequently forbidden for it to be shown in Egyptian movie theatres." (International Film Circuit press release)

Bookings to Date:

NuArt Theatre, Los Angeles, CA - starting September 8.

Roxie Theatre, San Francisco, CA.-starting September 29.

UC Theatre, Berkeley, CA. -October 13

Varsity Theatre, Seattle, WA - October 27

Detroit Institute of Art, Detroit, MI -one day only- November 6

Tivoli Theatre, St. Louis, MO - November 17

Ritz Theatre, Philadelphia, PA - Early December (Date yet to be determined)

Biograph Theatre, Washington, DC - December (ditto)

FOR FURTHER INFORMATION, or to check if other theatres in other cities will be screening this film, please contact: Wendy Lidell (International Film Circuit Inc)

Phone: (212) 779-0660 Fax: (212) 779-9129

You can also call the Tunisian Information Office in Washington, DC. Phone: (202) 466-2546. To be added to our E-mail mailing list drop us a note at:

tuninfo@gwuvm.gwu.edu

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).

LANGUAGE: English

283 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


CPJ Protest: Kenya


LENGTH: 1534 words


 

SENT BY FAX

August 24, 1995

President Daniel arap Moi

Office of the President

Harambee House

Nairobi

Kenya

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) strongly protests the acts of unauthorized censorship by Your Excellency's government on the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) World Television. We also support the BBC's ultimatum that, should unapproved interference continue, it will terminate its television operations in Kenya. CPJ also condemns the recent beating of six journalists by security forces.

The BBC contracted with the Kenya Broadcasting Corporation (KBC) to re-broadcast its world television news on KBC stations. The contract between the BBC and the KBC stipulates that the government may not interfere in its news broadcasts. Reports indicate that the KBC, on several occasions, has tampered, without authorization, with news items about Kenya that the Minister of Information claims discredit the government. 

The most recent censored BBC report was its story on the beating of Richard Leakey, a founder of the yet-to-be registered SAFINA political party, and six journalists, including a BBC stringer. On August 18, the BBC issued a statement objecting to the KBC's interference with the broadcast, and threatened to end the television contract. While Your Excellency's administration has yet to respond officially to this statement, Information Minister Johnstone Makau stated earlier this month that the contract would not be renewed unless the tone of BBC reports about Kenya changed. The BBC has been esteemed globally as an exemplary news organization with respect to its objectivity in news reporting and for its far-reaching news coverage. The BBC also remains valuable to Kenya's population as a source of international information and education. A discontinuation of its services would truncate the people's access to this information, to which they have a right.

CPJ also condemns the attack against local and foreign press on Thursday, August 10, which was the subject of the aforementioned censored BBC report. Plainclothes police, youth-wingers from Your Excellency's ruling Kenyan African National Union (KANU) party, and riot police beat six journalists and two other travelers. The journalists were attacked while covering a visit by Richard Leakey, Secretary General of the soon-to-be SAFINA party, to the Nakuru magistrate's court where detained human rights activist Koigi wa Wamwere was due to appear. Leakey was accompanied by human rights lawyer Paul Muite. While Leakey and Muite were assembling in the car park of the court, a mob, which was comprised of individuals whom the journalists recognized as KANU officials and Nakuru police in plain clothes, began to form. The mob launched their attack on Leakey and the SAFINA treasurer with eggs, whips, pick-ax handles, and stones, until they managed to escape the barrage. Both sustained severe injuries as it was difficult for Leakey, who has two artificial legs, to manoeuvre. No on-duty police came to their aid. Shortly thereafter, as the journalists and Muite and his party proceeded to the court, prison guards built a road block, prohibiting their entrance. In the meantime, witnesses report that the mob from below, plus men from two "Government of Kenya" (GK) vehicles with their plate numbers blacked out, also began to create a road block. Realizing the prison guards were not going to offer any protection, Muite and his group fled, breaking through the road block at the bottom of the road. At this point, riot police joined the prison guards, assaulting the journalists with truncheons from the back, and the KANU youth-wingers with whips and rocks from the front. Again, no police arrived to bring order.

After the melee, the journalists, notably the foreign correspondents, were threatened with death if they reported this incident. Two journalists and one traveler, who suffered fractured and broken bones, were hospitalized, while all sustained severe injuries.

As a nonpartisan group of journalists dedicated to the defense of press freedom and the protection of our colleagues worldwide, CPJ condemns the brutal assault. We feel that the involvement of official forces in this attack signals the Kenyan government's thorough disregard for the impartial role of journalists as observers. CPJ also regards this incident as one among many we have documented this year that constitute a disturbing trend of intimidation against the local and foreign press in Your Excellency's country. We urge Your Excellency to order a thorough investigation of this incident and see to it that those responsible are brought to justice. In the matter of the BBC, the Committee respectfully reminds Your Excellency that censorship is a violation of the right of free expression, which is guaranteed by Article 19 of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights, Article 19 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and Article 9 of the African Charter on Human and Peoples' Rights, all to which Kenya is a signatory. We hope that Your Excellency will ask the KBC to abide by the terms of its contract with the BBC and cease censoring its reports so as not to deprive Your Excellency's people of their right to information.

Thank you for your attention. We welcome your comments.

Sincerely,

William A. Orme, Jr.

Executive Director

cc: Attorney General Amos Wako

Minister of Information Johnstone Makau

Ambassador Benjamin Kipkorir

The Hon. Ambassador Aurelia Brazeal

Kenya Union of Journalists

Network for the Defense of Independent Media in Africa

TransAfrica

Newspaper Association of America

American Society of Newspaper Editors

Amnesty International

Article 19 (United Kingdom)

Artikel 19 (The Netherlands)

Canadian Committee to Protect Journalists

Congressional Committee to Support Writers and Journalists

Freedom House

Human Rights Watch

Index on Censorship

International Association of Broadcasting

International Federation of Journalists

International Journalism Institute

International PEN

International Press Institute

National Press Club

The Newspaper Guild

North American Broadcasters Association

Reporters Sans Frontieres

Overseas Press Club

The Society of Professional Journalists

World Press Freedom Committee

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).


LOAD-DATE: September 1, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


284 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Document: Request to Drop Charges Against Sierra Leonian Journalists


LENGTH: 1160 words


 

SENT BY FAX

August 1, 1995

His Excellency Captain E. M. Strasser

Chairperson, National Provisional Ruling Council

State House

Tower Hill, Freetown

Sierra Leone

Your Excellency:

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) is writing to urge Your Excellency to drop charges against The New Breed journalists. Judgment in their case, which has been before the Sierra Leonian courts for over 21 months, is due August 7. We are enormously concerned that if convicted, the defendants, including notable

journalists among them such as Dr. Julius Spencer, may be imprisoned for seven to ten years.

On October 13, 1993, The New Breed, a weekly newspaper based in Freetown, published an editorial titled "Redeemers or Villains" that asked Your Excellency's government to respond to an article in the Swedish newspaper Expressen that had accused Sierra Leonian government officials of corruption. The editorial simply cited the Swedish 

article, in an attempt to seek clarity on the issues. That same day, a group of New Breed publishers and journalists were arrested. They spent the next two weeks in jail, before being released on bail of 40 million Leones -- the stiffest bail conditions ever imposed on journalists in Sierra Leone, indeed almost in the history of the judiciary. The group were charged with a ten-count criminal indictment of sedition, defamatory libel, and publishing a false report.

The four accused -- Dr. Julius Spencer, managing editor of the newspaper, and a senior academic at Fourah Bay College; Donald John, acting editor; Alfred Conteh, sales manager and Alusine K. Basiru, general manager of the company that printed the paper, have appeared before the High Court, and the Supreme Court on several occasions. On December 12, 1994, the defendants' bail was revoked, and they were

returned to prison for 35 days. They were released on January 16 this year. Since then they have made several more court appearances, the last of which was on July 14.

CPJ would consider it a terrible miscarriage of justice if these journalists were convicted and sentenced to lengthy prison terms. We believe that the only hope is for the criminal charges against them to be dropped. We respectfully urge Your Excellency to do so.

As a nonpartisan organization of journalists committed to the defense of our colleagues' rights worldwide, CPJ urges Your Excellency to uphold in practice the right of journalists to hold and express opinions and ideas, as guaranteed by Article 19 of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights, by Article 19 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and by Article 9

of the African Charter on Human and Peoples' Rights, the last to which, we respectfully remind Your Excellency, Sierra Leone is a signatory.

Thank you for your attention. We welcome your comments.

Sincerely, William A. Orme, Jr., executive Director

cc:

Brigadier Julius Maada Bio, Deputy Chairman and Chief of Defense,

NPRC

Secretary Arnold Bishop-Gooding, Secretary of State for Information,

Broadcasting, and Culture

Secretary Claude Campbell, Attorney-General and Secretary of State

for Judicial Affairs

His Excellency Ambassador Thomas K. Kargbo

The Honorable Ambassador Lauralee Peters

The National League for Human Rights and Democracy

The Sierra Leone Association of Journalists

TransAfrica

American Newspaper Publishers Association
