Africa News


August, 1995


Democracy and Ethnicity


LENGTH: 1774 words


 

Zambia Post

August 18, 1995

The transformation of the African political scene in the last few years has been remarkable. In the 1980s, authoritarian, single-party or military regimes were the rule, not only statistically but also ideologically. There was widespread consensus that western-style democracy was not suitable for Africa.

Now virtually all regimes feel compelled to accept at least in theory the necessity of a democratic transition, although implementation often lags. Conceptually, democracy has become the norm, and most African countries have experienced at least a partial political opening.

Such transitions, however, have brought with them unexpected challenges, including ethnic conflict. The sharpening of ethnic divisions has been a regular outcome of democratic openings in Africa. 

This phenomenon challenges the notion that democratisation simply entails a transformation of the political regimes of existing states, to be achieved by amending the country's constitution, holding elections under international supervision, and carrying out complementary activities such as organising human rights monitoring groups, strengthening political parties and educating voters about their rights and duties. Rather, outbreaks of ethnic conflict threaten not only incumbent regimes but also existing states.

This is not a new unique phenomenon. Democratisation re-arranged the map of Europe in the 19th century; it has changed drastically that of eastern Europe, the Balkans and central Asia in the last few years. Changes in Africa have so far been less dramatic, with Eritrea and de facto northern Somaliland the only new states so far. But all countries in the Horn remain on the verge of disintegration, and the future of Zaire and Nigeria is in doubt. We can no longer assume that the political transformation of Africa will simply entail a change of regimes. The real danger is not the possibility of the break up of some African countries into new states - this would not necessarily be a problem - but the collapse of an increasing number of states into utter chaos and mass slaughter. The specter haunting Africa is not the possibility of new Eritreas but the likelihood of new Rwandas.

The relationship between democratic openings and greater ethnic conflict is a complex one, ultimately requiring separate explanations for each country. Several factors are common to all countries, however. First the present African state system has been crafted by authoritarian regimes that did not feel the need to consult their populations. The most important principle of the Organisation of African Unity, that of the inviolability of colonial borders, denoted such authoritarianism, although this has often been overlooked.

It implied not only a renunciation by governments waging war on each other in the pursuit of territory but also a statement by the same governments to their people that they had no right to self-determination. It meant not only that Somalia should stop going to war to conquer the Ogaden, but the Ogadenis would remain Ethiopian subjects whether or not they so desired.

As the heavy hand of the authoritarian state starts to release its grip, the issue of self-determination is bound to be reopened in many countries.

A second reason why democratising African states are experiencing renewed ethnic conflict is the failure of nation building since independence. While talking of nation building, African leaders devoted themselves mainly to building the state and, above all, their personal power. Most states became patrimonial, predatory and corrupt but also remained soft and eventually faced bankruptcy. Such states do not stimulate the allegiance of their populations and thus help consolidate a nation.

Third, 30 years after independence African populations remained to a large extent rural, thus they maintained local rather than national identities. This should not be a matter of surprise. Studies have shown that such local identities still prevailed in the so-called nation-states of Europe in the late 19th century and were slowly weakened, but never completely erased, by industrialisation, universal education, and geographic and social mobility. Most of these changes have come but slowly to Africa. As a result, democratisation gives a more important role to communities that are local in their outlook, allowing ambitious politicians to play on regional, ethnic and religious identities to gain support. Such manipulation can then turn what was in origin simply harmless identification with a local community into destructive conflict.

African governments have been unwilling to consider seriously the special problems of democracy in multiethnic societies. African leaders are prone to condemn ethnic divisions while manipulating them for their own purposes, but are reluctant to discuss ethnic diversity as a challenge, which entails legitimate demands and special requirements that need to be accommodated by a democratic state.

Nigeria and South Africa have shown more realism than other countries in dealing with ethnicity in politics. Yet years of constitutional and political engineering since the Biafran civil war have been undermined by the two great constraints of Nigerian politics: the concentration of oil revenue in the hands of the federal government, which precludes genuine decentralisation and empowerment of state and local governments; and the constant intervention of the army in politics, which precludes democratisation. In the end Nigeria remains very far from both democracy and ethnic reconciliation.

More encouraging, although highly ambiguous, is the case of South Africa, where the African National Congress, in theory committed to a race and ethnicity blind democracy, compromised sufficiently in practice to give the most vocal of ethnic groups, whites and Zulus, special representation in the political system. But the transition in South Africa is too recent, and the compromise too dependent on the good will of a few individuals, to provide clear lessons for other countries.

In addition of these two countries, where genuine efforts have been made to structure a political system making democracy possible despite ethnic divisions, Ethiopia also is developing a political system that takes the ethnic makeup of the population into consideration. However, the example of Ethiopia so far is one of ethnicisation of the political process but not of democratisation.

The new, ethnicity-based political system has been dictated from the centre. As a result, it has incurred the opposition of most political groups, including the ethnic nationalist movements.

The increase in the level of ethnic conflict everywhere, and particularly the crisis in Rwanda, have frightened governments and opposition parties in many countries. But fear is not enough. African countries need an arena where the issue of ethnicity in the transition to democracy can be discussed with some detachment from the problems of individual countries, and where some ground rules can be established on how ethnic problems can be tackled without sacrificing democracy. Such a forum may emerge if the proposed Conference on Peace, Security, Stability, Development and Co-operation in Africa (CPSSDCA) comes into existence.

The (CPSSDCA) is the brainchild of Gen. Olusegun Obasaanjo's African Leadership Forum. Modeled along the lines of the Conference for Security and Cooperation in Europe (CSCE), the CPSSDCA is supposed to go beyond the Organisation for African Unity (OAU), which is concerned mainly with relations among states, dealings with its citizen. After an initial meeting in Kampala in May 1991, however, the initiative has bogged down in the politics of the OAU. The underlying problem is the reluctance of many African leaders to set up an organization that would make relations between government and citizen a matter of international concern and commitment, rather than purely the internal affair of each country.

The revitalisation of the CPSSDCA initiative could make a major difference in ensuring that the democratisation process continues in Africa and in encouraging a more realistic approach to the problem of ethnicity. The problems of Africa and those of Europe are not identical, and African solutions will be different from European ones.

The CSCE shows the importance of an international discussion of these problems. It has been active in devising ground rules for ethnically heterogeneous countries. It has drafted charters on the rights of ethnic minorities, on autonomy in local government and on language and education. Such charters put both governments and mobilised ethnic groups on notice about their duties.

To reach the Zambia Post point a browser to: http://www.mg.co.za/mg/

Africa News


August, 1995


Editorial: Museveni Campaign On Wrong Footing


LENGTH: 654 words


 

The Monitor

August 14-16, 1995

President Yoweri Museveni is out campaigning to keep his job.

The president is campaigning at a time when what appears an unrelated event is taking place in parliament.

The National Ruling Council's (NRC) Public Accounts Committee (PAC) is embroiled in what is perhaps the most spirited fight again the graft-riddened Ministry of Agriculture, Animal Industry and Fisheries. PAC has done everything including a raid on the minstry's Entebbe headquarters as officials doggedly continue to frustrate their probe. 

This PAC effort is double-edged. While on the negative side it brings home sharply to the public the extent of corruption under the NRM government; on the positice side it shows that institutions to fight corruption have been set up, and that some of them, like PAC, have tried to discharge their duty.

Thus on the campaign trail, one would have expected the president to exploit such issues to articulate future tasks for government, and to drum up the positives of his rule.

Instead the president, apart from repeating his old theme of urging people to fight poverty, is falling into the trap politicians fell into during the Constituent Assembly campaigns.

He's chosen to play bread and butter politics; giving cows; dishing out bicycles and iron sheets; promising jobs to favourite children in areas he is campaigning in;and even pronouncing on plans to fight baboons.

It is still morning in the campaigns. If the elections now take place next year, by the time the president finishes his tour of the country, he will have promised iron sheets, bicycles, cows and grinding mills in the millions.

A presidential campaign is different from a local constituency fight. If the president promises a sub-county bicycles, and the local politician does the same, where is the difference in the call of their offices?

The president is running a big risk. Apart from diminishing his status, he can't deliver all that he is promising. There are only a certain number of jobs. In many places in the north, and places like Luwero etc., there are grinding mills and cattle which the president promised years ago and yet haven't been delivered.

The NRC Committee on Presidential Affairs recently urged restraint; because there are already billions of shillings worth of promises which President's Office hasn't honoured.

The president needs to focus his campaign on broad national issues, and a vision of the future. What is the plan to solve the education or health crisis for example? What economic and legal reforms does he plan to press if re-elected? Right now, Museveni is looking too much like a constituency politician. He needs urgently to rediscover his presidential voice.

The Monitor is published at P.O. Box 12141, Kampala, Uganda. Tel: 236939 Fax: 251352

Lira To Host Boxing


LENGTH: 254 words


 

The Monitor

August 14-16, 1995

by Martin Ekanyu

Lira is to host the Uganda National BOxing Championships, August 26 to September 3.

A two-man delegation from the Uganda Amateur Boxing Association (UABA) visited Lira recently to confirm the event. The delegation inspected the Uganda Technical Institute, Lira, where boxers will be based.

During their visit, UABA officials also donated to Lira Sports Club gloves, sets of head gear and other equiipment.

According to Lira's Ag. Sports Officer, Mike Alele, the team also visited Akii Bua Stadium, where Lira boxers were training.

Africa News


August, 1995


Museveni Reveals Why He Chose A Woman As VP


LENGTH: 387 words


 

The Monitor

August 14-16, 1995

by Mugabe Yunus

President Yoweri Museveni has said that he appointed Dr. Specioza Kazibwe to the post of Vice President because he feared an uprising by women.

The president, who was addressing members of the DRC, elders, opinion leaders and heads of NGOs in Hoima town on August 11, said women are a force to reckon with, "so he thought by leaving them out of big political posts they would one day rise up and overthrow the men." He said that in Kazibwe, he saw an able woman leader.

Kazibwe was appointed VP last November, a post she holds together with her other portfolio as Minister for Gender and Community Development. Kazibwe became the first woman vice president in Uganda and only the second in Africa.

The President said that what is needed now is for people to engage in economic activities which will guarantee them good returns. He expressed concern over the escalating poverty in rural areas. He said his main mission is now to fight uneven development in Uganda. The president said it was now upon the people to fight poverty as the government had completed its task ("Orubimbi") of providing peace, water and power.

Earlier the president donated 20 heifers to women's groups in Hoima and also gave them 200 iron sheets to construct a vocational centre. Bicycles will be donated to every sub-county youth council in Uganda.

The Monitor is published at P.O. Box 12141, Kampala, Uganda. Tel: 236939 Fax: 251352

August, 1995


African-American Dancers To Sell Gambia Abroad


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Daily Observer

August 2, 1995

by S. B. Danso

African-American dancers who are on a short visit to The Gambia, have promised to promote The Gambia on their return.

According to Chuck Davis, Founding Director of the group, Gambian people are open and made their culture available to them during their visit. He added that they chose The Gambia for their programme because the people are willing to share their knowledge with others.

Mr. Davis said he has been traveling to The Gambia since the 1970s and the knowledge he gained here is transferred to the people of America through the universities of North Carolina and Duke.

Pa Modou Joof, a Gambian counterpart, said the group, numbering 14, learned different dance styles and cultures form the Mandinka, Wollof, Jola and Susu. Mr. Joof revealed that the group also pays for their activities which help some Gambians with income.

Luther Cox, Jr., one of the members said while in The Gambia he feels like at home and that is why he like The Gambia than other countries.

Another member, Morris Johnson, Jr., said that Gambian culture is rich and that the people are proud of it.

Leah Gaiser, a nurse, donated some medicine to Gunjur and she hopes to continue working for the future development of Gunjur Health Centre.

The visiting members came from Philadelphia, Colorado, Minnesota, New Jersey and North Carolina. They include professional dancers, teachers, a nurse and others.

The Daily Observer is published at P.M.B. 131, Banjul, The Gambia. Tel. (220) 490608. Fax: (220) 496878

LOAD-DATE: September 1, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


305 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


What Abiola Told Me


LENGTH: 1080 words


 

Newswatch

August 21, 1995

Randall Echols, Moshood Abiola's chief lobbyist in the US, was in Nigeria for meetings with General Sani Abacha and Abiola. He discussed his visit to Nigeria at an interview in Washington, DC with Soji Akinrinade, deputy editor-in-chief of Newswatch. Excerpts follow.

Newswatch: What is your impression of the situation in Nigeria after your visit and meetings with government officials? 

Echols: My impression is that there is widespread disaffection throughout the country. However, in Abuja, where the population density is not bad and other amenities exist, one may not readily notice the disaffection. But after engaging in discussions with individuals within the government and out, I will say that there is some uncertainty as to the direction of the country.

Newswatch: From your own discussions, did you get any sign from government officials that they know how Nigerians feel about the present situation?

Echols: I didn't get that impression, I got the impression that government was ready to position itself in power, and was prepared to do whatever was necessary to see that they got situated in power. There is a lot of effort to appear organised and presidential rather than to deal with the most threatening issues such as the political crisis and the staggering economy. However, with Abiola and others still detained, it is virtually impossible to effectively address the problem of the economy, the political and social crises that exist in Nigeria.

Newswatch: When you met with the head of state, what did you tell him? Did you advise him on how to move or not to move Nigeria forward?

Echols: I did not consider myself in the position to advise General Abacha on anything. What I did was to ask General Abacha what should I do here in Washington that will expedite the release of President Abiola. What should I do for him in Washington with the people that I come in contact with on a daily basis -- policy makers, congressmen, senators, etc. -- that will help expedite the release of Abiola? So, "General what can I do for you?" was the approach that I took with General Abacha.

Newswatch: Did you get any response on what you should do?

Echols: Well, General Abacha indicated that he was willing to dialogue and I told him that he can get to me and we had scheduled a follow-up meeting, but I got no specific request as to what one could do that would make the situation more tolerable, that will lend itself to the release of Abiola, the sole focus of the mission. My priority was going over to see Chief Abiola, assess his health condition and appeal to government for his release.

Newswatch: Were you able to see Chief Abiola? What situation did you find him, his state of mind and what kind of things did you observe about him?

Echols: Well, what I observed is that the chief is being held in complete isolation. Unfortunately there is cruelty associated with his incarceration. He only has access to the Koran and the Bible. He doesn't have the time, he doesn't have magazines, he doesn't get his medication on a timely basis, he clearly has lost 50-60 lbs. He is walking with a noticeable limp. He is obviously in need of medical attention. This I shared with the government officials after the visit with Abiola. I met with Abacha on a Thursday night. We met with Abiola the next day at 3 o'clock. Later that night I reported back to Aso Rock my observations. And I shared with them what I am sharing now about my observations that there is something they can do to not have the cruelty associated with his incarceration. And they said they were unaware of these conditions and they promised they will look into them.

Newswatch: Now, when you spoke to government about releasing Abiola, what was their response to that?

Echols: What I shared with General Abacha, is that I thought the sanctions and pressure -- economic and diplomatic sanctions -- coming from the United States will only increase as long as Abiola remains incarcerated, as long as the press remains shut down, as long as the other political dissenters remain in jail; that I thought the pressure on Nigeria from outside including the United States would only increase. And that it was my impression that if he will release Abiola, that it will have a pre-emptive effect on the sanctions that are about to come on in Nigeria, and there are more coming, including a number of things that I can't discuss now. But that if he released him, if he shows some willingness to break the stalemate and show the world , as he says, he is interested in dialogue, and to what Abiola said that he was interested in dialogue as well, to reach a peaceful resolution of this political stalemate as a result of June 12 annulment, if he could do that, I thought, and that was what I told him, it will have a pre-emptive effect, nothing guaranteed though. Many of these sanctions I personally initiated. A, along with others, initiated, provided our views to the United States government and other governments as to what could possibly get General Abacha's attention. Now, if he releases Abiola, clearly I will go to some degree to say we see some movement. General Abacha is serious about a peaceful resolution of this problem, and he is not acting dogmatically.

Newswatch is published at P.M.B. 21499 Ikeja, Nigeria. Tel: 4960950. Fax:962887. Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

LANGUAGE: English

306 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Campaign Against Abacha


LENGTH: 1787 words


 

Newswatch

August 14, 1995

by Soji Akinrinade

For months Zubair Mahmud Kazaure, Nigeria's ambassador to the United States of America, was looking for an ace in the hole. He had been fighting an uphill battle to revamp the battered image of Nigeria in the US. He needed more concrete action from the Nigerian government to convince a skeptical American government and people that the Abacha administration is sincere in its efforts to return Nigeria to a genuine democracy.

Kazaure got his wish on June 27 when in faraway Abuja, Nigeria's federal capital, the draft constitution and other reports of the Constitutional Conference were submitted to General Sani Abacha. The head of state not only collected the reports, he lifted ban on politics and promised that his transition programme would be released by October. 

Asked how the development will help his battle for the ears and minds of the Americans, Kazaure told 'Newswatch': "Tremendously." He said the administration had proved once again that democracy would son return to Nigeria and that all that was needed was for everyone, including those in the opposition, to work together with the Nigerian government to ensure peace, unity and stability in the country.

The ambassador had a right to express his optimism. That week, which started Sunday, June 25, was not a particularly good one for the image of Nigeria in the US. Throughout the week one action or the other took place which further damaged Nigeria's standing among the world's democrats and gave the picture of a nation spinning out of control.

The week started with a re-run of the Columbia Broadcasting System, CBS, '60 Minutes' Programme on Nigeria. Mike Wallace, the programme's correspondent who visited Nigeria prefaced the re-run by going through the protests from the Nigerian government and the Nigerian embassy in Washington, DC. He ended up saying Nigeria was still the most corrupt nation he had ever reported from.

The programme showed how foreigners are conned into 419 deals and how corrupt Nigerian officials are. Kazaure told 'Newswatch' that the programme was calculated to embarrass Nigeria because of its political problems and that the decision to re-run it must have been taken after a team of Nigerian investigators showed up in New York to ask CBS to give the team access to some of the information they used in putting the documentary together.

The CBS programme was only the tip of the iceberg that week. On Tuesday June 276, just as Abacha was receiving the draft constitution, Randall Robinson, executive director, Trans-Africa Forum, who is campaigning for the return of democracy in Nigeria, was on a Worldnet programme fielding questions from Nigerian journalists and others assembled in Lagos and Kaduna by the United States Information Services, USIS, on Nigeria's political problem. The programme was the talk of the diplomatic circle in Washington and showed that Robinson was a formidable foe of the Nigerian government.

That same day Robinson, his supporters and other Nigerians demonstrated in front of the Nigerian embassy on 16th Street, just a stone's throw from Trans-Africa's office. The protest is on everyday. And although dismissed by Kazaure as consisting of Robinson's staff, it puts the Nigerian political problem on the front burner. Robinson himself on Wednesday briefed some members of the Clinton administration's National Security Council on the events in Nigeria.

By Thursday, June 29, action shifted to the offices of Shell and Chevron in Washington, DC. The International Roundtable on Nigeria, a coalition of human rights and pro-democracy groups in the DC area, sponsored a demonstration against the two oil companies drawing attention to the plight of the Ogoni people and asking Shell and Chevron to fight for an oil embargo against Nigeria. "No Blood for Oil" read some of the placards carried by protesters.

Events that week are not isolated. In fact, they happen with incredible frequency; if not in Washington, DC then in other cities were pro-democracy and human rights groups have affiliates throughout the United States. For example, in Boston, Massachusetts, the local branch of the Nigerian Democratic Awareness Committee, NDAC, headed by Muhammed Ighile, June 17 presented Nigeria's political situation to the members of that state legislature. Prior to that, the group had organised a protest march against Ibrahim Gambari, Nigeria's permanent representative to the United Nations. It had also on May 20, in conjunction with Trans-Africa, put together a forum to bring the problems of Nigeria to the attention of the Boston community. In Detroit, Michigan, Kofi Egbo's Nigerian Forum for Democracy has been in the vanguard of those boycotting Shell's services and products in the area.

From Houston, Texas, through Detroit to New York, activities of the pro-democracy and human rights groups continue to pose serious challenges for the Abacha administration and its representatives in Washington, DC and the UN.

In essence, the events of the week of June 25 were indeed a testimony to the damage that had been caused Nigeria by the annulment of the June 12, 1993 presidential election, and by the fact that the most populous nation on earth, one so rich in human and material resources, is still under a military rule when the rest of the world is headed positively towards democracy. And to compound matters, the Nigerian government, in their own estimation, has precious little to show that it is moving fast towards democratisation.

The lifting of the ban on politics and the promise of a transition Programme next October should have helped to produce some positive results and lead to a better understanding of Nigeria by the Americans, if Kazaure had his way. But that apparently is not the case.

Said Robinson: "That is not good enough. It will not command any favourable response from the rest of the world. He should release all political prisoners and victims of the trial which is still going on secretly... . In a country where there are no democratic parties, the military retains the right to arrest without charges and trial and to detain people indefinitely. It is hardly possible that you can have a free and democratic activity in any case. So, that announcement is not satisfactory; it was just pushed out to satisfy critics of the military regime."

Edward Oparaoji, president of NDAC and a professor at Howard University, Washington, agrees. He too told 'Newswatch' that: "the actions taken so far do not mean anything because there are certain parameters, certain actions that government should take that can make us start believing that they are serious about moving us out of this logjam...which is principally the release of political detainees." According to him no one could take the government, seriously about lifting the ban on politics since it said, in the next breath, that rallies were still prohibited.

If the lifting of the ban on politics has not impressed pro-democracy groups in the US, the conviction of 40 persons, including Olusegun Obasanjo, former military head of state and his deputy, Shehu Yar'Adua has certainly compounded Nigeria's image problems. Apart from the human rights groups' claim that the trial and conviction of the accused persons are further evidence of the abuse of human rights in Nigeria, pro-democracy groups have now become more vocal in pressuring the American government to impose oil and trade embargo on Nigeria if those convicted are killed.

If the lifting of the ban on politics has not impressed pro-democracy groups in the US, the conviction of 40 persons, including Olusegun Obasanjo, former military head of state and his deputy, Shehu Yar'Adua has certainly compounded Nigeria's image problems. Apart from the human rights groups claim that the trial and conviction of the accused persons are further evidence of the abuse of human rights in Nigeria, pro-democracy groups have now become more vocal in pressuring the American government to impose oil and trade embargoes on Nigeria if those convicted are killed.

Kazaure has responded by campaigning across America that the trials were fair and conducted according to the laws promulgated, not by this administration but in 1976.

The centre of the agitation to democratize Nigeria is Washington, DC. But it started as a move to de-annul the June 12, 1993 election and install M.K.O. Abiola, the undeclared winner of the election as president. Randall Echols, a Washington-based lobbyist and Abiola's executive assistant for US affairs, had as early as June 1993 been in the forefront of efforts to get the Nigerian government to de-annul the June 12 election. Since then, however, many pro-democracy groups started mainly by Nigerians have taken over the fight not only for June 12 but for the democratisation of Nigeria.

Newswatch is published at P.M.B. 21499 Ikeja, Nigeria. Tel: 4960950. Fax:962887. Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


307 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


OPPOSITION ALLIANCE AGREES ON COMMON ACTION


LENGTH: 1347 words


 

by Santino Makur Kot

Until last June, exiled Sudanese opposition leaders and armed rebel movements met more or less clandestinely in neighbouring countries. But in a "bold move", the Eritrean government openly hosted in the capital, Asmara, a controversial conference of the National Democratic Alliance (NDA), a Sudanese umbrella movement of both northern and southern opposition groups to agree on a wide range of actions to bring down the regime of General Omar El Bashir, and to work out the basis of an interim administration thereafter.

Eritrea broke off diplomatic relations with the Sudan in January this year, following accusations that the Khartoum regime was intent on destabilising Africa's second newest nation after South Africa.

Then in June, Asmara played host to Sudan's National Democratic Alliance, an umbrella movement that brings together the Arab-Muslim northern opposition parties and the African southern-based politicians and the mainstream faction of the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Movement (SPLM). The NDA agreed in principal, upon a comprehensive agenda for the overthrow of what participants termed "the repressive regime," and the basis of the interim period thereafter. 

Those at the conference agreed on a five point plan. The most critical point to many observers is the resolve to end the conflict in the South, through a recognition of the principle of self-determination of the Christian and animist southerners.

Other points include the implementation of a decentralised administration during the interim period, the setting-up of a secretariat charged with co-ordinating and following up on the activities of NDA constituent groups, the overthrow of General Bashir's regime and the establishment of a secular state where religion plays no part.

The Asmara conference it is hoped will create a momentum within the broader Sudan opposition for the overthrow of the Khartoum regime of LT. Gen Omar El Bashir who took power in a military coup in 1989.

In the past and for several years, suspicion and mistrust has characterised relations between northerners and southerners. "The Asmara conference, if it was genuine, represents a turning point," observers noted.

Putting traditional rivalries aside, observers further noted that Asmara was the first time northern political parties such as the Umma, the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) and others, recognised the principle of self- determination for southern Sudan.

In addition all parties, including the SPLM agreed that the present and previous regimes had distorted the causes of the war in southern Sudan, by describing it as a conflict between Muslims and non-Muslims. This they said, conjures up the religious passions of most people and succeeds in blurring the real causes of the conflict.

One of the more controversial issues discussed at Asmara was the problem of regions such as Abyei, the Nuba Mountains and the Ingessina Hills, which although geographically part of the North, are affected by the war. The political future of the regions and the possibilities of their wish to go with southern Sudan was a ticklish issue that remained unresolved.

The conference set up a sub-committee of eleven members to follow these issues. They include heads of nine parties: Mohammed Osman El-Mirghani, leader of the DUP as chairman and LT. Gen. Fatih Mohammed Ali, leader of the Legitimate Command as deputy chairman.

Others include leader of the SPLM and commander of the SPLM army (SPLA), Col. Dr. John Garang; Dr. Omer Nur El-Dayem, Secretary-General of the Umma Party; Eliaba James Surur, leader of the Union of the African Parties (USAP); Tighani El-Tayeb, leader of the Communist Party of Sudan; and Hashim Mohammed Ahmed, leader of a trade union movement.

The independent members who will be in charge of military and organisational matters respectively include Mohammed Tahir Abu Bakir and El-Tayeb. Whereas some members of the sub- committee head parties that are confessional in nature, parties based on religion will not be allowed to register in the envisaged "new Sudan".

Participants recognised the positive role the Inter-Governmental Authority for Drought and Desertification (IGADD), a regional grouping that has been involved in mediating peace to end the Sudanese conflict, and asked IGADD to incorporate in future peace initiatives the NDA agenda.

But critics of the Asmara conference are not convinced that the Umma, DUP and other northern parties are genuine in their declared acceptance of secularism and self-determination for the south. This is only a tactical, but temporary political move, to coopt the south in "their bitter rivalry" to overthrow the National Islamic Front (NIF) government, and impose a less fundamentalist but all the same Islamic regime, said one southerner.

Some northerners also critised the Asmara conference. El-Hadi Bushra, a retired major general and a member of the Legitimate Command, the NDA military wing, described the conference as an affront to Islam and Arabs. El-Hadi Bushra has since rejoined the regime in Khartoum to "fight for Islam and for the unity of one Sudan."

On the other hand, the SPLA faction of John Garang has been accused of signing the Asmara agreement without consulting other "equally important" groups. "This agreement would have been strong enough if the South was united," said Dr. Amon Wantok member of a south-based group keen on presenting a united front in any negotiations with the north. "The South must stand as a block to deal with any situation at all," Dr. Wantok stated.

The Asmara plan received another jolt mid this month when Khartoum announced that government troops had on Saturday August 12, captured Kaya, a rebel town on a key supply route near the Ugandan border. John Garang's Sudan People's Liberation Army a major partner in the NDA held the town since 1989.

"The fact that thousands of northerners powered in the streets of Khartoum to march in celebration of the capture, does not speak well of the northern-dominated NDA and the Asmara agreement," said an observer.

The march ended at the army's general command where First Vice-President Major-general Al-Zubeir Mohammad Saleh told the crowds all rebel held land would soon be liberated. The army's capture of Kaya, was the first major offensive, he said.

APS FEATURES -==- African Regional Centre for Computing (ARCC); Nairobi, Kenya

May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: September 1, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


308 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


MINISTER'S EXIT DENTS FLT. LT. RAWLINGS' "CIVILIAN" GOVERNMENT"


LENGTH: 1707 words


 

by K. Botchwey and A. Biney

Claiming frustration and fatigue, Ghana's Finance Minister, Dr. Kwesi Botchwey quit his post last July and became both a villain and a hero for "getting off" Flt. Lt. Jerry Rawlings' boat at a time when the president needed him most.

He is a villain! No, he is a hero! Opinions may be divided, but in the murky politics of Ghana, it is possible to be both. Dr. Kwesi Botchwey is one such personality.

A month since he quit the government of Flt. Jerry Rawlings, many Ghanaians are still debating why Dr. Kwesi Botchwey, the country's longest serving Minister of Finance "got off the boat at a most critical point in time."

The point is critical because for most of this year, Ghana has been rocked by cost-of-living protests, with many people saying they had little or nothing to show for (the IMF and World Bank-inspired) economic reforms. At the same time, President Jerry Rawlings and his ruling National Democratic Congress face a general and presidential election in the second half of 1996. 

Already some opposition parties are considering an alliance that would present one common presidential candidate against NDC's "indomitable airman". The least Rawlings expected at this moment in time, is a resignation of his confident and senior minister.

Recognising the ideological diversity of opposition parties, Sekou Nkrumah, second son of the founding father of independent Ghana and renowned pan-Africanist, the late Dr. Kwame Nkrumah, last year called on Ghanaians "to face the realities, even though some may not be happy with the alliance." Sekou Nkrumah is secretary to the publicity committee of the "Nkrumaist" Peoples Convention Party (PCP).

Rawlings was sworn in as the constitutionally elected president of the country's Fourth Republic for a four year term in January 1992, after winning the controversial presidential race in November of the previous year. This was the third time the military turned-civilian ruler assumed the presidency. On the first two occasions he assumed office as head of state after successful military coups in 1979 and 1981.

In the November 1991 polls, Rawlings, heading the NDC formed out of his former ruling Provisional National Defence Council (PNDC), polled 58.6 per cent of the valid votes cast. His closest rival, Professor Albert Adu Bohaen of the New Patriotic Party (NPP), garnered 30.1 per cent of the votes in a poll the opposition said was rigged with the PNDC acting as "player, referee and match commissioner".

Rawlings had been ruling the country for the second time for eleven years, since 1981. In that year, Rawlings stormed out of the barracks yet again to take power from the civilian government of President Hilla Limann to whom he had handed power in 1979, the same year he overthrew Lt. Gen. Fredrick Akuffo and organised elections that Hilla Limann won.

But despite touting Ghana as a World Bank and IMF success story, Rawlings' "civilian rule" has been characterised by greater impoverishing of the population, while enriching "a few traders, well placed exporters and corrupt officials." For many Ghanaians, Dr. Botchwey's exist means that "some of his policies may be reversed, if for nothing else, to find a scape goat for the government's poor performance".

Since 1983 when the country's Economic Recovery Programme started, Dr. Botchwey has pursued "very harsh economic policies which to all intents and purposes have benefitted a few and impoverished the majority." However, few people were courageous enough to challenge the then military government of "the same Rawlings".

Dr. Botchwey was, however, steadfast and had great belief in the policies he initiated. He almost single- handedly attracted World Bank and IMF support in the recovery programme. His policies of deregulation, restructuring, liberalization and the free market policies propelled the economy into the global market. With the cedi more realistically valued the policies also awakened entrepreneurs to the need for efficient management practices.

Unfortunately the policies proved "harsh and painful for the peasants, wage earners and those Ghanaians out of the modern formal sector." After twelve years of belt-tightening and infusion of billion's of loans into the economy, the life of the ordinary citizen is worse off than before. The growth in Gross Domestic Product (GDP) has meant nothing to them, economists have said.

In a country where a clerk in the civil service earns as low as $35.00 a month, while transportation to and from work costs about $18 a month and, rent for a single room without electricity or running water costs about $10 per month it can be argued that Ghana is not in the best of times.

Education has become a privilege rather than a right with 57 per cent of school going children roaming the streets, either serving as common-carriers or selling iced water and dough-nut. Those in school lack teaching and learning aids which make academic work more efficient and effective. Also the health sector has progressively deteriorated.

Just a week before Botchwey tendered his resignation Catholic bishops in the country issued a pastoral letter on July 14 decrying the state of the economy and its effects on ordinary Ghanaians. The bishops noted that in spite of international financial institutions portraying Ghana's economy as a model for other Third World countries, the state of the economy still leaves much to be desired.

The upsurge of strikes, demonstrations and other industrial actions, the bishops pointed out, are an index to the dissatisfaction of some Ghanaians facing unemployment, and other economic problems. These have brought about high exodus of Ghanaians to other countries, particularly Europe, in search of greener pastures.

"The tragedy is that many of these become criminals and find themselves in prisons everywhere, in the process, dragging the name of Ghana into the mud," lamented the bishops.

The bishops also expressed grave reservation about the health policy of the Government particularly the freeze on the employment of paramedical personnel and the redeployment of 15 per cent of personnel in Church hospitals who are on Government payroll.

This action on the part of the Government, the bishops noted, is seriously affecting the activities of Church-owned hospitals which are allocated in rural areas. "We would wish to believe that the Government is averse to a situation where we are forced either to close down our hospitals or downgrade them to the level of clinics or health posts, as this will spell disaster for our already marginalised rural dwellers." But it is an option that cannot easily be discounted if the Government persists in carrying out such a policy, stressed the bishops.

With regard to the country's educational system the bishops appealed to the Government to pay particular attention to the plight of students and the teachers.

Referring to the closure of three of the country's national Universities, the bishops urged that a quick and lasting solution be found to the impasse between the Government and the University Teachers Association of Ghana (UTAG). The UTAG has embarked on a strike since April 1995 over salary scales which the Government has refused to meet.

Rightly or wrongly, Botchwey has been blamed for all these unpopular reforms in the economy, irrespective of their contribution to GDP. "GDP in any case," critics argue, "is not a measure of the well being of a people in backward economies where the distribution of wealth is heavily skewed in favour of a handful." Dr.Botchwey has also been accused of supervising "the rape of the national treasury" to fund the 1992 general elections that resulted in a whooping cedis 170 billion (US$170) deficit. Of this amount about cedis 120 billion could not be accounted for.

On these accounts Botchwey, who is also said to be shying away from presenting, in an election year, a "difficult budget" that will include the already controversial Value Added Tax, is considered a villain.

But for opposition political activists, any member of the ruling party, and for that matter a senior government minister, who "sees the light" and quits the "discredited NDC government" is a hero.

Copyright 1995, All Africa Press Service (APS). All rights reserved by the Africa Church Information Service, Nairobi, Kenya. Tel: (254-2) 442215. Fax: (254-2) 445847. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


309 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


HUMAN RIGHTS: PATTERN CHANGES BUT VIOLATIONS CONTINUE


LENGTH: 1934 words


 

by Odhiambo James

Massive human rights violations continue to take place in Africa, in streets and in prison cells, with both governments and opposition groups perpetrating heinous abuses, charges the Amnesty International (AI) report for 1994. Torture, using methods that include chaining prisoners and suspending them upside down, rape, electrical shocks, suffocation with rubber and the use of tight leg shacks remained a widespread reality in 33 African countries, further tarnishing the bartered image of the continent. Our APS writer reviews the "changing pattern" of violations documented in the AI report that was released in July.

Thirty years since the demise of the brutal colonial administration, a review of the African press reads very familiar, but at the same time very disturbing.

Some common lines illustrate the point: "The New York-based Human Rights Watch, Africa has expressed concern over police action in dispersing a crowd of peaceful demonstrators." The former colonial power has joined other Western donors to "urge the government to respect human rights and hinted on cutting aid." 

And the lines that authorities love to hate, continue on and on. It is as if nobody, including those in and outside government, care about the image of the African continent and her people, or the implications for development, investment and international reputation.

Only Ethiopia and South Africa recorded any improvement on the human rights scorecard according to the 1994 Amnesty International (AI)report released last month. Elsewhere it was the gory business as usual.

Almost 200 people were sentenced to death in 1994 in 13 African countries, with more than 1,000 people in 15 countries remaining under sentence of death from previous years. More than 200 were actually put to death, the AI report states.

A similar trend was experienced elsewhere in much of Africa, with armed opposition groups equally committing serious human rights abuses, including torture, hostage taking or deliberate and arbitrary killing.

In the Maghreb region - Algeria, Egypt, Libya, Tunisia, Western Sahara and Morocco - appalling human rights violations were committed by governments and their agents. This included imprisonment of prisoners of conscience, judicial and extra judicial executions, "disappearances", torture, arbitrary political detention and unfair trials of political prisoners. Many people died in police custody as a result of torture or ill treatment.

Hundreds of civilians were killed by armed Islamist groups especially in Algeria. Women, lawyers and journalists appeared to be prime targets in some of the Maghreb countries.

In Central Africa especially in the Sudan, the government arrested hundreds of suspected opponents, trade unionists, journalists and lawyers. Many were prisoners of conscience, most were detained without charge or trial for up to a few months, some in secret detention centres called "ghost houses". Scores were tortured in Chad and Zaire.

Amnesty International also documented human rights abuses by the Rwanda Patriotic Army, which gained control of Rwanda in July 1994 and formed the new government. Hundreds, if not thousands, of captured opponents and unarmed civilians suspected of participating in genocidal killings were summarily executed. Others were detained and killed or "disappeared".

Between April and July 1994 an estimated 32,000 people were held in detention without charge or trial. Many prisoners died because of overcrowding. There were also numerous reports of ill-treatment, especially in secret jails.

In Burundi, thousands of Hutus were targeted in politically motivated massacres by the Tutsi-dominated security forces and associated armed groups. The government failed to control the armed forces or prevent Hutu and Tutsi extremists from arming themselves and carrying out killings. An almost complete breakdown of law and order ensued.

In West Africa, Nigeria carried out at least 100 executions in 1994. In Gabon, overcrowding amounted to cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment leading to 67 prisoners suffocating to death in a single incident. Another 150 died in one prison in Cameroon because of inadequate diet and lack of medical care.

In Sierra Leone, where distinction between government soldiers and rebels has become blurred, soldiers tortured, ill-treated and extra judicially executed, captured insurgents or those suspected of being rebels.

In Somalia, hundreds of unarmed civilians were killed, including women and children, while in Djibouti scores were tortured. However, says the Amnesty report, positive steps were witnessed in Ethiopia where the government released thousands of opponents detained in the past two years. Authorities also started to bring charges against members of previous government detained since 1991.

In East Africa, Tanzania secretly executed eight. Kenya had the largest number of death-row inmates with 26 prisoners sentenced to death during 1994. This brought the death row population to 568. Uganda held hundreds under sentence of death at the end of the year.

In Southern Africa, in Mozambique's second year of peace, police torture and ill-treatment by security forces continued to be reported in 1994. Commissions were set up under the peace agreement to monitor the police and security services, but these ended up investigating human rights abuses by police and soldiers.

Malawi's first multiparty elections in more than 30 years unseated Dr. Hastings Kamuzu Banda, whose government had been responsible for widespread human rights abuses. After the election, over 100 prisoners on death row had their sentences commuted to life imprisonment. An investigation was launched into the suspicious deaths of three government ministers and a member of parliament in 1983. But Amnesty International continued to receive reports of police ill-treatment of suspects.

The world's attention was on South Africa in 1994, as the country's first non- racial national elections were held. The new government established a commission to promote and protect human rights and signed human rights treaties, including the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

After the elections, political violence subsided in most of the country, though by the year's end, the toll of political killings rose sharply in Natal Province (KwaZulu-Natal) with at least 75 people killed in December.

One of the major highlights of the 1994 Amnesty International report is that women continue to be targeted for state repression. Women suffered every abuse and violation of fundamental rights, including sexual harassment and threats of rape. Some of the women-victims were innocent wives of political activists.

Cases involving women were recorded in some 15 countries among them Algeria, Chad, Kenya, Liberia, Mali, Niger, Rwanda, Sierra Leone, Somalia and Sudan. In the run up to the September 1995 United Nations Conference on Women to be held in Beijing, China, Amnesty International is calling on governments to restate their commitment to women's entitlement to all human rights and to take concrete measures to protect these rights.

With growing human rights violation throughout Africa, so have the continent's social, political, cultural and economic crises worsened. The report updated to cover January-May 1995 highlights "notorious" human rights violations in Sudan, South Africa, Sierra Leone, Liberia, Burundi, Rwanda and elsewhere.

But on the eve of the "second liberation" only five years ago, African political, business and other leaders recognised at various forums that: "The absence of security for citizens, and the pervasive lack of democracy and respect for human rights are to a large extent responsible for Africa's predicament."

"This state of affairs has in particular made popular mobilisation and effective accountability difficult. It has also further marginalised Africa in the world economy, while political leaders suffer from loss of legitimacy and respect," noted the International Conference on Popular Participation in Recovery and Development Process in Africa held at Arusha, Tanzania in February 1990.

The subsequent (Arusha 1990) African Charter for Popular Participation in Development and Transformation said in part: "We believe that for people to participate meaningfully in their self- development, their freedom to express themselves and their freedom from fear must be guaranteed.

This can only be assured through the extension and protection of people's basic human rights and we urge all governments to vigorously implement the African Charter on Human Rights, the Convention on the Rights of the Child, the ILO Convention No.87 concerning Freedom of Association and Protection of the Right to Organise and the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women."

Nevertheless citizens are still tempted to ask: When will Africa create a climate where impunity will prevail no more? When will the perpetrators be brought to justice? When are the victims going to be given back their dignity as human beings? When will Africa create a free atmosphere for the African people to really contribute optimally to the development and growth of their continent as free and happy human creatures? When?

Copyright 1995, All Africa Press Service (APS). All rights reserved by the Africa Church Information Service, Nairobi, Kenya. Tel: (254-2) 442215. Fax: (254-2) 445847. May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: September 1, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


310 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


SUDAN CHURCHES OBJECT TO OIL EXPLORATION


LENGTH: 934 words


 

NAIROBI (APS) August 18 - Churches operating in southern Sudan have protested to the Canadian Government over the oil exploration activities of a Canadian multinational corporation, Arakis Energy Corporation, in the region and its implications for peace initiatives to end the Sudanese conflict.

In a strongly-worded letter the New Sudan Council of Churches draws the attention of the Canadian Foreign Affairs and International Trade Minister, Andre Quellet, to "the consequences of Arakis Energy Corporation business dealing with the Sudan Government and on the future of IGADD peace initiatives in which your Government is one of the supporters."

The Arakis Energy Corporation has purchased Sudan's State Petroleum Corporation, giving the multinational a 100 per cent interest in blocks covering five million hectares and option to acquire another 12 million hectares. The fields were previously abandoned by the American firm-Chevron Overseas Petroleum International. Now Arakis' goal is to raise US$750 million to build a pipeline from the Hegleg and Unity oil fields, in the Bebtiu region, to Port Sudan. 

But the oppressed people of southern Sudan feel let down by the Canadian Government because of the action of Arakis, the NSCC says, adding that: "While we acknowledge with appreciation that Canadian policy towards the Islamic Government is one of diplomatic pressure, we feel dismayed at your policy, which separates human rights concerns from trade related matters."

"How can business opportunities exist in a country like Sudan," asks the letter, "where citizens are humiliated, tortured and killed just because they happen to belong to a different religion and race or colour?"

IGADD peace initiatives, which the Canadian Government fully supports, could also be jeopardised when multinational companies like Arakis engage in business, which is bound to "harden the heart of the Islamic regime towards any peace process," the NSCC further asserts.

The letter signed by the NSCC Executive Secretary, Rev. (Dr.) Haruun L. Ruun asks the Canadian government to "do everything in your power to encourage Arakis to disinvest in Sudan in order to persuade the Sudan to opt for peaceful solution in the current civil war."

In another protest note to the Chief Executive Officer of Arakis Energy Corporation, Terry J. Alexander, the NSCC says: "We are writing this letter to raise objection to your economic activities in the Sudan. We are deeply concerned about the consequences of such business activities at the time when the international community is putting pressure on the fundamentalist Islamic regime in Khartoum to reach a peaceful end to the conflict."

The NSCC urged Arakis to disinvest in Sudan, and join other multinational firms in campaigning for a just and lasting peace in the country. "It is only when that nation is in peace that a conducive atmosphere for investment can become meaningful not only for investors but also the nation and its people," the letter stressed.

According to the Toronto, Canada-based Inter-Church Coalition on Africa (ICCA), Arakis intends to have the pipeline complete as early as October, 1996. This would help it swing into partial production of between 65,000-85,000 barrels a day, shortly thereafter, with indication that it could reach its full production of an estimated 100,000 barrels per day by January 1997.

"If such rapid development is actually feasible, the Government of Sudan could be reaping the fruits very soon", the Canadian church body said in a report. "It is imperative that as much pressure as possible be put on Arakis," it added.

The South Sudan Independent Movement (SSIM) has also protested the exploitation of "critical strategic minerals" in South Sudan when the war is still raging. The SSIM said it would sabotage any project by Arakis Energy Corporation to build a pipeline from Liech State (Bentiu) Upper Nile, where the oil is, to Port Sudan.

"The SSIM, its army and the people of South Sudan will not allow the Government to finance its forces of occupation for a Jihad (holy war) against the South with our oil," said the SSIM in a statement the movement faxed to APS. The Sudan People's Liberation Movement has also called on Arakis to "abandon its plans on the oil exploration business where she is working hand in hand with the Khartoum Government."

August, 1995


VIOLENCE CONTINUES UNABATED IN BURUNDI


LENGTH: 920 words


 

BUJUMBURA (APS) August 18 - Ethnic violence continues to spiral in Burundi with some 93 people massacred in a week of bloody attacks between the majority Hutus and minority Tutsis. In the first incident, a 100-strong Hutu militia unit on August 7 slaughtered 58 displaced Tutsis, 25 of them children, using machetes and knives.

A statement released by the Burundian government said the militia, who attacked the Kaburantwa displaced persons camp in northwestern province of Cibitoke, did not use guns to avoid alerting nearby soldiers of the Tutsi-dominated army. The assailants fled into Zaire after the attack. 

In the second attack, exactly a week later, assailants armed with grenades and machetes killed 30 people in the central Burundi province of Karuzi, the state radio reported, but did not specify the ethnicity of the attackers or victims in apparent fear of reprisal killings that could easily degenerate in massive bloodletting. Another 5 people were killed by unidentified attackers in Bujumbura and elsewhere.

In the past, killings by one ethnic group have usually been followed by reprisal killings by the other especially in the capital Bujumbura. Victims in reprisal killings are in many cases innocent civilians whose only crime is their tribe.

Few Hutus today remain in Bujumbura following "ethnic cleansing" which started in March. Those still in the capital especially in the northern suburbs of Kamenge and Kinama, frequently take to the nearby hills as Tutsi soldiers and militiamen battle with Hutu militias.

Until the massacres in the first week of this month, a brief period of relative calm followed the visit to Burundi by UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali in mid-July, who appealed for reconciliation.

Later in the same month the Anglican Archbishop of South Africa, Rt. Rev. Desmond Tutu made a pastoral visit to Burundi on a mission to support reconciliation efforts in that country. But despite the two visits, killings are now reported virtually daily.

Tutu, who is also the current President of the Nairobi-based All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) with a membership of over 140 Churches and associate National Christian Councils (NCCs) in more than 38 African countries, arrived in Burundi on July 27 at the head of an AACC delegation to consult withchurch leaders on the role of the Church in the process of national reconciliation. Bishop Tutu proceeded to Rwanda on Saturday July 29, on a similar mission.

While in Burundi, Bishop Tutu preached at different churches and other sites on issues related to reconciliation. His sermons culminated in a public rally and prayers for the nation in the national stadium in Bujumbura. His sermon focused on the general theme: "Christ our Hope". Tutu, a Nobel Peace Winner, also met with top political leaders in the country.

In all his meetings Archbishop Tutu, stressed the need for the restoration of peace among the "suffering Burundians." Said he: "This is God's world. God is in-charge. If peace and stability can come to South Africa, it can and will also come to Burundi".

Earlier this month, Boutros-Ghali asked the UN Security Council to set up an international judicial inquiry into the death of Burundi's first Hutu elected president, Melchior Ndadaye, and the ensuing killings. The atmosphere of impunity was a major obstacle to reconciliation, Boutros-Ghali stressed. Ethnic killings had been estimated at between 20 to 40 before the visit of Ghali and Tutu and virtually all killers went scot- free.

The army accuses Burundi Hutu extremists of cooperating with Rwandan Hutus in Zairean refugee camps, some of whom were members of the Interahamwe militias. This militia carried out the worst massacres during Rwanda's civil war last year, slaughtering more than 500,000 Tutsis, moderate Hutus and their families. The Rwandans in the camps are reported to be rearming, training and carrying out cross-torder guerrilla raids into Rwanda.

An Organisation of African Unity (OAU) delegation, headed by Nagash Kibrat, a special envoy of OAU chairman and Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi, is currently touring Uganda, Zaire, Rwanda, Kenya, Zambia, Tanzania and Burundi for talks on how to diffuse the escalating tension and put an end to the killings in Burundi.

Copyright 1995, All Africa Press Service (APS). All rights reserved by the Africa Church Information Service, Nairobi, Kenya. Tel: (254-2) 442215. Fax: (254-2) 445847. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). August, 1995


KENYA GETS NEW ECUMENICAL BODY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

NAIROBI (APS) August 18 - A new body of churches, which aims to "keep the National Council of Churches of Kenya (NCCK) is on its toes and to work closely with the Government" has finally gained legal recognition.

The Regional Fellowship of Churches of Kenya (RFCK), whose interim General Secretary, Rev. John Wycliffe Wanga, is a former employee of the NCCK, was registered on July 28, under Section 10 of the country's Societies Act.

A statement issued at the end of the new organisation's interim Executive Committee meeting held at Kenya's Lake Victoria town of Kisumu, 400 km North-west of Nairobi, said the RFCK "aims to work closely with the Kenyan Government for the welfare of Kenyans and to keep the NCCK on its toes."

"We are not worried of the new Christian body. Our main concern is the tone of some of the statements the officials of the new body are currently making," the NCCK General Secretary, Rev. Mutava Musyimi told 

APS in an interview. "It's our strong belief that such a new Christian body, should target at challenging us positively. There is too much that is yet to be accomplished in our pastoral mission," the NCCK chief further said.

"The long-time monopoly held by the NCCK is at long last broken and we will make survival difficult for them now that RFCK is formally registered," Rev. Wanga is reportedly said to have told the Kisumu meeting of his interim Executive Committee. Officials of the new body have also accused the NCCK of being too political.

It was also claimed during the meeting that at least 40 independent churches and three dioceses of the Church of the Province of Kenya (CPK) were said to have sought membership of the RFCK. The new christian body, which intends to establish its headquarters at Eldoret, about 200 kilometres, north-west of Nairobi, is particularly targeting churches in the Rift Valley, Nyanza and Western provinces.

In an interview with APS, an interim official of RFCK who sought anonymity, said "most of our members are former members of the NCCK, who have remained dissatisfied with the NCCK for a long time; but with no alternative. We have simply come to their rescue."

But Rev. Musyimi has refuted these claims saying that "we have already carried out a survey in the said areas and to our satisfaction, no member of the NCCK has officially left us for another church body." With a current membership of 38 churches, the NCCK is one of the largest and oldest national council of churches in the world.

A legal adviser and trustee to the RFCK, David Ngala, said some members of the NCCK in parts of the Nyanza, Rift Valley nd Western Kenya areas, became dissatisfied with the way money, donated by ecumenical donor agencies for community projects was distributed. Most churches in these regions had a low deal and chose to leave NCCK, he said.

The creation of a new church body, according to Rev. Wanga, has been necessitated by concerns that have been expressed by international organisations sponsoring the NCCK. He said the sponsors complained that funds they have donated in the past have not benefitted the projects they were intended for. He added: "Donors had recommended for the formation of regional bodies through which any funds they donate can be channelled to community-based projects."

On allegations that NCCK had become "too political", the NCCK boss was quick to retort that it was not possible for churches to "disengage" because politics affects all God's people both christians and non- christians alike.

Rev. Musyimi said he doubted whether the new church body was not politically geared. "Going by recent developments, I would not be surprised if the RFCK was a politically-supported plot to finish NCCK," said Rev. Musyimi. He also denied allegations of misappropriation of funds.

Copyright 1995, All Africa Press Service (APS). All rights reserved by the Africa Church Information Service, Nairobi, Kenya. Tel: (254-2) 442215. Fax: (254-2) 445847. August, 1995


CAPTAIN STRASSER READY FOR TALKS "ANY TIME, ANYWHERE"


LENGTH: 720 words


 

FREETOWN (APS) August 18 - President Strasser has reiterated his government's readiness "at any time, anywhere" to open peace talks with the Revolutionary United Front (RUF), despite the rebel movement's rejection of an invitation to attend a national conference to discuss how to return war-torn Sierra Leone to civilian democratic rule.

Addressing the opening session of the conference on Tuesday August 15, the head of Sierra Leone's military junta, Captain Valentine Strasser, told delegates that the four-year civil war "remained the largest single obstacle to the democratic process."

"We are prepared any day anywhere to begin unconditional talks with the rebel movement about the need for a general cessation of hostilities," Captain Strasser, 29, told the meeting, especially organised to discuss practicalities of holding elections at the end of this year. 

Captain Strasser's government has promised to hand over power to an elected administration early next year after lections planed to take place at the end of 1995. But with nearly 40 per cent of Sierra Leone's 4.5 million people currently displaced, many observers feel the only form of election that could be organised would be a highly modified form of proportional representation. Many Sierra Leoneans feel the vote should be postponed until the war is over.

Three days of registration of political parties ended on August 14, with 17 parties provisionally registered, among them the All People's Congress (APC). The one-time sole party was overthrown by junior officers in a coup on April 29, 1992 that brought Captain Strasser's National Provisional Ruling Council (NPRC) to power. The NPRC immediately banned all political parties, only lifting the ban in June this year in the run-up to the proposed vote.

RUF leader Foday Sankoh launched his rebellion in the extreme south-east of the country in late March 1991, initially to overthrow former military leader General Joseph Momoh, who fled to neighbouring Guinea where he still lives today. The war has claimed over 10,000 lives, according to official statistics.

Interim National Electoral Commission (INEC) chairman, James Jonah, a former UN under secretary- general, said that Foday Sankoh's RUF had not replied to an invitation to join the three-day conference. The conference was sponsored by the UN Development Programme (UNDP) as a "reaffirmation of its support" for Sierra Leone's march towards multiparty democracy.

"We issued an invitation through a third party, but up to this moment, we have not received any response," Jonah said. "I regret this very much as this is an opportunity for the RUF to join other Sierra Leoneans to chart a new course for the country," he declared just before the conference opened.

According to the INEC, 155 delegates finally took part, another 250 "observers" were allowed in on condition they paid their own expenses. Jonah stressed popular sentiments here that "unless the RUF is willing to sit for round-table talks peace will remain a mirage."

Delegates included representatives of student organisations, Universities, trade unions, women's groups, traditional chiefs and representatives of Sierra Leonean refugees currently living in neighbouring Guinea and Liberia. Jonah also urged delegates "to avoid the influence of money, bribery and corruption in their discussions."

Copyright 1995, All Africa Press Service (APS). All rights reserved by the Africa Church Information Service, Nairobi, Kenya. Tel: (254-2) 442215. Fax: (254-2) 445847. August, 1995


AFRICAN WOMEN IN REGIONAL "MINI-BEIJING"


LENGTH: 760 words


 

NAIROBI (APS) August 18 - Over 1000 women from Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania, Sudan and Somalia converged on Kenya's Nairobi University for a "Mini-Beijing", in rehearsal of the forthcoming women's conference in China. Among issues addressed at the three-day event were economic empowerment and poverty reduction among women. Cultural problems, family and socialization, and violence against women were also discussed. 

Mini-Beijing (August 10-12) was organised to get women's views particularly those that will not travel to China, and to agree on priorities and how to champion them. The women, representing various interest groups shared experiences and views in workshops, plenary sessions and exhibitions.

But grassroots women, who according to some experts bear the brunt of discrimination, expressed disappointment at having been left out of the preparations. They said their urban counterparts had not briefed them adequately and they had only relied on radio information.

A spokeswoman charged that, "rural women have been take for granted for too long." Other rural women expressed fears that they will not be fully represented in the Beijing UN women's meeting.

On the opening day, a "torch of peace" from South Africa that will be taken around several East and Central African countries before African women delegates leave for Beijing, was lit.

The September 14-15 Beijing conference will be the fourth world conference on women, the first having been held in Mexico in 1975. The Beijing conference is expected to discuss strategies to remove obstacles to the advancement of women. Some of critical areas of concern identified include poverty, inequality in education, health care, employment and economic participation.

In an earlier pre-conference continental preparatory meeting, over 5000 African women met in Dakar, Senegal, in November 1994, to come up with a common "African Platform for Action". For each of the 11 areas identified under the "Dakar Platform" the women proposed measures to be implemented by various organisations and agencies under the leadership of national governments.

Recognising that women were the primary victims of poverty, the platform stresses the need for specific policies to support female-headed families, which now represent 35 per cent of all households in Africa. The platform further calls for special economic programmes for poor women, especially in the informal and agricultural sectors, and urges for changes in gender-biased laws that limit the economic potential of women.

Other crucial areas covered at Dakar included property rights, land rights, inheritance and asset holdings. "The women's rights had been abused for too long", the women said, adding that to reverse this trend:

"It was imperative for gender concerns to be integrated into environmental impact assessments and the overall development process."

The Nairobi Mini-Beijing further discussed these and other issues such as women and the peace process in Africa; women, political empowerment and decision making; women, agriculture and food security; and women and the media. Also discussed were concerns of health and women's reproductive rights, women's legal and human rights and issues pertaining to the youth.

Most of these issues which are incorporated in the African Platform for Action adopted in Dakar last year, include a section on the girl-child, making Africa the only region treating this issue very seriously."

Copyright 1995, All Africa Press Service (APS). All rights reserved by the Africa Church Information Service, Nairobi, Kenya. Tel: (254-2) 442215. Fax: (254-2) 445847. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).
