August, 1995


GABON CALLS FOR MILITARY ACTION IN SAO TOME AND PRINCIPE


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

LIBREVILLE (APS) August 18 - President Omar Bongo of Gabon, the mainland country nearest to Sao Tome, has condemned the coup in the island nation of Sao Tome and Principe, and warned that international military action like the one which led to the reinstatement of Haitian President Bertrand Aristide could be undertaken if the coup leaders refused to heed calls to return the country to democracy.

Omar Bongo's call was supported by France, whose foreign ministry spokesman Yves Doutriaux also warned that if "constitutional legality was not restored, there will be consequences as far as our cooperation is concerned." The French warning followed a threat by the European Commission, which said it would suspend development aid if ousted President Trovoada was not reinstated.

Rebel soldiers struck in the tiny West African island nation of Sao Tome and Principe on Tuesday August 15, and seized power in a bloodless coup, ousting the first democratically elected President Miguel Trovoada. The soldiers declared a National Salvation Council to rule the country for the next 90 days pending arrangements for new elections. 

The insurrection on the islands located 300 kilometres (185 miles) off the coast of Gabon and populated by only 130,000 people, was led by Sub-Lieutenant Fernando Sousa Ponte "Craque" and Quintas de Almeida.

Announcing the takeover, the two coup leaders said that "a democratic military coup d'etat" was justified by a social crisis in the country. Ponte, leader of new regime, further said his comrades in the 600 strong army wanted to put an end to "corruption, indiscipline and disorder in the country," before elections could be organised.

But despite prompt assurances to return the nation to civilian democratic governance within three months, news of the coup triggered disquiet in many quarters apart from Gabon and France. In Washington, a State Department spokesman condemned the takeover and said aid to Sao Tome and Principe, valued at some one million dollars annually, could be at risk because of the putsch.

In Addis Ababa, the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) condemned the coup and demanded that the government be reinstated. "This is an era of dialogue and democracy. Whatever grievances there were in Sao Tome should be addressed through dialogue and not force," said OAU spokesman.

Immediately after the coup announcement, diplomatic envoys of Portugal, Sao Tome's former colonial master, and of Angola, another former Portuguese colony, appealed for clemency for the ousted leaders. Portuguese President Mario Soares said his country was ready to offer sanctuary to Trovoada if the coup leaders and the deposed president agreed.

Prime Minister Carlos Graca, who was on the island of Prencipe when the coup took place, said he had not foreseen the coup. But he said he had recognised the population's unhappiness with social conditions, adding: "I am at home and I am well, but I cannot answer any questions because the National Salvation forbids me to make any statement."

Portugal became the first European power to "discover" Sao Tome and Principe in 1471. The two islands became a Portuguese colony in 1522, before gaining independence on July 12, 1975. The islands make up one of the poorest countries in the world.

Until the coup, Trovoada, 58, led the country since April, 1991. He recently called for a government of national unity to tackle the problems facing his administration after the country was hit by a crippling economic crisis. The crisis in recent months had forced civil servants, including teachers and doctors, to stage several strikes to ask for massive wage increases of between 300 and 1, 000 per cent.

In October last year, the former monopoly party of deposed Prime Minister Graca, the Movement for the Liberation of Sao Tome and Principe (MLSTP), won general elections leading to a period of uneasy co- habitation with Trovoada's Party of Democratic Action. Then in July 1994, Justice Minister Manuel Vaz Fernandes resigned and sources said he might head the campaign of former president Manuel Pinto da Costa for the presidential election scheduled for early next year.

Da Costa, who ruled the country from Independence in 1975 to 1991, also offered to mediate, saying he had already been in contact with coup leaders. "The first contact was positive. I don't accept this military coup as I would not accept anything which could put the democratic regime in danger," Da Costa declared.

As we went to press coup leaders had agreed to start talks with various political groups in an apparent bid to set up a government national unity, while Travoada and Graca remained in detention.

August, 1995


TANZANIAN OPPOSITION PARTIES AGREE ON SOLE CANDIDATE


LENGTH: 587 words


 

DAR ES SALAAM - TANZANIA (APS) August 10 - As widely expected three Tanzanian opposition parties have agreed to field a sole presidential candidate in the first multiparty national elections slated for October this year.

The Party For Democracy and Development (CHADEMA), the Civil United Front (CUF) and the National Convention for Construction and Reform (NCCR-Mageuzi) will field Augustine Mrema, leader of the NCCR-Mageuzi to contest the presidency. Mrema is a former Deputy Premier and Cabinet Minister who quit the ruling Chama Cha Mapinduzi (Revolutionary Party) in a fit of anger over corruption issues. 

At the same time Abdulrahman Babu, a former Cabinet Minister in the immediate post-independence government, ended more than 15 years of self exile in Europe to return home as a potential running mate for Mrema.

Babu received a tumultous welcome home when his plane landed at Dar es Salaam airport on August 4, and immediately told a press conference that he would throw his weight behind the opposition. Since former President Julius Nyerere was openly campaigning for Benjamin Mkapa, the presidential candidate for Chama Cha Mapinduzi (CCM), said Babu, he would also support Mrema, said Babu.

Babu, a former political detainee in Zanzibar where he was born 76 years ago is seen by observers as a political heavy weight who will provide some counter weight to Nyerere's support for the CCM candidate.

Earlier this year Nyerere urged Tanzania's mushrooming political parties to think seriously of establishing a post-election government of national unity. "It is clear now, however, that Nyerere would prefer Mkapa to be an outright winner," the opposition has charged.

Nyerere's own son, Charles Makongoro Nyerere, a defector from the CCM to the NCCR-Mageuzi, reminded his father that the time was gone when Tanzania was a single party State. "A President for Tanzania could emerge from a party other than CCM," he asserted.

Meanwhile, a senior member of the CUF, Mr. Gideon Nipewa, has warned Nyerere that the opposition would adopt a common strategy against him. He charged that Nyerere who was in power for 23 years until 1985, had ruined the economy with his "misguided socialist policies" termed Ujamaa. The policies were based on getting the country's scattered population in communal villages.

Indeed Babu himself decried the poverty of Tanzanians upon his return. He said Tanzanians were worse off now than before independence.

(APS) - African Regional Centre for Computing (ARCC); Nairobi, Kenya

August, 1995


CHURCHES FORM GROUP ON WORLD BANK, IMF


LENGTH: 760 words


 

NEW YORK (APS) August 10 - A coalition of over 30 religious organisations throughout the United States, The Religious Working Group on the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) has been formed to address justice issues surrounding the two Bretton Woods global financial institutions.

Formed at Bretton Woods in the USA, the World Bank and IMF have pursued lending strategies that have impoverished people and communities in the Third World, devastated the environment, and created impossible debt burdens for the poor. In Africa, the debt burden estimated at $164 billion is forcing most sub-Sahara Africa to forego investment in education, health, industry and agricultural production. 

The "debt crisis" has been exacerbated by the continued fall of commodity prices, prompting the governing body of the Nairobi-based All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC), known as the General Committee, to call on the international community to address more critically the African debt burden, the IMF/World Bank terms vis a vis poor countries, and the unfair trading practices of the international market place.

In a statement issued nearly two years ago, the AACC General Committee against a background of rampant human rights abuses, proposed that "African countries be accorded a moratorium of 12 months during which time their respective records on human rights, democratisation and meaningful development would be scrutinised as a basis for debt cancellation."

Calling for greater World Bank and IMF accountability, an end to current structural and sectoral adjustment programmes and the cancellation of debt in the most severely affected countries, the new Religious Group (RWG) has produced a Declaration for Change, signed by hundreds of U.S. religious leaders.

The ecumenical group, comprised of Methodist, Unitarian, Mennonite, Baptist, Episcopal, United Church of Christ, Christian Church (Disciples of Christ), Catholic and secular organisations, institutions and individuals, plans to organise a number of events to coincide with the October 1995 World Bank/IMF annual meetings in Washington, D.C.

On Saturday, October 7 and Sunday, October 8, 1995, a forum on alternatives to the global economy will be held by the U.S. Fifty Years is Enough Campaign which has spent the past year educating participating groups on the issues of debt and development, a press statement issued by the United Church Board for World Ministries here, says.

The next day, Monday October 9, there will be a press conference at noon, a public rally, and an Ecumenical Prayer Service and Candlelight Vigil at 7 p.m., led by Mexican Bishop and Nobel Peace Prize Nominee, Samuel Ruiz, a key figure in negotiating a peaceful settlement of the Chiapas revolt. Also speaking at the service will be religious and lay leaders from around the world.

In addition, high-level meetings with World Bank and IMF officials are being arranged, and public vigils will be held by individual groups and denominations from October 10 through 12, outside the World Bank and IMF meetings.

The RWG is facilitated by the Maryknoll Society Justice and Peace Office in Washington, DC. The United Church of Christ and the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) are represented in the RWG through the Division of Overseas Ministries and the Board for World Ministries, as well as hundreds of activists across the North America.

Copyright 1995, All Africa Press Service (APS). All rights reserved by the Africa Church Information Service, Nairobi, Kenya. Tel: (254-2) 442215. Fax: (254-2) 445847. August, 1995


GOSPEL MUSIC ROCKING KENYA


LENGTH: 467 words


 

by Wafula John

Kenyan musicians whose litany of woes include the sorry tale of "rags to more rags" seem to have found a new lease of life in gospel music, which appears to be increasingly popular with local music fans.

Kimani Thomas, formally of Mbiri Stars today "cooes for the Lord". Augustus Barasa, once a vocalist cum-drummer with Toddy National band, is now with the Revival Flames, serenading fans with such gospel hits as "Yahweh! Yahweh!" 

The list of Kenyan musicians who have abandoned secular music for gospel tunes in recent years is as varied as it is impressive. The nearly endless list reads like a roll call of popular local artists.

Patrick Sanna, once a saxophonist of the famous Mangelepa, who enthralled fans with acrobatic stage shows now "sings for the Lord". He refers to night clubs, whose fat he once lived-off, as places "full of sleazy things, easy sex, and excessive alcohol consumption." His former mate, Bwami Walumona, sings gospel music too.

Joseph Munyau, a sales manager at Assaatholic and the Lutheran churches' stand on church and politics, stressing that the Church has every right to ask questions on all matters affecting the life of the people.

On the country's forthcoming general elections, scheduled for October 29, the CCT document challenged the government to see to it that all officially registered political parties are allowed full freedom and that all legible Tanzanians can exercise their right to choose (vote) in a free atmosphere.

In response to a specific question the CCT General Secretary, Rev. Angetile Y. Musomba told APS in a telephone interview that the document was the general effort of all churches, both Protestant and Catholic, in the country.

"It represents the pastoral concern of churches on the current situation in the country and the need to stress upon Tanzanians to exercise their right to vote and to seek for leadership positions, putting the good of the country before their personal ambitions," he said.

Copyright 1995, All Africa Press Service (APS). All rights reserved by the Africa Church Information Service, Nairobi, Kenya. Tel: (254-2) 442215. Fax: (254-2) 445847. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

Africa News


August, 1995


OPPOSITION IN BATTLE TO RECAPTURE POLITICAL INITIATIVE IN ZAIRE


LENGTH: 1494 words


 

by Sam Gonza

Forsaken by France, The United States, Belgium and other Western nations who have always quietly supported him, Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seko is now hopeful that his prime minister and confidant, Kengo wa Dondo who has the enthusiastic support of donor nations will salvage his image. However, despite major setbacks, opposition and grassroot church groups across Zaire are now intensifying the battle of wits to recapture the political initiative from the government and put the democratisation process back on course.

A month since the end of the transition period, Mobutu Sese Seko Kuku wa Zabanga is still president of Zaire. Fresh killings of peaceful demonstrators in Kinshasa at the end of July confirm that Mobutu, who has been in power for 30 years, remains obstinate and can still act drastically with or without a mandate. 

The protestors, members of the pro-Lumumbist PALU Party, were gunned down by gendarmes as they tried to reach the Peoples Palace (Parliament) to register their anger that Mobutu was still firmly in power after the five year transition period.

The transition period, decreed by the Sovereign National Conference in the early 90s, was supposed to allow for the gradual dismantling of Mobutu's dictatorial machinery, and lead to elections. Instead, Mobutu seems politically more sure of himself than ever. The elections are no where in sight, corruption continues unabated with Lebanese diamond and gold buyers, allegedly receiving protection from the Special Presidential Division.

Meanwhile soldiers remain un-paid for months and could unleash another round of looting sprees that could yet again, further damage the economy. The President himself continues to be accused of sabotaging the economy so that "the clique in power" may continue to benefit from the "parallel economy".

Against this background, the mainstream opposition, the Sacred Union of Radical Opposition Allies, (USORAL), led by Etienne Tshisekedi, Kibassa Maliba, Mende Omanga and others have served notice that they will start a campaign of disobedience and demonstrations to try and force the government to restore the democratic process. "Killings and terror tactics by Mobutu would not deter us", officials of USORAL which is working for change in Zaire said.

Among the aspirations of the Zairean people mirrored through USORAL is a transparent process towards real democracy, respect for the decrees of the Sovereign National Conference, a free and independent press and Judiciary as well as respect for human rights.

Five years ago when the "wind of change" toppled many despotic regimes in Eastern Europe, there was also pressure for African dictators to conform to a "New World Order". Then on April 24, 1990, President Mobutu announced he would introduce democratic reforms.

Such was the euphoria that swept Zaire with many thinking Mobutu would soon be blown away, that at one time the National Sovereign Conference nearly wrested all executive power from the despotic ruler.

But unlike Kaunda of Zambia, Ngueso of Congo, General Karekou of Benin or the de Klerk of South Africa, Mobutu had no real intention of quitting. He only played along to buy time. Drawing from his immense personal fortune, Mobutu withdrew from the trouble-torn Kinshasa, sometime living in his houseboat on the River Zaire but mostly in his palace at Gbadolite, hundreds of miles from the capital.

The elite Presidential Guard took control of security and a special unit began to implement a campaign of terror that saw newspaper offices fire bombed and the homes of opposition members attacked with rockets. There was even an attempt to kill the Catholic Archbishop of Kinshasa area, Mosengwo Pasinya, Speaker of the Transition Parliament that succeeded the national conference.

In its annual report in 1994, the Zairean Association for Defense of Human Rights said 60 per cent of the 152 murder or summary execution cases it had recorded were committed by soldiers operating with impunity. The press has also regularly reported on hold-ups, roadside extortions, kidnappings, robberies and rapes committed by "bandits in uniform, throughout the country.

Mobutu in the meantime continued to cleverly play off one group against another within the Transition Parliament. Some were simply bought off. The popular and widely accepted Tshiskedi found his premiership taken over by Birindwa. Birindwa in turn gave way to Kengo wa Dondo, the incumbent Prime Minister and Mobutu's confidant who seems to enjoy the "enthusiastic support" of donor nations.

In a vain attempt to coax opposition politicians who want to ouster him, Dondo on July 22 reshuffled the Cabinet in a move to create "a genuine government of national unity". However, the opposition which holds the majority in the interim parliament refused to take part in Kengo's consultations to form a new government. It is doubtful opposition figures included in the new cabinet will "bite the bait".

Today a large number of Zaire's 40 million strong population feel deeply betrayed as the transition period that initially looked so promising has passed "quietly like a village wedding", observers have said.

But Zaireans are a courageous people, and Mobutu's attempt to foster a regional policy by working one tribe against another as a survival gimmick has not taken root. Spates of ethnic cleansing have died down, observers further say.

Instead, grassroots organisations for the purpose of "radical civic education" have sprung up with Catholic church parishes playing a critical role in the awareness campaigns. The campaigns are, however, largely initiated by lay people according to some sources.

The Amos Group of Kinshasa, is one such group. The group has organised a number of popular demonstrations in Kinshasa. It regularly encourages members to "challenge fear" and to be actively involved in pro-democracy work and initiatives.

"Everyday the people have to be prepared to challenge fear. It is the only way to ensure that true freedom will reign one day," a spokesman of the group said. The people are taught that having lost everything under the dictatorship of Mobutu, "they should no longer be afraid of losing their jobs or afraid to say 'No' to unjust laws and fraudulent reforms."

Members, who like their membership in the church, try to shun tribal loyalties are further taught to search their hearts and look to solutions and ways of getting rid of the dictatorship. "Its going to be costly but its ones duty. Educate yourself for democracy and be prepared to assume positions of leadership."

The Amos Group also reminds the people that many died to rid the country of the notorious Belgian colonisers and that "the challenges of those says must challenge us to similar sacrifices today."

There are many more similar groups such as Groupe Jeremie in Bukavu which is actively involved in sensitising the people in the manner of Groupe Amos. Their intention is not to take the democratisation initiative away from political leaders, but to "support the process from bottom-up".

Copyright 1995, All Africa Press Service (APS). All rights reserved by the Africa Church Information Service, Nairobi, Kenya. Tel: (254-2) 442215. Fax: (254-2) 445847. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


320 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


SKEPTICS DOUBT NIGERIAN JUNTA'S COMMITMENT TO CIVILIAN RULE


LENGTH: 1427 words


 

Barely two months since the ruling military junta lifted the ban on political activities in an apparent first move to return Nigeria to civilian rule, recent secret trials and sentencing of alleged coup plotters to long jail terms, crackdown on human rights activists and journalists and the harassing of pro-democracy agitators has cast a shadow over "any meaningful" democratisation programme in the country.

by a Correspondent

A new era dawns on Nigeria, declared the Champion. But for the A.M. News, another independent daily, the Nigerian strongman General Sani Abacha had merely left people in suspense.

Many critics, among them opposition politicians and pro-democracy activists, seem to share the later view. Bani Fawehinmi, a leading activist and lawyer, said Abacha was trying to set up a political dummy which Nigerians are not prepared to accept. 

"He is pathologically committed to dictatorship because it is only under dictatorship that Abacha can function," Fawehinmi said. But despite the doubts expressed by most politicians and activists, a few other media groups joined the Champion to welcome the lifting of the ban on political activity. Abacha's military junta.

Abacha announced the immediate lifting of the ban he imposed when he came to power in November 1993, at a ceremony in the federal capital, Abuja, to receive the "controversial text" of a draft new constitution.

During the ceremony on June 27, Abacha said a new National Electoral Commission (NEC) would be set up to organise civilian elections. He promised to give details regarding plans to give up power to a democratically elected government during his traditional independence day speech in October. The general who gave no further details, however, warned politicians to beware of irresponsible activities that could threaten national security.

Many critics doubted the sincerity of the announcement and could not take it on its face value. Michael Adenkunle Ajasin, one of the founders of the opposition National Democratic Coalition (NADECO) expressed disappointment that Abacha did not use the occasion to free detained politicians, notably the presumed winner of the June 1993 presidential elections, millionaire businessman Moshood Abiola.

NADECO, the main group backing Abiola is composed of prominent politicians, senior retired military officers and pro-democracy activists drawn largely from the Yoruba ethnic group in south-western Nigeria. The group wants Abacha to hand over power to Abiola, also a Yoruba, to form and head a government of national unity.

But the junta is still holding the ailing Abiola, who faces treason charges for declaring himself winner of the presidential poll in June 1994 on the first anniversary of the cancelled elections. The military cancelled the elections when it became evident Abiola was winning. A former head of state and an international figure, General Olusegun Obasanjo, is also being held and his name has featured among the more than 40 people tried secretly for allegedly plotting to overthrow Abacha's junta in March this year.

Nigeria has been ruled by military regimes for all but 10 years since it achieved independence from British colonial rule on October 1, 1960. Abacha, described by opponents as a hardline anti-democrat, took over power after the military refused to publish the results of June 1993 elections and set up instead a short-lived hand-picked civilian government.

Insisting that his aim was the ultimate restoration of "true" democracy in Nigeria and an end to corruption, Abacha closed down all the country's democratic institutions, arrested opposition leaders and banned a series of hostile newspapers.

At the same time he formed a Constitutional Conference, dubbed "a charade" by opponents, which he said would map out the future political government of Nigeria. The Conference officially wound up its work on June 27, and presented a report to the Provisional Ruling Council (PRC), the top military body headed by Abacha. The PRC is expected to ratify the new constitution.

But opponents of the PRC have already dismissed, as undemocratic, the new constitutional proposals, notably the provision for a rotating presidency between the mainly Muslim north and the largely Christian south. Pro-democracy and human rights groups spurned the Conference, as a farce and a manoeuvre aimed at keeping the military in power. The Conference was eight months behind schedule with its report.

During the June 27 announcement, Abacha was at pains to show that he was still on the track to hand over power to civilians. But his actions have remained "diametrically opposed" to the supposed intent of the Conference and in particular, plans for the military to give up power, observers have noted.

Prior to the announcement, Abacha ordered the rounding up of more than 50 opposition leaders and human rights activists to forestall any unrest that could result from the arrest, secret trial and sentencing of the alleged coup plotters. The "plotters" include Generals Obasanjo and his former deputy Yar' Adua, two most respected former Nigerian military leaders.

Those arrested also include Chief Michael Adenkunle Ajasin, 86, of NADECO who was picked up at his home in Owo, along with scores of others attending a meeting of the "Afenifere", a group inside NADECO. Chief Ajasin is one of the architects of Nigeria's independence and a former civilian governor of the south-western state of Ondo, while the "Afenifere" group to which he belongs is the core group inside NADECO.

Several labour activists and opposition members, including ex-civilian governor Chief Cornelius Adebayo, and other leading NADECO members were also taken in at Ilorin, the capital of the central Kwara state, allegedly in connection with a bomb blast a day earlier in the city stadium during the official launching of a government project.

Observers saw the clampdown on the opposition, as part of a bid by an apparently panicky government to forestall any form of demonstration as the second anniversary of the June 1993 presidential election drew near. However, the anniversary passed quietly without major incidents.

Now Abacha has turned his wrath on journalists, forcing a number of them to go into hiding. Their fear was heightened by reports, at the beginning of this month, that a number of journalists had been arrested and convicted of sedition over stories that criticised the ruling military regime.

It is this crackdown combined with total disregard for international outcry against the trials and calls for the pardoning of the alleged coup plotters,that has prompted many Nigerians to fear their country was at "the crossroads of a military dictatorship that could eventually destroy the country's international image beyond repair. Most doubt than any democratisation process can commence at all when "the ground is so unlevel" except for those willing to work in cahoot with the military.

Copyright 1995, All Africa Press Service (APS). All rights reserved by the Africa Church Information Service, Nairobi, Kenya. Tel: (254-2) 442215. Fax: (254-2) 445847. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

Africa News


August, 1995


BISHOP RORIC, A "COOLING SYSTEM" IN SUDAN'S MILITARY JUNTA


LENGTH: 1040 words


 

by Santino Makur Kot

Gabriel Roric Jur, a black African southern Sudanese and a bishop of the Province of the Episcopal Church of the Sudan (ECS) doubles as Minister of State for Foreign Affairs in the almost exclusively Arab- Muslim government headed by Lt. General Omar Hassan El-Bashir. Since 1986 Roric, who is Bishop of Rumbek Diocese in the South, has lived in Sudan's capital, Khartoum, following the destruction of Rumbek in fighting between government troops and the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA). Bishop Roric was interviewed by Santino Makur Kot in early August in Nairobi, Kenya where he was attending a senior meeting of the ECS House of Bishops.

Q. As an African Christian cleric from the south what prompted you to serve in a government that discriminates against southerners because of their faith and colour? A. First of all, as a Christian, I am a strong believer in coexistence and tolerance. I also draw inspiration from the story of Prophet Daniel during the Babylonian Captivity. Daniel did his best to save his people from many difficulties especially persecution. There are many other examples in the Old Testament which relate to such situations. I also believe in non-violence. My mission is to put the message of reconciliation to the Government and opposition groups with a view to normalising the existing situation. 

Q. How did you join the Islamic Government?

A. Before my appointment to the Cabinet, I served in 1988 as a member of the Council for Mercy, a Christian-Muslim group that was set up to work for peace through dialogue. My church nominated me to the Council. I saw my appointment as another window which God had opened for the church's voice to be heard beyond and within the Islamic Government.

Q. But in spite of your presence in the government the war has dragged on and your government continues to be accused of a policy of Islamisation and annihilation of your fellow southerners?

A. Firstly the conflict in Sudan is not religious. In my opinion it is a political war, because the rights of the southern Sudanese people are not granted. I stand for the political rights of all people, which in the case of South-Sudan have not been addressed since Sudan's independence in 1956, when the north and the south which are religiously and racially diverse merged. The present government inherited the war from past regimes. The war has raged since 1955 except for 11 years between 1972 and 1983 when a peace pact was brokered between the two regions. The then President Gafer Numeiry abrogated the peace agreement of 1972, among other things by introducing Islamic Law, which particularly annoyed southern Christians. This has tended to give the war a religious dimension that has overshadowed its origins that are rooted in the demand for political rights.

Q. But why does the present government still maintain Sharia Law?

A. The introduction of Sharia Islamic Law complicated an otherwise simple political problem. The political problem needed a political solution at the time of Sudan's independence, but this was not done. Issues of political and civic rights for the people of southern Sudan were not addressed. Southerners include people such as Nuba, Ingessira and others who administratively and geographically are presently not in the south. The issue is now complicated and needs to be handled cautiously, so that the number of radicals on either side does not increase. My point is that the duty of all Sudanese, including those in the Government and the SPLA, is to sit together and work for peace and reconciliation before the situation gets worse. We need to sit and discuss alone as Sudanese without interference from outside. On October 4, 1994 the Government passed a Provisional Order requiring church-related agencies to register as societies or Non-Governmental Organisation (NGOs) under the Societies Act of 1957.

Q. What is your opinion of this order which many churches have criticised?

A. It is true this order has caused controversy between the Church and the Government. As instruments of the church these agencies are part and parcel of church establishments and their role should not be confused with the normal work of the church. The Government wishes to give legal entity to these agencies to enable them have rights and privileges for humanitarian work. The churches themselves are not required to register.

Q. What would you consider as major achievements during your tenure in the Cabinet? A. Against a background of religious, cultural and racial diversity, I consider myself a cooling system. I facilitated the visit of Pope John Paul II to Sudan in February 1993. I also facilitated the visit of the Archbishop of Canterbury in 1994. The Archbishop is set to return to Sudan in the near future. I have also laboured for the cancellation of the Missionary Act which deprived Christians of their freedom of worship and denied them access to land for church buildings. I consider myself a symbol of unity between the north and south and between Christians and Muslims

Copyright 1995, All Africa Press Service (APS). All rights reserved by the Africa Church Information Service, Nairobi, Kenya. Tel: (254-2) 442215. Fax: (254-2) 445847. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: September 1, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


322 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


NIGERIA'S ACTION CRUCIAL IN RESOLVING LIBERIA CRISIS


LENGTH: 1427 words


 

by Nernlor Grudah

The latest peace accord on Liberia is most significant and extraordinary not because all the warring factions were signatories but because Nigeria, the main power player, put its thumb on the pact, thereby unlocking the long-drawn process. Although nominal in a sense, there are reasons to believe that the latest peace accord in Liberia is very likely to stick.

Liberians who welcomed the August accord with guarded optimism did so out of disillusionment and perhaps, out of ignorance. They are disillusioned because 12 previous accords have largely been broken, and ignorant of the high-class propaganda that has made a scapegoat of the warlords and kept the bloody conflict going for more than five years. 

Propaganda is capable of shaping, transforming and above all, misleading international opinion, and that is what has happened in the Liberian civil war. Under the latest agreement, signed in the Nigerian capital, Abuja, on August 20, a cease-fire was expected to come into force on August 26 and a six-member transitional state council to be set up within two weeks of the signing. Democratic elections are to be held within one year following disarmament and demobilisation.

Brokered by Nigeria and Ghana, which holds the chairmanship of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), the agreement was signed by all seven warring factions. They include the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL), Ulimo-K, Ulimo-J, Liberia Peace Council (LPC), Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL), Lofa Defence Force (LDF), and NPFL-Central Revolutionary Council (NPFL-CRC).

But most baffling to many Liberians, was the unanimous endorsement of a less known university professor, Wilton Sankawulo, as chairman of the new state council. He replaces the aging Chief Tamba Tailor (in his 90s) who has been presented as candidate. However, the Chief will remain a member of the council as a representative of traditional leaders.

Other members are Charles Taylor of NPFL, Alhaji Kromah of the United Liberation Movement-K (Ulimo-K), George Boley of LPC, who represents a coalition of the other factions including his, and Oscar Quiah of the Liberian National Conference, representing the civilians. The signing, overseen by ECOWAS Chairman, President Jerry Rawlings of Ghana, and Nigeria's military strongman, Sani Abacha, was also witnessed by representatives of the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) and United Nations, which has an observer mission in Liberia. This follows Abacha's decision to break with the path taken by his predecessor, Ibrahim Babangida, and to arrange a high-profile reconciliation visit of Nigeria's erstwhile bitter foe in the conflict, Charles Taylor, to Abuja in June.

Having made the visit, his first in five years, Taylor has since made a couple of other trips to Nigeria, culminating in the signing of the accord. Observers see this as part of Abacha's efforts to patch up his government's battered international image because of human rights abuses and lack of commitment to return the country to democratic rule. Analysts advance that the reason why this accord will hold is that all the warring factions signed.

But this is not the first time all factions have signed a peace accord to end the civil war that has claimed more than 150,000 lives, destroyed the economy and infrastructure of Liberia and displaced half the population of nearly 3 million. The Cotonou Accord signed in Benin, in July, 1993, was by all three main factions at the time, the NPFL, ULIMO and the Interim Government of National Unity (IGNU) led by Dr. Amos Sawyer, which controlled the ramp AFL. It followed 10 days of intensive negotiations in Geneva, Switzerland. But that collapsed soon afterwards, because during the process, the Nigerian-led ECOWAS Monitoring Group, ECOMOG, was propping up a new faction, LPC, at the time, which refused to abide by the accord. And to make matters worse, another Nigerian-sponsored faction, Ulimo, split into two over the seating of the present transitional state council.

It has been established by independent bodies like the UN and human rights groups that Nigeria is responsible for the heating up of all the other splinter armed groups to fight against the NPFL. Except for the NPFL-CRC led by former Taylor's Defence Minister, Tom Woewiyu, the rest of the factions are all splinter groups from the AFL.

At one stage, Nigeria even tried to allegedly sponsor another faction in Nimba county, the Nimba Redemption Council (NRC) - an area which is a NPFL stronghold. But that group soon fizzled out and disappeared from the scene as it lacked operation base and support among Liberian refugees in both Ivory Coast and Guinea. That would have meant brother against brother, and husband against wife (from the same ethnic groups), for it was in Nimba county that some of the most gruesome killings under the military tyranny of the late Samuel Doe took place, including the burying alive of women and children. Based on the foregoing, one can conclude that Nigeria holds the key to ending the war in Liberia.

Factions which have no popular support among the population rely on the Nigerian military presence to demand a stake in any administration. The latest developments in the Liberian crisis have also apparently been precipitated by a UN threat to withdraw its mission, UNOMIL, if the factions did not make progress to end the stalemate, disarm and set a date for general elections. Such withdrawal was expected to be effected by September 15 this year if all or some of the conditions were not met, when a UN mandate is expected to expire.

"It is extremely difficult to justify the continuation of manpower tied to disarmament when there is no disarmament going on," UN Special Envoy to Liberia, Anthony Nyakyi, told journalists. By softening its stand, Nigeria appears to have come to terms with realities on the ground in Liberia. But the move comes too little and too late when irreparable damage has already been done.

The NPFL remains the most representative group in the conflict and still wields widespread support among the population, although some may not be fans of its leadership. Yet it has been the arch-foe of the Nigerian-led ECOMOG, which has thrown everything into battle, unsuccessfully, to crush it.

Many Liberians are wary of a Charles Taylor presidency for fear of his becoming another Doe, given that he (Taylor) is already alleged to have masterminded the assassination of key politicians and potential rivals, mostly from Nimba county, including Jackson Doe, David Duanyan and Moses Duopu, to name but a few.

Ironically though, Taylor is not from the region, he draws the bulk of his NPFL fighters from there. The reason for enormous NPFL support is simple. All the other factions, except NPFL-CRC, are no different from the AFL; in fact, they are one and the same. Real lasting peace will come to Liberia when all foreign forces have completely withdrawn from the country.

Copyright 1995, All Africa Press Service (APS). All rights reserved by the Africa Church Information Service, Nairobi, Kenya. Tel: (254-2) 442215. Fax: (254-2) 445847. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: September 1, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


323 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


WHAT MAKES INDIGENOUS CHURCHES TICK?


LENGTH: 2120 words


 

by Wafula John

African indigenous churches were explained away as an "overnight fad" when they first emerged in Sierra Leone around 1819. This contemptuous portrayal did not, however, stop them from flourishing, sometimes as a direct counteraction to colonial administration. But decades since the demise of colonialism indigenous churches, also referred to as African Independent Churches (AICs) now estimated at 9000 with millions of followers, are a force to reckon with. Our writer explores some of the things that make AICs trick.

Christ saves and comforts all, but when Raymond Mukilwa, 45, first "embraced the gospel of the Lord Jesus Christ" more distress gripped him. What shall I do with my two wives? He wondered. Suppose he separated from one of them, as the wisdom of his church prevailed upon him, what would become of the divorced wife and her children? Whatever he did, he would always have to live with the stigma of having been polygamous. He would never rise to any position of responsibility in his church, even if he deserved it. And he, like his second wife, would never go to Communion. 

A haunted Mukilwa brought his distress to Sinaida Dorcas Mary Akatsa, fondly referred to as "mama" or "the prophetess". Akatsa, a former domestic servant, is the founder of the Jerusalem Church of Christ (JCC) situated in the sprawling Kawangware area, a poor suburb of Nairobi. The prophetess boasts of over 30,000 adherents. Prophetess Akatsa's church put to rest Mukilwa's anxieties without much fuss. He was allowed to keep his two wives. But he would be excommunicated if he added another.

The JCC is one of the many African Independent Churches (AICs) that are steadily gaining popularity in sub-Saharan Africa partly because of their ability to reconcile uniquely African experiences. In earlier years, these churches were seen as a reaction against colonialism. But when they continued to flourish and even mushroom in modern times society, began to look at them more seriously. A leading African scholar, Rev. Professor John S. Mbiti, once described AICs as "a messy soup".

Today there are about 9,000 AICs with millions of followers estimated at 15 per cent of Africa's total Christian population. But according to some sources these estimates are too conservative since the movements are growing faster than scholars are studying them.

"There is also reluctance to acknowledge their phenomenal growth," says Jack O. Nandi, a scholar in African indigenous religious movements and a lecturer in religion at Maseno University in Kenya. In South Africa, for example, statistics show that only 9 per cent Christians were members of indigenous churches by 1950. This figure rose to 18 per cent in 1960, 29.3 per cent in 1980 and was estimated at about 35 per cent in 1990. The World Christian Encyclopedia estimates that in the mid 80s Zaire had 4,777,500 indigenous church adherents who were expected to increase to 8,848,500 by the year 2000.

Experts now agree there must be another explanation for the constant drift of believers from the mainstream or "mission planted churches" to the AICs. Apart from polygamy which many accept, a majority of these churches have built a sense of brotherhood among members not unlike the traditional extended family system or communalism.

Many AICs also embrace and enthusiastically encourage a lively presence of the Holy Spirit and guardian angels in a manner similar to the role of, and respect traditional society paid to ancestors. Also the unique baptism, confirmation and other rituals, in some cases resembling the customary initiation ceremonies of some ethnic groups in the successive age groups, have attracted many believers.

Members of the Africa Church of the Holy Spirit for instance, urge the faithful to style their worship on experiences drawn from their African traditions as long as they confirm to, or do not violate fundamental Biblical teachings.

On the other hand mainstream churches have been accused of patronage, lack of understanding of the African reality, and a blind onslaught on traditional customs and practices. Where they are recognised such as the last funeral rights (inheritance) of the Baganda of Uganda, rather than fuse tradition with what is good from Christianity, the opposite appears to be the case. The church tends to take over the tradition and seek to fuse Christianity with what is good or appropriate from the tradition.

Prophesy and healing are the other major attractions of indigenous churches. The fact that their leaders lay claim to prophesy and healing is a great boon that has attracted not only Africans, but also people of different socio-cultural backgrounds including a few Asians and some Europeans. This aspect in a way conforms with the "perversive religiosity" of the African people.

Writing on African spirituality, Father Renato Kizito, a well known Italian priest cum-journalist, asserts that matters that affect people such as health are fundamental concerns, that make healing a critical issue. Yet these dimensions, he writes, "have been put aside by a Western spirituality preoccupied - sometimes one could say obsessed - with moral and sexual behaviour."

Father Kizito further asserts that AICs take the spiritual and physical well-being of their adherents extremely seriously. "It can be said that their very life and worship revolve around healing, visions, dreams and the overcoming of evil forces." On a continent where spirits both good and evil are a crucial component of traditional beliefs, this aspect undoubtedly appeals to many ordinary African worshippers especially when not "schooled" in the Western sense. However, the most binding cord of these churches is often the charisma - power to inspire devotion and enthusiasm - which their leaders often exude. This charisma is often bolstered by the often mysterious aura of their founders and leaders.

Sinaida Mary Akatsa, for example, has a very mysterious childhood tale. Born through a cesarean birth two months pre-maturely, she came three hours after her mother had been pronounced dead. The infant Akatsa is said to have "outwitted" innumerable attempts at her life. Among these were poisoning, bewitching and even abandonment in a thicket for three days and nights. The worst had yet to happen. In March 1983 "mummy" was poisoned, "died for three days and three nights", and was ordered out of heaven to come back and "lead lost souls".

Skeptics may be sobered by the fact that by 1993, "mama" Akatsa's Jerusalem Church of Christ had 11,222 registered members and over 20,000 unregistered followers in four branches in Kenya. The church boasts of a following of between 30,000 and 40,000 members countrywide.

The attraction of AICs also include their fusing of indigenous elements with their worship. Worshippers are perennially active throughout a worship service, with choral singing, dancing, hand clapping and even ululations. Often, the songs, which carry rich African tones and beats, are accompanied by such indigenous instruments as the kayamba, the horn and jingles.

Professor Julius Murikwa of Daystar University based in Nairobi, concedes that the style of preaching in indigenous churches" is yet another of their attractions. The worship is "active, interactive and participatory," with the preacher and congregation all taking part. It is not unusual for congregations to plunge in collective hymns, adoration, prayers and communal castigation of sin and Satan. Said Prof. Murikwa: "Church services are not seen as an hourly rite where congregants listen to some sermon, absolve themselves of sin and leave. It is a communal activity of renewal which often lasts for six hours or more."

What is more, AICs are now attempting to solve their adherent's temporal needs through a very strong bond of a mutually beneficial brotherhood among the faithful. In an African milieu where even manual jobs continuously shrink, it is no wonder that the young flock to churches like "prophetess" Akatsa's. In infusing this African "holistic" view of worship - that religion should serve the total person for spiritual and temporal nourishment - indigenous churches have greatly endeared themselves to "the disoriented urban immigrant", says Prof. Murikwa.

But perhaps what is most puzzling is the immense power and influence which female leaders often wield in these churches contrary to male dominance in mainstream churches. The churches confer status and prominence to women, often building some into formidable prophetesses who, if not checked, can easily build personal cults. Father Kizito states that these prophetesses spring up especially when the male leadership fails.

"They are the last resort, the last voice or possibility of protest, even violent protest, left to the poor," he concludes. Some indigenous churches' prophetesses who left an indelible mark on the African continent include prophetess Leshina of Zambia, Lakwena of Uganda and Mother Jane Bloomer of Freetown, just to name a few. Scholars say that the increasing drift of women to independent churches is also due to barrenness, delay in conception, and domestic difficulties. Many indigenous churches respond to these problems through deliberate and open healing and prayer sessions.

Perhaps where indigenous churches score a hat-trick is their handling of the dead and the deceased. Most African communities loathe burial in communal cemeteries with the unknown. Also responsibility to the dead and the deceased is communal. So is the case in many African indigenous churches. Often the churches or members, communally meet all funeral expenses including the transportation of both corpses and mourners among other requirements.

The same is true of weddings, big hospital bills and other responsibilities that an individual, family or friends alone may not afford. One adherent put it plainly: "My church is my insurance policy to a decent burial." With the growing destitution, particularly in Africa's expanding cities, many people may continue to seek supportive brotherhood and comfort in an African independent church.

But as Professor Murikwa notes, most indigenous church leaders have very little formal education if at all. Some AICs leaders in fact, understand Bible teachings only superficially, and hence do a great disservice to their flock by misinterpreting the Holy Scriptures. "Therefore there is need for Christian institutions of missiology as well as mainstream churches, to reach out to these leaders to help train them," recommends Murikwa.

August, 1995


VATICAN RELEASES DETAILS ON POPE'S VISIT TO AFRICA


LENGTH: 440 words


 

VATICAN CITY (APS) August 28 - As Christians, particularly Catholics in Africa look forward to the eleventh pastoral visit to Africa by Pope Paul II mid-September, the Holy See's press office has released the Pontiff's detailed itinerary. A recent dispatch from the Vatican says the Pontiff will spend two days (September 14-16) in Yaounde, Cameroon, another two in South Africa, (September 16-18), where he will travel between Johannesburg and Pretoria.

On September 18 he is scheduled to leave Johannesburg for Nairobi, the Kenyan capital, where he is expected to stay until September 20 when he returns to the Vatican. During his visit to Africa, the Pope intends to hold concluding celebrations of the Special Synod for Africa and Madagascar, whose working sessions were held in Rome from April 10 to May 8, 1994. 

Highlights of the journey include celebrations of Mass and sessions of the Assembly of the Special Synod for Africa in the countries covered by the Pontiff's visit. According to the media dispatch, the visit to South Africa will be the first Papal visit to the country, while Cameroon's will be his second, having been there in 1985. Kenya will be hosting the current head of the Catholic Church for the third time as he visited the country on two previous occasions, 1980 and 1985.

In the same press release, the Holy See says, the Pope will be accompanied by, among others three presidents-delegate of the African Synod, Cardinals-Francis Arinze of Nigeria; Christian Tumi of Cameroon; Paulos Tzadua of Ethiopia; Hyacinth Thiandoum of Senegal and the Secretary-General of the Synod of bishops, Jan Schotte. The Vatican dispatch says the Pope's September pastoral visit to Africa will bring to 37 the number of African countries he has so far visited, since he was enthroned as the head of the universal Roman Catholic church in 1978.

Copyright 1995, All Africa Press Service (APS). All rights reserved by the Africa Church Information Service, Nairobi, Kenya. Tel: (254-2) 442215. Fax: (254-2) 445847. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

Africa News


August, 1995


BISHOPS URGE AFRICAN GOVERNMENTS TO END CIVIL WARS


LENGTH: 600 words


 

MANGOCHI-MALAWI (APS) August 28 - Internal hostilities, wars and conflicts that continue to affect some African communities are incompatible with development and therefore African leaders should work towards eradicating them, a group of Catholic bishops from the East and Central African regions has cautioned.

The clergy, drawn from Malawi, Zambia, Tanzania, Kenya, Uganda, Sudan, Ethiopia and Eritrea, and meeting here under the Catholic church's regional body of the Association of Episcopal Conferences of Eastern Africa (AMECEA) between August 6 and 20, stressed that civil strife has made development among certain communities impossible. Exemplifying Sudan and Somalia, the bishops said events in those countries have led to the uprooting of thousands of people from their homes and resulted in terrible loss of human life and property. 

On the role of women in development, the Catholic clergy noted that many women are bearing burdens of responsibility that are beyond their capacity, stressing that without the contribution of women, social and economic life in our nations would come to a standstill. The contribution of women needs to be recognised and economically rewarded, the bishops further stressed. They also expressed support for delegates to the Fourth World Conference on Women in Beijing, China and acknowledged the struggle for their (women's) rightful place in society.

The Catholic clergy, who addressed various issues pertaining to the social, economic, political and religious needs of the African people, underscored the need to make the Church central in the life of the African people. "If the Church is to become the family of God in Africa, we all, clergy, religious and the laity have to learn to sit together, to look together at our situation, to listen to each other, to plan a common project and feel all responsible for realising it," stated the bishops.

Meanwhile, a Rwandese catholic bishop, invited to attend the AMECEA assembly, strongly defended his church against claims that the latter was involved in the genocide that took place in the Central African country between April and July 1994. "The Catholic church is falsely accused of having a share of responsibility in the Rwandese tragedy. In fact, it is the craving for power that has led to this tragedy, while the church was incapable of defending even its own members," noted Bishop Wenceslas Kalibushi.

The Rwandese clergy lamented that "the numerous criticisms abusively thrown at the church in Rwanda by the national and international media do not make the moral recovery of our people any easier."

Copyright 1995, All Africa Press Service (APS). All rights reserved by the Africa Church Information Service, Nairobi, Kenya. Tel: (254-2) 442215. Fax: (254-2) 445847. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

Africa News


August, 1995


CIVILIAN RULE RESTORED IN SAO TOME


LENGTH: 694 words


 

SAO TOME (APS) August 28 - Soldiers who ousted Sao Tome and Principe's first democratically elected President Miguel Trovoada mid-August have handed back power under an amnesty deal worked out by Angolan Foreign Minister Nenancio de Moura. The coup leaders, who struck early on August 15 and said they had ousted President Trovoada, handed back power a week later on August 22 after they failed to win support from their countrymen and women at home and abroad.

The ousted president resumed possession of his offices at midday on August 22 and approved an amnesty law protecting the coup leaders, which had been voted in by the national assembly a day earlier. The same day, the Sao Tome cabinet held an extraordinary meeting presided over by Prime Minister Carlos Graca, a move that indicated that a ministerial reshuffle could be in the offing. 

As a further measure to restore order to the impoverished West African nation, one of the poorest in the world, foreign ministers from Angola, Cape Verde, Guinea-Bissau, Mozambique, as well as Sao Tome and Principe, were expected to attend a summit in Sao Tome in the coming days to discuss the country's economic, political and social situation, a source close to the Angolan Foreign Minister said. Earlier, De Moura, who helped to negotiate an end to the crisis, went on the island republic's national radio to announce that civilian rule had been restored in this country, declaring: "Thanks to understanding, good sense and a spirit of patriotism shown by all sides, it has been possible to normalise political life in Sao Tome.

De Moura said a memorandum had been signed between the coup leaders and the civilian authorities calling for a series of measures including a restructuring of the military, but with Trovoada remaining as commander in chief.

According to sources in the army, the coup leaders agreed to sign the amnesty document after getting assurance that they would neither be prosecuted, tried nor disciplined. The mutineers also obtained satisfaction in a dispute over the make-up of the presidential guard, after they were assured that the personal guard of the president would continue to be trained by officers from Sao Tome and Principe and not by foreign soldiers as the president had wanted. The signatories were coup leader Sub-Lieutenant Quintas de Almeida and the Speaker of the National Assembly, Francisco Fortunato Pires.

The accord came only a few hours after the National Assembly unanimously voted to amnesty those involved in the coup, thus meeting the main condition set by the soldiers before they would relinquish power. Trovoada, who was elected president in the first democratic elections since independence, was arrested and overthrown at dawn on August 15 in a bloodless coup organised by a group of officers who said they wanted to "restore order" to the island republic, which won independence from Portugal in 1975.

But the coup failed to win general support here or abroad, with numerous countries condemning the putsch and suspending aid desperately needed in a destitute nation where, for example, teachers earn only dollars 10 a month.

Copyright 1995, All Africa Press Service (APS). All rights reserved by the Africa Church Information Service, Nairobi, Kenya. Tel: (254-2) 442215. Fax: (254-2) 445847. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

Africa News


August, 1995


SIERRA LEONE NATIONAL CONFERENCE VOTES TO PUT OFF ELECTIONS


LENGTH: 734 words


 

FREETOWN (APS) August 28 - Delegates to Sierra Leone's National Consultative Conference voted on August 17 to postpone general elections in the West African country from December to February 1996.

Many delegates had during the three-day meeting voiced support for the original date to be maintained, but the chairman of the Interim National Electoral Commission (INEC) chairman James Jonah, a former UN under secretary-general, proposed the deferment of the elections until March 1996. According to Jonah, the need to postpone the elections arose out of lack of funds for the poll, whose cost was estimated at US dollars 17 million. 

"It is also to give time for political parties to canvass and also for the National Committee for Democracy (a UN-sponsored group) to increase their civic voter education," Jonah said after the conference closed. But the delegates voiced open opposition against Sierra Leonean rebels denouncing the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) of renegade Sierra Leone army officer, Corporal Foday Sankoh for not taking part in the conference. They also called on the military government to provide security and design a security plan of action before the elections.

The ruling military junta, of Captain Valentine Strasser, which had the responsibility to confirm the conference's proposals, has since welcomed the proposals and is now expected to endorse the conference's proposals. But news of the postponement was greeted with mixed feelings, especially from 10 out of the 17 political parties expected to take part in the coming polls. One angry politician hit out: "What is the need for the postponement? The election was one thing that could have ended the war."

But diplomats here, mainly from western Europe, said the postponement was necessary and they even cast doubts on the possibility of holding the elections by February. When the conference opened, only six delegates out of 70 had opted for a change of the polls date. Before the closure of the conference, Major Karefa Kargbo, the defence spokesman and a member of the military junta, had told the conference that the military government did not want to take a position on the timing of the vote, saying: "We are looking up to delegates to reach a consensus."

More than 40 per cent of Sierra Leone's 4.5 million population have been displaced by the four-year-old civil war, and despite an invitation to attend, the RUF failed to turn up. The delegates included representatives of student organisations, universities, trade unions, women's organisations, traditional chiefs and representatives of Sierra Leonean refugees currently living in neighbouring Guinea and Liberia.

Captain Strasser's government had promised to hand over to an elected administration in early 1996 following elections at the end of this year, but many observers felt the only form of election that could be organised would be a highly modified form of proportional representation due to the very high number of Sierra Leoneans forced to live outside the country.

Three days of registration of political parties ended on August 14 with 17 provisionally registered, among them the All People's Congress (APC), the one-time sole party which was overthrown by junior officers in the April 29, 1992 coup that brought Captain Strasser's National Provisional Ruling Council (NPRC) to power. The war has claimed over 10,000 lives, according to official statistics.

Copyright 1995, All Africa Press Service (APS). All rights reserved by the Africa Church Information Service, Nairobi, Kenya. Tel: (254-2) 442215. Fax: (254-2) 445847. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

328 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


BORDER TOWN FALL HEIGHTENS TENSION BETWEEN UGANDA, SUDAN


LENGTH: 654 words


 

KAMPALA (APS) August 28 - The capture of the southern Sudanese border town of Kaya by Sudanese troops and a new Ugandan rebel movement, the West Nile Bank Front, has increased tension between Uganda and Sudan. Kaya was previously a stronghold of the Garang faction (mainstream) of the Sudan People's Liberation Army, SPLA. The guerrillas of the SPLA fled Kaya which was taken virtually without a fight on August 12. 

Uganda's Minister of State for Defence, Amama Mbabazi told the State newspaper New Vision that there was a possibility that the capture of Kaya by Sudanese troops and the West Nile Bank Front "was intended to create a platform from where the Sudan government may aid the rebel to disrupt the peace in Uganda." The West Nile Bank Front comprises former soldiers who served in the Idi Amin regime. Most members are believed to be from West Nile area. They are commanded by a one time Cabinet Minister in the Amin period, Juma Oris.

Uganda has on a number of occasions over the past year accused Sudan of sponsoring the rebels to destabilise Uganda. These accusations were directed mainly against Joseph Kony's Lords Resistance Army (LRA) which in the past engaged in acts of banditry, killings and kidnappings, mainly in Kitgum District in northern Uganda. However the LRA troops have recently been kitted in new Sudan Army uniforms and carry a heavier range of weapons.

On April 23 this year following the massacre of 200 villagers in Kitgum District near the Sudan border, Uganda angrily severed diplomatic relations with Sudan and warned that it reserved the right to attack their bases inside Sudan in future. In turn Sudan accused Uganda of supporting the SPLA.

Suspicions continued despite a meeting between Uganda's President Yoweri Museveni and President El Bashir of Sudan aimed at reconciling the two countries. The meeting, last May in Malawi was at the behest of the Malawian leader, Bakili Muluzi. Already there are reports that Ugandans are fleeing Kobiko village on the border, following persistent aerial bombing and artillery shelling by Sudanese troops and the new rebel group now in Kaya.

Meanwhile Uganda's Defence Ministry has confirmed that government troops mid-August killed Major Oryem Lagwaramoi second in Command to Joseph Kony. Thirteen rebels of the Lords Resistance Army also died during the pitched battle north west of Kitgum town at Obolokome. The rebels are believed to have entered Uganda from Sudan about August 15. They roamed and terrorised villagers in Palabek, Padibe, Ocettoke, Lemo Lugwar, and other villages in Kitgum before being confronted by Uganda's National Resistance Army (NRA) troops. The death of their deputy commander is believed to be a major blow to the Lords Resistance Army who are generally described as "Christian fundamentalist forces".

However, they carry out regular atrocities in areas that they attack and are hated by their own Acoli people. Their Commander, Joseph Kony is believed to have been injured during a rebel incursion into Uganda early this year.

Copyright 1995, All Africa Press Service (APS). All rights reserved by the Africa Church Information Service, Nairobi, Kenya. Tel: (254-2) 442215. Fax: (254-2) 445847. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

Africa News


August, 1995


SCHOLARS CHALLENGED ON POVERTY ERADICATION


LENGTH: 814 words


 

NAIROBI (APS) August 28 - Scholars meeting here recently have challenged fellow experts in Africa and elsewhere in the world to work hand-in-hand with their governments to help eradicate poverty among the affected communities. During the Fourth World Conference of the World Future Studies Federation (WFSF) held in the Kenyan capital recently, scholars drawn from all over the world were also urged to make sure that their research work was matched with implementation. The 250 delegates to the world conference, the first to have been held on the African soil, expressed concern that in some cases, the amount of work that goes into research work was not matched with similar effort when it came to implementation. As a result, we end up having too much knowledge on paper and little and sometimes none on the practical level, the delegates, who were drawn from diversified disciplines, among them theologians, observed.

Noting that poverty was on the increase among many communities in the world over, the scholars pointed out that "it would be naive to abdicate that responsibility to governments". The scholars concern over poverty and its effects among the affected communities comes in the wake of reports indicating that the number of poor people is growing in the world over and particularly in Africa. 

The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) in its July report on the food situation in Africa, expressed concern that an estimated 23 million people in sub-Saharan Africa are faced with starvation as food aid declines. According to the FAO report, the largest concentration of these vulnerable populations is in Southern Africa (10 million), followed by Eastern Africa (9 million), Western Africa (3 million) and Central Africa (one million). "Widespread drought has seriously undermined production in southern Africa, while persistent civil strife and security problems in some countries continue to limit farming and distribution activities," the FAO report points out.

Reports on deteriorating famine, drought and civil strife in Africa will definitely increase poverty among communities. That is why, we, scholars, among others, should get involved towards its poverty eradication, observed South African Archbishop Desmond Tutu, while delivering his key-note address at the conference. The South African clergy who is the current president of the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC), further urged African nations to find a lasting solution to the many problems facing the continent as a first step towards social and economic reforms. The continent's survival is threatened by all manner of social, economic and political ills and can only sustain itself if it reassesses the past with the intention of starting a new chapter, Archbishop Tutu emphasised.

Archbishop Tutu who addressed the conference on "Accountability and Poverty in Africa", challenged Africa to make efforts to stand on its own feet as the continent is no longer a priority to the West, which he said, prefers to support the former Eastern bloc.

In another development, a two-day meeting, held in the Uganda capital, Kampala on the management of Science and Technology for development in Africa decried Africa's falling standards as far as self-sufficiency in food is concerned. The forum attended by some 500 delegates, among them five African Heads of State representing Zimbabwe, Uganda, Botswana, Malawi and Mozambique lamented that ineffective application of improved production technology linked to ineffective pricing and marketing and high rates of population growth had resulted in declining per capita food production.

The late July meeting was attended by Presidents of Zimbabwe, Uganda, Botswana, Malawi, and Mozambique. They were among the estimated 500 delegates at the two-day meeting.

Copyright 1995, All Africa Press Service (APS). All rights reserved by the Africa Church Information Service, Nairobi, Kenya. Tel: (254-2) 442215. Fax: (254-2) 445847. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

Africa News


August, 1995


SUDAN'S EPISCOPAL CHURCH CALLS FOR END OF CIVIL WAR


LENGTH: 734 words


 

NAIROBI (APS) August 28 - Bishops of the Episcopal Church of the Sudan (ECS) have appealed to the government and the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Movement (SPLM) to work relentlessly towards achieving honourable peace to save their people from the long-standing civil war which continues to drain human and material resources from the Sudan. Saying that they believed Sudanese are "naturally peace-loving" people, the bishops asked Lt. General Omar Hassan Ahmed El-Bashir, leader of the Sudanese junta and the SPLM and its army, the SPLA, to disassociate themselves from hostilities, start peace talks "anywhere on earth acceptable" and allow food to reach starving people in the regions they each control.

In a letter addressed to Bashir but intended for and sent to both the Sudanese President and John Garang, head of SPLM and commander of SPLA, the bishops said that "freedom of evangelisation and free movement of bishops" ought to be facilitated throughout the country. The letter signed by all the 20 bishops of the ECS, was issued at the end of a week-long meeting here. Among the bishops at the August 4-12 meeting was Gabriel Roric, Bishop of Rumbeki in the south, who is also Minister of State for Foreign Affairs in Bashir's cabinet. Bishop Roric has lived in Khartoum since 1986 when Rumbeki was destroyed by fighting between SPLA fighters and government troops. He was appointed Minister in August 1992. In another development, Hassan Al-Turabi, a renown and influential Islamist leader, has said that his country had been unjustly criticised abroad because it applied Islamic laws and revived the concept of Jihad or holy struggle. 

Turabi was quoted by the official Sudan News Agency (SUNA) as saying the change which Sudan has been witnessing since the implementation of Islamic laws would take it to the position of leadership in the world. After living through the first half of this century of Western domination, Sudan had revived the concept of Jihad otherwise forgotten in the Islamic world, Turabi said. Western nations led by the United States, together with Egypt and several other Arab states have repeatedly accused Sudan, led since 1989 by the Islamist-backed government of giving refuge and training for Muslim militant groups. Sudan denies the charge.

Citing achievements of Bashir's government, Turabi said the Sudanese Head of State had ended a state of disintegration under the rule of sectarianism and political parties, in reference to outlawed political groups, the Umma and the Democratic Unionist Party. Upon taking power, Bashir dissolved parliament and suspended the constitution. He also banned political parties, including Turabi's National Islamic Front, thus ending Sudan's third spell of democratic rule since independence in 1956.

Meanwhile Lino Rol Deng, another controversial southerner in Bashir's government, has asked the UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) to stop SPLA form recruiting Sudanese refugees in neighbouring countries. Mr Lino Rol Deng, Secretary-General of Sudan's High Council for Peace was quoted as saying his country had also called on representatives of human rights groups to visit such camps in Uganda, Kenya and Eritrea. The government and the SPLA have accused each other of rounding up men and young boys for military training.

Khartoum has accused the United Nations of turning a blind eye to SPLA round-ups.

Copyright 1995, All Africa Press Service (APS). All rights reserved by the Africa Church Information Service, Nairobi, Kenya. Tel: (254-2) 442215. Fax: (254-2) 445847. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.
