331 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


The perils of flight


LENGTH: 640 words


 

Mail & Guardian

August 25, 1995

by Clive Simpkins

THE collapse of Avia Airlines and the South African leg of Sudan Airways has highlighted some major flaws inthe protection of passengers.

People who had bought Sudan Airways tickets were stunned recently to learn that not only did they haveto pay a 15 percent excess on their claims, but in many instances they weren't covered at all because Sudan Airways per se continues to operate healthily. TheSouth African leg is in "suspension" and may be resumed later this year. However, this doesn't help thosewho've already forked out for a fare and need to travel immediately. 

People don't only take out travel insurance when flying"iffy" airlines. I have, for years, taken out insurance whenever a fare has been one of those penalty-attracting packages which cannot easily be changed, or in case I get ill. The flaw in the present insurance system is that the risk is skewed and the insurance companies have discovered that.

British Airways (BA) gets a 10-out-of-10 for lending a hand to passengers in distress. BA allowed strandedpassengers special privileges on a standby basis to get'em back home. Compare this with the unbelievably insensitive and unhelpful response of South AfricanAirways' (SAA) Leon Els who said that "it was their choice to fly Sudan Airways". He's just nullified a few hundred thousand rand of SAA's advertising and public relations budget in one foul swoop.

The previous government refused requests from theAssociation of Southern African Travel Agents (Asata)for a small levy to be imposed on all airfares to allowthe creation of a travel-industry trust or fidelityfund.

Market forces should have been allowed to dictate themechanisms for default-insurance procedures. I hope thepresent government will recognise this and leave decisions affecting specific industries and services tothose in the know.

On the subject of air travel, it's saddening to notethat airlines are going for the jugulars of oppositionairlines yet again. This certainly contributed to thedemise of Flite Star and it seems airlines are using thesame tactics to get rid of Phoenix.

Instead of trying to win passengers by offering thembetter service, some airlines seem hell-bent on thedestruction of the opposition. Competition is scary,remember?

Comair's ad about its R14-million trust fund forpassenger protection focuses more on a challenge toopposition airlines to do likewise than on the meritsof its plan. It is interesting to note that SAA'sformer head marketing honcho is now at Comair.

I'm not for one moment advocating protection of somesort, just a more consumer-benefiting approach.

Jan Carlzon, the famed President of Scandinavian Airlines, says: "You'll never be 50 percent better than your opposition at what you do. If they were so bad,they'd be out of business. What you've got to do is be one percent better at 1 000 little things." Travel industry please take note.


LOAD-DATE: September 1, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


332 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Leaked: government rules to prevent leaks


LENGTH: 880 words


 

Mail & Guardian

August 25, 1995

by Marion Edmunds

A special National Intelligence briefing to the Cabineton how to deal with sensitive and potentially embarrassing information and prevent leaks has been leaked to the Mail & Guardian.

Concern about security leaks and sabotage of government plans prompted National Intelligence to brief Cabinet on how to safeguard sensitive information. A document on safety measures was distributed in the recent Cabinet briefing, and has since then been distributedto government ministries.

The document urges civil servants to be ever-vigilant when dealing with matters that could embarrass, damage or bring down the government. In particular, it lays out guidelines for preserving confidentiality and sensitive information, which could either be contained in documents or on computers. 

Implicit in the preamble is the warning that there maybe forces at work to sabotage the RDP and the country's transition.

The authors of the document note that there has been an"escalation of intelligence activities by a growing number of foreign countries and other interest groups".

Apart from laying down procedures for dealing with bomb attacks and fires, the document describes the differences between "restricted", "confidential","secret" and "top secret" information. According to the definitions, a "restricted document" contains information that could embarrass the government, a"confidential document", if leaked, could damage the government, a "secret document" might be used by opponents to disrupt the running of government and a"top secret document", if leaked, could lead to the downfall of the government, the severing of relations with another state or a declaration of war.

"Top secret" and "secret" documents have to be kept in strong rooms or vaults, where as confidential documentmust be kept in reinforced steel cabinets. The Cabinet briefing document -- a restricted document -- also contains a number of tips about keys, fires and how to deal with suspicious-looking maintenance men.

Moe Shaik, advisor to Deputy Minister of IntelligenceJo Nhanhla, would not confirm or deny that the Cabinet briefing took place, but he did say that National Intelligence had a responsibility to protect sensitive government information.

He said that by compiling the report, National Intelligence was not suggesting the need for excessive secrecy. But, said Shaik, "our peace and emerging democracy is fragile and needs to be protected".

Shaik said that foreign countries were interested to see how South Africa was emerging as a democracy, andthat there were interest-brokers who might, for thei rown political or economic purposes, try to acces sconfidential information.

Shaik said that the leakage of classified documents tothe media was a problem. He said that National Intelligence was concerned by recent fires in the RDP and Finance offices. It was speculated in the mediathat the fires could be part of a sabotage campaign.

Despite this attempt to tighten things up ingovernment, Parliament's security remains slack. Many parliamentarians suspect their phones may be bugged and a source in the Freedom Front said this week that therewere times when the party felt the need to sweep its caucus room for bugs.

A private secretary for a prominent ANC MP said tha they had the sorts of conversations on parliamentary phones "that they wanted other people to hear", and the National Party said this week it had stepped up personal security over the past few weeks, "because they were aware that other parties were interested in getting their hands on confidential information".

Not all infiltration is cloak-and-dagger. Common criminals are getting through the barriers. Sources in Parliament's catering department say they suspect that up to R60 000 worth of silver teapots, spoons andcrockery have gone missing. A parliamentary spokesman refused to confirm the figure, saying that the tea set audit was still under way.

In the meantime, Parliament's silver has been lockedaway to prevent further theft and parliamentarians are being served tea in stainless steel pots.


LOAD-DATE: September 1, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


333 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


SABC to be cut back -- in 1998


LENGTH: 1014 words


 

Mail & Guardian

August 25, 1995

byJustin Pearce

The South African Broadcasting Corporation will lose one of its three television channels at the end of1997, to make room for South Africa's first privately owned, free commercial television broadcaster.

The SABC will, however, retain its present three channels until then.

Independent business concerns will have the opportunity to put in proposals for broadcasting rights on the third channel, leading to the establishment of SouthAfrica's first terrestial commercial TV channel in1998.

These guidelines form part of the Independent Broadcasting Authority's report on the future of theSABC in the context of a restructured broadcasting industry in South Africa, handed to Minister of Posts and Telecommunications Dr Pallo Jordan last week. It has not yet been tabled in Parliament, though details of the report were leaked to the Mail & Guardian. 

The report is the conclusion of the IBA's TripleEnquiry into the functions of the SABC and regulationsfor cross-ownership and local content.

During the hearings which informed the writing of the IBA report, the SABC argued that it would have to retain three TV channels if it were to fulfil its responsibilities as a public service broadcaster catering for 11 language communities, and still include enough entertainment material to make the service partly self-financing.

In the final set of hearings, however, the SABC conceded that it might be able to relinquish one of its channels after a consolidation period. It appears that the IBA -- which in terms of the Broadcasting Act has a responsibility to preserve the viability of the national PSB (public service broadcasting) service --has taken its lead from this eleventh-hour concession by the SABC.

The SABC will retain a monopoly on free terrestrial television and its advertising revenue for the next two-and-a-half years, before the handover of the third wave band to a private company. After 1998, according to the document in the hands of the M&G, the SABC will also have, "in all probability", a licence for one satellite service.

The television services of the former homelands will be merged into these SABC services.

There is likely to be some debate over the time scale,with impatient aspirant broadcasters wanting to enter the market sooner, but others arguing that 28 months is a reasonable minimum period of time for the SABC to consolidate its finances, for business interests to prepare their proposals for the new channel, for the IBA to consider these proposals, and for the chosen broadcaster to set up the new station.

This time scale gives satellite broadcasters almost two-and-a-half years in which to establish their audience with only the SABC and M-Net as competition. Some commentators believe this will allow satellite television to gain dominance in the market.

In 1998, the IBA will also consider "the financial viability of introducing a second private channel,either nationally or regionally", but argues that there are limited resources in the country and "there will, of necessity, for the foreseeable future, be a limited number of television stations licensed".

The IBA argues that by ensuring these stations are"high quality and distinctly South African", they will be better placed to compete against foreign satellite sand to encourage foreign investment.

It will now be up to Jordan to prepare legislation to go before Parliament, which will enable the transfer of the licence to broadcast on the third channel, as well as a certain quantity of SABC assets, into private hands.

When the IBA eventually considers business proposals for the commercial station, it is likely that the submissions will have to meet a strict set of criteria as conditions for the granting of a licence. According to the document, the public service responsibilities of the SABC will be shared with other TV channels,including commercial terrestrial, satellite and community TV stations. All television licensees will have to "make some appropriate contribution to addressing the needs of the South African public".

The ownership of the company chosen as the broadcaster for the third channel will, in all probability, be required to include a substantial number of"historically disadvantaged" South Africans, in order to prevent established foreign and South Africanb usiness dominating what is likely to be an extremely lucrative business.

The model outlined in the document given to the M&G has been described as one which "regulates for quality rather than for money". The guidelines are likely to come in for criticism from those who favour thep roliferation of purely commercial broadcasting in South Africa -- which some believe is the best way to encourage foreign investment in the local broadcasting industry.

However, the overall proposals will find favour with those who support the existence of a strong, though pruned-down and independent, public service broadcaster.


LOAD-DATE: September 1, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


334 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


The perils of flight


LENGTH: 747 words


 

Mail & Guardian

August 25, 1995

by Clive Simpkins

THE collapse of Avia Airlines and the South African leg of Sudan Airways has highlighted some major flaws inthe protection of passengers.

People who had bought Sudan Airways tickets were stunned recently to learn that not only did they haveto pay a 15 percent excess on their claims, but in many instances they weren't covered at all because Sudan Airways per se continues to operate healthily. TheSouth African leg is in "suspension" and may be resumed later this year. However, this doesn't help thosewho've already forked out for a fare and need to travel immediately. 

People don't only take out travel insurance when flying"iffy" airlines. I have, for years, taken out insurance whenever a fare has been one of those penalty-attracting packages which cannot easily be changed, or in case I get ill. The flaw in the present insurance system is that the risk is skewed and the insurance companies have discovered that.

British Airways (BA) gets a 10-out-of-10 for lending a hand to passengers in distress. BA allowed strandedpassengers special privileges on a standby basis to get'em back home. Compare this with the unbelievably insensitive and unhelpful response of South AfricanAirways' (SAA) Leon Els who said that "it was their choice to fly Sudan Airways". He's just nullified a few hundred thousand rand of SAA's advertising and public relations budget in one foul swoop.

The previous government refused requests from theAssociation of Southern African Travel Agents (Asata)for a small levy to be imposed on all airfares to allowthe creation of a travel-industry trust or fidelityfund.

Market forces should have been allowed to dictate themechanisms for default-insurance procedures. I hope thepresent government will recognise this and leave decisions affecting specific industries and services tothose in the know.

On the subject of air travel, it's saddening to notethat airlines are going for the jugulars of oppositionairlines yet again. This certainly contributed to thedemise of Flite Star and it seems airlines are using thesame tactics to get rid of Phoenix.

Instead of trying to win passengers by offering thembetter service, some airlines seem hell-bent on thedestruction of the opposition. Competition is scary,remember?

Comair's ad about its R14-million trust fund forpassenger protection focuses more on a challenge toopposition airlines to do likewise than on the meritsof its plan. It is interesting to note that SAA'sformer head marketing honcho is now at Comair.

I'm not for one moment advocating protection of somesort, just a more consumer-benefiting approach.

Jan Carlzon, the famed President of Scandinavian Airlines, says: "You'll never be 50 percent better than your opposition at what you do. If they were so bad,they'd be out of business. What you've got to do is be one percent better at 1 000 little things." Travel industry please take note.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.mg.co.za/mg/

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: September 1, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


335 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Leaked: government rules to prevent leaks


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

Mail & Guardian

August 25, 1995

by Marion Edmunds

A special National Intelligence briefing to the Cabineton how to deal with sensitive and potentially embarrassing information and prevent leaks has been leaked to the Mail & Guardian.

Concern about security leaks and sabotage of government plans prompted National Intelligence to brief Cabinet on how to safeguard sensitive information. A document on safety measures was distributed in the recent Cabinet briefing, and has since then been distributedto government ministries.

The document urges civil servants to be ever-vigilant when dealing with matters that could embarrass, damage or bring down the government. In particular, it lays out guidelines for preserving confidentiality and sensitive information, which could either be contained in documents or on computers. 

Implicit in the preamble is the warning that there maybe forces at work to sabotage the RDP and the country's transition.

The authors of the document note that there has been an"escalation of intelligence activities by a growing number of foreign countries and other interest groups".

Apart from laying down procedures for dealing with bomb attacks and fires, the document describes the differences between "restricted", "confidential","secret" and "top secret" information. According to the definitions, a "restricted document" contains information that could embarrass the government, a"confidential document", if leaked, could damage the government, a "secret document" might be used by opponents to disrupt the running of government and a"top secret document", if leaked, could lead to the downfall of the government, the severing of relations with another state or a declaration of war.

"Top secret" and "secret" documents have to be kept in strong rooms or vaults, where as confidential documentmust be kept in reinforced steel cabinets. The Cabinet briefing document -- a restricted document -- also contains a number of tips about keys, fires and how to deal with suspicious-looking maintenance men.

Moe Shaik, advisor to Deputy Minister of IntelligenceJo Nhanhla, would not confirm or deny that the Cabinet briefing took place, but he did say that National Intelligence had a responsibility to protect sensitive government information.

He said that by compiling the report, National Intelligence was not suggesting the need for excessive secrecy. But, said Shaik, "our peace and emerging democracy is fragile and needs to be protected".

Shaik said that foreign countries were interested to see how South Africa was emerging as a democracy, andthat there were interest-brokers who might, for thei rown political or economic purposes, try to acces sconfidential information.

Shaik said that the leakage of classified documents tothe media was a problem. He said that National Intelligence was concerned by recent fires in the RDP and Finance offices. It was speculated in the mediathat the fires could be part of a sabotage campaign.

Despite this attempt to tighten things up ingovernment, Parliament's security remains slack. Many parliamentarians suspect their phones may be bugged and a source in the Freedom Front said this week that therewere times when the party felt the need to sweep its caucus room for bugs.

A private secretary for a prominent ANC MP said tha they had the sorts of conversations on parliamentary phones "that they wanted other people to hear", and the National Party said this week it had stepped up personal security over the past few weeks, "because they were aware that other parties were interested in getting their hands on confidential information".

Not all infiltration is cloak-and-dagger. Common criminals are getting through the barriers. Sources in Parliament's catering department say they suspect that up to R60 000 worth of silver teapots, spoons and crockery have gone missing. A parliamentary spokesman refused to confirm the figure, saying that the tea set audit was still under way.

In the meantime, Parliament's silver has been locked away to prevent further theft and parliamentarians are being served tea in stainless steel pots.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.mg.co.za/mg/

LANGUAGE: English

336 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


SABC to be cut back -- in 1998


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

Mail & Guardian

August 25, 1995

byJustin Pearce

The South African Broadcasting Corporation will lose one of its three television channels at the end of1997, to make room for South Africa's first privately owned, free commercial television broadcaster.

The SABC will, however, retain its present three channels until then.

Independent business concerns will have the opportunity to put in proposals for broadcasting rights on the third channel, leading to the establishment of SouthAfrica's first terrestial commercial TV channel in1998.

These guidelines form part of the Independent Broadcasting Authority's report on the future of theSABC in the context of a restructured broadcasting industry in South Africa, handed to Minister of Posts and Telecommunications Dr Pallo Jordan last week. It has not yet been tabled in Parliament, though details of the report were leaked to the Mail & Guardian. 

The report is the conclusion of the IBA's TripleEnquiry into the functions of the SABC and regulationsfor cross-ownership and local content.

During the hearings which informed the writing of the IBA report, the SABC argued that it would have to retain three TV channels if it were to fulfil its responsibilities as a public service broadcaster catering for 11 language communities, and still include enough entertainment material to make the service partly self-financing.

In the final set of hearings, however, the SABC conceded that it might be able to relinquish one of its channels after a consolidation period. The SABC will retain a monopoly on free terrestrial television and its advertising revenue for the next two-and-a-half years, before the handover of the third wave band to a private company. After 1998, according to the document in the hands of the M&G, the SABC will also have, "in all probability", a licence for one satellite service.

The television services of the former homelands will be merged into these SABC services.

This time scale gives satellite broadcasters almost two-and-a-half years in which to establish their audience with only the SABC and M-Net as competition. Some commentators believe this will allow satellite television to gain dominance in the market.

The IBA argues that by ensuring these stations are"high quality and distinctly South African", they will be better placed to compete against foreign satellite sand to encourage foreign investment.

When the IBA eventually considers business proposals for the commercial station, it is likely that the submissions will have to meet a strict set of criteria as conditions for the granting of a licence. All television licensees will have to "make some appropriate contribution to addressing the needs of the South African public".

The ownership of the company chosen as the broadcaster for the third channel will, in all probability, be required to include a substantial number of"historically disadvantaged" South Africans, in order to prevent established foreign and South Africanb usiness dominating what is likely to be an extremely lucrative business.

The model outlined in the document given to the M&G has been described as one which "regulates for quality rather than for money". The guidelines are likely to come in for criticism from those who favour thep roliferation of purely commercial broadcasting in South Africa -- which some believe is the best way to encourage foreign investment in the local broadcasting industry.

However, the overall proposals will find favour with those who support the existence of a strong, though pruned-down and independent, public service broadcaster.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.mg.co.za/mg/

LOAD-DATE: September 1, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


337 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Coups are not yet irrelevant topics


LENGTH: 920 words


 

By Aka Mbikusita-Lewanika

SECURITY means more than AK-47 guns in the hands of soldiers and police officers protecting the minority in power.

There is no real security where the majority are used as misguided and abused voters, to be cheated at election time and then forgotten.

The country's rulers and others have understood this. Thus they over-reacted again over some commonly understood pronouncement by certain politicians regarding military coups. 

The place of violence and the military in politics is not yet an irrelevant topic in Africa. And we cannot afford to ignore it in Zambia.

The present governments of Uganda, Eritrea, Ethiopia and Rwanda are the'possible' cases in Africa which 'may' be categorised as arising out of just revolutionary forces.

Most other African governments, both the military and the so-called civilian ones, better fit the category of unjust and reactionary regimes.

The violence of the former is more legitimate than of the latter, although in all cases non-violent struggle is both preferred and superior to violence of any kind and certainly to military coups in Africa.

Violence is a corrupting and counter-productive means of struggle, even in a just war. The physical wounds and deaths in its wake can hardly ever be healed.

The option to make the struggle peaceful or violent is always in the hands of the defenders of unjust status quos and campaigners for the prevention of the coming of the future.

There can be no lasting security where the majority are economically, socially and culturally insecure.

The late Dr David Simonda prophetically noted that telephone tapping, eavesdropping, intimidation, false arrests, harassment by security officers and overcrowded and unhygienic prison conditions are crimes against society. He has written that: "Where such crimes are committed against society, individual members of society do not feel obliged to defend and respect the institutions used for the same oppressive purpose. They will find a way of either neutralising or even destroying such institutions. The ultimate result is crime."

Resorting to brutalising suspects, without due civilised legal process,w ill never control this crime culture.

It is a state in which even persons in responsible positions can abusep ublic offices and even endanger lives in a whole sub-continent through dealings in dangerous drugs. It arises out of the reactionary, hypocritical and uncontrolled nature of the present governance.

In Zambia, for example, it has sometimes been recommended, even at the ministerial level, that poor people suspected of crime or caught up in compromising situations be shot dead on sight. But for the rich and powerful, the walls of protection reach up to the summit of some nationalauthorities.

Where the precious images of ministers and members of parliament are suspected to have been soiled in the press, a law established a quickservice special express court for political leaders. Crimes most likely tobe committed by the wealthy and political-business classes are cushionedfor velvet high-class treatment.

Nominal African governments have gladly inherited oppressive laws, and even added new ones, as a substitute for better orienting, financing, equipping,training, motivating and expanding law enforcement agencies.

The new multi-party Zambia is not markedly exempt from these criminal assaults against human rights.

This situation calls for real fundamental change throughout our country and continent. These false starts and counterfeit leaders have provided for what the late Simonda called the "political justification of criminal acts by powerful figures".

Only justice, fairness and democracy can prevent political and social violence.

The starting point in the case of Zambia today is to have a good constitution, a good leadership and a good national development programme,on which scores we are still failing dangerously.

To reach the Zambia Post point a browser to: http://www.mg.co.za/mg/

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: September 1, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


338 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Police summon Wezi Kaunda over KK's death plot document


LENGTH: 454 words


 

By Anthony Mukwita

POLICE yesterday summoned UNIP's Malambo member of parliament Wezi Kaunda for questioning and possible arrest over a matter he raised in parliament about the planned assassination of his father, former president Kenneth Kaunda, by the state intelligence service.

The plot was first exposed by The Post on June 23 this year, but the policehas not moved on the paper.

Kaunda confirmed this in Lusaka in an interview on Wednesday. 

"I have been told to report to force headquarters room 118," Wezi said. Police action follows protests from Vice-President Godfrey Miyanda that Wezi was in possession of state security documents and wondered if he was in order to table them before parliament.

Speaker Robinson Nabulyato ruled in favour of the Vice-President and warned he could waive parliamentary immunity and hand over Wezi to the police.

Immediately, Inspector General of police Francis Ndlovu applied to the Speaker to waive Wezi's prosecution immunity."

It now appears like the Speaker has waived my immunity. But I have not been informed at all," Wezi said.

But critics have charged that the police action implicated the state.

"If the plot is not there, why are the papers being classified as statesecurity documents ?" asked former member of parliament and Lusaka lawyerJohn Mulwila. "Police were running away from the real issue. They should investigate the strength of the allegations made by Wezi and his father."

And Zambia Civic Education Association chairperson Lucy Sichone also came out in support of Wezi saying: " It was the role of parliament to check the excesses of the executive and Nabulyato was wrong to have ruled Wezi out of order."

To reach the Zambia Post point a browser to: http://www.mg.co.za/mg/

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: September 1, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


339 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


TUNISIAN FILM TO BE SCREENED IN VARIOUS AMERICAN CITIES


LENGTH: 640 words


 

"HALFAOUINE" (BOY OF THE TERRACES) will have its US premiere at the NuArt Theatre in Los Angeles, September 8-14 (followed by runs in San Francisco, Seattle, Detroit, Philadelphia, St. Louis and other cities nationwide). (Please check schedule at the end)

The film is distributed by the New York-based "International Film Circuit Inc." which specializes in booking of highly acclaimed foreign films and screening them throughout the country. "Halfaouine" is their first Tunisian film, and they need your support to spread the word to achieve major success for its US premiere. 

According to their press release, "Halfaouine" breaks new ground in Arab cinema with its flank depiction of sexuality. It tells the story of a 13-year old boy who goes to the women's Turkish baths with his mother in Halfaouine, a working-class neighborhood in Tunis. His dawning puberty stirs up the restlessness of being torn between the man's world which beckons him, and the woman's world which still protects him.

The film was written and directed by Ferid Boughedir, one of the most well-known film critics in the Arab world, and features actors from Tunisia's acclaimed New Theater. It is a French-Tunisian co-production. Speaking from Paris where he is editing his new feature film, "A Summer in La Goulette", Boughedir noted that "the film was an enormous commercial success in Tunisia, and although it was shown in neighboring Maghreb nations, Algeria and Morocco, it was banned in all the other Middle Eastern countries, including Lebanon and Jordan. It was even invited to the Damascus Film Festival in Syria, but the authorities would not allow it to be shown." He continues: "There was nearly a riot at the Cairo Film Festival when "Halfaouine" was shown there, and although they had planned to show the film just one time, they were obliged to show it six times. It was subsequently forbidden for it to be shown in Egyptian movie theatres." (International Film Circuit press release)

Bookings to Date:

NuArt Theatre, Los Angeles, CA - starting September 8.

Roxie Theatre, San Francisco, CA.-starting September 29.

UC Theatre, Berkeley, CA. -October 13

Varsity Theatre, Seattle, WA - October 27

Detroit Institute of Art, Detroit, MI -one day only- November 6

Tivoli Theatre, St. Louis, MO - November 17

Ritz Theatre, Philadelphia, PA - Early December (Date yet to be determined)

Biograph Theatre, Washington, DC - December (ditto)

FOR FURTHER INFORMATION, or to check if other theatres in other cities will be screening this film, please contact: Wendy Lidell (International Film Circuit Inc)

Phone: (212) 779-0660 Fax: (212) 779-9129

You can also call the Tunisian Information Office in Washington, DC. Phone: (202) 466-2546. To be added to our E-mail mailing list drop us a note at:

tuninfo@gwuvm.gwu.edu

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).


LOAD-DATE: September 1, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


340 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


CPJ Protest: Kenya


LENGTH: 1534 words


 

SENT BY FAX

August 24, 1995

President Daniel arap Moi

Office of the President

Harambee House

Nairobi

Kenya

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) strongly protests the acts of unauthorized censorship by Your Excellency's government on the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) World Television. We also support the BBC's ultimatum that, should unapproved interference continue, it will terminate its television operations in Kenya. CPJ also condemns the recent beating of six journalists by security forces.

The BBC contracted with the Kenya Broadcasting Corporation (KBC) to re-broadcast its world television news on KBC stations. The contract between the BBC and the KBC stipulates that the government may not interfere in its news broadcasts. Reports indicate that the KBC, on several occasions, has tampered, without authorization, with news items about Kenya that the Minister of Information claims discredit the government. 

The most recent censored BBC report was its story on the beating of Richard Leakey, a founder of the yet-to-be registered SAFINA political party, and six journalists, including a BBC stringer. On August 18, the BBC issued a statement objecting to the KBC's interference with the broadcast, and threatened to end the television contract. While Your Excellency's administration has yet to respond officially to this statement, Information Minister Johnstone Makau stated earlier this month that the contract would not be renewed unless the tone of BBC reports about Kenya changed. The BBC has been esteemed globally as an exemplary news organization with respect to its objectivity in news reporting and for its far-reaching news coverage. The BBC also remains valuable to Kenya's population as a source of international information and education. A discontinuation of its services would truncate the people's access to this information, to which they have a right.

CPJ also condemns the attack against local and foreign press on Thursday, August 10, which was the subject of the aforementioned censored BBC report. Plainclothes police, youth-wingers from Your Excellency's ruling Kenyan African National Union (KANU) party, and riot police beat six journalists and two other travelers. The journalists were attacked while covering a visit by Richard Leakey, Secretary General of the soon-to-be SAFINA party, to the Nakuru magistrate's court where detained human rights activist Koigi wa Wamwere was due to appear. Leakey was accompanied by human rights lawyer Paul Muite. While Leakey and Muite were assembling in the car park of the court, a mob, which was comprised of individuals whom the journalists recognized as KANU officials and Nakuru police in plain clothes, began to form. The mob launched their attack on Leakey and the SAFINA treasurer with eggs, whips, pick-ax handles, and stones, until they managed to escape the barrage. Both sustained severe injuries as it was difficult for Leakey, who has two artificial legs, to manoeuvre. No on-duty police came to their aid. Shortly thereafter, as the journalists and Muite and his party proceeded to the court, prison guards built a road block, prohibiting their entrance. In the meantime, witnesses report that the mob from below, plus men from two "Government of Kenya" (GK) vehicles with their plate numbers blacked out, also began to create a road block. Realizing the prison guards were not going to offer any protection, Muite and his group fled, breaking through the road block at the bottom of the road. At this point, riot police joined the prison guards, assaulting the journalists with truncheons from the back, and the KANU youth-wingers with whips and rocks from the front. Again, no police arrived to bring order.

After the melee, the journalists, notably the foreign correspondents, were threatened with death if they reported this incident. Two journalists and one traveler, who suffered fractured and broken bones, were hospitalized, while all sustained severe injuries.

As a nonpartisan group of journalists dedicated to the defense of press freedom and the protection of our colleagues worldwide, CPJ condemns the brutal assault. We feel that the involvement of official forces in this attack signals the Kenyan government's thorough disregard for the impartial role of journalists as observers. CPJ also regards this incident as one among many we have documented this year that constitute a disturbing trend of intimidation against the local and foreign press in Your Excellency's country. We urge Your Excellency to order a thorough investigation of this incident and see to it that those responsible are brought to justice. In the matter of the BBC, the Committee respectfully reminds Your Excellency that censorship is a violation of the right of free expression, which is guaranteed by Article 19 of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights, Article 19 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and Article 9 of the African Charter on Human and Peoples' Rights, all to which Kenya is a signatory. We hope that Your Excellency will ask the KBC to abide by the terms of its contract with the BBC and cease censoring its reports so as not to deprive Your Excellency's people of their right to information.

Thank you for your attention. We welcome your comments.

Sincerely,

William A. Orme, Jr.

Executive Director

cc: Attorney General Amos Wako

Minister of Information Johnstone Makau

Ambassador Benjamin Kipkorir

The Hon. Ambassador Aurelia Brazeal

Kenya Union of Journalists

Network for the Defense of Independent Media in Africa

Africa News


August, 1995


Document: Request to Drop Charges Against Sierra Leonian Journalists


LENGTH: 1160 words


 

SENT BY FAX

August 1, 1995

His Excellency Captain E. M. Strasser

Chairperson, National Provisional Ruling Council

State House

Tower Hill, Freetown

Sierra Leone

Your Excellency:

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) is writing to urge Your Excellency to drop charges against The New Breed journalists. Judgment in their case, which has been before the Sierra Leonian courts for over 21 months, is due August 7. We are enormously concerned that if convicted, the defendants, including notable

journalists among them such as Dr. Julius Spencer, may be imprisoned for seven to ten years.

On October 13, 1993, The New Breed, a weekly newspaper based in Freetown, published an editorial titled "Redeemers or Villains" that asked Your Excellency's government to respond to an article in the Swedish newspaper Expressen that had accused Sierra Leonian government officials of corruption. The editorial simply cited the Swedish 

article, in an attempt to seek clarity on the issues. That same day, a group of New Breed publishers and journalists were arrested. They spent the next two weeks in jail, before being released on bail of 40 million Leones -- the stiffest bail conditions ever imposed on journalists in Sierra Leone, indeed almost in the history of the judiciary. The group were charged with a ten-count criminal indictment of sedition, defamatory libel, and publishing a false report.

The four accused -- Dr. Julius Spencer, managing editor of the newspaper, and a senior academic at Fourah Bay College; Donald John, acting editor; Alfred Conteh, sales manager and Alusine K. Basiru, general manager of the company that printed the paper, have appeared before the High Court, and the Supreme Court on several occasions. On December 12, 1994, the defendants' bail was revoked, and they were

returned to prison for 35 days. They were released on January 16 this year. Since then they have made several more court appearances, the last of which was on July 14.

CPJ would consider it a terrible miscarriage of justice if these journalists were convicted and sentenced to lengthy prison terms. We believe that the only hope is for the criminal charges against them to be dropped. We respectfully urge Your Excellency to do so.

As a nonpartisan organization of journalists committed to the defense of our colleagues' rights worldwide, CPJ urges Your Excellency to uphold in practice the right of journalists to hold and express opinions and ideas, as guaranteed by Article 19 of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights, by Article 19 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and by Article 9

of the African Charter on Human and Peoples' Rights, the last to which, we respectfully remind Your Excellency, Sierra Leone is a signatory.

Thank you for your attention. We welcome your comments.

Sincerely, William A. Orme, Jr., executive Director

cc:

Brigadier Julius Maada Bio, Deputy Chairman and Chief of Defense,

NPRC

Secretary Arnold Bishop-Gooding, Secretary of State for Information,

Broadcasting, and Culture

Secretary Claude Campbell, Attorney-General and Secretary of State

for Judicial Affairs

His Excellency Ambassador Thomas K. Kargbo

The Honorable Ambassador Lauralee Peters

The National League for Human Rights and Democracy

The Sierra Leone Association of Journalists

TransAfrica

American Newspaper Publishers Association

American Society of Newspaper Editors

Amnesty International

Article 19 (United Kingdom)

Artikel 19 (The Netherlands)

National Press Club

The Newspaper Guild

Africa News


August, 1995


Report Cites Declining International Aid


LENGTH: 1880 words


 

August 21, 1995

No Relief in Sight for Humanitarian Aid: Dwindling Aid Budgets Will Have Grave Consequences

Humanitarian aid groups from Europe and the United States are warning that steep reductions in foreign aid to developing countries have become an alarming trend in the West that could undermine global stability and rapidly increase the number of people living in absolute poverty.

The warning came as aid groups released a new report, "The Reality of Aid 1995," which shows that aid from the richer countries to the world's poor suffered a substantial decline in 1993 -- falling from $61 billion to $56 billion, a drop of six percent in real terms.

"Taken alone, this worldwide decline is disturbing enough," said Julia Taft, president of InterAction. "But when you consider that the US Congress is now considering an additional 35 percent reduction in development assistance next year, it is not an exaggeration to say that this trend could have catastrophic consequences for hundreds of millions of people."

Taft noted that severe cuts in aid for international programs such as economic development, environmental protection and disease control might pressure other

industrialized nations to cut aid by similar proportions. 

"If this trend continues, by the turn of the century, the flow of development assistance could be little more than a trickle, exacerbating global threats such as rapid population growth, forced migration and environmental degradation," said Taft, adding that "the AIDS epidemic could worsen and outbreaks of infectious diseases like the Ebola virus will become more likely."

"The Reality of Aid" reports that public opinion polls in countries throughout the industrialized world indicate that most people -- including those in the United States -- support aid to the poorest countries. At the same time, however, government support appears to be declining rapidly.

In spite of commitments to eliminating poverty at the March 1995 Social Summit in Copenhagen, aid as a percentage of donors' GNP fell from 0.33 percent of GNP in 1992 to 0.30 percent in 1993. The US share is equivalent to 0.15 percent -- or one-half the average of other industrialized nations. The United Nations target is 0.7 percent.

Donors also allowed their proportion of government spending to fall from over 2 percent to under 1.8 percent for the first time since 1990. In the United States, the proportion of the federal budget that goes to foreign aid is less than 1 percent. On a per capita basis, the US contribution to development assistance ranks last among all industrialized nations.

According to the report, the US is not the only donor nation considering further aid reductions. Germany is expected to cut aid disbursements by 1.4 percent in 1995; Italian aid for 1995 is 60 percent below its 1992 figure. Canadian aid will decline by 15 percent in 1995/96 and will fall by 21 percent over the three-year period to 1997/98.

Among the traditionally generous donors, the Netherlands has committed to restore aid to 0.9 percent of its GNP by 1998. Sweden has decided to freeze aid at $1.78 billion until the next election -- guaranteeing a real cut in aid over the next three or four years. Denmark and Norway look set to remain the only donors giving over 1 percent.

Non-governmental organizations (NGOs) say they fear increasing marginalization for the least developed countries, particularly in Africa, where reduced aid is likely to mean further environmental degradation, increased poverty, disease, conflict and refugee flows. The human cost will be terrible, and the long term financial cost is likely to outweigh the price of an effective strategy to assist Africa now.

"The Reality of Aid 1995" explains that aid spending not only makes a major contribution to human welfare, it is also a highly cost-effective investment in the future. For example, an additional year of school for 1,000 women in Pakistan at a cost of $30,000 is estimated to increase wages by 20 percent and prevent 60 child deaths, 500 births and 3 maternal deaths.

The increasing share of aid being allocated to emergencies and the growing allocations of aid to debt reduction are substantially reducing the availability of aid for long-term development, according to the report.

Development cooperation has become increasingly sensitive to the links between poverty reduction and gender equality. As 70 percent of the world's poor people are women or girls, any aid agency seriously attempting to fight poverty has no choice but to address women's needs and potential.

Much of the attention to gender, however, remains at the level of rhetoric. Despite near universal recognition that investment in education for women and girls results in better returns than perhaps any other investment, most donors are not yet even reporting their spending on basic education, let alone basic female education.

Donor countries have recognized the global nature of many threats to human security -- including poverty, drugs, environmental degradation, migration and unemployment -- in policy statements and in aid spending. As the distinctions between foreign, defense, development, trade and environment policy diminish, nations are beginning to acknowledge that sustainable development is a matter of both common security

and good economics.

It is increasingly clear that development cooperation is in the interests of both rich and poor nations. It is also clear that helping poorer countries is seen as a moral imperative by many people throughout the industrialized world.

"The Reality of Aid" calls for all countries that are reducing aid to reverse the cuts -- and for all donors who have not achieved the UN target to honor commitments by setting firm timetables to reach 0.7 percent. Tony German, one of the principal authors of the report, concludes that: "With the number of people in the world surviving on less than $1 a day still rising -- and clear evidence that aid directed to human need is an excellent investment, donors should build on public commitment to humanitarian action and redouble their efforts -- not to cut aid to some of the

world's neediest people."

"The Reality of Aid 95: An Independent Review of International Aid" (120pp; ISBN 1-85383-292-8) was published jointly by the Europe-based groups Actionaid, ICVA and

Eurostep. It is available from 1) Earthscan Publications Limited, 120 Pentonville Road, London N1 9JN, United Kingdom. Price: 12.95 pounds. (2) ICVA Secretariat, P.O. Box 216, 1211 Geneva 21, Switzerland. Tel: (41 22) 732 6600; Fax: (41 22) 7388804;

Email: icva_gva@gatekeeper.unicc.org. Price: 30 Sw Fr. (3) Island Press, P.O. Box 7, Covelo, CA 95428 U.S.A. Tel: (800) 828-1302; Fax: (707) 983-1302; Email:

ipress@igc.apc.org. Price: $20.95 + shipping & handling.

This article appeared in the June 26, 1995 issue of Monday Developments, a bi-weekly newsletter published by InterAction: American Council for Voluntary Interational

Action. InterAction is a coalition of over 150 US-based private and voluntary organizations (PVOs) working internationally in sustainable development, disaster relief, refugee assistance, public policy and education of Americans about the developing world. Monday Developments contains news, analysis, features and commentary on changing global events that affect humanitarian work. In addition to reports from around the globe, it provides updates on initiatives in Washington that affect people in the developing world and suggests ways readers can influence US government policies. The newsletter also lists important conferences and seminars

on international issues, reviews new resources, and has a section on employment opportunities in the US and abroad. To receive a sample copy, send $4 (US currency only please) to Monday Developments, InterAction, 1717 Massachusetts Ave. NW

#801, Dept. IN, Washington, DC 20036, USA. More information on InterAction is available from ia@interaction.org.

This material is being reposted for wider distribution by the Africa Policy Information Center (APIC). APIC's primary objective is to widen the policy debate in the United States around African issues and the U.S. role in Africa, by concentrating on providing accessible policy-relevant information and analysis usable by a wide range of groups and individuals. APIC is affiliated with the Washington Office on Africa (WOA), not-for-profit church, trade union and civil rights group supported organization that works with Congress on Africa-related legislation.

For basic information on WOA, send an email message to woa-info@igc.apc.org. Messages requiring more than this automatic response must instead be sent to apic@igc.apc.org or woa@igc.apc.org. LANGUAGE: English

343 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


100-year Lesson They Just Refuse To Learn


LENGTH: 1520 words


 

Mail & Guardian

August 4, 1995

by Jon Swift

At the root of all the current upheaval and litigation facing world rugby union is the insistence by the game's authorities that the game be an amateur sport. This iconoclasm, this sticking to the ideals of a bygone era, is rooted in the breakaway just on 100 years ago, when some of the game's participants, largely in Britain's industrialised areas and almost wholly from the working classes, rebelled against taking the hard knocks and losing pay in the process.

The rival code of rugby league comprising 13 men against the 15 in union and largely devoid of the messy scrums and line-outs of the amateur game was born. And the players were paid.

It meant that working men in towns like Wigan, St Helens, Castleford and Warrington could supplement their week's wages at the coalface or similar through a payment for a Saturday game with the added attraction of win and draw bonuses. 

But by far the biggest attraction was the signing-on fee. Tradition would have it that this amount was used to buy the recipient freehold title to his home. It was a system that was both honoured and accepted as an honest adaptation by the working classes of a game invented and perpetuated by the public school gentry.

The cynics within rugby league would have it, even today, that it freed the hard men from having to push in the scrums so that their lords and masters could cavort in the backline.

Germane to the current state of affairs in union, the contracts the players in league signed were binding in that an above-the-board cash agreement between a professional body and a professional player was undertaken. There was nothing hidden.

In union, this has never been the case. In the days when the amateur rules meant something, no-one was paid. As society changed, so did this true blue ethic. While still nominally amateurs, the top players in union began to both expect and accept payments.

They bowed to an iniquitous system known as boot money, a term drawn from the intriguing picture of an official skulking round the changeroom after the game and depositing cash in the players' boots while they busied themselves washing off the mud and soaking the bruises.

The amounts became too substantial in many cases to fit even the average lock forward's size 13s. Take the R3000 a test the members of the Transvaal side supposedly got for making the Springbok team against Willie-John McBride's 1974 British Lions. Translated through normal inflation into today's monetary terms, this represented a direct payment of some R20 000 a test.

Certainly this is far more than the official allowance of around R12 000 a man which the national squad earned for winning the World Cup, a competition which generated hundreds of millions of rands to the Channel Island based World Cup Limited.

It would be naive to believe that this country's World Cup heroes earned only the officially allowed expense money. You only have to look at the edict by South African coach, Kitch Christie, shortly before the start of the competition that the squad stop all advertising and promotional activities and get down to playing rugby.

Certainly the faces of Francois Pienaar, Joost van der Westhuizen, Chester Williams and James Small were not used on posters, billboards and in national advertising for nothing...no matter how orgasmic it seemed to be for the actors coming face to face with the Springbok captain over a steak.

But any monies earned could not, as the International Rugby Board (IRB) decreed, be earned directly from rugby. They had to be from promotional or other activities.

In a sense, the amateur players had remained poorly paid serfs within the game with the potential - admitted large in the case of the stars - to earn outside it.

It was clearly a system bound for implosion. The catalysts for this came in the form of the intentions of two Australian media magnates to dominate the broadcasting of the game.

Rupert Murdoch struck first with a R2-billion offer, spread over the 10 years from the start of the 1996 season, for the rights to all representative rugby played by South Africa, New Zealand and Australia, thus far the only three holders of the World Cup.

The three unions hastily formed SANZAR, the company who signed the deal with Murdoch and who were to run the rugby-playing end of things.

The deal was announced by South African supremo, Louis Luyt, on the eve of the World Cup final and the understanding was that increased benefits would flow through to every playing facet of the game, from test sides to development projects.

Somehow though, the members of SANZAR had forgotten to tie up the top players, who far more than any altruistic motives of promoting the game lower down the scale, were the real targets of the broadcasters.

It was a difficult situation. The players were amateurs and in some respects beholden to the unions they represented. But, as they could not be paid directly, any contract had to be of a private - one hesitates to say covert - nature.

The very rules laid down by the IRB dictated this. As such, the legal enforceability of such contracts has still to be fully tested under law.

This will surely also be the case when the IRB rules - as it must - that the game is no longer an amateur domain when they meet in Paris later this month. Even if such a ruling is made, can contracts be considered retrospective and legally enforceable? Again, the courts must decide.

The issue has been further complicated by Pienaar acting as an agent for Murdoch's arch rival, Kerry Packer, and getting letters of intent signed by the 28 members of the South African World Cup squad to join a yet-to-be- launched global superleague.

Packer's World Rugby Corporation - which has reputedly put nearly R400-million aside for the launch - also has the signatures of a number of other top players both in this country and worldwide and was the entity which brought last weekend's dramatic urgent interdict to prevent SARFU from putting the Springboks under contractual obligation.

This came in the wake of a statement from SARFU chief executive Edward Griffiths last Friday that an agreement had been reached between the South African body and the players and that "the storm has passed".

One suspects that this was a highly premature appraisal by Griffiths. This week's Supreme Court hearing on the issue in Cape Town and the almost inevitable string of litigation which will follow the finding whatever it is prove that Griffiths and SARFU will have to keep a close eye on the barometer for a while yet.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.mg.co.za/mg/

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: September 1, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


344 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Aid and Debt Eat At Africa's Development


LENGTH: 974 words


 

Mail & Guardian

August 11,1995

by Karen Harverson

Africa urgently needs trade and investment to drive its development which is slower now than it was 30 years ago, says one of Southern Africa's leading economists.

Tony Hawkins, professor of Business Studies at the University of Zimbabwe, was speaking at a Standard Chartered conference held last week.

Noting that per capita incomes in Africa were lower now than they were in the 1960s, as populations grew faster than economies grew, Hawkins explained that unlike the South East Asian countries, whose rapid economic development was driven by trade and investment, Africa's lack of development is driven by aid and debt.

"In the 1960's Thailand's gross domestic product (GDP) was lower per head than Ghana's -- today, it is five times greater," said Hawkins. 

He said a radical change in certain African countries' economic policies was necessary to attract investment by multinationals which he believed would be crucial in leading the development of Africa.

"Many African governments have shown commitment to the liberalisation of trade and investment policy but have found it difficult to implement these changes."

Another problem facing many African countries is that their economies are 80 percent commodity-based and highly vulnerable to adverse international trends and climatic conditions.

"Fortunately, the protracted downturn in commodity prices in 1992 and 1993 appears to have ended and this bodes well for potential investment."

Another plus in Africa's favour was that the return on investment in Africa was greater for multinationals than in any other country.

"Of course, the risks are also much higher."

Hawkins said that Africa's best chance for attracting investment was in traditional industries or in the area of privatisation.

"Excluding privatisation, most investors are attracted to ventures in oil, gas and mining, especially in West Africa."

Africa's difficulties are compounded by tiny markets which hold little attraction for the modern multinational companies, said Hawkins.

Only South Africa and Nigeria have market sizes topping the $10-billion mark.

"South Africa is the only 'star' on the continent in terms of market size, growth rate and market attractiveness. It's the only market investors view as essential to enter."

He said investors measured the market attractiveness of a country in terms of resource endowment, political stability, policy environment, infrastructure and institutional capacity, foreign debt-burden and export concentration.

"Of these, policy environment is the most important. Resource endowment is a key factor in attracting investment but not essential as proven by the successful economies of the South East Asian countries."

He said countries such as Mauritius, Botswana, Namibia and Swaziland were seen as "limited scope" countries.

"They have good policies and political stability but their markets were just too small to attract investment interest beyond exploitation of raw materials."

Despite its market size, Nigeria, along with Cote d'Ivoire, Angola, Zimbabwe, Ghana, Kenya, Uganda, Zambia, Cameroon and Tanzania, was ranked as a "problem child".

"These countries have good growth environments when markets improve but the scope is limited by the moderate market size. Investors need to pick the winners and establish joint ventures."

He relegated Ethiopia, Mali, Mozambique, Sierra Leone, Toga, Somalia, Rwanda and others to the ranks of "dog" countries.

"These are viewed as no-go countries which will take a long time to develop market attractiveness."

He warned investors to adopt a "watch and wait" attitude to these African countries apart from some exports and marketing outlet opportunities.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.mg.co.za/mg/

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: September 1, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


345 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Decision Imminent On McDonald's Trademark


LENGTH: 867 words


 

Mail & Guardian

August 11,1995

by Karen Harverson

The trademark dispute between Chicken Licken owner George Sombonos and US hamburger chain McDonald's will be heard in the Pretoria Supreme Court this month.

The case consists of two applications; one of which will be tried under South Africa's old Trademark Act and the other under the new Act passed in May 1995.

The first application -- to expunge McDonald's trademark from the registrar for non-use -- is being brought by Joburgers Drive-In Restaurant, owned by Sombonos, and Dax Prop, a franchisee of Sombonos.

It will be tried under the old Trademark Act as legal action was taken before the new Trademark Act was passed in May 1995. 

According to South African law, a third party can apply to the registrar to remove a trademark if non-use of the trademark for a period of five years can be proven. A trademark can only be registered if there is intent to make use of it.

"McDonald's first registered its trademark in 1968, re- registered in 1974, again in 1980, once again in 1985 and finally in 1993 shortly after we applied for its expungement from the register," says Sombonos attorney Sean Ryan of Ryans Attorneys and Trade Mark Agents.

"Twenty-seven years have passed and McDonald's still has not made use of it -- therefore, we are entitled by law to apply for its expungement."

McDonald's will contest the expungement applications brought under Section 36 of the old Act which justifies non-use if there are "special circumstances in the trade". In papers before the court, it contends that sanctions and sanctions legislation constituted such "special circumstances".

"McDonald's was seriously considering investing in South Africa as far back as 1979 in the normal course of its international expansion. However, the threat of sanctions and later, sanctions legislation, precluded such an arrangement. The critical five-year period of non-use fell right in the middle of the sanctions period," says Spoor & Fisher partner Gavin Morley.

However, Ryan argues that the Anti-Apartheid Act had two provisions which enabled US companies to operate in South Africa during the sanctions period -- at arm's length, through licensing agreements, or through handing over the reins to a black-owned or -controlled company or person.

The second application, brought by McDonald's, will be tried under the new Act which has a provision under section 35 which affords protection to foreign trademarks which are "well known" in South Africa.

"Although the trademark is not yet in use, the evidence in the case, including surveys, prove that a substantial portion of the South African population recognises the name," says Morley.

Not so, says Ryan. He claims that the McDonald's survey only represents the opinions of a mere 200 whites from households with incomes in excess of R6 000, while a survey conducted on behalf of his client indicates most South Africans have no recognition of the trademark.

He further slates the passing of the new Trademark Act which he views as "an appalling piece of legislation" which gives more rights to foreigners than South Africans would be afforded in those countries.

US legislation states if a trademark isn't used in two years of registration, it is presumed abandoned and struck from the register unless the owner can prove he didn't abandon the mark.

In South Africa, a trademark, if renewed every 10 years, remains registered indefinitely unless a third party applies for expungement after non-use of five years.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.mg.co.za/mg/

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: September 1, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


346 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


McDonald's First Franchises In South Africa


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Mail & Guardian

August 11,1995

by Karen Harverson

Multinational hamburger chain McDonald's is on track to open its first two restaurants in South Africa despite the fact that the court case over the rights to its trademark has not yet been resolved.

South African George Sombonos, owner of franchise chain Chicken Licken, is seeking the right to expunge McDonald's trademark from the South African register on the basis of "non-use".

"We are in the process of establishing a full country office in South Africa and plan to have a mix of operations in this country," says Carter Drew, newly appointed managing director and president of McDonald's South Africa. 

He is adamant that McDonald's had nothing to do with pressure exerted on South Africa by the United States to intervene in the case.

"We are operating in good faith and expect to open in South Africa. We have confidence in South Africa's due process system."

The first two outlets will be based in Johannesburg and Cape Town and will be franchised with individual franchisees owning and operating their own businesses.

Three South African potential licensees are already undergoing training in New Zealand

Drew says the company expects operations to be up and running by December this year.

He indicates that a substantial marketing drive will be undertaken prior to the opening.

It is McDonald's policy to use local suppliers wherever feasible.

"Suppliers have been identified and will be appointed within the next two to three months," says Drew, adding that most of the ingredients will be sourced locally.

The restaurants typically employ 60 to 80 people. "It will be some time before the company becomes a large- scale employer in South Africa," adds Drew.

The company is the leading food service retailer in the global consumer market place, with more than 15 700 restaurants worldwide.

About 80 percent of its businesses are locally owned and operated by independent entrepreneurs.

South Africa will be the 84th country in which McDonald's opens its doors, and the third African country after Morocco and Egypt. Morocco has two outlets while Egypt has four.

Drew says that the company will own or lease the property in South Africa on which the restaurants will be sited.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.mg.co.za/mg/

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: September 1, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


347 of 395 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August, 1995


Portnet May Run Congo's Cargo Port


LENGTH: 1014 words


 

Mail & Guardian

August 11,1995

by Karen Harverson

Portnet may enter into a joint venture with the People's Republic of the Congo to manage and operate the country's major port, Pointe Noire.

Portnet chief executive Neil Oosthuizen says in-depth discussions have been held with the Congolese ambassador and minister of transport who have expressed serious interest in the South African port authority taking joint control and management of the port.

"In the next two weeks, a Portnet delegation will fly to the Congo to do an on-site assessment of the port's infrastructure and, thereafter, assess the feasibility of the venture," Oosthuizen says.

The main requirements of a port are that the harbour has adequate depth and safe waters, and basic infrastructure such as breakwaters and quay wall structures. 

Although uncertain of the exact size and port infrastructure at Pointe Noire, Oosthuizen believes it is a general, all-purpose port similar to Port Elizabeth, handling general cargo, containers and a small amount of bulk commodities using normal crane operation but without sophisticated belt-operation facilities.

"I believe some terminals are operating but the Congolese government is keen to improve the situation and has shown preference for South Africa to assist, despite interest shown by other foreign countries," says Oosthuizen.

Financing details would be discussed within two weeks and would depend on the structure of the joint venture.

"Other options might include contracting the terminal facilities out to private operators."

Oosthuizen says a major factor influencing Portnet to consider the venture has been the recent relocation of South African farmers to the Congo to build up the agriculture industry.

"There is great potential for the production of a large amount of agricultural produce for export as well as increased trade between South Africa and the Congo."

At Transnet's annual financial results held this week, managing director Dr Anton Moolman said for the first time since its inception five years ago,

Transnet had made a sufficient profit to make provision for the R1,9-billion contribution to its pension fund and still reflect a net profit of R118-million.

The public company inherited a deficit of R17,2-billion in the pension fund when it was first commercialised and has managed to get it down to R4,2-billion this year.

Improved turnover was reported by transport businesses Spoornet, Petronet, Autonet, South African Airways (SAA) and Portnet, while goods distributor PX recorded a net loss of R297-million.

PX has now decided to modernise and unbundle into focused businesses to improve its operations.

"We'll be moving away from rail transportation into road," said chief executive Wicus Pretorius.

He added that plans were afoot to modernise depots.

"We plan to restructure the business and concentrate on commercial and industrial parcels, courier services and express services."

Portnet's net profit rose 45 percent on last year's profit to R1,1-billion.

A record high of 154,9-million tons of cargo was handled by the port authority despite the labour unrest which had lead to congestion in March and April this year.

Bulk cargo, which accounts for the major portion of its business, rose almost seven percent to a new record of 96,7-million tons, which equals 74 percent of the total cargo.

New records were set in the export of iron ore through Saldanha Bay of 20,9-million tons and wood chips through Richards Bay of 5,3-million tons.

Coal exports through the Port of Richards Bay amounted to 53,7-million tons.

Container traffic showed the greatest increase with the number of containers handled increasing by 20 percent to a record 1,20-million 20-foot equivalent units (TEUs).

"The container business is very profitable, so the increased traffic in containers has contributed greatly to our overall performance," said Oosthuizen.

The Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.mg.co.za/mg/
